editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Full documentation of the original data capture process is available from the Text Creation Partnership web site. All versions of the texts are now archived and freely available for download. See the TCP Download FAQ for detailed information. The TEI P5 versions are also freely available from the TCP Github repository.

div.p: A BRIEFE APOLOGIE, OR DEFENCE OF THE CAtholike Ecclesiastical Hierarchie, & subordination in England, erected these later yeares by our holy Father Pope Clement the eyght; and impugned by certayne libels printed & published of late both in Latyn & English; by some vnquiet persons vnder the name of Priests of the Seminaries.

p.hi: VVritten and set forth for the true information and stay of all good Catholikes, by Priests vnited in due subordination to the Right Reuerend Archpriest, and other their Superiors.

q.p: Obey your Superiors, and submit your selues vnto them.
We beseech yow brethren represse those that are vnquiet amongst yow.

div.p: Permissu Superiorum.

div.head: THE AVTHORS OF this booke touching the difference betweene their Apologie & the libels therin impugned.
div.p: SApitisne inter verum falsumve discernere? inter inflatum & solidum? inter tutbidum & tranquillum? inter tumidum & sanum? inter probationes & criminationes? inter documenta & figmenta? inter causae actionem, & causae auersionem? si sapitis, benÃ¨ & rectÃ¨; si autem non sapitis, nos vestri curam gessisse non poenitebit, quia etsi cor vestrum ad â¢â¢ cem non conuertitur, pax nostra tamen ad nos reuertitur.

DO yow know to distinguish betweene true and false? betweene solide and puffed vp? betweene turbulent, and quiet? betweene swelling and sound? betweene probations and criminations? betweene instructions and fictions? betweene handling the cause, & running frÅ the cause? if yow know this, wel and good, If yow know it not we are not sorie, that we haue had this care to instruct yow, for albeit your harte be not turned to peace, yet our peace returneth to vs.

div.head: AN INDEX OF THE chapters of this Apologie.

list.item: WHat great hurtes haue come to England from tyme to tyme by aemulation of the laitie against the Cleargie, and of seculer priests against religious, and of the state of the present cÅtrouersie in question. CAP. I.

Of the great disobedience, that our discontented brethren haue vsed in these their contentions, and how vnduetifullie they haue behaued themselues towards all sortes of Superiors, & namely towards his Holines. CAP. II.

Of the great iniuries and ingratitude offred by our discontented brethren to the whole body & Societie of the Iesuites, how pleasing, and profitable this is to heretikes, and how preiudicial, and dishonorable to all our Catholike nation. CAP. III.

How greatly our late Cardinal Allen, D. Stapleton, D. Barret, and other principal men of our nation now dead are iniuryed by these our discontented brethren, in that they are made to haue byn of their faction against Iesuites: & the same iniurie is offred to diuers other great men also of forrayne nations as to Cardinal Boromeus, Card. Toled, and his Hol. himselfe. CAP. IIII.

Of the great troubles and scandalous seditions raysed vp presently after Cardinal Allens death in
the English Colledge at Rome by the foresaid faection, the beginning, progresse, & end therof, with the causes, & true Authors, & how imprudÄtlie this is now brought in agayne and defended in these books by our discontented brethren. CAP. V.

Of the troubles raysed among Catholike prisoners in the castle of VVisbich, who were the beginners, and continuers therof, and of the most vntrue and slaunderous narration set down â¢ in these late libels about the same. CAP. VI.

Of the general troubles and disquietnes r â¢ ysed amÅgst English Catholikes in Flaunders & England during the former styrres in Rome and VVisbich, and how the one gaue hand to the other and all proceeded from different members of this selfe same faction. CAP. VII.

How his Hol. hearing of the former disorders & contentions did resolue to make a subordination, and Ecclesiastical Hierarchie in England vnder the gouernment of an Archp. & 12. Assist â¢ nts, & how the same was ordayned, & intimated by the Protector, & called in question by some of our discontented brethren without reason or necessitie, and how great troubles haue ensued therof. CAP. VIII.

How after the first contradiction made by our brethren against his Hol ordinance of the Archp. by the Protectors letters, they went forward, and sent a coople to Rome, & what happened to them there, & how his Hol. confirmed the foresaid ordinance & protectors letters with a new Breue. CAP. IX.

Of the ending of all controuersies vpon the publication
of his Hol. Breue, & how by the arte of the common enemy matters were brought to worse breach soone after then euer before, and of the excesses of our discontented brethren together with their dealing with the Counsel from that tyme to the publication of these late libels. CAP. X.

About the two late bookes or libels set foorth by our discontented brethren how iniurious slaunderous, and false they are, and how highly the writers and publishers haue offended God, and all good men therby, with the defence of certayne particular men slaundered therin. CAP. XI.

Of the particular calumniations and slaunders layd vpon F. Persons in these two libels without all foundation of truth or regard of Christian; and priestlie modestie, and how hurteful this is to the publike Catholike cause, and grateful to the common enemy, with a letter also of a blessed martyr touching one of the chiefe of these calumniators, & some notes about equiuocations. CAP. XII.

Some reasons, and serious considerations, wherby such of our discontented brethren as are of good conscience, and not to farre gone in wilful passion may be stayed, or recalled from this scandalous and dangerous course begonne of mutual diuision and dissention, and a better way taken to the revnion of all agayn. CAP. XIII.

div.head: A TABLE OF CERtayne principal deceypts, falshoods, and slaunders conteyned in the two libels set foorth by the discontented priests, which in this our Apologie more at large are confuted.
div.p: FOr so much as this our Apologie was not instituted by vs to answere these seditious libels according to their leaues and pages, but rather to lay foorth the progresse & successe of the whole controuersie by a serious, and orderlie narration of the chiefe matters that haue fallen out; obseruing also therin the order & successiÅ of the tyme it selfe; For this cause we haue thought it conuenient in this place to note some poynts also concerning the said vntruthes, slaunders, and calumniations according as they ly in the pages of the said books (especially of the latyn) to the end that by these fewe a mÄ may iudge of their spirite, & manner of proceeding in the rest.

div.head: Out of the Latyn booke dedicated to his holines.
div.p:
The first p. ful of falshoodes.Pag. 1. Declaratio motuum, &c. A declaration of the styrs & troubles which haue come by the cÅtrouersies with Iesuites, &c. In this inscriptiÅ,
& first page are shewed to be no lesse, thÄ 5. or 6. deceipts shiftes, & falshoods as yow may see Apol. cap. 11. And therby gesse what truth we may expect at these mens hands in the rest of their booke infarced wholy with calumniations.

The seditious fauored by the enemy.Pag 2. Hinc a communi, &c. on one syde we are most heynously wounded and murdered by the cÅmon enemy of our sayth, on the other syde we are most grieuouslie oppressed, &c. Fewe of these men haue byn eyther wounded or put to death by the common enemy, but rather are cherished, and fauoured in secret to make opposition against the whole body, as is shewed in the Apol. cap. 10. 11. 12. & 13. And as for their oppression it is none, but such as they list to imagyne, when they cÄnot haue their owne licentious wil in al things. See cap. 1.5.6.7. &c.

Dissembling vvith his HolinesPag. 4. Cogimur, &c. we are forced to fly to the feete of your Hol. &c. How false & fayned this is appeareth by that they neuer sent yet any of their Appellations to his Hol. nor any man to prosecute the same for thÄ, but are content to gayne tyme at home, & to make reuel in the meane space, as free from all Superioritie. See cap. 2. 7. 8. Apol.

VVilling force.Pag. 5. Haec autem, &c. VVe are forced to divulge these things in print, &c. This force is as the former, to wit from the counsel (if any be at al) to whom it may be they haue promised
to defame such as they most mislike, & so are forced to performe it. For as for informing his Hol. alone, printing was not needful. See cap. 10. 12. 13. Apol.

Abusing Card. AllÄPag. 6. Igitur dum, &c. wherfore while Card. Allen our common Father was alyue, &c. They glorie of Card. Allen now he is dead, whÅ while he liued they exercised as they do now other good men, he being opposite vnto them and their factious proceeding, especially against the Fathers of the Societye as by his owne letters appeareth a litle before his death, &c. See Ap. c. 4. & 7.

Fond & false bragging.Pag. 7. Desudantibus, &c. VVhile Seminarie priests did sweate in the haruest of England, which haruest was then wel manured and almost rype, some Iesuites were called in by D. Allen to helpe them, &c. This whole narration hath many falshoods and vanityes. For first how wel manured & rype the English Cathol. haruest was 22. yeares ago, when the Iesuites were first sent, there being then but fewe priests in England (as hauing had but one only Seminarie vntil that tyme) and fewe knowne Catholikes also in respect of the number, that after had ensued, this we say is knowne to all men, that vnderstand our case. And all the rayling stuffe that foloweth in this place against Iesuites is false, & of meere malice as appeareth. cap. 3.4. & 12. Apolog.

F. Heyvvood calumniated.Pag. 8. Ostentans se, &c. A certayne Iesuite vaunting himselfe among our people as though he had byn legate, to the sea Apostolike, &c. This is spokÄ of F. Iasper Heywood sent into England 1581. a graue and learned man as all men know. And how false and malitious this ly is, with diuers other vttered against him yow may see c. 3. & 11. Apol. where the matter is examined.

Rectors of the English Coledge in Rome.Pag. 9. Pari etiam modo, &c. In like manner the Rectors of our English Romane Colledge did go about many things that were greiuous, and asperous to our youthes, &c. VVhether the fault of disorders, and troubles in the Colledge were in the Rectors or in these mens youthes (to wit the disorderly and tumultuous) let the Visitors testifie that haue examined the matter, and yow may see this poynt handled at large cap. 5. Apol.

A slanderous vntruth.Pag. Ibidem. Conspectis, &c. Card. Allen after he had cÅsidered, and discouered the endeauours of the Iesuites was wonte to say, that they sought more their owne good, thÄ eyther that of our Country or Colledges, &c. This to be meere false, & a notorious vntruth slaunderous both against the Cardinal and Fathers of the Societie do proue not only his owne letters and doings, but all those that were most intrinsecal vnto him, See c. 4. & 11. Apol. And what priuate good can the Iesuites pretÄd for themselues worth their labours & perils
in England (more then in the Indies) except the good of soules, and seruice of God? of what conscience then are these men that print so manifest calumniations? See cap. 3. 7. & 11.

Iniurie offred to Card. Toled.Pag. 11. Iam tum, &c. At that tyme both the Colledge, and all the schollers had byn vndone if Card. Toled, had not opposed himselfe as a wal for the said schollers, &c. Al Rome, and his Hol. himselfe wil easely see how many euident vntruthes are in this narratiÅ, & how slaunderous it is to Card. Toled to make him a fauourer of troublesome and seditious against their Superiors. See the truth of this matter, cap. 5. Apol.

VVisbich faction begonne.Pag. 12. Dum haec Rome, &c. while these things were in doing at Rome, the troubles of VVisbich began, &c. See the true storie of these troubles, cap. 6. Apol. where are discouered an intollerable multitude of vntruthes, & calumniations vttered by these men heere against F. VVeston, and the farre bigger and better part of Cath. prisoners, for that they would liue in order, and retyre themselues from these mens licentiousnes.

Vnited priests in diuision.Pag. 15 Laicorum, &c. The Iesuites did alienate many lay mens mynds ab vnitis sacerdotibus, from the vnited priests, &c. Note the phrase of vnited, they being farre the lesse number, & deuided both from their head, & the rest of their body the English Cleargie: It
is as the HollÄders do cal their rebelled States against the King. The vnited prouinces, &c.

Contumelious spech.Pag. 16. Ticonius ille Donatista, &c. That Tyconius the Donatist, &c. Note the spirite of these men they compare all the good, and quiet Cath. prisoners in VVisbich to Donatists, for that they retyred themselues from these mens tumultuous, & scÄdalous lyfe, and put themselues vnder rule, See cap 6. Apol.

A fiction.Pag. Ibidem. Quorum vnus, &c. One in VVisbich Castle fel out of his witte, by reason of opprobrious letters writtÄ vnto him, &c? How egregious an intruth this is the whole cÅpany wil testifie. See the former cap. 6. of the apologie.

A malitious deuise. Pag. 17. Hanc vero. &c. This sodalitie (of them that liued vnder rules in VVisbich besydes many stumbling blocks which it brought into our Church was vehementlie also suspected by the Q. and councel? Great stumbling blocks, that a few pious rules of modest lyfe, in a fewe prisoners could bring into our whole church. And if it were suspected by the prince it must needs be, for that these men had maliciously perswaded, that this Sodalitie (as also the institution of the Archp.) was not for religion, but for matters of state See more of this malice, cap. 9. 10. 11. & 13. Apologie.

M. StÄdishPag. 19. Dominum StanditiÅ«, &c. M. Standish
who had geuÄ his name to be a Iesuite, &c. All are Iesuites with these men, who are not of their factiÅ, the Archp. & all. This calÅ«niatiÅ needeth no answere. See c. 3. 5. & 7. Ap.

An other fiction of F. VVestonPag. 20. P. Igitur VVestonus, &c. F. VVeston then seing no tergiuersation would serue to retayne his Authoritie, etc. He became dumme vpon the suddayne, and fel astonished to the ground, etc. This impudent fiction is refuted by autentical testimonies of all the quiet prisoners in VVisbich. See cap. 6. Apologie.

A nevv Association for gouernment.Pag. 21. Consilium inimus, &c. VVe tooke a counsel together (say these men) for appoynting Pr â¢ uosts and Superiours ouer vs in opportune places of the kingdome, &c. This was the worke of thier Affociation, wherby a fewe busy & ambitious men tooke vpÅ them to be cÅsellours of state without cÅmissiÅ, or consent, of the rest of the Cleargie, or licÄce of their Superiours to appoynt dignityes to themselues and others at their pleasures, & to make a newe sedition as may appeare by the letters of the Assistents and other proofes. cap. 8. &. 9.

F. Persons in Rome.Pag. 23. Quid interia F. Personius. VVhat did F. Persons in this meane space, the Author, incensor, and actor of all our perturbations, &c. F. Persons in this meane space, whiles yow began new broyles in EnglÄd, came from Spayne and liued quietlie in Rome,1577. and attended to pacifie the English Colledge set in tumults
by yow and yours, & like to be lost therby: He prayed for yow also, & assisted yow by sending in many newe priests for your succour: he wrote against the heretikes which yow do not. And as for being Author or incensor of your perturbations (which do ryse of your owne inordinate passions) all men know it, to be a playne calumniation, and so yow may see it proued at large by your owne letters & other euident testimonies, Cap. 10.11.12. Apol.

M. Blakvvel the Archp.Pag. 26. Videns autem D. Blakwellus, &c. M. Blakwel seing this, &c. All this slanderous, & spiteful speach vttered heere, and in the rest of the booke against their Superiour, the Rt. Reuerend M Blakwel, whÅ they name euery where without any reuerence at all) concerning ambition, and other odious imputations is so farre from all shew of truth to them that know the man and his maners, as no modest catholike can but blush at these speches of him, and therby discerne their lamÄtable spirite. See c. 4. 10. 11. Apo.

Manifest c â¢ lumniationPag. 27. Cum omnes, &c. VVheras all Iesuites almost in England be children of pore parents, &c. How manifestly false and shameles this is there needs no other proofe but to know the parties, and consider also what maner of children and of what parents they be that do obiect this, if all of them were examined one by one.

Pag. 29. Non vt, &c. For not to speake of Pope Sixtus 5. who was named a wolfe â¢ y the Iesuits, and defamed as a most wicked man, &. All this to be a most wicked slaunder deuised by thÄselues, as also the propositiÅs set downe about the stewes in Rome, & odiouslie annexed to this matter is cÅuinced by the testimonies of aboue twentie witnesses then present in the prison, as also that this matter appartayneth nothing at all to the Iesuites or F. VVeston, but was a controuersie betweene priests themselues. See ca. 6. Apologie.

Odious calumniatiÅ.Pag. 30. Iesuitae, &c. The Iesuites dispairing to be able to get superioritie to themselues by way of voyces or suffrages (of the priests) and on the other side hating and slying to admit Episcopal digniti â¢ (into England) thought to procure dominion to thÄselues vnder the maske of an other mÄs person, &c. Marke the modestie of these men, they cal the authoritie of their Superiour instituted by Christes vicar, LaruÄ, that is a masking visard, and then how falsely, and malitiously they affirme Iesuits to haue hated and fled the admission of episcopal dignitie into England, his Hol. and the whole congregation of Cardinals of the inquisition can testifie, who haue yet sundry memorials of F. Persons in their hands inrreating for obteyning Bishops. See cap. 8. Apol.

Pag. 33. Nullo, &c. No respect being had to the
most Catho. Archbishop of Glasco, &c. Desire of setting stryfe. See the strange desire of these men to set stryfe euery where. They would styrre vp the Archbishop of Glasco resyding in Paris for aboue 30. yeares against the Protector, for that he geueth iurisdiction to the Archp. vpon English priests in England, ScotlÄd and Ireland, and yet these men do aske faculties for these three coÅ«treyes, but would be vnder no authoritie in any.

Fictions & exaggeratiÅs against F persons.Pag. 35. P. Personius, &c. F. Persons who rÄne away out of our tents 18. yeares past, &c. All this ignominious speach against F. Persons both for his departure out of England (the causes wherof are examined at large cap. 12. Ap.) as also his dealing with their messengers in Rome Pag. 40. 41, & 43. His shewing their sockes also of fyne Holland, and nightcoyfes layd with gold Pap. 43. All these things we say being partly fictions and partly exaggerations are confuted at large cap. 9. & 12. Apol. where also are examined many other false slanders deuised against him, pag. 56.57. & 59. &c. And finally the rancor of malice vttered against this man being so much beholden to him as they are; is proued to be to to vnchristian.

Fayned submissionPag. 61. His visis, &c. As soone as we sawe the Apostolical letters of the new Breue (for cÅfirmation of the Archp.) we all presently subiected our selues to him, &c. How fayned, and forced a subiection this was, the euÄt doth prooue
and the quicke subtractiÅ therof agayne, & that it could be no other wise, hauing entred with the counsel so farre as they had done, is easie to be seene by that we haue shewed cap. 10. and 13. Apol. where we shew by their owne letters their conspiratie with the persecutor.

Feare of ad mitting to speach in the Archp.Pag. 69. Archipresbyter, &c. The Archpriest denyeth vs accesse vnto him, he wil not be seene, he doth disdayne to talke with his brethren, &c. All these thinges are rhetorically exaggerated; yet is it not maruaile though the Archp. do vse some moderatiÅ, and circumspection in admitting these men to his speach, whom he knoweth to haue an euil myn â¢ towards him, and to deale with the counsel and B. of London, and to seeke his speach only to branle,M. ColetÅ. M. Charnock. and to take some aduantage at his wordes, as two of them did who accused him of an heretical propositiÅ in talking with him presentlie vpon the arryual of his first commission. See cap. 8. 9. and 11. Apologie.

Exprobati- for benefits receyued.Pag. 83. Plura, &c. The Iesuits do brag that many more Seminaries haue byn erected by them, &c. This is very calumnious, but if they should speake of any such matter compelled by your slaunders; should they not say truth? seing 5. or 6. partly Seminaries, partly Residences haue byn erected by them, and namely by him whom yow most impugne in
these libels, This is to insult ouer good men for their benefits and good turnes. See more of this most insolent ingratitude discouered. Cap. 3. 5. 10. and 11. Apoligie.

And these fewe places taken out as they ly in order of an infinite heape of slaunders, calumniatious, and contumelious speaches may suffise for a taste of these libels what they conteyne as also of the bad spirite, and worse resolution of the wryters to wit, what they meane, whither they tend, and where they are like in the end to arryue.
The rest that foloweth in this latyn booke about the appellation, as also about a fond and seditious latin letter of M. Ihon Mush theron insuing are sufficiently examined, cap. 10. and 11. Apologie.

And as for the second booke set out in English and instituted: The copies of discourses &c. VVe meane not to cyte any thing therof in this place for breuities sake, hauing examined the same sufficientlie, Cap. 1. 2. 7 and 11. Apologie.

And the scandalous places gathered out therof already and sent (as we vnderstand) to his Hol. wil sufficientlie declare,The secÅd libel vvritÄ in English. what a worke it is, and how fit for Cath. Priests to write, and publish to the world. It may be some other wil examyne more exactlie
these and other their libels hereafter. This we take wil be sufficient for the present, especially to him that wil take the paynes to reade ouer the Apologie folowing.

div.head: A LIST OF THE PRINcipal persons that are iniured by these libels and defended by our Apologie.

list.item: HIs Holines and the Sea Apostolike, that appoynted the institution of the Archpriest, opprobriouslie impugned by these libels.
The cÅgregatiÅ of all the Cardinalles of the InquisitiÅ that examined the matter and allowed therof.
Cardinal CaÃ«tau then Protector, who intimated the same by his letters Patents.
Cardinal Farnesius now Protector, who restrayned the number of schollers in Doway Seminarie for paying their debts, misliked and calumniated by these men.
Cardinal Burghesius Viceprotector who concurred with the said Protectors in the foresaid affayres, by commission from his Hol.
Cardinal Sega twise Visitour of the Colledge in Rome condemning these men, and their fellowes in all these styrres.
Cardinal Allen ignominiouslie drawne in by these men to be a fauourer of their factions.
Cardinal Boromeus iniuriouslie fayned to be opposite to the Iesuites.
Cardinal Toled slaunderouslie affirmed to take parte with the seditious, and troublesome schollers in Rome against their Superiors.
Cardinal Bellarmyne falsely said to haue conspired with F. Persons to imprison their two messengers in Ferrara.
The most Reuerend F. in God the Bishop of Tricatica, Nuntius to his Hol. in Flaunders, who being appoynted Viceprotector & Iudge of English Ecclesiastical affayres these men refuse him.
The R. Reuerend Father Claudius Aquauiua, General of the Societie of Iesuites, suspected to be partial for kynred sake in behalfe of Card. CaÃ«tan.
The R. Reuerend M. Blakwel Archpriest, condemned, and dishonored by thÄ as ambitious for accepting his authoritie without their consentes.
Diuers of his Assistants slaundered as dissenting from him in iudgment, and some of them partially chosen to that office.
The worshipful, and R. Acaritius Canon of S. Iohn Laterans, Fiscal of his H â¢ l. Apostolical Visitation, for examining their two messengers, and misliking their proceedings.
Doctor Stapleton, Doct. Barret and others now dead slaundered to haue byn of their factiÅ, wheras they abhorred it, as appeareth by their owne letters.
The R. F. Alphonsus Agazarius and other Fathers Rectors for the tyme past of the English Seminarie in Rome, accused by these men for mouing troubles.

The R. Father Robert Persons Rector for the present of the same Colledge most eagerlie, and aboue all other impugned, as chiefe procurer of the Archp. authoritie & defender therof against their liking.
The R. Fa. Henrie Garnet Superior of the Fathers in England, for maintayning the same.
The whole Society of Iesuites ignominiouslie handled by these men in most partes of their libels, as also these Reuerend particuler men that follow by name.
M. Richard Haddoke Doct. of diuinitie and deane of Dublyn for being procurator in Rome for the Archpriest.

M. Martyn Aray Prouost of the English Church and
residence of S. George in S. Lucar of Spayne, for the same cause while he was in Rome.
M. Iames Standish Assistant to the Archp. in England for being sent to Rome to sollicite some order and subordination.

F. Edmund VVeston. F. Iasper Heywood, F. VVilliam Holt, F. VVilliam Baldwyn, F. Thomas Lister, and diuers other learned, and graue men calumniated by these libels in diuers places, and vpon sundry occasions.

div.head: Â¶ The principal Authors of these Libels.
div.p: THe chiefe doers in making and spreading these infamous libels are held to be these fiue or six following aboue the rest, to wit, M. Christopher Bagshaw, Iohn Colington, Rob. Charnoke, Iohn Mush, VVilliam Bishop, Anthony Champney: wherof the three last haue put their names in print to diuers partes of these Libels, the other three haue not, though the first be esteemed to be the penner of the latyn booke, and chiefe broacher of most of these calumniations with counsel and consent of the rest.

div.head: TO THE CATHOLIKES OF ENGLAND MOST VVORTHY OF THIS honorable name, that suffer for profession of that fayth and Religion. THE PREFACE.
div.p:
NOthing in this life could euer happen vnto vs more doleful or vnhappy (right honorable) and worthy seruants of God, then to be forced to write to you Catholikes (our dearest bowels) any displeasing thing against Catholike Priestes our most intierely beloued brethrÄ. But for so much as the vrgent necessitie which in our former Epistle we haue declared vnto our highest Pastor & in this do bewaile, & lamÄt vnto you, hath driuen vs against our wils to make this answere, we thought it expedient to forewarne, and forearme you also in this Preface what is meant thereby, least the matter being otherwise taken then it ought should yeeld to scandal, and thereby ouerthrow you and worke your ruine, which is intended and permirted
by almightie God Father of all mercyes to your trial and greater merit, to which end you are diligenly to consider, that most wonderful no doubt among so many other wonders in the affaires of al mightie God, is that his prouidence, or rather patience (as to mans eies it may appeare) whereby he permitteth; not only his whole church, familie, kingdome, and dearly bought portion to be afflicted continually with tempests, and contradictions in this life, but euery particular man also and member of most merit in the same, and according to the degree of his worthines so is the measure commonly of his suffrings. Both partes may be shewed by infinite examples of a perpetual succession of times, and matters happened from the beginning of Christian Religion, vnto our dayes.Diuerse kinde of aduersaries let out against the church, and all good men. For against the Church in general Christe the author had no sooner planted it, but he opened presently all the gates of hel to set out aduersaries, and enemies to assault it, the Iewes first his owne people before, then the heathen and Pagan Emperors with all their mighte and power, and after those againe (or rather with those) he sent a new kinde of aduersaries neuer heard of in the world before named heretikes, that took vnto them selues the name of the best sort of Christians, and yet further, and besides all this among such as remained Catholike Christians and vnited in profession of one faith, he suffred some to be so troublesome and apt to set debate either vpon ambition, enuie, contention, anger, treason or other like passions, as they were no less
combersome to the Apostles and other true laborers, then if they had byn open enemies.

Yea by this later sort especially were particular good men most vexed, and galled from time to time, for of the others open persecution being knowen enemies they did not so much care, but these men being of there owne bowels, yea somtimes also suffring for the same Religion (as by diuerse epistles of S. Cyprian to them that were confessors,S. Cyprian in epistolis ad Martires and liued discorderly in there prisons is euident) they gaue more affliction to the parties whome they vexed; more ioy and hart to the common enemie, and more scandal and grief to all sortes of theire owne side that lo â¢ ed on.

Wel then (most dearly and tenderly beloued) this was then, and this is now; and this shalbe to the worlds end the state of Gods seruants. Times do change, and men do pas,Psal. 116. Verbum autem Domini manet in aeternum. Christes word must endure for euer, and in this he sheweth himself to be God, he hath put the law ineuitable, Pressaram habebitis, Ioan. 16. Acto 20. you shall haue afflictions & exurgent ex vobis viri loquentes peruersa, euil tonged men shal rise out of you, but what, ad probationem fidei benorum, to proue good mens fayth and constancie,Iacob. 1. and what shalbe the ende qui perseuerauerit vsque in finem hic saluus erit, Matt. 24. hee is safe that shal stand out constant to the end, and is not mooued with these blastes. In patientia vestra possidebitis animas vestras. Wee must saue our sowles by patience,Luc. 21. and not otherwise. But one sentence appertaineth especially to you (o worthy Catholikes) in
this our case.Matt. 11. Beatus qui nÅ fuerit scandalizatus in me. Happie is he that shal not be scandalized in me, that is, shal not leese his patience or constancie, or good opinion of the cause; for this my permission of contradictions and difficulties for that this is permitted to proue you, and not to ouerthrow you.

Diuers impugnations of the English Cathol. cause.Trewly he that wil consider attentiuely, the difficulties and temptations which this our Catholike cause in England hath had since it was first assaulted by heresie, partely by force and flatterie, and other artes of the open enemie, & thÄ by the peruerse dealing of some of our owne for many yeares together; but especially of late, shal easely thereby discerne the prouidence of our merciful and almightie Saueour therein, & wel say that we are partakers of the same discipline that others haue passed through before in like case,Hebren. 8. and consequently shalbe also of like good end, and happie succes through his grace, if we haue patience, and longaminitie as they had.

And to say nothing in this place of the open impugnation of enemies which too wel you know, and feele dayly, what mightie difficulties haue those had I pray you, that haue byn our chiefe guides, and leaders in sustaining this holy cause for many yeares? and this from such as should haue chiefly assisted them if this diuine prouidence had not otherwise disposed that they should rather exercise them: diuers pointes you know alreadie, and some more you are like to perceaue by this our Apologie (being driuen thereunto) but not all;Reason of vvriting this Apol. for auoyding further
scandal, which respect of scandal should haue with held vs wholy from putting pen to paper in this case, if the intemperance of some persons (giuen ouer as it seemeth to choler and reuenge) and forgetting both themselues and others, and the times wherein they liue; had not broken forth of late to such exces, as we are forced against our wils to put some stop or brydle to so licentious and scandalous proceedinges least it infect euen the good, and trouble the strongest when they see such enormous matters pas without controlment.

And albeit we do not doubt, but that the more graue, and wiser sort wil consider of thÄselues Without our answere, the principal pointes that we can by answering note vnto them, as the extreme passion of these libellers in discending to such kinde of reuenge if they had bin iniured, the most bitter and opprobrious stile of speech against there owne,Pointes to be considered in the libels set forth. nothing sauoring of that spirit that should be in seruants of one God; the nature of libelling & contumelious writing wherin no certaine author, no licence of superiours for printing is named; and wherein worthie men are defamed by name without intention or possibilitie to proue it by lawful meanes, and then what greiuous sin,L. Si quis fa mosum L. 9. tit. 36. causa 5. Lt. c. 1. 2. & â¢ . and censures are incurred thereby not only of the doers but consenters also and spredders of such bookes.

Though we say it may be presumed that euery discret reader of himself wil ponder these pointes, as also what manner of men these be, that haue aduentured to be the authors of so intolerable
a scandal in our English Church, what may be there motiues, what there endes, what there meanes by secret cÅbining themselues with the enemie, for defaming such as they most feare & hate, and finally what may be doubted in the sequele, and how disunited these men be from there lawful superiors, and consequently from God also as iustly may be suspected, yet for better informing the reader of diuers particularities falsly, and iniustly set downe in their late bookes or infamatorie libels, which I suppose the more pious sort of men wil haue scruple to read or looke vpon, we are inforced as well for these respects, as for the honor of our nation least we seme to strangers to be more then barbarous, as also for some defence of innocencie excedingly iniured in these writings; to make this necessarie Apologie, but in a far other stile then the authors of these bookes haue vsed (if God assist vs with his grace and holy spirit thereunto) and to the end our Apologie may be the more substantial and autentique and these matters depend not o â¢ only saying or denying, we haue thought good to send into diuerse partes, as well of our Countrie, as foraine Realmes where Catholike English remaine,Informations â¢ ent for about this cÅtrouersie. to get such informations as may bee had; with the originals or trew copies of letters, and other wrytinges concerning this affaire, which when they shall come to our hands (as some alreadie haue don) our intention is (God willing) to set downe euery t â¢ ing at some length, for both present, and posteritie to see what God hath don, or permitted in this behalf, and who haue byn
trewly helpers, and who disturbers in our cause, who ioyne with the whole body and who impugne it, and other such particularities which wil easely decide the controuersie, if we be not deceaued.

But for that we are forced to expect yet some longer time, before we can haue these informations together, and in the meane space are much vrged by the request of dyuers good men as also by the in â¢ emperate manner of proceding in the authors of these late bookes (who so euer they be)ReasÅs for setting forth this briefe Apologie before the larger. to sert forth somewhat for a stay or stop for that these men cease not to write most oprobriously without all regard of truth or modestie and doe promise more dayly in the same Kynde therefore haue we yeilded to this necessite (though sore against our wils) hoping that shortly the other wilbe ready to succeed also albeit our harty desire should be, that the authors of these infamous bookes, & of this most scandalous diuisiÅ in our church would so enter into themselues, and Christianly corect there owne doings as both this and that mighte bee spared, and all ioyne againe in the sweet vnion of peace, which is nedeful for our work in hand, and was inioyed by vs before this animositie of a few hath put all a fyre, to theire heauie iudgment no doubt according to the Apostles threat if seriously they seake not to remedie the matter in the time, and we do say of a few,Galatas 5. for that we cannot perswade oure selues that all those who by diuerse occasions are named in these bookes for discontented, haue giuen consent to haue thÄ writtÄ in the stile they go in, and much les
to be printed, and published to the world, for we haue a far different opinion of their modestie, and Christian spirit, so as these bookes must needs be presumed to haue byn published eyther by some one or few discomposed passionate people, or by some heretike, or other enemie to dishonor them all, and discredite our cause and nation, and so as to such wee shal answere, and not against our bretheren whome we loue most intyrely, and of whose prayers we desire to be partakers, as them, and we and you all of the sweete, and holy spirite of Iesus our Saueoure; to whome we commed you most hartely this first of Iuly 1601.

div.head: VVHAT GREAT HVRTS HAVE COME to England by emulation of the Laity against the Cleargy; & of secular priests against religious, And of the State of the present controuersie in question. CAP. I.
div.p:
IF euer the enemy of mankinde did bestyrre himselfe and all his power to let any publike good of the English nation, it hath byn in this, of the reductiÅ to the Catholique fayth. For hindring wherof he hath tryed all his possible meanes, as before we haue noted, but especially that of diuision, emulation, and contention hath byn his cheefest. For by emulation of the Nobility against the Cleargy, and of secular priests against religious, he raysed Iohn VVickliffe aboue 200. yeares past, whome Iohn of Gaunt Duke of Lancaster, sonne to K. Edward
the 3. together with the residue of his faction (vpon emulatiÅ he had with B. ArÅ«del of LÅdon,Io. sto in vi- Edou. 3. anÌo 1377. & Tho Æ²Æ²alsingam in vita Rich. 2. B VVickam of VVinchester, and others) did set vp and maintayned against these and the rest of the Cleargy especially against religious men that had possessions, wickiffe being a secular priest himselfe. And by the same emulation it was diuers tymes proposed in Parlament, and otherwayes, vnder the Kings that followed, Richard the 2. Henry the 4. Henry the 5. and others, to haue the Abbey lands taken from them, and giuen to the mayntenance of the crowne:Malitious suggestious. which malice and deuice tooke effect afterward in the tyme of King Henry the 8. by the same emulation, which hindred also much the reconciliatiÅ in Q Maryes dayes, wherby no perfect reformation could be made, nor such restitution of religious orders, as in iustice should haue byn, and as the good Queene her selfe desyred.

In the begyning also of this Q. dayes, the litle affection which the laity did beare vnto the Cleargy procured by some vnquiet spirits, as also the smal vnion of diuers Cleargy men amÅgst themselues some holding with the heretikes and politikes by heat of faction, was a great occasion of the total ouerthrow of religiÅ whervpon
also the same diuel brought in the diuision of opinions about going to the heretical Churches and seruice,Religion hindred by faction. which most part of Catholikes did follow for many yeares: And when the better and truer opinion was taught thÄ by preistes & religious men from beyond the seas as more perfect and necessary; there wanted not many that opposed them selues: especially of the elder sort of priestes of Queene Maryes dayes. And this diuision was not only fauored by the Councel; but nourished also for many yeares, by diuers troublesome people of our owne; both in teaching and wryting.

The first English Seminary also being gathered togeather, and set vp at Doway in Flandres by the special prouidence of almighty God for restoring a new English Cleargy in the yeare 1568.Institution of Seminaries. by maister D. Allen (afterward Cardinal) D. Richard Bristowe and other good men ioyning with him; many contradictions rose vp at the beginning by certaine men, that albeit they were Catholikes, yet liked they not this attempt, and wrote diuers letters against it which are yet to be seene: so as this passion of emulation hath wonderfully hurt and hindred the English Catholike cause for many yeares, and some
ages: and so much the more ought it to be auoided by all good men now, seing that we are not ignorant, what hurts haue and doe and wil proceede therof, which is confusion and ruine to the whole.

Emulation the ground of this cÅtrouersy.And for so much as the principal or only ground of this our present cÅtention and scandalous controuersy, is the very same disease of emulation, partly of lay men against priestes & partly of priestes against religious men (especially the fathers of the Society, with whome at this present they haue to doe) and that this emulation is accompained with apparent wicked sisters and daughters, as ambition, enuy, hatred, contention, malice, pryde, malediction, and otherlike, it is an easy thinge for our brethren & others to discerne, from what roote these buddes do spring, and consequently eyther to auoyd them in them selues, or that other men be careful to take heed of them.

But for better declaratiÅ of this matter I shal go forward with the narration of these hurtes and difficultyes which vpon emulation haue fallen out in this our English cause vnder the Queene that now is especially concerning the Seminaryes, and the reduction of England by that way and mean procured, for these 20. yeares and
more, to wit since the beginning of the Romane English Colledge which was in the yeare 1578.The beginning of the English Colleg in Rome 157 â¢
at what tyme a contention being begone, betwene maister D. Lewes then Archdeacon of Cambray, but after Bishop of Cassane and the English schollers, about the maner of gouerment and gouernours of that house erected especially by his procurement and industry, there followed such a breach of this smal beginning as hardly afterward could euer be sodered agayne, wherof the Councel of England hearing, did lay handes presently, hoping heerby to keep a perpetual diuisiÅ in our nation. For which cause diuers spies were sent ouer to nourish the said diuision as namely one Vaune (yf we remember wel) who died in the inquisition at Rome in the yeare 1581. And soone after they vsed another named Salomon Alread a tayler by his trade and marryed, first at Lyons in France but after getting acquaintance in Rome and Millayne he became a states man, went in & out diuers tymes to the councel of England vntil at last being discouered, he remayned for seruant with Sir. Francis walsingam the Q. Secretary, and lastly professed heresy.

And from this tyme forward the councel of England endenoured by all meanes
possible to maintayne suspitiÅ ielousy, and emulation betwene those that fauored D. Lewes on the one side, and the rest that were ioyned with D. Allen & the Iesuites on the other, though much (no doubt) against both their willes.The diuisi n that fel amongt English Catholikes anÌo 1580. & aftervvard. VVhich attÄpt of theirs was holpen soone afterward by a new accident that fel out in Paris in the yeare 1583. and 1584. where two or three lay gentlemen belonging (as was said) to the Q. of Scots then prisoner in England, falling to be discontented with D. Allen, F. Persons Sir. Francis Inglefield and others vnited together in the affaires of our countrey, these gentlemen parting themselues and their actions from them, & going by another way, encreased greatly the forsaid breach, and made a farre stronger opposition against the forsaid men and whole body of Catholikes ioyned with them at home and abroad,M. Char. Paget. M. Thomas Morgan. M. Tho. Throgmor. wherof many great inconueniences did ensue, and among others (as the world doth knowe) the ouerthrow at length of the said Queene her self, and many more of her frendes, as more particularly shalbe shewed (yf need require) in our larger Apology when it cometh forth.

About this tyme also and soone after diuers impugnations were attempted at
Rome against the Seminaryes and missions of England, by men of opposite spirite & emulacion, some geuing vp memorialls to Pope Gregory the 13. and affirming that it was charges but cast away to maintayne them, seing they weare too weake helpes to reduce such a great countrey as England was, and therfore the money were better bestowed vpon maintenance of particular men.Memorials against the Seminaries Anno 1583 14 &c. VVhich petition when Pope G â¢ egory would not harkÄ vnto, thÄ they went about to persuade his Holynes: that it was cruelty and desperate dealing to send men into England to most certayne death. against which suggestiÅ there be extÄt letters wrytten as wel by D. Allen from Rhemes anÌo 1584.LrÄs of D. Allen 2. Aug of F. Persons 15. Sept. 1584. as also of F. Persons the same yeare from Paris to be shewed to his Holynes by the Rector of the Roman Colledge. The Copyes wherof we haue seene.

And not only lay mÄ, but diuers priestes also brought vp in the Seminaryes were drawne by little & little to be of this factiÅ against D. Allen, F. Persons and the Iesuites, & namely some in Rome, as appeareth by a visitation yet extant sent to the English Colledge by Pope Syxtus in the yeare 1585. wherin Bishop Sega (aftetward Cardinall) was this first tyme also visitour, & one of the priestes that is said to
be most busy in this contention now,Doct. B. had a cheife part also in those former troubles that were cause of this first visitation. And two yeares after this againe to witt in the yeare 1587. two other priestes brought vp in the Romayn Seminary and of this faction,G. G. E. G. conspiring togeather at Paris with consultation of some of the same humour, resolued to deale with the councel of England them selues, and for more grace and gratification with them, they wrote two mischeuous bookes, the one against D. Allen, the other against F. Persons and the Iesuitesâª geuing them vp to VValsingham the Q. Secretary, affirming also among other poyntes to make the partyes more odious (as our men their successors do at this day) that these men depended of Spaniardes and were enemyes to their Countrey.

The Confessions of G. G and E. G. anÌo. 1587 and 1583 and the Card. vvryting 1589.These bookes do yet remayne, and the whole matter is testified together with their complices in this fact by large confessions of their owne, the one being in prison at Paris the other in Rome, and vnder the hand of D. Allen when he was Cardinal in a latyn relation wrytten to the Cardinals of the Inquisition which we reserue to our larger Apology.

And about this tyme to witt in the
yeare 1587. when D. Allen should be made Cardinal diuers memorials were giuen vp against him by tho â¢ e of the contrary factiÅ espetially to the Count Oliuario,Deuises aga â¢ nst D. Allen. then Ambassadour in Rome for the K. of Spayne affirming among other poynts that the said D. was sworne subiect to the King of Fraunce in respect of his Canonry in Rhemes and many other like deuises to bring him in suspitiÅ, and therby let this promotion. And afterward when he was made Cardinal, and had the dignity they neuer ceased notwith-standing tyl his dyng day to deale and negotiate against him by all possible meanes,The lettres of Morgan to the Bish. of Dublyn, 20. of Aug. 1589. and of Prior Arn. to Morgan 13. of Nou. and of the Card. to Char. Paget 4 Ian. & 26 Oct. 1591. &c. and diuers other of the Card. to Thomas Throg. Tho. Morg. & others in the same yeare to the same effect first to discredit him with the King of Spaine, and to set vp his emulator against him in the same dignity while he lyued. For which purpose they sent to Spayne immediatly after F. Persons was gone thither to wit in the yeare 1589. Prior Arnold, as appeareth by his and diuers of their owne lettres yet extant, and by some of the Cardinals to thÄ vnder his owne hand.

But not being able to peruayle in this against the Cardinal himselfe, they began to set more earnestly against the Iesuits his cheifest frends and constant defenders, as wel in styrring vp the schollers in Rome against the Fathers that gouerned them, as
also to make a faction against them by secular priestes in England, as may appeare by a lettre of the Cardinals owne, wrytten most earnestly not six monethes before his death to a priest named Mush a principal actor (as it seemeth) in these later troubles, who hauing byn with the Cardinal at Rome, and hauing done some euil offices (as is presumed) in this behalfe, as wel in the Colledg amongst the schollers, as afterward vvhen he came backe into England,This is to be proued by diuers lettres of his yet extant vvryttÄ about this affayre. though he pretended this Romayne iorney to enter into the Society & to make himselfe a Iesuite) the Cardinal perceyuing his humor wrote most effectually to him, and by him to others against this diuision and faction, but litle preuayled,Card. Al. his letters to M. Mush. 16. Marc. 1594. as now appeareth: only it may serue to proue how false, & farre from the truth it is, which he and others of his faction do auow in these books that the Cardinal was disvnited from the fathers before he died, for that he said (as they relate) that when he should be dead, farre greater troubles and oppositions would fal out against the Iesuits, which may be true, for that he saw so much emulation against them, by libertynes and factious people, already begone in his tyme, which yet were retayned som what from
breaking forth, by his authority whyle he lyued.

But the good Cardinal being dead in the yeare 1594. all factions broke out togeather against the Iesuits destitute now of the Cardinals assistance,The beginning of the styrres against Iesuits in Rome, Fland. and EnglÄd Anno, 1594 and in Rome they begane first against Cardinal CaÃ«tan then Protector, and F. Claudius Aquauiua general of the Iesuits, for that they imagined them (but falsely as we haue credibly heard) not to fauour the promotion of the B. of Cassane, bringing into this contÄtion notwithstanding by litle and litle the greater part of the English Roman Colledge.The letters & memorial of M. Ch. P. are yet extant. And in Flaunders they began at the same tyme against F. VVillam Holt an English Iesuite in great credit with the gouernours there and M. Hugh Owen conioyned with him, vnder pretence that they were partial and furthered not those of that faction in their pensions and other sutes by them pretended.Styrres in VVisbiche In England also they began like styrres against the Iesuits there, and namely in the castle of wisbich, where there were about 30 preistes and other Catholike prisoners for their conscience, who hauing liued in great peace and contentment of mynd, for diuers yeres in that place after a Collegial and religious maner of lyfe,F. VVestÅ. by the instructions of a religious father of the
Society,D. B. who had liued also about 7. yeare prisoner in the same place, they were put into diuision by certayne troublesome spirites: the cheife wherof was he whome we haue now mentioned,See the Roman Register anno, 1584. mÄs Ian. who was dismissed out of the English Colledg not many yeres before for like behauiour as by publike Register it appeareth.

But when after two or three yeares of perpetual trouble which had wearyed his Hol. the Cardinals, and all other good men exceedingly, F. Persons comming to Ro. 1597 F. Persons came from Spayne to Rome in the yeare 1597. and hauing informed his Hol. of the nature and groundes of these contentions, and made capable also the discontented parties themselues of the inconueniences ensuing therof, and of the true way of remedy which they confessed,The liÄs of Six priests named arbitres to the general of the Iesu. then at Naples 18. May 1597. and accepted, as by their owne letters is yet extant, there was a fynal end made of these controuersies, and the College reduced to a most happie state, and quietnes, which (God be thanked) indureth to this day, to the great comfort of his Hol. & ioy of all good men, that loue the publike benefit of our country.

But the relikes of those that had byn troublesome and vnquiet before, coming into England, and conferring againe vvith their consorts, of their former actions, and
designements, frustrated as they thought, by F. Persons dealing at Rome, resolued to beginne againe, but after an other fashion, to wit, by deuising a certayne new Association among rhemselues, with offices,A nevv deuise of Associtation tending to sedition. and Prelacies of their owne institution, whervnto meaning to be chosen by voyces of such, as they would procure to fauour them, his Hol. should be enforced afterward to confirme them; and by this meanes they being Prelates of their owne making they should haue more power to woorke what they list, but especiallie against the Iesuites, whom they had procured at the very same tyme, by a man sent ouer to this purpose into Flanders to be accused to his Hol. in a most odious, and infamous memorial, as ambitious men, that wil gouerne thÄ against their willes, as appeareth at this day by the memorial it selfe yet extant, and by the voluntarie confession of the man sent ouer to this effect, vnder his oth,The cÅfession of Ro. Fisher 8. Marty 1598 and the rules of the nevv Association eodÄ anno. and this memorial was so slaunderous, and manifestlie false, as most of the Priests in England wrote to his Hol. against it, as appeareth by their lettres, and hands subscribed in great number. This passed in the yeare 1597. and 1598.

VVhen his Hol. sawe this manner of proceeding, he willed the Cardinal Protectour
to cal vnto him F. Persons, and other Englishmen in Rome, to see what remedy was best for these disorders, they answered, that the only way which seemed good to them was to geue them a superior or Prelate of their owne order, and to deliuer therby the Iesuites from these calumniatiÅs, which his Hol. yealded vnto, after diuers monethes cÅsultatiÅ had thereabout, with the whole congregation of Cardinals of the InquisitiÅ, but yet wheras a Bishop, or Bishops were demanded, they thought it not best, for auoyding suspitions, and troubles of the state of England for that tyme, to geue that Tytle, but rather an Archpriest with 12. Assistantes, nor was it thought expedient for his Hol. to wryte himselfe for the same cause, and considerations, and therfore hauing taken such enformation out of England of fit persons, for gouerment as was thought sufficient, his Hol. gaue ful commission to Cardinal CaÃ«tan the Protector to appoynt the same with con â¢ enient instructions,The Archpriest instituted by his Hol. & receyued by the quiet. as he presently did, and thervpÅ the said Archpriest was receyued, and obeyed willingly and ioyfully by our English cleargy, excepting, only a fewe that misliked the fact, for that it hind â¢ red their particuler designement of going forward with their forsaid opposition,
by association; & for that the Archpriest being a quiet, learned, and vertuous man, and wel vnited, in loue, and Iudgement, with the Iesuites, they distrusted euer to be able to drawe him to their faction & for that cause deuised many scruples and lets, partlie of the fayth and credence of the said Cardinals lettres, then whether his Hol. could do it by that meane, and order, and lastlie detracting to yeald him obedience, they sent two of their owne to Rome to oppose against the said ordination, styrring vp in the meane space as many as they could in England to enter into the same opposition with them.

But their Embassadors coming thither, and shewing no desyre of peace or vnion at all, or to accept of any good condition to liue in obedience vnder the Archpriest but endeuouring rather by all meanes possible sinistrously to infame diuers principal persons about the affayres of England, and therby to set further discord so farre foorth as in them lay, his Hol. for auoyding greater sedition commanded, after more then a fortnight they had byn at Rome, and neyther by the earnest perswasions of the two Cardinals, Caetan & Burghesius, & F. Persons, or others, could be perswaded to be quiet, and that diuers lettres out of England,
Flaunders and other places came to his Hol. daylie from the principal men of the English nation requesting some restraint might be put to their seditious attempt,The lettres of D. Stapl. D. Hall. D. Baret. D. VVebb. D. Kelliton, Licentiate VVright, & others to this effect anno 1598. for these causes I say his Hol. take order that they should be retyred to the English college in Rome, and there their cause heard, and handled by two Cardinals Caetan & Burghesio, to whom he gaue especial comission for that effect, as also to Acaritius Canon of S. Iohn Laterans his owne officer, to be examiner of the same matter vnder the Cardinals, and fynding after three monethes treating and examinatiÅ that they brought nothing worthy of consideration to alter the course already begonne,The examining of M B and M. Ch at Ro vnder their ovvne hÄdes and othes 1598. be confirmed all that was done already by the Cardinal with a newe Breue commaunding peace, and all obedience for the tyme to come.

A nevv Breue 1599This was promised at that tyme of all handes, and the two messengers did sweare it also by a corporal oth, and hope was that all would be quiet hervpon, to which effect F. Persons also wrote very courteous,F. Persons letres to M. Colynton, M. Mush. 9 April 1599. and pious letters vnto M. Colington, and M M â¢ sh and they accepted kindly of the same, as after we shal haue occasion perhaps more perticularly to set downe. But now Satan being loth to haue sedition ended, began againe to set them out in England,
and to put them in worse case then euer, by the industry of certayne seditious humors of the cheefest contenders, wherof some deuised new iniuryes offered them by the quiet, some required satisfaction for the old, some fayning and divulging that certayne of their side were to be called to Rome and Flaunders and to be put in prison; vpon which occasions they came not only to speake and thinke hardly one of another againe, but also to wryte many sharpe and vndecent lettres vp and downe from one syde to the other, vntil in Nouember last 1600. diuers of the discontented made a general Appeale from the Archpriests iurisdiction, as wel for themselues, as for whosoeuer hereafter should take their partes, which being a clause rather appertayning to sedition then AppellatiÅ euery man may see to what end the Appeale was directed; neyther do we yet learne, that in all this tyme any one hath appeared in Rome to prosecute the said Appeale,Appeales vvithout prosecutiÅ. as neyther certayne other Appeales of some of them of VVisbich made before this, from the Archpriest, neyther that of M. Charnock which he made (as he saith) in Lorayne from the sentence of the two Cardinals, after he had accepted it,M. Ch. letters to Card. Burg. 1600. and sworne to the obseruation therof in Rome, none of
these Appeales haue we heard to be prosecuted hitherto in Rome (according as the nature and obligation of a good and sincere Appeale requireth) and in the meane space, no obedience, or regard is performed to the Superior during the dependance of the said Appeale which is an other great disorder in conscience, and Iustice, and by all this may be coniectured; that libertie, and freedome from all Superioritie is heere sought, and not tryal of the cause.

But not resting heere, nor cÅtented with this freedome during the dependance of the said Appeales, they haue proceeded to farre greater disorders,Contumelious libels sett forth by the contentions. which is, to publish in print most iniurious, contumelious, and infamatorie bookes, and libels (as before hath byn said) without particuler name of Author, without licÄce of Superiour, & other circumstances of modestie, right and conscience required in such attemptes, and the effect and very drifte of these books indeed howsoeuer they goe about to disguyse matters, by laying the fault vpon the Archpriest, F. Persons, & other particuler men) is, to cal in question his Hol. actions, yea and his power, and authoritie also in instituting the Archpriest as he did, and to exagitate the proceedings and doings of Cardinal Caetan and Cardinal Burghesius our
Protectors at that tyme, as wel about the Tumultes of the College of Rome which these men wil needs approue, and defend, as also in hearing and determining the cause of M. Bishop and M. Cha â¢ nock their Messengers. They do also neglect and contemne whatsoeuer the present Protector Cardinal Farnesius hath done or written,Card. Farm, his lettres appoynting him Protonot. by the Popes commandemÄt 17. IÄ. 1600. or deferred to the Archpriest, namely in procuring him to be Prothonotarius Apostolicus neyther do they geue him the tytle of Reuerendissimus, due to that degree, and vsed towards him by the Cardinal himselfe in his lettres. They do also shew extreeme immodestie in speaking both presumptuosly of themselues, & contumeliously of others, and haue diuers Assertions both scandalous, remerarious, and euil sounding, vttered (as it seemeth) vpon only pryde and choller in these their books, besydes infinite vntruthes, and contumelious slaunders divulged against worthy men wel deseruing of them and theirs in particular, with whom without all reason they seeme to be enraged with bitter choller, and desyre of reuenge, which is a greiuous point in men of their calling, and that professe such a cause as they haue in hand, and greatly to be lamented: And this is the effect of both their books that hitherto we haue seene,
but yet shal we brieflie say somwhat more to the particuler matters in euery of them conteyned, so farre foorth, as shal seeme to vs expedient, for this briefe Apologie, reseruing the rest to our larger, that is to ensewe.

div.head: OF THE GREAT DISobedience which our discontented brethren haue vsed in these their contentions, and how vndutifully they haue behaued themselues towards all sorts of superiors, & namely towards his Holines himselfe; and of some scandalous and temerarious propositions, set downe in their bookes. CAP. II.
div.p:
1. Thess. 4.IF to conforme our selues to the holy wil of almighty God be our sanctification & only way to saluation as the whole course of holy scripture teacheth vs, and that for this cause our Sauiour taught vs with such diligence to pray dayly, Fiat voluntas tua: Math. 6. and if the interpretation of this wil of God vnto vs, be the wil and voice of our Superior wherunto we are bounde to harken and obay, for obtayning all grace &
blessing: And if the contrary spirit of rebellion and disobedience be most opposite to Christ,2. Cor. 2. Tit. 3. Heb. 13. 1. Reg. 11. Eccles. 3. Prou. 21. qui factus est obediens vsque ad mortem, &c. And that the resisting of our Superiors wils be accounted the highest sinne of all others, by holy mens opinions, and so prooued by the dreadful examples of Saul & others cast of and made reprobate cheefly for the same synne. Yea if the scripture do so much abhorre this disobedience, as it maketh the same equal to idolatry it selfe, saying: quasi peccatum artolandi est repugnare: & quasi s â¢ elus idolatriae nolle acquiescere. 1. Reg. 15. To resist obedience is as great a synne as to be a southsayer, and neuer to be quiet, is as bad as the heynous sinne of idolatry: if all this be so as it is; Alas, in what case can diuers of our brethren think themselues to stand at this day before God, who haue so long and so stubornely and in so weightie matters resisted the wils & desyres prayers, and commandements of all sorts of due Superiours?

For first of all to beginne with Cardinal Allen of whome these men would seeme to make most account, now he is dead and gone, as though he had fauoured them when he was alyue, which yet (as we shal shew) is quite contrary: For he in his forsaid lettre of the 16. of March to M. Mush
doth most earnestly geue in charge to him and to all other preests to lyue in great vniÅ with the fathers of the Society, yelding for his reason the singular obligation they had to their manifould benefits. His words are these:A clause of Card. AllÄs letter to M. Mush 1594 16. March, I haue hard (saith he) to my great greefe, that there is not that good correspondence betweene the fathers and other priests, I cannot tel vpon what discontentmÄt, &c. But wherof soeuer it cometh it is of the enemy, & with all possible discretiÅ & diligÄce by the wiser sort on both sides to be rooted out, or els it wilbe the ruine of the whole cause, &c. therfore in this poynt especially (M. Mush) be ernest and peremptory with all partyes,Consider hovv vvel this is performed. and euery one in particular, and tel them that I charge and aduise them by the blessed bloud and bowels of Gods mercy, that they honour loue and esteeme one another, according to euery mÄs age order & profession, & that those of the secular order, especially those that haue byn brought vp vnder the fathers and haue found so great loue, charity and help in all places at their handes, that they be correspondent in all gratitude and thankefulnes, reuerencing them in word and deed, as is requisite to their merits and calling, &c.

Thus wrote the good Cardinal not aboue
halfe a yeare before his death. And by this we see both what his opinion & loue was towards the fathers, and what his commandement and order was to all these preests (he being Superiour to them all appoynted by his Holines) that now are so contentious against the Iesuits. VVhat would the good man haue said if he had lyued til this day to se his request and commandement so contemned by them? And how canne M. Mush and others name so often the Cardinal without blushing when they breake so earnest an exhortation and order of his in so great a matter. But let vs see and lament their progresse from worse to worse.

As soone as euer the Cardinal was dead they began the contention in Rome, and brake forth with the Rector, Prouincial, & General of the Iesuits, appoynted by his Hol. for their lawful Superiours, and presently thervpon with Cardinal Caietan also their Protector and higher Superior, and after him againe with Cardinal Sega their lawful visitour,Card. Sega his visitatiÅ of the English Colledg exhibited the 14. of May 1596. immediatly sent from the Pope, who after due examinatiÅ condemned ther actions by publike sentence, as appeareth yet by his visitation geuen vp to his Hol. vnder his owne hand and seale a litle before his death, anno 1596. And albeit
besides these diuers others were sent from his Hol. in like mÄner to pacifie them as Monsignor Antoniano, now Cardinal then master of his Hol. ChÄber. Monsignor Morro, now Bishop then Referendary, & others, who shewed vnto them plainly the Popes wil and commandement, as himselfe did also in a most effectual manner, when he restored foure of them, that by his owne order had byn put forth of the colledge before, though also not long after, when diuers of thÄ tooke their leaue of his Hol. in the moneth of September 1597. to go towards England he made them a most vehement exhortation in this behalfe, charging them to lyue in vnion among themselues,The relatiÅ of the Popes spech sent into Engl. that yeare 3. of Sept. 1597. and namely and particularly with the fathers of the Society. All this notwithstanding, they haue shewed to continue stil their old mynds of diuision and dissention against these expresse commandemÄts of God, by the voyce of so many his substitutes. And what good consciencÃ¨ then alas can there be heere, and how doth not the feare of Gods iudgments enter to end these dissentions and represse these disorders? One reb â¢ llious act was sufficient to make Saul reprobate though he were a King. And the like seuerity of Gods iudgment was seene in our first parÄt, for one disobedience.
and how then do not our brethren feare to lyue in this continual disobedience so often iterated, and that against so many Superiors. But let vs go forward.

His Holines hearing of certayne new associations begonne in England soone after the forsaid tumults ended in Roome, and perceyuing the same to tend to a new diuision and contention as wel by the lawes & rules thereof, as by a certayne new cÅtumelious,Fishers Mem. in Sept. 1598. and most enormous memorial before mentioned sent ouer against the Iesuits, he appoynted them a Superiour of their owne order, as yow haue hard, and such a one, as â¢ heir owne two Embassadours sent to Rome, confessed vnder their owne hands and othes (as appeareth in their examination) that he had byn the likeliest man of all others to be chosen by voyces; if the election had byn permitted vnto them. But did they quiet with this, as obedient men should, and as the rest of the body of the Cleargy did? No alas; for then we should haue had peace; but all their wits were bended straight wayes to seeke out new exceptions,Deuises & shifts against obedience. and so to euacuate the Superiors ordination. Is this the vertue of obedience? Is this humility? Is this according to the oth they tooke, the most part of them at least; when they were schollers of
the Seminaryes to go in these missions by subordination and obedience? and such as vvere not of the Seminaryes vvhere the oth is vsed, yet promised they the very same vvhen they receyued their facultyes. And the thing is included in the very nature of Apostolical missiÅs, to obay all subordinate Superiors.

The Breue for cÅfirm of the Archpriest 6. April 1599.But at lÄgth his Hol. to resolue al doubts declared by his Breue that all & euery point of the former institution by the Cardinal vvas by his order, consent, knowledge and commandement; and should not this haue brought some remorse to good and tender cÅsciences of all the broyles and turmoyles raysed vp before about this vnnecessary doubt? or at least wise, should not this haue so appeased men for the tyme to come, as vvhat soeuer the Superior had byn for his person, yet should his authority neuer more haue byn called in question? But what ensued? Truly vve are afrayd to recount it, remembring that dreadful saying of the Apostle:2. Tim. 3. Mali autem homines proficiant in peius, il men shal go from vvorse to vvorse. And so it semeth to haue comen to passe; for that diuers of these cheefe heades of this seditiÅ seeming to haue lost much of Gods grace by not obeying promptly that Apostolical declaration and determination
haue runne sythence to farre greater contempt & perturbatiÅ of mynd, as by their wrytings and facts hath appeared, not only in contemning this Superior heere in England,Great presumption against Superiors actions. and abusing him with cÅtemptuous and contumelious vvordes and deedes, but calling also in controuersy the Protector & his Hol. actions and power about this affaire, especially in these their two late bookes, or libels, vvherof the one being in latyn the other in English; they do flatter his Hol. in the latyn, but doe examine his doings in the English, and in the one and other they cal in question and do seeke to disprooue or bring in contempt vvhatsoeuer hath byn done in Rome hitherto, about the institution and continuation of this Hierarchie of the Archpriest and his Assistants and gouernment.

And first of all they speake euery vvhere very contemptuously of the dignity and office of the Archpriest, and also of the maner of the institution therof by his Hol. calling it,In the booke intituled Copies of certayne discourses: pag. 10. A new and extraordinary authority: Ibid. pa. 3 vnpleasing and obtruded authority: Ib pag. 30 disorderly procured gouernment, exorbitant, and altogeather dissonant from reason, & to the accustomed practise of Gods Church: yea and to make it more odious they say:Ib. pag. 6. that it is already thought by the Queenes counsel to be of purpose erected (not
for religion) but for the better effecting of plots and desigments of state, which odious speeches and interpretations these mÄ do wryte and print to the end they would haue the Counsel so thinke and say, and by taking his Hol. meaning in the wrong sense, bring al good Catholikes that obey this ordination and the Archpriest appoynted by him, within the compasse of treason for matter of state. VVhich poynt, these men to woorke more mischeefe do teach the persecutors in playne woords againe a litle after in the same page, in these woords.

Ibid. pag. 6. Besides all this by the opinions of diuers men in the lawes of our countrey, this our cause may & wil be drawne within the compasse of an old law enacted, as wel by our Catholike Bishops and Prelats, Very malitious & remeratious speches of a fevv against the vvhole body. as by the Prince aboue 300. yeares agoe viz, the law of Praemunire, because it is an external iurisdiction brought into this Realme against the wil and notice of the Prince and countrey, which made the late reuerÃ©d Bishop of Lincolne D. VVatson to refuse all external iurisdiction offered him ouer his fellow prisoners, although once he had lawful Episcopal iurisdiction within the Realme and was vnlawfully depriued therof.

These are their words: wherby his Hol. and all other godly and learned men may see and pitty them, but especially their spirit
of vindecatiue and maleuolous proceeding, who go about to bring all obedience to the Archpriest within the statute of Praemunire (which inflicteth the losse of goods and liberty. For that it is instituted by his Hol. from Rome, and therby in their interpretation an external iurisdiction, brought in against the wil and notice of the Prince and countrey. Malignant indeauors. VVherin is to be noted first that these men would haue the Princes cÅsent also (though different from them in religion) to be needful for legitimation of this authority: secondly, by the countrey they must needs meane themselues only, that is to say some 5. or 6. that opposed themselues at the beginning, for that his Hol. had not asked their consents. For other countrey they cannot meane, seing all Catholikes besides them consented, and it was not needful for his Hol. to aske the consent of Protestants or PuritÄs that liue in the same countrey. VVherfore heere is nothing but maleuolence and disobedience discouered with desyre to bring the Archpriest, and all those which obey him within the cÅpasse of temporal lawes and treason.

And as for the Statute of Praemunire by them mentioned,The Statute of Proemunite. it is not so auncient as they make it, but was begonne to be treated about the tyme that VVickliffe rose vp
when emulation was in heat against the Clergy, and the cheefe pourpose therof was at the beginning to prohibite Appellatton to Rome in the first instÄce, vnder the paynes afore said, & the woorst Kinges of England euer since haue most vrged it, and it was not made (as these men say) by our Catholike Bishops and Prelates (nor could not in consciÄce) but sorely rather against their wils was it passed in Parlement, by the streame of temporal power and emulation against them,Great iniurie offered to D. VVatson B. of Lincolne. and it is most contumelious and false that which is added about D. VVatson Bishop of Lincolne a most pious confessor in this Queenes dayes that he refused all external iurisdiction offered him from his Hol. for that had byn to deny his Hol. Ecclesiastical iurisdiction in England. And vvheras they say, that he had once Episcopal iurisdiction within the Realme, good Catholikes do hold and say that he had alwayes that lawful iurisdiction during his life, notwithstanding his vnlawful depriuation by Protestants, and that he acknowledging this his Episcopal iurisdiction (as he did and ought to do) from the Sea of Rome, he alwayes acknowledged (as all Catholike Bishops do) an external iurisdiction in this sense vvhich these men do heere impugne. But vve would aske
