them what if their owne deuised and attempted plot of gouernmÄt by Association and popular regiment (more new and straunge then this) which at the very same tyme, they vrged so much, had takÄ place, how would that haue stood vvithout external iurisdiction, seing that one of these two points they must confesse, that eyther they vvould haue asked confirmatiÅ therof from Rome, and consequently it would haue byn external iurisdiction as wel as this of the Archpriest, or els they vvould haue gouerned absolutely of them selues without any dependence or approbation of his Holines and this had byn a farre worse inconuenience to exclude wholy the Sea Apostolike for auoyding the Statute of Praemunire. VVherfore vvhether this spirit tendeth all men do see.

And thus much about their contempt & impugnation of the authority it selfe instituted by his Hol. and confirmed afterward by an expresse Breue. But if vve vvil see now how daungerously they do teach disobedience to this authority and to all other vvhich they mislike let vs heare their owne woords, vvhich are these.Prefat. pag. 5. Those that are so ignorant (say they) must be taught, and such as are contented at this tyme to make shew of so grosse ignorance must bee put in mynd, that authority
is not an infallible rule of truth in all who haue authority, Daungerous & offensiue doctrine. and consequently that noe man is bounde in all things to beleeue or execute what eue- man in authority ouer him shal put vpon him, in how many thinges not only Archpriests but their Superiors also the Archdeacons, and other of higher degree haue done amisse and swarued from the truth? and who vpon earth is warranted from erring but one? and not he in all things, &c. Lo heere these mens doctrine, which albeit in some senses, meaninges, & interpretations, they may endeauour to verifie and defend, yet how daungerous, and scÄdalous it may prooue, to teach the people in this general manner against their Superiours, is easy to cÅsider, seing it teacheth men to doubt, whether & how farre they be to be obeyed yea his Hol. himself in some points for that they say he is not warranted in all and consequently may erre also in some of his ordinances and commaundements, and by the same argument, which they vse against the Archpriest and other higher superiors, a man may argue also against his Holynes & men are taught by this doctrine to examine euery thing coming from their Superiors, by their owne iudgments, and admit what they please, and leaue the rest.

And what other way did heresy take at the beginning against ecclesiastical gouernors?
or vvhat other gate did some vnquiet and disobedient Catholikes in those dayes open to heresie, who being offended with their Superiors taught that their subiects in conscience might dissent from them and disobey them in diuers cases; vvhich though it were true in it selfe, yet these cases not being put downe nor obserued in particuler, but the doctrine only deliuered in general; wrought infinite hurts in Gods church. But our men not contented vvith this general doctrine against obediÄce, they passe on to diminishe the credit and estimation of their Superiors in particular, not only of them that be immediate in England,vndutiful spechs against Card. CaÄtan. which are the Archpriest and his assistants (whome many wayes they endeauour to bring in contempt) but euen their immediate and higher Superiors also in Rome, to wit Cardinal Caetan their protector, and his Hol. of both which they speake very vndutifully oftentymes; and first of the said good Cardinal now dead, they wryte (to diminish his estimation with Catholikes) that he was Protector of the English Colledge at Rome, Praefat pag. 3. and afterward honored by the Title of Protector of England But not graunting that he was so indeed, or that they did acknowledge him for such, they adde:Ibid pag. 7. That they were not bound to beleeue him in
that matter of so large cÅsequence (about the institution of the Archpriest) without Bul or Breue. That he was knowne to be allied to the contrary part (to wit to F. Claud. Aquauiua general of the Iesuits) and said to be ruled altogeather against those (the English schollers and preests) whose Protector he pretended to be. Pag. 121. That his letters drew on a general and extreme persecution vpon the neckes of the Preists of England, and consequently were not to be allowed by them. Pag. 7. That they were not bound to obay his ordinances vpon his letters only, Pag. 26. not holding him for their Superior. And that to no man, though in neuer so great honour is it due to haue his owne testimony admitted for acknowledging of that authority which he hath not of himselfe, but from another. And further.Pag. 11. That they are not to giue creditte to the Cardinals bare words in a matter of so great weight, seing that in such busines he hath byn found hereto fore to much affected to the one part.

And finally not to be ouerlong in this point vvhich toucheth the most honorable Cardinal,Vndutiful behauiour tovvards the C. Protector. Protectour now gone to God, it is sufficient to shew their passionate and discomposed mynds, that he hauing byn to all our nation a most deare Patrone and father in all occasions, these men in all their speches and wrytings, and namely in this last English booke of theirs do speake euery vvhere very vnkindly and vnreuerently
of him, and do so contemne the institution of the Archpriest made by him vpon his Hol. expresse order, and confirmed after by his Breue, and the most graue approbatiÅ of the congregation of Cardinals of the Inquisition, as in one place of their booke, they go about to shew it to be voyd and vayne, and of no force, by one and twenty fond reasons deuised by themselues wherof no one hath any force at all.Pap 84. 85. 86. & deinceps. And this of their Protectour, whose letters as a Cardinal bearing credit vncontrolable in any Catholike court Christian, these men do so lightly set by, as yf he had byn a man of no credit at all.

But vvhat of his Holines? doth the modesty of these men spare him & his doings when they are pressed therwith? No truly. For that they professe liberty of spech in all things and against all men, and so they say of themselues in this their latyn booke, that they are ni iniurijs liberÃ¨ repellendis ammosiores, Pag. 3. of more animosity in repelling freely iniuries offered, which is conforme to that, which some of them wrote to their two Roman messengers in the yeare 1598. to be shewed to his Hol. and is yet extant vnder the hand of M. Bagshaw,Their behauiour tovvards his Hol. who hauing set downe their opinion about the Archpriest, addeth this conclusion: Sic nos, sic
fratrum nostrorum plurimi, quorum citÃ² indignabitur libertas, si premitur. So do we iudge, and so do many of our brethren iudge, whose liberty wil quickly be angry, and fal into indignation, yf it be strayned. Behold these good libertynes, and consider also that this was spoken to no meaner man then the Pope himselfe, seing it was to be shewed to him by the messengers. And it was one clause of their comission from six humble prisoners in Wisbiche. And cÅforme to this is that other glorious saying in this their late latin booke to the Pope immediatly, Indignum quippe nimis gloria nostra (say they) nec amplius ferendum duximus, Lib. Lat. pag. 6. &c. we esteeme it to to vnworthie of our glory, and no further to be tolerated, &c. And againe in the English booke,Pag. 7. to thinke that his Hol. accounteth vs so base and abiect a Cleargie, or so vnworthie members of Gods Church, that we deserue not, Pag. 14. &c. And a litle after they tel vs plainly, that there is great reason why his Hol. should not appoint a Superior in England, without their aduise and allowance, and that in doing contrary he should do against the Canons of the Church, Di â¢â¢ bb ca. 1 â¢ . & i â¢ i â¢ . b. cap. 3. and against the decrees not only of Popes but also of Emperors, (as though this were more)(as though this vve â¢â¢ mo â¢ e) which â¢â¢ p â¢ nt, that the Cleargy may resist and withstand any Bis â¢ op put vpon them against their consent & liking, for which they cite the ordinary
glosse vpon 63. dist. cap. 34. by all which is not hard to iudge of these mÄnes haughtie spirit.

But their greatest disorder in this point is first to cal into suspition of forgery the Popes breue it selfe when it came forth for confirmation of the Cardinal Protectors letters, saying in their English booke that it was procured God knoweth out of what office, &c. (what can be spoken more cÅtemptuously) and then after the discrediting the Breue it selfe, to draw his Hol. most pious meaning in geuing them an Ecclesiastical Superiour, to matter of State and temporal driftes (as before hath byn shewed) ioyning therin with the heretikes and persecutors themselues, which string they do touch in many places of their English booke, thinking (perhappes) that this wil not come so easily to his Hol. sight (as the latin vvherin they flatter more). And in one place, they haue these words:Pag. 29. Very seditiÅs speech against his Hol. meaning. The thing it selfe (to wit the institution of the Archpriest) carryeth euident remonstrance of an vntollerable burthen without any comodity at all, and not without manifest suspition of a playne plot or stratageme to confound or take away all Ecclesiastical Hierarchie, and ancient approued gouernment in our Church.

Thus do wryte and pronounce of his Hol. actions, three or foure headdy people
of as many hundreds abyding in England, and what can be spoken more rashly or more seditiously then this? But yet heare another proposition of as bad or vvorse quality.

Treating of the Sacrament of confirmation, the administratiÅ wherof, they would haue granted to some of them (and truly all good men haue made often supplication to his Hol. for the vse therof, yet content to stand to his iudgment therin) these men do so farre vrge, and amplyfie the matter that they affirme it (in these words) eyther to be most necessary in tyme of persecution, Pag. 103. or alto â¢ eather vayne, and as a superfluous ceremony in Gods Church. VVhich is a very temerarious and scandalous speech not to censure it any further heere,A very temeratious propositiÅ. but to leaue it to whome it belongeth, for that the words, vaine and superfluous ceremony, are contemptuous phrases of the heretikes, nether doth it follow, that albeit his Hol. and predecessors hitherto haue not thought the vse of this Sacrament necessary in England, during the tyme of our persecution (as in deed to no man in any time is it absolutely necessary to saluation) therfore good Catholikes should esteeme it for a vaine and superfluous ceremony. D. Tho. p. 3. q. 6 â¢ . art. 4. & Suerez in cum locÅ« & in q. 72. disp. 38. sect. 1. These are woords of great excesse & conteine false doctrine & are very reprochful
aswel to his Hol. as to his predecessors. And to these disorders are men brought, by pride, wrath, enuy, emulation, & such passions; and worse may be feared, yf stop be not made in tyme.

div.head: OF THE GREAT INiuries and ingratitude offered by our discontented brethren to the whole body and society of the Iesuites, How pleasing and profitable this is to heretikes, and how preiudicial and dishonorable to all our Catholike Nation and cause. CAP. III.
div.p:
AFter disobedience followeth ingratitude as her sister; both of them borne of one mother, which is pride, who as she persuadeth to disobay, least a man may seeme to be vnder another, so doth shee dissuade from gratefulnes, least he might seeme to haue need of any other, wherby it cometh to passe as Seneca wisely noteth,Seneca ãâã epist. that a proud man seing him selfe loaden with anothers benefits, and his passion not permitting him to acknowledg or recompence thesame, chaungeth his retribution into hatred and impugnation, therby to remooue
so lothsome an obiect. Thus saith that Learned man, and how wel it is verified in this our case euery man of meane discourse may easily consider, seing the benefits which the body and Society of these religious men named Iesuits haue bestowed vpon our Catholike nation in this tyme of their affliction and banishment are knowne to all the world, whether we consider the education of our youth in Seminaryes, their teaching in schooles, their institution in manners and lyfe, their assistance in all countreyes, their helps with all Princes, yea the erection of our Seminaryes themselues, there labours against the common enemy, their ioyning vvith vs in our missiÅs and sufferings, and by infinite other wayes, helping, comforting and encouraging vs.

Most notarious ingratitude.Yea diuers of those that be heads now of faction against them are so farre beholden vnto them, as probably they had neuer byn men of learning or atcounte, or able to wryte bookes, yf these religious men and their charity had not byn: some of them going ouer poore seruing men, other souldiers, other wanderers in the world, and none lightly but more or lesse one way or other in neede of their help and fauour, which euer they found ready, and their hands and harts open to all, and now for
them to receiue such payment at our hands as these libels and calumniations are, and haue byn hertofore from othets of this humor, must needs be a great shame and preiudice to our nation. And surely if these men did know what hurt they do to others of their owne nation, and did heare the lamentations and maledictions that are layd vpon them, by many English Catholike people liuing in other countreyes, vvho hauing great need many wayes of the Fathers helpes, do blush to aske it, in respect of the enormous ingratitude vsed by others of their owne nation against them, they would I think be somwhat mooued therwith, as we and other our brethren are in their behalfes.

But yet surely all this is much more tollerable to Catholike eares and eyes, then is this which followeth,Very scandalous and passionate proceding. that our brethren being sacred preists should be content vpÅ passion and reuÄge only to ioyne with the heretikes in open printed books for defaming and defacing them, whome the said heretikes account their cheefest enemyes and impugners, and our best frends and defenders: This I say is toto iniutious a fact to God, our countrey and comon cause. To God, for that his seruants are impugned vpon maleuolence, & many of them (in so
much as the whole body and name of Iesuits is impugned) are touched and iniured, who cannot possibly haue any fault at all in the matters in question, for that they neuer dealt therin. To our countrey it is iniurious, for that straungers must needs think basely of vs to see vs of so reuÄgeful a mynd against so manifold benefactors. To our cause also it must needs be highly preiudicial, for that (say men what they wil, and pretend what they list) no godly man liuing wil thinke them to be led by Gods spirit, that proceed in this order, and if they should come to be put to death for, religion they would say of them as S. Hierome did of the like, that they suffered, vt martyrio delerent errorem, Hier. Ep. ad Pammach & Ocean. 65. & culpam sanguinis effusione purgarent, they were martyrs for satisfying their former offences, and not to iustifie their former actions therby. And lastly this course is hurtful also and aboue all, to our brethrens owne reputation, euen with the very enimy, to see them vpon splene conspire vvith them against their owne for (as the common saying is) howsoeuer the treason be embraced, yet the traytor is hated and contemned. VVhich we hope our brethren after this first heat of choler past, vvil more maturely consider of.

And to the end they may the easier enter into some consideration of the enormity of this fact, we shal lay before them some particulars to be pondered, as for exÄple out of their latyn booke, let them thinke what Catholike strÄgers wil iudge of them when they shal se the very margents of their said Libel so stuffed with peeuish and malignÄt notes against Iesuits in general,A fond malignity in decking the margÄt vvhich contumelious speche â¢ . as if they vvere the woorst men liuing, and publike enimies of peace, vnion and of all vertue and good conscience, which heretikes thÄselues (at least the more moderate sort) would scarse set downe, nor hitherto (vve thinke) haue not done. For that euery temperate man wil easily see that it is great excesse of passion, not only to wryte and print contumelious matters in the pages & leaues themselues, but also to decke the margents vvith ostentation therof; wherof here vve shal set downe some few examples.

In the page 23. they make this general note in the margent: Iesuitae quae sua sunt, quaerunt. Iesuits seeke their owne, and not those things which are of Iesus Christ (for vnto that place of the Apostle they allude) but what shewe of truth hath this?Philip. 2. or do these mÄ proue it in their text? no truly, no more then in the margent, and yow may see the place and shal find it so. Againe they note
in the margent pag. 29. Iesuitici sedem Petri afficiunt ignominijs: Iesuitical men do dishonour and shame the seat of Peter; & againe in the same page: Their propositions are impious against the Sea Apostolike. And may there be any probability thinke yow of this?

Furthermore page 37. they say in the margent, that the persecution of Iesuits is more greiuous vnto them, then that of the aduersaryes, which perhaps may haue some secret true meaning, if the aduersary be he that setteth them on in this worke; and then pag. 45. Iesuits do trouble the peace of England, which accusation may come also perhaps from the same aduersary, who vseth it in all his wrytings and speches. And to the same effect they make another general note pag. 63. Iesuitae parum curant Ecclesiae tranquillitatem. Iesuits do litle care for the tranquillity of the Church, as who should say, that these men ioyning with the aduersary against their head and brethren, do care more for it, and more procure it.

And finally not to spend more tyme in these trifles we wil end with one most odious note made against them, but indeed touching our selues and our countrey. The note is this, pag. 83. Inanis iactatio Iesuitarum de seminarijs Ã se erectis. The vaine bragging of Iesuits of Seminaryes erected by them.
But where and when and by whome of them in perticular,Very disdainful ingratitude. this vaine bragging hath byn vsed, they do not set downe in their booke, nor cannot, as we thinke: but sure we are that the general body vvhich they touch by this woord Iesuitarum cÄnot haue bragged therof, for that all are not acquainted with our Seminaryes, and they are men that comonly are wont to do more in such affaire then willing to bragge, and truly vve cannot imagine, but that this is some deuised bragge, inuented and brought in by our angry brethren, to gaule them withall, but indeed to iniury vs and our countrey, who haue receaued the benefit of so many Seminaries by them and their labours, and haue need of their help and assistance stil, for their holding vp and maintayning, which these men would soone ouerthrowe vpon splene and emulation, if it lay in their hands. And by this act of so extreme ingratitude, they do what they can to that effect, but God (we hope) vvil defend his worke begunne, and restrayne their power in pulling downe, which haue no will to set vp or conserue.

And with this we might end, but that in this place our brethren do vse so fond a calumniation against the Iesuits and so notoriously false as no man can but wonder
therat; for they say that the new Seminaryes set vp by the Iesuits in Spayne and Flanders, are not so beneficial to England as may counteruayle the hurts done by thÄ to the two auncient Seminaries of Doway and Rome, Latin booke pag. â¢ 3. which we cannot s â¢ what least shew of probability or truth it may beare, for that the benefits receyued by the new Seminaryes, as well that of S. Omers, wherin wel neare 100. are maintayned,Benefits procured by the Iesuits to our Countrey by Seminaryes. as those also of Valladolid and Siuill, where no lesse number is betwene them, with the two Residences also of S. Lucar and Lisbone, as in like maner that of Ewe while it stood, (all which no man can deny, but they were procured by the fathers, and him especially whome those men most impugne and exagitate in these their bookes) These benefits we say, are so notorious, as no man with any modesty can cal them in question.

But what these other so great damages were or may be, which these men affirme the fathers to haue brought to the foresaid two Seminaryes Doway and Rome that were hard (I thinke) to ghesse, seing that of Doway receyued singular help by them at the very first erection, and namely that they procured the first hundred crownes of monethly pension to it from Pope Gregory
the 13. as the world knoweth, and Card. Allen did alwayes confesse while he was alyue, and it is testified by a particuler letter yet extant of M. Licentiate Martyn to F. Campian then in Prage in the yeare 1577 which lettre we haue seene vnder his owne hand.M. Licent. Martyn. his letter 1577 And further that F. Persons alone procured two thousand crownes a yeare pension more for the said Colledg of the K. of Spaine in the yeare 1583. & hath euer since by his owne labour principally procured the payment,Colledg of Dovvay. besides diuers other extraordinary helpes otherwise, this I say the Colledge bookes of accÅpt wil testifie, and we could wish that any of our contradicting brethren, or all ioyned togeather had, or could help the Colledge of Doway so much as this one father hath done, besids many other good offices of his brethren.

And as for the RomÄ Colledge, if peace quietnes and contentment of the students togeather,Roman Colledg. with exceeding increase both of learning, vertue, and deuotion, and remoual of all dissention and vnquietnes since his arriual there, may be counted a benefit, he hath procured the same with most happy successe as al Rome seeth, and reioyseth. And as for temporal comodityes and benefits, how farre that Colledge hath
byn increased therin, vnder the Fathers gouernment by his Hol. liberality, from the pouerty and disorder it was in, when they tooke it first in hand no man can be ignorant that knoweth the State of both tymes; for then they had neyther Abbey nor Priory, nor vineyard, nor garden, nor fayre house at home, all which now they possesse; and wherein then doth consist that which these mÄ here do exprobate, to wit:Pag. 83. damna illata illis antiqutoribus seminarijs, Duaceno scilicet & Romano? hurts inflicted by Iesuits vpon the two more ancient Seminaryes of Doway and Rome? They say that the RomÄ Colledge was wont to nourish 70. schollers, and that now it is brought to almost 40. but if it were so (as it is not altogether true, for that cÅmonly the number of schollers are nearer to 50. then 40. and the number of the whole house doth allwayes exceede 70. persons what accusation were this against Iesuits, seeing the reuenewes wil maintayne no more,MayntenÄce of the Roman Colledge decreased. and those three hundred crownes of gold euery moneth which Gregory the 13. did giue extraordinarily out of his owne treasure for mayntenance of that bigger number, haue not byn continued since his death by his Successors? This then is a very vayne calumniation.

About Doway they obiect a new Statute of Card. Farnesius the Protector, wherby is ordayned that no more shalbe maintayned in that Colledge for a tyme (by the expÄces of the Colledge) vntil their debts be payd, then 60. persons, and those to be admitted by examination of the President and his Assistants there; and by commendations of the Archpriest, and Superior of the Iesuites and other principal men in England, and this decree made the Card. Protector, vpon the relation and petition of the President himselfe, and two graue men appointed Visitours, M. Doctor Hall, Canon of S. Omers and M. Licentiate VVright deane of Cortricke for that they affirmed no other meanes to be left for paying their debts but by diminishing their number for a tyme, and the same hath the President himselfe demaunded since by his presence in Rome;Meere calumniation against the Iesuits. shewing many reasons for the necessity therof, to vvit, that aswel a competÄt number only be admitted til their debts be payd, & that such as be admitted be of good choise, both for their age, learning health, ability, commendation out of England, and other such circumstances. And what is there in all these points worthy eyther of reprehension or murmuration against Superiors? Or vvhat do they appertayne to the Iesuits especially
in so highe a degree of hurtes as that all their other benefits and good turnes done vnto vs should be ouerwhelmed with the imputation of these imagined damages belonging nothing vnto them? do not our brethren shew a wonderful desire of cauilling against them vvhen they bring in these thinges so weake and impertinent? There are scarse two moneths past (as we are enformed) since this Seminary of Doway receaued 2000. crownes in Antwerp from Spayne procured and sent by F. Creswel, and two thousand more they expect daylie by the same meanes and sollicitation. And what ingratitude then is it to accuse Iesuits for hurting this colledge, which dayly they do so greatly benefit.

But these good fathers eares are now accustomed to these vngrateful songes, and wil not be discouraged (we hope) therwith to perseuer and do vs good stil, seing they know now not only by Gods promises but by former practise also and experience that these blasts do blow ouer and come to nothing but to the exercise & trial of his seruants, and discredit of the doers. VVhat tempests and stormes these good fathers haue suffered with patience at the hands of diuers of our Nation these later yeares without all cause in the world, but only
vpon emulation and stomake, and other such motiues, is not vnknowne and we are ashamed to recount.

For to let passe more ancient tymes and that conspiracy made against them in Paris in the yeare 1586. and 87. by some that had bin their owne schollers,Bad vsage of the Fathers by EnglishmÄ and others otherwayes obliged to them (as before hath byn touched) at what tyme there was a combination made by some of our order (an vnworty thing to remember) with our open enemie Sir. Francis VValsingam in their preiudice and bookes wrytten in their disgrace,In the confession of G. G. in Paris 1587. & 88. as yow haue hard, and are yet to be seene. Aftet these we may consider the most odious memorials, libels, exclamations and other exaggerations vsed against them & their whole order by the tumultuous in the RomÄ stirres and troubles which began 1585. and endured for 2 or three yeares, and are yet remayning in record to our no smal greife & shame,In the visitat. of Cardinal Sega. cap. 3. 4. 5. 6. 7. & deinceps. and so much the more for that no one point amongst so many obiected could euer yet be proued against the said fathers by the accusers, as appeareth by the sentence of the Visitour & iudge appointed; giuen after due consideration & examination of all.

And this tempest being past ouer with
another of the same kinde in Flandres, wherof are extant most passionate memorials and iniurious lettres wrytten and exhibited to diuers princes: The treatise intituled Acta & scripta calumniosa D. G. Giff. D. H. Grif. & C. Pag. alie. rumque contra Presb. societ. anno 1598. and amonge other to his Hol. himself for defacing the said Fathers and their whole order by some English there who had in like maner both fauored and fostered the Romane tumults (of which memorials and lettres we haue seene a latyn treatise or collection of a aboue a dozen sheets of paper, which we reserue to our larger Apology) there were diuers others, set on to spread about England at the same tyme or soone after many infamous and opprobrious reports against the same religious men, partly as passed in Rome and Flandres and partly other where; but all tending to their infamy and discredit, wherof noe one of moment was eyther true or probable. VVhich practise when we priests vnderstood by the general lettres of the Superior of the said order in England bearing date the first of March 1599. we all or the most part of vs within the Realme (as also many without) thinking our selues boÅ«d in cÅsciÄce wrote to Rome most effectually against these shameful practises and our lettres are yet extant,The Conf. of fisher 8. Mar. 1589. which we did the sooner for that we vnderstood by some of them that were
the publishers of these sclaunders that they were set on of purpose to disgrace the said Fathers.

And at the very same tyme some of our nation beyond the Sea being weary of their banishment and styrred vp (as it semeth) with the spirit of dissention and auersion against these men,Diuers lettres vvryten this yeare into Engl. about this matter are yet extant and ready to be shevved vvhen need requireth. sought to make their peace with the Q. and Councel by offering seruice against them, wherof we haue seene sundry lettres wrytten in the yeare 1598. and in one of them no lesse then 15. articles suggested against Iesuits and how the Q. and councel might get them out of England by help of the King of France; to his Hol. which we might set downe in particular togeather with the letters and wryters therof, if we would follow the course of our discontented brethren and their consorts in this faction, but we meane to proceed more temperatly and spare their names for this tyme except we be forced in our longer Apologie to expound our selues further; only we say in this place, that it is an vnworthy and lamentable act for Catholike men to make their peace with the common enemy by offering to wound good men of their owne syde, & religion, for gayning the others fauour.

And by this in part we may vnderstand
what these good Fathers haue suffered at our hands in repayment of so many good turnes and courtesyes towards vs, which God (no doubt) wil repay more aboundantly,The effects of Iesuits labours tovvards English. by how much lesse they are rewarded by vs. Surely if we looke at this day not only into the general body of our English Catholike cause (for which they haue done for vs, as before hath byn said, by Seminaries, institution of our youth and other like meanes) but into the particular members and parts of this body also; ther number, condition and quality, as for example men and women conuerted within these 20. yeares synce Iesuits came into England, eyther from heresy to Catholike religion or from schisme and liberty to more perfection of life, if we looke into the English monasteries of both sexes, erected continued or encreased in this tyme of our banishment abroad; if vve consider or wil enquire of the particular persons therin liuing as also in the Seminaryes and els vvhere, hovv they vvere conuerted, & by vvhome, vvho first taught and instructed them, vvho sent them ouer, vvho assisted thÄ most and other like circumstÄces, and then consider vvithal the smal number of fathers that haue liued and do lyue in England in respect of the other vvorkemen
(vvhich labour vvel and zealously also) vve shal easily see by the effects and vvorkes themselues, vvhether they haue byn idle or vnprofitably imployed; and much more vvhether they haue sought themselues; their ovvne good, and not that of others; and of their maister Iesus as heere their emulators do fondly calumniate. And this shalbe sufficient, for all godly and pious myndes to ponder in this behalfe, and therby to iudge with vvhat spirit our discontented brethren do proceed in the contrary course. And so much for this.

div.head: HOVV GREATLY our late Cardinal Allen, D. Stapleton, D. Barret, & other principal men of our Nation now dead are iniured by these our discontented brethren, in that they are made to haue byn of their faction against Iesuites. And the same iniury is offered to diuers other great men also of forraine Nations, as to Cardinal Boromeus, Cardinal Tolet, and to his Holynes himselfe. CAP. IIII.
div.p:
IT is commonly and truly said, that all sorts seeke company to approue and authorize their actions, good or bad, but especially the bad, whose doings and sayings not being approueable by reason do need more authority to beare them out.All sorts desire partners. VVe read of S. Cyprian, that hauing, vpon to much zeale, fallen into certayne controuersies with the best men of his tyme about rebaptization of heretikes and some other points therÅ depending (whervnto though he fel principally for hatred and detestation of heresy as is wel knowne) yet sundry sectaries vpon this occasion, said after his death, that he was of their side while
he lyued,Aug. lib. 1. cont. Don. cap. 17. & cont. Iul. Pelag. lib. 1. cap. 1. 2. 4. & lib. 2. c. 1. which diuers auncient fathers & especially S. Augustine is forced to confute most earnestly in sundry parts of his workes. And not vnlike falleth it out in this our case, for that the late good Cardinal hauing enclyned as some men report in his later dayes, to contract a certayne affinity with a gentleman, carried away somwhat with this faction; though the Cardinals intention (no doubt) was (if the matter be true) to gaine him and his frends from that faction, yet by this shew and pretence,M. Thomas Throg. the contentious party in this our cause, wil needs persuade men, that the Cardinal was of their side, & would if he had lyued haue declared himselfe against the Iesuites & all those that stood with them, and so do say & signify our discontented brethren in these their bookes, vvhich is as much to say, as the Cardinal would haue byn contrary to himselfe (for against him principally vvas the faction, as hath byn shewed, and vvil appeare in this place by his owne testimony) and that he would haue broken withal his old frends and with the whole body Catholike in this English cause,Sup. cap. 1. & would haue chaunged his vvhole course of lyfe held to that day, and would haue ioyned vvith a dozen vnquiet, factious people perturbing the rest, then which thing, nothing
can be imagined more absurd or dishonorable to his memory.

And first of all I would aske our brethren that do publishe this to the world, so greatly to his discredit, vvherby such Princes also as were his aduauncers and benefactors may take suspition of his former actions, and thinke worse of him now, when he is dead, then they did while he was alyue, what reasons or firme argumÄts can they shewe, for this their Asseueration? Haue they any letters of his owne testifying this intentiÅ, or can they alleadge any one fact of his, vvherof this may be inferred? VVe haue cyted before his earnest letters to the contrary wrytten not six moneths before he died to M. Mush (who seemeth the cheifest brocher of all these suspitious reports) as though the Cardinal had vttered great secrets vnto him at his being in Rome, vvhich is very vnlikely, the Cardinal knowing his busy nature & condition to set strife,The author of these false reports against the Cardinal. as may appeare also by the earnestnes of his said letter vnto him. Moreouer, we know that the Cardinal at this tyme, when the vnquiet by occasion of M. Throg. hoped mariage vvith his neece presumed to haue most part in him, stood most entyrely vnited vvith the Fathers & all their frends, as may be shewed by great
multitudes of letters of his owne hand wrytten to F. Persons and S. Francis Inglefield in Spayne geueing accÅpt of this motion of marriage proposed by the other side, and asking their opinions therin, and many orher letters of like argument to F. Holt, Sir VVilliÄ Stanley, M. Hugh Owen, M. Thomas Fitzherbert & others in Flaunders, wherby his entyre confidence vvith them is testified to his dying day. And surely, he that shal consider how and by whome, and by how many wayes the said Cardinal in all his affaires, both publike & priuate, had byn holpen, preferred and assisted most zealously and confidently by the Fathers and their frends in all his lyfe, cannot imagine how any such chaunge should fal vpon him, as these men against all reason and probability do deuise.

But on the contrary side, if any man wil know how hartely he did hate and detest this faction (though he much desired the conuersion of the authors,Card. AllÄs iudgment and censure of this faction. as all good men do) and that he perfectly vnderstood, that it banded principally against himselfe, and for his sake against the Fathers or rather against God himselfe and the publike good of our Catholike English cause, there be so many testimonies extant of his owne hand and other mens ioyned with him to this
effect,See a long letter of Sir F. Inglefeld to M. Th. Throg. an. 1596. of 8. sheets of paper to this purpose. as this place cannot receyue them, & therfore leauing the longer recital vnto our other Apology, we shal here only touch some few.

And to beginne from some yeares past, vve haue seene the latyn original before mentioned of the said Cardinal gathered out of diuers letters of G. G. by his owne hand; of the Parisian conspiracy against him and the Iesuits, vvherof one clause is this:Ex Ires. G. G. 10. & 11. April 1588. M. Morgan (saith G. G. did vrge me day & night to returne into England againe, but I would neuer yeld thervnto vntil Grateley persuaded me thervnto; and the same Morgan was the counselour, that we wrote the booke against the Fathers of the Society, to the end I might haue more iust occasion to returne to VValsingham, and for so much as appertayneth to Morgan, he would haue byn wel content, we should haue wrytten not only against the Iesuits, but against the Pope himselfe.

Thus much is vnder the Cardinals hand, and then in the same letters and confessions of G. G. in the other booke is confessed to haue byn wrytten against the printed letter of the said Cardinal to Sir VVilliam StÄley about restoring Dauentry to the King of Spayne,The booke vvryten & exhibited to Sir. F. VValsingham by the faction against the Cardinal. vvhich beginneth: VVe haue tried by experience, &c. And finally the Cardinal fully perceaued by these letters and examinations of G. G. and E. G. and others, that
this faction was by name only against the Iesuits, but the principal intention against himselfe and all others, that ioyned vvith him in the publike aduancement of our comon cause. For more proofe wherof the next yere after, he saw a large plot laid and discouered by a certayne letter of the aforsaid M. Morgan vvrytten vnto a Carthusian monke of the Scotish nation that had byn Bishop of DÅ«blayne, and residing for the present in the Duke of Sauoyes court, in vvhich letter was laid downe at length, & vvith many particularityes, how the faction raysed against the late made Cardinal of England should proceed in their affaires by their agents in all Courts, as wel at Rome & Spayne, as in France also, Flaunders, Sauoy and other places, and vvhat men of their side vvere fit, eyther English Scotish or other nations (for they meant to draw in all by these meanes) to be actors in euery of the said Courts: In this letter amongst other things, he vvryteth thus: The course of proceeding holden by the Cardinal of England, and his, is so violent, Th. MorgÄ to the B. of dumblayne 20. August 1598. and their expestation so great, as all England and Scotland must obay and serue them, &c. Yt is more then tyme that my L. of Cassano or some other be aduaunced, for the comÅ good, and to counterpeise the Cardinal of England and his, to help to conserue vnity and conformity
in the handling of things. Consider this meanes of vnity. The Card. counted malitious by the faction. And againe. The enuy to my L. of Cassano, his merits and good gifts in him is maruelous great and the ground of all the malice, that the Cardinal of England and his do beare vnto me.

And then againe making mention of diuers of his faction (vvherof he seemed to accompt the L. Paget and his brother for the principal) he speaketh also of the fornamed gentleman M. Tho. ThrogmortonM. Thomas Throgm. thus. There is a gentleman of honour heere of England a frend of ours very wel qualified, and is worthy to serue any king or prince that liueth, and I thinke him wel worthy, hauing all languages and qualityes as I haue said to be in the seruice of the Duke of Sauoy, if your Lordship can bestovv him vvel vvith the Duke he should haue honour and seruice therby, and the gentleman would be profitable in that place to his frends.

And thus much about the agent in Sauoy vvhere they thought to do much (that Duke being sonne in law to the King, and put in head by them to pretend the gouerment of Flaunders insteed of the Duke of Parma, as the most part of this letter doth treate, & many ielousyes are cast in, to set suspition betweene those Princes, and with the King of Spayne, but all against Parma) but for Spayne they designed a Scottish man Bishop of Vessun in Fraunce, nephew
to the forsaid Dumblayne to be agent for English affaires, for that he was of their faction; to whose help and assistance notwithstanding (for that F. Persons was gone thither the yeare before, and thought to be in good credit with the king) they had sent already one F. Arnold prior of the English Carthusian Monks in Flanders,Prior Arnold sent vnder hand into Spaine against the Card. yet would not Morg. cÅfesse here so much to Dumblayne, least he should thinke his nephewes iorney thither to be but a shewe: VVe must suspend (saith he) our iudgment of the Priors silence all this while, trusting, that he wil giue vs satisfaction at the last. I wrote vnto your Lordship, it was wrytten vnto me that the said Prior was gone to my Lord of Cassano I haue borne and do bea e not a little for his sake, whome the Cardinal of England, and all his, do so much mislike and there is great diligence taken to conserue him and his bretheren (the monkes) at difference, which is a maruelous vngodly maner of proceeding, &c.

Thus wrote this man at that tyme, devising and setting downe agents also for all other Courts to oppose themselues against the Card. as my Lord of Cassano his nephew and others ioyned with him or depÄding that way in Rome, the lo. Pag. and his brother whith their adherÄts at Brussels, and as for the court of France he offered to
lyue there himselfe. I haue (sayth he) vnder your L. correction assigned vnto my selfe my place (in Paris) which I desire to haue with allowance and good liking of your L. and continuation of my pension of 40. crownes a moneth which shal walke necessarily. M. MorgÄs pension vvalketh. The Duke of Sauoy and your Lordship are able to bring this to passe, and the King of Spaine at the Dukes meditation, and your L. labours wil confirme the matter, &c.

And thus much of the designment, but of the execution, the Card. saw another letter wrytten the next moneth after by the forsaid Agent in Spayne,The letter of Prior Arnold 13. Sept. 1589. Prior Arnold, vnto this same M. Morg. which letter begyneth thus: There is wrong done both to yow and me (good M. Morg.) if yow receaued no letters from me since my conflict at Granoble, for as soone as that conflict was done I wrote thence both to my brethren and yow and committed the carriage to those my Brethren I am sure to the foole that followed me vp to Granoble,This vvas a reuerend Priest sent by the monkes to complayne of him to their General and Chapter at Granoble, and is novv of this order. and I thinke also of those to yow, which it seemeth he hath wreaked his anger vpon in the way, for the sore cut I gaue his combe in that combat at Granoble, or if I comitted them not to him, as perhaps I did not (clearly knowing him to be a suborned Traytour) I surely left them with the B. of Dumblayne to be sent to yow.

By these words a mÄ may knowe a little the spirit of this Agent against rhe Card.
and Iesuites, but let vs heare him yet further In these letters to yow (saith he) I partly spoke of the maner of my skyrmish; but cheefly required yow to follow me with all speed possible vnto the King of Spayne, with whome I am now, passing first by the B. of Dumblaine who should haue procured yow the letters of the Duke of Sauoy and his bedfellow hither, The commission of Priot Arn. in Spayne against the Card. importing profit both to yow and your frende and cheefly to our common frend the B. of Cassano, whose preference to the same liuery which Card. Allen weareth is the principal cause that made me take this iorney, &c. And then further. I am enforced to differre vntil our meeting the declaration of that I haue done here with the King, because I cannot do it without great daunger by pen and paper, One of thÄ grateth on the other for before M. M. said he suffered for the Priors sake. the wayes euery where are so ful of iniquity. My familiarity with yow much encreaseth the fury of my enemyes against me and in deed is the cheefe cause why the greatest of them all wrote to ouerthrow me at Granoble, but I haue now tould the king of Spaine such tales of them, Card. AllÄ. as I am sure they haue gayned nothing by coping with me, though they entred the field, with as high a stomake as Goliah did against litle Dauid, &c.

By all this and much more that might be said (for we omit of purpose many other letters, or rather reserue them for our other Apology) it may be seene that all this complot for many yeres was against the Cardinal
principally, and against the Iesuits and their frends as accessary only so far forth as they vvere ioyned with him, and that is ment when they say, The Cardinal and his, meaning by his, the Iesuits, for so M. Morg. in the former letter hauing vsed those words against the Cardinal, and his, he addeth presently: F. Holt playeth filthy playes in Flaunders, and deuideth the English into factions. And M. Ch. Pag. in a letter yet extant vnder his owne hand, in the yere following to wit 1590. when M. Morg. was now in prison, wryteth thus: Touching the causes of our dissention here (in Flaunders) I differ from your opinion, M. Ch. Pag. letter to F. C. 8. Aug. 1590. I thinke malice and pride to be the causes which maketh inferiour persons forget to acknowledg their duty to their Superiors, by thinking themselues equal when as they faile both in degree, credit experience, & euery other thinge, & therin will I not excuse F. Holt, who surely hath behaued himselfe very partially, &c. It had byn a good turne both for my Lord Cardinal, & vs of the better sort heere that he had neuer come hither, &c. I haue already said inough to his Prouincial, if that wil not serue, I suppose there wilbe further complaint of him, Many other reports as true as this haue byn diuulged by thÄ that deuised thÄ perhaps not so much to him & his freindes contentment, &c. By this trouble of M. Morg. I can assure yow that both of the best in England & here be cold in affection towards your Society, the report being made in England by many Catholikes, that
M. Morg. was hanged by the persecution of Iesuits, &c.

Lo heere all faults layd on the Iesuits by them that accompted the Cardinal their cheefe enimy, as before hath byn shewed. But now how the B. of Cassano himselfe tooke this matter, whome they had made their head and for more strengthening of him against the English Protectour, they adioyned Card. Mon de Vi, (procuring him to be protector of Scotland, for that they imagined him not greatly to fauour Spayne) this poynt, I say, is not so euident, albeit the Card. in diuers letters (wherof after we shal make mention) doth alwayes seeme to excuse him,Hovv the B. of Cassa. behaued himself in t â¢ is matter. and so did F. Persons in like maner as may appeare by diuers of his, persuading themselues that these attempts vvere but deuises, of particular factious mÄ to set the Cardinal & Bishop out, without his consent, yet are there certayne speches extant in some of his letters to the former prior Arnold, vvhich make the matter very doubtful, and that he yeilded ouermuch to this their humour, if not set them on, or fed them therin. As for example in one of the 11. of December 1587. which vvas not many monethes after the Card. was made, he vvryteth thus: Haue pitty vpon my Lord of Dumblaine who I doubt is the more persecuted for
my sake, yow know by whose meanes. Our Cardinal of himselfe tould me, that notwithstanding the chyding of my nephewe, which yow know, yet his Grace and I shal euer be true frends, &c. Here that he meaneth the Cardinal by vvhose meanes Dumblayne is said to be persecuted though without all cause (for that Dumblayne did rather persecute the Card, as by many his actions and lettres doth appeare) is most manifest, for that no other can be imagined to be meant therby.

And a litle after in the said lettre he desiring to be commended by the Prior to Don Iohn Idiaquez the king of Spaynes Secretary (as he calleth him) by the said Prior to some higher prefermÄt he wryteth thus: If yow wryte to Sr. Iohn Idiaquez excuse me that I wryte neuer to his honour for modesties sake, least I should seeme importunate for my selfe, but when he doth me a good turne he shal haue letters from me and others inough to thanke him, and shal haue honour and ioy by me. The Bish. of Cassan. his complaint. And truly I remÄber him daylie at masse; if he knew the meanes that are wrought to persecute me and blynd the world, he would loue me aboue all my nation, to the which truly I haue done more seruice then all others of them, be it spoken to the glory of God.

This the good man wrote complayning of his persecutions as yow see and preferring his owne merit before all others of
the nation, by which his discontentment and emulation is more discouered, then were to be wished, which seemeth to haue growne afterward rather then to haue byn diminished, for that the next moneth and yeare after, to wit the 2. of Ianuary 1588. he wryteth thus amongst other things to the same man, hauing relation to his former letter to deale with Don Iohn de Idiaquez: what yow wryte to Spayne to the good Secretary, and my L. Duches of me, I know it shalbe louing and modest and if there were therin a few lynes pithie, and short and effectual separately wryten as your owne attestation to be shewed to the king it were vvel that the Secretary if he listed might read it to the king, Truly this ambition of the monopolie of all busynes of our nation is a very daungerous thing, and I knovv they cannot do yt, and are not so fit as they thinke, to do all alone. This said the good man. And by this we may see how daungerous a matter emulation is, and how by litle and litle it taketh roote & increaseth, If the good Bishop had neuer said nor wryten more then this in approuing these mÄnes dealing against the Card. from him, it had byn sufficient, not only to foster but to inflame their humours to go forward they being so vnquiet and restles spirits as may appeare, and desirous
to swymme against the streame and hold a faction against the good Cardinal.

VVherfore to go forward in declaration of our Cardinals knowing and discerning this faction to be against himselfe; and the common cause, there be extant two long letters of his vnder his owne hand to the forsaid gÄtlemÄ M. Th. Throgmort. wryttÄ the next yeare after to wit 1591. for his instructiÅ & reuocatiÅ, if it would haue byn, from the said partiality; In which letters amÅg many large discourses, he saith thus: It is wel inough knowne,Card. AllÄs letters of the 4. Ian. and 30. of Feb. to M. Th. Throg. an. 1591. that the things, vvhich haue byn done by that faction were neuer done against me for any particular or personal respect of myne owne, my selfe neyther before my promotion nor after, neuer geuing them any occasion in the vvorld of offence; But were rather done to the offence and special hurt of the commÅ cause, as to giue yow example, to draw from me my schollers vvhen I was in lesse degree then now I am, and to imploy them in publike seruices, yea such whome I knew to be discontented and disloyal to me, then their Master, as G. G. and diuers other priests, whome the world hath now discouered, all which were set a vvorke to their owne destruction, and ruine of the cause, &c. And when it pleased God of his
prouidence to induce the Pope and King to put me in this place, for Morg. and his faction to be so bold to addresse a special messenger the poore vnfortunate Prior of the Carthusians vnder pretence of other busynes of his order and house to deale openly with his Maiestie against me, and vnder pretence of my eyther insufficiency, or il dealinge in the comÅ affayres, to make supplication that another might be exalted to the like dignity and opposed against me and my doings and followers, was not this a matter of comly quality,Treason against the common cause. or can yt otherwayes be accounted then a plaine treason against the common cause.

p.q:
That againe some like discontented persons after the death of the said prior, and MorgÄs imprisonment haue sought to persuade some about his Maiestie that this pretended or fayned diuision of our banished countreymen rose vpon the difference of English and vvelsh Prouinces, & that the remedy therof vvas to haue a Cardinal also of that part to ballance the matter as though it was alwayes necessary in EnglÄd that theere shold be one English Cardinal,Good councel of the Card. to M. Tho. Throg. and another vvelsh Cardinal or els none at all, &c. And in the end he concludeth vvith him thus: It shalbe euer good for yow (M. Throg) to follow in this kind
the mayne streame, and the principal Catholikes of your nation with so many of the best and greatest without comparison of the nobility, Cleargy, and religious, and not to cast your selfe into the creekes of a few, and very few discontented persons, who are not yet so many nor of such credit, eyther at home, or with such Princes abroad as to counteruayle the number of those that mislike the dealings of these left handed men, Left handed men. neyther yet inough to giue the name vnto a faction of a whole nation, as though the English vvere indifferently deuided among themselues, about these matters, vvhich is altogeather vntrue, and in a manner also impossible, though some of folly or fraud may geue it out & others of simplicity beleeue it.

div.p:
Thus wrote the Cardinal to this gentleman, and at the same tyme he wrote also seuerally to M. Ch. Pag. a large letter, defending first F. Holt in very earnest & honorable tearmes as he wel deserued,Card. AllÄs letter to Char. P. 4. Ian. 1591. and then telling his opiniÅ and feeling of this factiÅ against himselfe, auerreth it to be against not only himselfe, but the publike good of our comon cause. VVhere of (saith he) yow must needs giue me leaue to be the leader because so it hath pleased God, his Hol. and his Maiestie to accompt me; and not
for my owne priuate, but for the aduauncement of that seruice haue put me in this roome. VVherby it followeth that all those that seditiously conspire my disgrace, do bÄd themselues directly and traiterously against the good of their countrey and against the seruice of the highest Princes in christendome,Directly & trayterously against the good of our Countrey. by vvhome only we expect succour and releefe for our so vnfortunate state, and vvhen I name preists and religious yow must not straight wayes inferre (as yow seeme to do in your letter) that the priests band themselues against the nobility, as though all the nobility in banishment, or at home; were of Morg faction, or that preists vvere not diuers of them, of as good nobility as most of those few that be addicted to Morgan.

p.q: And as for seruants and followers in England which yow say he shal fynd more by following another course rathet then this I do, God send vs come to the trial, and happily arriue there, and then shal you see by the effect, what lacke of frends I shal there haue, vvhere I thinke verily to haue yow my frend also, vvhich shalbe best for yow, and very grateful vnto me, howsoeuer vnaduisedly yow haue here entangled your selfe in my aduersaryes broken matters.

div.p:
VVe do pretermit of purpose many other letters vvhich might be cyted, for that they would be ouerlong, as namely one vnder the Cardinals owne hand wrytten to the Gouernour of Flaunders 30. of Feb. 1592. about this faction by occasion of imprisonment of Th. Morgan for other matters, wherin he doth shew the ruyne of the Q of Scots and of those 14. Gentlemen put to death togeather for her cause,The ruine of the Q. of Scots & many gÄt. by this faction. and diuers others ouerthrowne, to haue proceeded of this faction though not purposely meant by them. I omit also another large letter by M. Ch. Paget to M. Mush then in Rome about the said Card.M. C. Pag. to M. Mush about the Card. in Feb. 1594. which beginneth thus: Good M. M. I receaued yours of the 14. of Ianuarij after the ordinary that weeke was departed hence and before the next was ready to go: Your other of the 22. came to my hands, to both which I wil make answere at once and the more breeflly, because I perceaue we shal haue yow heere shortly, &c. Your former long letter of the 14, conteyned 3. poynts principally of moment, the first is a comendation of the rare parts & vertues of my L. Cardinal the second is a frendly chiding & taxing me for not breaking to his grace the motion of the peace; and the 3. an effectual exhortation to concur with his Grace in any thing that may concerne the state of our countrey. Of all which to say somwhat in order and breefly, I say,
the first is superfluous, the second euil grounded, and the 3. as impertinent to be vsed vnto me.

Thus began M. Pag. answere and in prosecuting the same vvhich is more then two sheets of paper it may easily be seene, how matters vvent betweene the Cardinal him, and others, and vvhere the faction lay, as also we haue seene before by the Cardinals owne woords, and so much the more are these preists our brethren to be wondred, at and pitied that are fallen now vpon emulation into the reliques of this faction set vp and maintayned against priests & the Card. their head & of this man M. Mush in particular it is more to be wÅdred whose letters are extant in most vehemÄt sort against the same,M. Mush. sharp letter against the B of Cassa. the 4. Mar. 1594. and against the very cheefe therof by name. But this falleth out when men suffer themselues to be led away vvith passion.

But now to returne againe to our good Cardinal vvho seing himselfe beset & battered on euery side by the said faction complayned much therof, and namely to the Fathers of the Society who were his cheefest refuge for particular comfort in these tribulations and contradictions; but aboue all others the man whome our brethren seeke to disgrace now and vvould make vs beleeue that the Cardinal and he disagreed,
vvas he vvith vvhome he dealt in most cÅfident maner by vvryting about men and matters of this faction, vvherof vve could alleadge many letters, but a peece of one only shal serue for the vpshot of this busynes.Card. AllÄs letter to F. P. 7. Ian. 1592. Thus he wryteth vvith his owne hÄd. My good Father God is angry vvith vs, as yow may perceaue, and we do feele by the open taking from vs our head and Pastor, for now is Innocentius also (in vvhome for his great prudence learning and vertue, vve had great hope) takÄ vnto God, after he had byn in the seat only 2. monethes, &c. And now vve are to enter the 10. of Ian. into the Conclaue againe, God send grace & mercy and auert his vvrath from vs, &c. And this for that. Now for our English matters I wrote to yow I thinke by one of myne vpon the 26. of October last past, how N. N. had written hither from Flanders to some of the Inquisition,This is a cheefe piller of the faction. that the Counsel of England offered him a pasport and safe conduct to passe and repasse especially with C. and H. who wil he saith become Catholikes, by vvhich yow may see what kind of practises these good fellowes (of the faction) haue in hand, and with vvhome they deale. Moreouer I had warning 2. or 3. moneths agoe, and vvrote to yow of the same, how the two companions
N. N. N. N. were vvith the treasurer, and were suspected to haue discouered all they knew, and perhaps added somwhat of their owne more then they knew, since vvhich the former of them hath byn heere, as yow ere this knowe. But now we are further aduertised that they haue betrayed all indeed, &c. by vvhose aduertisments, & I know not by what other meanes or surmises, they haue lately set forth a proclamation of an entÄded inuasion by the King of Spayne, wherin particularly they ser downe his practises, and how he procured me for my treasons to be made Cardinal, & other things to bring vs and all priests into hatred of the people, and I thinke yow be named in the said proclamation, and the vvay how the preists are sent out of Spayne to prepare (as they say) the vvay to the said inuasion, and so followeth in the said proclamation most strayte order and prouision for preuention of the said fayned inuasions vvith very cruel prouision against priests and Catholikes:A most cruel proclamation against priests and Catholikes 1592. the poore wretches are more afrayd then vve know cause, sed Deum non inuocauerunt ideÃ² trepidauerunt, &c. And D. DeeD. Dee. their coniurer or Astrologer is said to haue put them in more doubt, for that he hath told the Counsel by his calculation, that the Realme indeed shalbe conquered
this Somer, beleeue him who vvil.

p.q: If it should come to his Maiestie or other Supe â¢ iors eares, that those priests should betray the Catholike cause, or be occasion of this proclamation, it would be very scÄdalous, especially there in Spayne. I trust we shal haue a copy of the Proclamation shortly; I doubt me your way of enter course betwene England and Spaine and contrary wise, is now by the said companions discouered.ConfidÄce betvvixt the Card. and F. P. Gods wil be fulfilled and saue vs Ã falsis fratribus. I hope yow be before this perfectly recouered, haue a good hart in God, for by him we shal ouercome all. Thus much for a farewel before I enter the Conclaue, adew my deare Father my comfort in these tribulations & temptations this 7. of Ian. 1592.

div.p:
And this is â¢ ufficient for this place, I thinke, to repel the calumniation about our good Cardinal, and to shew that he neyther was nor co â¢ ld be presumed to fauour this faction against the Iesuits, which was principally against himselfe while he liued. And much lesse that he should mislike or breake with F. Persons, whome all the world knoweth to haue byn as confident and zealous for him in all his affayres, as one mÄ possibly could be for another, &
most of the Cardinals preferments to haue comen by his special sute and labour.

The like also touching the Society, and coniunction therwith, and auersion from the forsaid faction may be shewed of D. Stapleton, who by diuers letters of his owne hand, yet forth coming vtterly disauowed the same, as for example in one in English of the 6. of Iuly 1597. to F. P. in these woords:About D. Stapleton. I am very glad that the troubles and dissentions of the Colledg of our Nation there, are now ended and appeased, no doubt, by your prudent, and laborious endeauour. The opinion that I euer fauored these factions, or should fauour them if I came thither, may euidently be conuinced by two letters by me wrytten, one to Cardinal Caietan Protector a â¢ eare since and more, another to his Holines the last wynter subscribed by diuers others, not only I neuer lyked, but haue alwa â¢ es vtterly misliked, & condemned such vnquiet heades against their Superiors, and namely against the Society, to whome all our countrey Catholike youthes are so highly beholden, &c.

Thus wrote he to F. P. & in another latin letter the yeare following wryttÄ to the Card. Protector of the first of May 1598. he vttereth his iudgmÄt of this factiÅ against the Iesuits thus:D. StapltÅs iudgment of the trouble & troublesome. Quae quidÄ ego quorundÄ gentis nostrae vtcunque Cathol. malÃ¨ sana cerebra aemulationis
& inuidiae stimulis turpiter agitata, Ã sancta charitate (qua in augmentum corporis aedificare debuerant) heul nimis vacua, si non vnicam certÃ¨ primariam causam esse arbitror. I do thinke the only or principal cause of these our styrres to be the mad heades of certaine of our NatiÅ, that being in some sort Cathol. are fÅdly carried away with incitations of emulation and enuy, and are toto voyd of holy charity, wherby they ought to build, to the increase of the whole body. This was his censure which we could much wish were attentiuely considered by those of our discontented brethren, that haue the remorse of a good conscience left in them. And so much of D. Stapleton.

About D. Barret.As for D. Barret no man can make doubt and his last serious speech with so many teares vpÅ his death-bed exhorting all present to fly this foule faction against the Fathers (wherof many priests now in England are witnesses) is a sufficient testimony of his detesting the same, & yet we shal haue occasion afterwards to alleage diuers of his letters vpon sundry occasions about the same matters, as also of many other the grauest men of our nation, among whome no one can be alleaged to be of this faction, and such few others of meaner sort, that
are thought to enclyne that way do carry their knowne notes of discredit with thÄ if they be examined.

And as for that which our discontented brethren do cyte in diuers places of their bookes of Card. Boromeo of holy memory,A great calumniatiÅ about Car. Boromeo. that he tooke the gouerment of one of his Seminaryes in Millan from the Fathers we haue informed our selues of the truth, that the Fathers of their owne wil & vpÅ their owne earnest sute left the said gouernment for the great labour and trouble therof, as also some litle difference in opinion about the schollers education, which the good Cardinal would haue had somwhat more bare in their diet, and apparel then the Fathers order in their Seminaryes did permit, for which the holy Cardinal alleaged no euil reason, saying that seing they weare his Oblati (for so they were called) & were to be sent afterwards abroad to poore benefices amonge countrey people, where they must fare hardly, they would refuse to goe, being brought vp after the diet of other Seminaryes. But the Fathers thought it easyer for them to leaue this gouernmÄt, then admit this difference, and so they left it. And the good Cardinal did vse all the meanes possibly he could both there, and
in Rome, to stay it in their hands, as appeareth by many letters yet extant of that matter, and many men also aliue, that are witnesses of it, and the said Fathers haue had so great sute made vnto thÄ since that tyme, to take vpon them the gouernment of the Switsers Seminary vnder the same Ca â¢ dinal and his nephew now Card. and Archbishop in the same citty, as doth easely conuince the calumniation of the mislike of the old holy Card. who was so far of from misliking the fathers as he vsed specialy their helpes not only for others but also for his owne person. and euery yeare once while he liued made the spiritual exercise of the Society, by the direction of one of the said Fathers.

About Cardinal Toled.For Cardinal Toled, litle is needful to be said. He was of the Society, and cannot be presumed, but to haue loued his mother, and when he died, he shewed the same both in woord and deed, hauing those fathers about him, and leauing in almes 500. crownes to the Casa Professa in Rome, and his library to the Roman Colledge which was of much more worth. And if the Society die resist more perhaps his preferment to the dignity of a Cardinal then some men may imagine; did giue him
or his frends contentment) which yet is but their coniecture) it followeth not that he bore them euil wil for that considering they did it only for preseruation of the sincerity of their rule and exemption in that behalfe, vntil that tyme.

But as for the fauours which the troublesome of the Roman tumult do vaunt to haue receyued at this hand, we shal haue occasiÅ to speake of them afterward. He seing their obstinacy, yeilded in certayne poynts for a tyme, as Phisitions are wont to do in desperate diseases, to giue the sicke what they cal for, but he protested to diuers most reuerend and honorable persons before his death (as we are credibly informed) that seing they grew worse and more insolent by his indulgÄce, he intended to procure the heades of them to be exemplarly punished. And of this we are informed very sufficiently that all that is true. And the poynts themselues which he graunted them were reproued afterward, and reiected vpon better consideration and experience of the euent, by them that had demaunded them, as in the peace made by F. Persons meanes betweene them and their Superiours is manifest.

Lastly then there remayneth to say a
word only of this Hol. whome these discontented for more discredit of the Iesuits,About his Hol. haue put downe in their booke, that his Holines in their general congregation did warne them, vt fastu & supercilio deposito, humiliter de se sentirent: which words if he did speake we know not; nor wil not be inquisitours in our superiours deeds: yet was it and is a very vndecent and immodest presumption for these men to publish in print, that which his Hol. spake as a Father in priuate, not to note or discredit therby the whole order, as these men seeke to do, knowing how many good and humble men there be therin, but to aduertise them rather what was principaly to be loked into for consideration of humility amongst so many great benedictiÅs which God hath bestowed vpon the order; and the like pious prouidence and fatherly admonitiÅ we heare that his Hol. vsed also in the congregation of the Capucions & some other religions, & yet were it not reason nor charity to draw them into publike obloquie for the same, as these do seeke to doe the Iesuits, whome his Hol. is knowne by publike report (what soeuer these men say) both to loue and esteeme, as worthie and painful laborers
in the vineyard of almighty God, espetially agaynst heretikes whome the cÅtrary report of these our discontented brethren do only gratifie, & no man els. And thus much of this matter, wherof we shal haue occasion to speake more herafter.

div.head: OF THE GREAT troubles and scandalous seditions raysed vp presently after Cardinal Allens death in the English Colledge at Rome by the foresaid faction; The beginning, progresse and end therof; with the causes and true authors; and how imprudently this is brought in now againe and defended in these bookes, by our discontented brethren. CAP. V.
div.p:
NO one thing truly doth make vs more to maruayle at the passionate proceeding of our discontended brethren then that they are not ashamed in diuers parts of their bookes to mention & seeme to defend the scandalous troubles and tumultuatiÅs of some vnruly schollers from tyme to tyme in the English Colledge at Rome, seeing they haue byn so greatly
misliked, euer by al wise and graue men both of our owne nation and others, and condemned by al iudges and Superiors, that euer haue had the examinatiÅ therof. Rectores nostri Collegij Romani (say they) &c.And the doers comonly made shipvvrack in the end, eyther of faith, honesty or both, vvho yet here ate iustified by our brethren, & the fault laid vpon the Superiors. The Rectors of our Roman Colledge that were in tymes past, did go about to bring in many things, that to yong men liuing freely in banishment for piety, were greuous and hard, and not necessary to the institute of the Colledge nor profitable to the schollers desyres or proceedings, & therof euery second or third yeare commonly came great stryfe and tumults betweene the Fathers and the schollers to the ruine of many yong men and hurt of our Church.

Lo heere the causes of old tumults from tyme to tyme layd vpon the Rectors,Lib. lat. pag. 9. and our free yong men that held discipline for greuous are iustifyed. But (say they) while the Cardinal lyued the Iesuits did this but vn â¢ er hand against our yong men: A ridiculous defÄce of free yong men against Superiors order & discipline. Illo autem vita d â¢ f ncto prodeunt audacius Patres Iesuitae, & sese vbique produnt. He being dead the Iesui s creeped forth more boldly, & euery where discouered thÄselues. And then followed (say they) that our schollers were troubled with new & most perilous tumults in Rome, Lib. lat. pag. 10. and the whole house was set on fyre with the flames of discord, &c. In which conflict the Iesuits did gather togeather and strayne all the forces of their whole body, their
wits and powers of their frends to ouercome our yong men freely liuing in banishment in a strang countrey for their faith.

Thus they wryte, which truly we are ashamed to repeate and do greatly wÅder that they do not blush to wryte it in latyn, so as both his Hol. and so many other learned vertuous men as lyue in Rome and saw what passed in these tumults should read the same and blush with vs in reading; for is it possible that preests brought vp in order and disciplyne and sent to such a mission as this is should so change their iudgements and sense by passion as to take vpÅ them the patronage of such disorders as these were & to lay the fault of all vpon thÄ that gouerned thÄ? How do the youths of so many other nations (as free as ours) who are gouerned by the same Society in Seminaries and vnder the same discipline, passe on both in France, Germany, Italy, Spayne, and other places? And in that they say they he in free banishment, &c. this ought rather to make them more capable of order & discipline then impatient thereof, Nay how did so many other English youthes as free by nature, and as willing in banishment as these, lyue quietly and contentedly at the very same tyme vnder the Iesuits gouernment in Spayne? Or how
haue they liued in the Roman Colledg euer synce the heades and authors of these tumults were remooued, and do at this day, with great peace, vertue and contentment of all? But to the end the true causes of these troubles and inconueniences may be seene, we shal with as great breuity as we can; runne ouer the whole story of these broyles of the Roman Colledge from the beginning, noting only by the way the authentical records that remayne therof, which heere cannot haue place to be set downe at length, but must be reserued to our larger Apologie if need require.

The gouernment of the English Colledge giuÄ to the Iesuits, 1579.There are now two and twenty yeares past since the gouernment of this Roman English Seminary was layd vpon the Fathers of the Society by the commÄdement of Pope Gregory the 13. at the most instÄt and vehement sute of the Schollers themselues and by all the English nation then in Rome. The Fathers for diuers causes refusing the same, but particularly for that they were ouercharged already with the gouernmÄt of diuers other such Colledges in the same City, and for that it occupied many of their subiects needful to be imployed els where in Gods seruice, according to their institute. For which cause
they had made a decree before in their second general cÅgregation,Congre. â¢ . Canon. 13. that the gouernment of such externe Seminaryes should not be admitted, where comodiously they might be auoyded. But the sute of the English then in Rome vvas so earnest, togeather with the intreatyes and teares of the schollers themselues that demaunded the same, as it moued his Holines to lay a precept vpon F. Euerardus Mercurianus then general of the Iesuits to take the charge. And he being a blessed holy man also, and seing the spiritual necessityes of the English nation was mooued as wel by compassion as by obedience to accept therof. The whole rehearsal of this matter is extant in a short latyn story remayning in record, whose title is this: Initia & progressus Collegij Anglicani de Vrbe ab Anno Domini 1578. vsque ad Annum 1587. which contayneth the first ten yeares of the Colledges beginning and growth. There are extant also many memorials of the Schollers then in Rome exhibited as wel to Cardinal Morone then protector as also to Pope Gtegory himselfe, and to his M. de Camera, Mem. 28. to Card. Moron. 20. 28. & 30. Ian. 1579. To his Hol. 2. 23. Feb. 1579. Ludouicus Blankettus, and others. In all which they do most instantly desyre to be comitted to the gouernment of the Fathers of the Society in respect of their end and desyre they had
to be brought vp in vertue, learning, deuotion and ecclesiastical discipline and after to returne to their countrey & exercise the same there. To which effect, after they had alleged many reasons which are yet extÄt, they procured by humble entreaty, as wel the L. Thomas Goldwel Bishop of S. Assaph as also the L. Richard Shelley great Prior of England, & the rest of the nation then in Rome to make humble sute to his Hol. for the same effect. VVhich effect was expressed in these words in all their memorials: Reuerendos Patres Societatis Iesu ardentissimis rotis conspirante animer â¢ m omnium consensu disciplinae ac pietatis magistros totius seminarij Rectores petimus. Mem. 3. Ian. 1597. VVe demaund with most inflamed desyres and with vniforme consent of all myndes, that the Reuerend Fathers of the Society, which are maisters of discipline and piety be made gouernours of the whole Seminary.

And yet further to try better their mynd and resolutiÅ, the said Protector by the Popes apoyntment comaunded euery one of the said preists and schollers in particular to wryte his petition, and subscribe it with his owne hand, with othe and protestation that he did it vpon his conscience, and for no other respect eyther of affection to the fathers, or auersion from M. D. Morrice
Clenock, vnder whose gouernmÄt they weare at that tyme, and so they did some two or three and thirty. And their said schedels and superscriptions are yet extant. The first and formost wherof was that excellent man and martyr of Christ M. Sherwin in these words: Ego Rodulphus Sherwinus Deum testor cordium omnium scrutatorem, me eius tantum honoris amplificandi, The petitiÅ and protestation of the English schollers in demanding the gouernment of the Iesuits. patriae{que} iuuandae causa regimen seminarij huius patribus Societatis committendum censeo, atque supplex peto. I Ralfe Sherwyn do cal God to witnes the searcher of all harts, that only for the encrease of his deuyne glory, and help of our countrey, I do iudge the gouernmÄt of this Seminary to be comitted to the Fathers of the Society, and do humbly request the same.

And after him do follow in like sense though in different words all the rest, and in the sixt or seuenth place followeth also M. Mush, who now in this later latyn booke setteth forth an Epistle (yf it be his) to MÅsignor Morro, wherby he vrgeth to haue the gouernmÄt of that Seminary taken from the Fathers, but in the forsaid petitions he protested to the same effect as before we haue hard M. Sherwyn to do, to wit: Ego Ioannes Musheus propria conscientia & motu, &c. humiliter peto, &c. I Iohn Mush vpon my owne conscience and proper motion
do most humbly desyre to haue this gouernment giuen to the Fathers of the Society, &c. And the same man almost 20. yeares after this again hearing of the great troubles in the Colledge after the Cardinals death, and that the general of the Iesuits was determyned to haue giuen ouer the gouerment, wrote a very vehement letter to one of the Society against it, and against the troublesome in these words:M. Mush to F. G. 19. Mar. 1596.
