VVoe is my hart for the heauy newes yow wryte of the disordered and vnfortunate company (of vnquiet schollers) that vndoe their selues, discredit our whole nation, and do most shamfully hinder and harme others, &c. Yow know what a do we had to get those good men to gouerne vs, and what greate profit our countrey hath reaped of that house since, many tymes the diuel hath labored as yow knowe to ouerthrowe that building of God, & at this tyme though he rage and hath by these disordered heads greatly shaken the frame, yet in no case must he be yeilded vnto, for by Gods grace, this is the last plunge he can make. VVherfore wryte and encorage your general to stand firme, &c. For if he labour to giue it ouer (so litle hope I haue) and do effect his desyre, I wish it were with all dissolued, &c. This and much more to this effect followeth in that letter,M. I. M. his inconstÄcy. extant vnder his owne hand which is so contrary to that, which now he wryteth and laboreth for,
as a man cannot ascribe so great inconstancy, but to meere passion or fond indiscretion.

But to go forward in our narration, the Fathers hauing receyued this gouernmÄt, imployed their endeauours to make the schollers fit for the mission of England, and so many prooued. But finding a diuision made in the nation and a faction raysed vp both against them and D. Allen,Sup. cap. 4. as before hath byn signified and that in part by occasion of this gouernment it selfe, and that diuers principal heades or agents of this opposite part lyued in Rome, they did easily forsee the difficultyes that would ensue, which was, that presently when any youth should be weary of wel doing, tempted with liberty or licence of lyf,The difficulties that the Iesuits haue had in this gouernment. or otherwayes troublesome of nature or geuen to strife and sedition, he would runne to the aduerse part, and by them should be borne out, or secretly fauored and encouraged against the discipline of the Colledge and obedience of his Superior, And therby would ensue great troubles and mischeefe.

These inconueniences were easylie foreseene, but not so easily remedied, especially the Rectors being strÄgers for many yeares, that could not so wel looke into the true causes of disorders that ensued. And albeit
they suspected them yet could they not remooue them. And as alwayes Sathan seeketh to cloke his attÄpts with some shew of piety, so heere such as ment to be troublesome, and to styrre sedition, pretended diuers zealous causes of their discontentments: some, that the Colledg and hospital of our nation was in strangers hands: some, that many of the schollers entred into the Society, and were drawne therunto, as these men would imagine: some other, that the orders of the house were rather for children then for men, especially for graduates of English vniuersityes, vvhen they came ouer. All which pretenses being easily allowed by such as lay abroad in the towne, or from other places had correspÅdence by letters, and were content to heare of these difficultyes in the Fathers gouernment troubles grew daylie; and it is pittiful to consider and shameful to our Nation, what molestations these good fathers receyued by these meanes for diuers yeares togeather vntil the yeare 1585. that Pope Syxtus hearing therof, sent two Bishops to visite the Colledge, wherof the principal being Sega B. of Placence afterwards Cardinal;The first visitatiÅ of the colle. 1585. he found out the roote therof, as he testified in his second visitation 11. yeare after; but could not so wel put
the remedy by reason that the faction that was abroad, was now growne so strong (Cardinal Mondeuy Protector of Scotland and others being drawne to fauour it) as in the former Chapter hath byn shewed.

But D. AllÄ & F. PersÅs coming to RomeD. Allen & F. P. comming to Rome an. 1585. in the end of this yeare, did put a great stay thervnto, first by dispersing diuers of the heads of diuisiÅ within the Colledge, & repressing the rest b â¢ their presence, and thÄ by persuading of F. General to prooue the gouernmÄt of some Englishman therin for a tyme, not for that Italian Rectors did not loue the Schollers and prouide for thÄ in all respects as wel as English could do, but only to yeild to our mens infirmityes, & to proue some litle chÄge & variety, Ther vpon was F. VVillÄ Holt (as we are informed) first made Rector, and he being sent into FlaÅ«ders in the yere 1587. F. Persons remayned in the gouernmÄt vntil the end of the yeare 1588. To whome succeded F. Creswel for other two or three yeares. And albeit partly by these changes, and by the presence of D. Allen then Card. some more quietnes there was then before, yet the same sticklers abroad neuer ceasing (and some humours growing vp euer at home which the other fed) there wanted
not from tyme to tyme some troubles, and F. Creswel also being called into Spayne, for assisting of the Colledges and common cause there, two other Italian fathers very vertuous learned and religious men the one called Mutius vitellescus & the other Hieronimus Florauantus succeeded the one after the other for diuers yeares in the gouernment, & had their parts both of good and bad quiet and trouble, as the other had before. But the second had more trouble, for that in his tyme the Card. dying, all the factions ioyned togeather, and put matters into a fyre, as before hath byn said. And it is to be noted, that as the same Father testifieth in a certain letter of his,The letter of F. Floranant to F. P. the 1. Aug. 1595. the troublesome for a great while told him that they had nothing at all against him, or the Society, but only against certain English fathers that were absent, but yet whÄ it came to the proofe of visitatiÅ they exhibited whole memorials of articles as wel against the Society in general as his person also;In visit Car. Sega. anno 1596. cap. 1. 2. 3. & 15. as in the visitation it selfe appeareth.

Now then to runne breefly ouer some cheefe poynts of this scandalous tumultuation from the beginning of the yeare 1595. wherof there is extant (besides the former visitation of Card. Sega contayning 40, chapters, and a multitude of particular
Memorials giuen vp to and fro) a certaine breefe and succinct treatise wryttÄ in latyn by a reuerend learned priest,M. Rob. Chambers Confessor of the English religious noble vvomen in Bruxels. that was present in the said tumult, from the beginning to the ending, and for some tyme had followed the troublesome also (as himself testifieth) vntil he saw whither it tended. The treatise is intituled thus. Breuis narratio eorum quae gesta sunt in Coll. Angl. de Vrbe tÄpore tumult: An. 1594. 95. 96. & 97. In which he setteth downe from tyme to tyme what fel out. The summe is this, as we haue hard also by diuers others that were present, and by some cheefe pillers of that faction it selfe.

The good Cardinal being dead, great care was had presently for aduauncing the B. of Cassano into his place as no doubt it is thought that he should easily haue byn in tyme, if this ouermuch hasting of his frends had not hindred. But those that would needs haue aduaunced him preposterously against the Cardinal while he was lyuing, as in the former chapter yow haue hard) had not patience to expect any tyme now when he was dead, but as though the matter had byn sure now and due and presently to followe, they caused first his nephew to buy all the dead Cardinals habit and apparel, as this narration sheweth which being hard of in the citty and
the tumultuation of these schollers following presently to the same effect did giue great suspition and mislike also to many.

The first petition that vvas made for the B.First then it was agreed vpon among these pretenders, that wheras Cardinal Allen had authority to giue facultyes to all priests that should go into EnglÄd (though he were not Protector) his authority should be demaunded in particular for the Bishop, as a man that knew better the particuler merits and abilityes of Englishmen for geuing them facultyes then could the Protector Cardinal Caietan being a stranger, and it was so wrought that the Protector himselfe should be entreated to demaund this grace of his Hol. for the B. as he did most willingly and effectually (as he was a man of a mo â¢ t noble and royal nature) but his Hol. foreseing by his great wisdome what might be pretÄded hereby refused to giue the said faculties to the B. and gaue them to the said Protector, which made the actors of this designmÄt to fal into suspition and diffidence with the said Protector.

And here vpon hauing taken cÅsulation a new (for now was M. Thomas Throgmorton come to towne, and ioyning with D. Hugh Griffin the Bishops nepew and some others of this part, made the councel
abroad and two or three priests of the Colledge ioyned with him drew many schollers after on the other side) their second resolution was to make a very fayre Memorial to F. Claudius Aquauiua General of the Society that he would persuade Cardinal Caetan to obtayne this matter for the B. of the Pope praysing infinitely the Societyes good gouernmÄt ouer them,The memorial for the B to F. General of the Society. and acknowledging their singular benefits bestowed vpon them and promising all odedience and gratitude for the tyme to come if this their desire might be obtayned by his meanes for the publike benefit of their countrey. This memorial did Cardinal Sega afterward much wonder at, when he saw how many cÅtrary Memorials to this they gaue vp against the Society in all the points that heere they so highly comÄded. And the cause was, for that the General talking with the Cardinal & finding that the Pope was resolute in this poynt, he exhorted the Schollers at their repayre vnto him for answere to be quiet and attend to their studyes, and to desist from these pretensions, vntil eyther his Hol. should of himselfe thinke what was conuenient to be done for aduauncing some man of our nation, or that the matter might be proposed by other men of higher calling thÄ
schollers, whose estate required to be quiet and follow their bookes, leauing those other matters to God and to their Superiours.

The retyring of some schollers from the faction and others going on vvith a nevv association.This counsel some â¢ oke very wel, with purpose to follow the same, and so retyred themselues from ioyning any farther in this action (for all in the former sutes had concurred) but the troublesome (especialy the heads) tooke the matter in very il part, persuading them selues, that the General for being the Duke of Atria his brother & allyed somwhat to the house of Caetan (as these men say, though we cannot learne so much) he had said it only in fauor of Card. Caetan and so from hence forward, they broke with them both being their highest Superiors vnder his Hol. and consequently much more with Prouincial Rector Minister Maistres and what soeuer other superiour vnder these of that Society. And to be sure that no more of the yonger schollers should slip backe from that combination,This is testified also by D. Barets letter, An. Domini 1596. vvhich after is set dovvne. they tooke a corporal oath of them to persist vnto the end; aad whosoeuer should leaue them and returne to obediÄce of their Superiors againe without the consent of the whole should be counted infamous and trayterous to their countrey. and by this they made themselues a common
welth as yow see. And no man falling once into the pit, durst go back againe for feare of infamy. And this is testified by the depositions of many in the moneth of October 1597.

And for that with sedition euer lightly entreth liberty, and F. Edmund Harwood a good blessed vertuous man, and most quiet and myld of cÅdition hauing at that tyme the office of Vicerector or Minister of the Colledge,The beginning of the troubles against F. Edm. Harvvood. vnderstood by the better sort, that there were certayne libertyne laddes, who began to be very dissolute in corners, thought himselfe in conscience bound to be more vigilant, and finding some thinges much amisse amonge some of the tumultuous, caused them to be warned therof in secret and general termes only, by one of their owne,This vvas Shepard. but these turning the matter to more tumult, would needs force the said Father to vtter both men and matter, which he refusing to do they broke into open hostility & defiance, persuming also to put his name out of the Colledge booke by violence; he being their Superiour (and so one of them did) And they neuer ceased by outragious clamors against him, vntil F. General for apeasing them, remoued the good man from the Colledge. And yet he for sauing the honour
ã1 page duplicateã
ã1 page duplicateã
of them and the nation could neuer be brought to vtter those particular disorders which he had found and knowne vntil a litle before his death being commÄded by obedience: and then he put them downe in wryting, but with great secresy, and confirmed the same againe vpon his death bed.

And many such like acts of open mutiny and tumultuation they committed at that tyme which were ouer long and to vngrateful heere to repeat: as namely one day they brake by force out of the Colledge and ran like furious men towards the Popes Pallace but that they were commaunded from his Hol. to stay and returne. Diuers seditious sermons were made by them within the Colledge, open insolency was vsed to Cardinal Caetan the Protector and other like excesses, for which causes foure at last were put out of the house by iustice, but restored after againe by compassion & vpon promise of amÄdment. But litle was seene by the effects.

The visitatiÅ of Car. Sega 1596.Hervpon his Holines in the yeare 1596. sent Cardinal Sega for Visitour, who found the mutined party so intemperate, both in word and deed, as the very first letters that euer he set vp publikely in the hal about this visitation, willing them all to keep
peace and obay their Superiours, vntil the visitation was done, they tore in peeces,Se the fornamed latyn narration. which he bore with greate patience, and went forward in his visitation, and caused euery man to say, & wryte, what he would or could, yea harkening to some one for a whole day togeather not weary with any molestation and labour. For so he testified himselfe vnto the Pope in his Visitation talking of this turbulÄt spirit of our men. Hoc tantum dico, quod res ipsa clamat, &c. Cap. 3. This only I say in this place, which the thing it selfe doth testifie that these spirits of Englishmen, are exactly to be tryed, and no meane cautiÅ & care is to be vsed in gouerning and moderating of them, wherof we shal haue place to say more afterward, only this I am forced to say to your Hol. in this place, about these tumultuous schollers, that how soeuer it go with them in other matters, yet seeme they in their mynds to be greatly diseased and out of tune, in that they so obstinatly do persist in their tumults,Cardinal Sega his iudgment of the tumultuous English in Rome. which I perceauing by their disordinate motions and perturbatiÅs euen from the first day I entred into the said Colledge to visite, I thought good to accomodate my selfe to their infirmytes, and to lend them most patient eares to heare whatsoeuer they could wryte or say: and
so I did sparing no labour or payne on my part, wherby I might mittigate their perturbed mynds, and reuoke them to some reason, if it were possible.

See heere his iudgment of the passionate and perturbed mynds of our tumultuous in Rome, in wryting and speaking against the Fathers. VVhat would he haue said if he had liued to see priests in England do worse? Yow shal heare what he saith in another place of their contradiction in speaking so much euil now, and so much good a litle before in their memorial to F. General:Card. Seg. in visit. cap. 1.
Quot quantÃ­sque fuerint (saith he) Ã Societate Patrum beneficijs affecti, numerando percensent. In this memorial to the General, they do recken vp how many and how greate benefits they haue receyued of the Society,The soule contradictiÅs of the seditions in Rome. acknowledging beneuolence in the highest degree, and extolling their equity, indifferency & fatherly affection in their gouernmÄt, thinking and speaking most honorably of all their Superiors, so as then there seemed to be no memory of so many old greefes and complaints, which after 10. or 12. dayes broke forth against them with such violence, as yf they had neuer byn frends before. Wherby I was forced to wonder at their lightnes and inconstancy. For if those thinges were
true which they said of their prayses in this memorial to the general, with what face could they make such inuectiues against them to me as they did soone after, when no new cause of offence had happened betweene them. Truly eyther they were great lyars, when they did so highly prayse the Fathers or they are fond men now to deuise such complaints against them. But we shal haue fitter place afterwards to discusse these matters more exactly.

Thus wrote to his Hol. that worthy learned man and Cardinal after he had twise byn Visitor of the English Colledge. And this relation he gaue vp euen a litle before his death, and when he knew he could not liue being in an euident consumption; and so much the more may he be presumed to haue wrytten it with a good conscience. And how then can our brethren with any regard of honor or good meaning to truth order or discipline, put forth in print now againe their approbation of these tumults in the schollers behalfe laying all the fault vpon the Fathers, their gouernours. But it is no great maruayle, seing diuers of them were heads, or members of that tumult or sticklers abroad therin by correspondence of letters, and cÅsequently, they do defend but their owne actions.

body.p:
The grauest of our natiÅ condemned these styrres by vvryting.I wil not heere stÄd to bring in the iudgement or rather detestation of all the grauest of our Catholike nation about this fact, testified by letters from euery place, both in Spayne, France, Flaunders, diuers parts of Germany, and Italy which letters are yet extant, wrytten partly to his Hol. partly to the Protector, partly to the Schollers themselues, which are ouerlong to be inserted heere, yet one clause, that was added by that worthy knight & Catholike counselour S. FrÄcis Inglefield in a postscript to a large letter of M.D. StilingtÅ out of Spayn which he wrote to the tumultuous schollers in Rome the 15. of Iuly 1595. I cannot omit for that it is both short and substantial.A clause of S F. Inglefeld and addition to M.D. Stillington. his letter 1 â¢ . of Iuly 1595. Thus then he saith: Only I wil repeat & commend vnto your memoryes the last two points of this letter as most true & importÄt in my iudgement, to wit, that if the best Catholikes of our nation both within and without should meete togeather to wryte a letter vnto yow in this affayre, I weene they would wryte no lesse in substance then heere is set downe, and if all heretikes our enemyes should deuise a way to disgrace both yow and vs, and to ouerthrow our whole cause: they could lay hands of no better then this already begone to put vs out with the fathers of the Society, and according to this euery one of yow may iudge both of his owne spirit and of others who tend that way. Our
Lord Iesus for his mercyes sake giue yow his spirit, which is farre different from this yow follow, if I and many others be not deceaued, &c.

closer.signed: Your louing countrey man, freind, and fellow in banishment. Francis Inglefielde.

div.p: This admonition of so graue and wise a man and so worthy a Counselour and confessor for so many yeares;An aduise to our discontÄted priests. may as wel serue for our discontented brethren to examine their spirits as for the schollers at Rome. And he that shal read the whole letter of the said Doctour heere commended by this knight, and ponder the reasons and considerations layd downe therin, hath eyther a hard hart, and is farre gone, or els wilbe much mooued as also with another long letter of 7. or 8. sheets of paper at the least, which the said knight wrote to his cosyn M. Tho. ThrogmortÅ then in Rome, vpon the 23. of October 1595. to dissuade him from this faction in which letter the true reasons and motiues of these Roman troubles,S. F. Inglef. to M. Tho. Throg. 23. Oct. 1595. as a member and relique of the former faction against the Cardinal and Iesuits, are set downe.

D. Baret also President of the Colledge of Doway comming to Rome in the beginning
of the yeare 1596. to do somwhat for appeasing of these troubles if it might be,D. Barrets letter to F. P. 10. April 1596. about the true causes of Romane troubles. and to learne out the true cause therof, he wryteth thus to F. Persons then in Spayne. Louing F. the cause of these shamful styrres I find to be these: First that the schollers were permitted by the Rector at the beginning to deale in publike affayres, as namely for a Cardinal, for facultyes, and the like. VVherin being persuaded now that the Society is of a contrary mynd they haue conceaued indignation and auersion, as though the fathers were enemyes to them, their cause, and countrey, and a faction is cunningly brought in before the Rector suspected it, &c.

p.q: Secondly some of the same faction heere abroad in Rome were put in hope to haue gotten the fingering of the Colledge rents vnder the name of a cÅgregation, and promise was made to the heads of offices and roomes to their contentment; and many priuiledges to the schollers.

Thirdly there is one here vehemently suspected for a false brother sent hither of purpose (out of England.) Fourthly I fynd such here, as I expelled out of Rhemes for their misdemeanour. Fifthly I find very many receyued at all aduentures. Sixtly during these troublesome broyles, where
neyther study of learning nor exercise of vertue keepeth them occupied, no maruel if some yong men would willingly looke backe to the world, and take any occasion to go away with the rest. Seuenthly I fynd their heads ful of false bruits and differÄces betwene Iesuits and priests in England, yea the selfe same faction that is at Bruxels to be heere also against the Spaniards, & such as take that way. Eightly these are gone so farre and haue committed so many out rages, as they dispayre to go backe, and the multitude being sworne togeather maketh them more bold.

These causes & some other I fynd, & haue shewed to his Hol. these dayes in more ample sort, then now I can wryte, beseeching his Hol. to haue pitty vpon the Colledge & their madnesse,D. Barets spech to his Hol. 1596. who vndercolour of doing good to the Colledge and their countrey, do take the ready way to ouerthrow both, by putting vs in diuision not only with the fathers, but amongst our selues also. And for the Fathers I told his Hol. the many respects wherby we are most bound to the Society, and could not breake vvith them without wonderful shame and vndoing of Gods cause in our countrey. And concerning the secÅd which is our nation, I declared to his Holines that
against these few factious heads the whole colledge at Doway, the colledges in Spayne and S. Omers, the priests in England and generally all our nation Catholike (a few only excepted, by whose il councel these youthes were deceaued) stood vnited with the fathers, and with order and discipline against these factions.

This was the effect of my speech to his Hol. who answered much to my contentment willing me to attend to the remedies and to consult with the Cardinal protector, and his Hol. would allow of that wee should conclude. So vpon thursday last the Cardinal F. General F. Tyrius the Rector and my selfe haue agreed vpon the remedyes, expecting his Hol. authority for the execution of the same. Thus it standeth, and within a few dayes we hope for an end.

div.p:
Thus wrote that good man, but his hope had not effect for that tyme, through the exceeding obstinaty of the mutyned company, but rather matters went worse and worse, in so much that F. General after diuers cÅsultations, with his AssistÄts resolued to giue ouer the gouernment; but yet wrote once againe therof first to F. Persons in Spayne by a letter of the 29. of Octob. 1569. beginning thus:F. Claud. Aqua. General to F. P. 29. Octo. 1596. Gia Va. Ra. sÃ li
trauÃ¡gli ch' in diuersi tempi ci hanno dato l' Alunni del semrio. Inglese di Roma, nelli quali, &c. Your reuerÄce now knoweth the troubles, which the schollers of the English Colledg haue giuen vs diuers tymes; for which after due consultation, we haue thought good to giue ouer wholy the gouernment, &c, alleaging many reasons for that resolution, but yet promised to expect his answere. And to be breefe these matters went from bad to worse, til God him selfe put to his holy helping hand, cutting of first by death and otherwise some six or seauen persons that were the principal mayntayners therof, wherof one was Friar Sacheuerel that after bad life discouered ran away, and became an Apostate, as all the world knoweth, and then Gods holy prouidence drew F. Persons to Rome,F. P. comming to Rome and the peace made 1597 by whose prudent and moderate dealing, matters were soone after brought to a very grateful peace and conclusion, as all men know, but yet notwithstanding we wil rather relate the effect therof, by other mens words that were of the same faction, then by our owne considering the extreme passion, that these â¢â¢ r discÅtented brethren without all cause and reason haue of later tyme taken against this man and his doinges. Thus
then do wryte the six priests that were chosen by the discontented schollers to treat their affayres with F. Persons and to make an end of all, and their letter was directed to the general of the Iesuits then in Naples beginning thus.

p.note: The letter of the 6 ãâã Priests the 17. of May 1597 about the peace made.
p.hi: Rme. Pater, &c. Ex quo Va. Paternitas non quibus hominum, &c.

body.p:
Most reuerend F. by that which your Fatherhood did cÅmit the whole affayres of our Colledge not to any other at your departure, but only to our most louing contrey man and most skilful in our affayres the R. F. Persons, we haue therby perfectly vnderstood that our peace & profit hath byn euer most deare vnto your Fatherhood, &c. VVherfore albeit the said father by his singular prudence, charity mansuetude and dexterity waying euery thing with equal ballance, hath made at last a most desired end of our discords, and hath brought vnto vs most sweet peace, yet this notwithstanding must iustly be attributed also to your Fatherhood as the Author of so great a benefit, in so much as yow did vouchsafe of our owne accord appoint him to this office, who only may seeme to haue byn able to bring it to passe we easily vnderstood how cÅfortable this our new peace wilbe vnto your fatherhoode,
and how grateful our agrement of myndes after so long endurance of discord, and we must needs acknowledge in yow the affection of a fatherly mynd that reioyseth with the concord of his childrÄ, liuing togeather in one house, we shal thinke our selues happy, if we shal conserue in yow the sollicitude of a louing father, and in our selues the dutyes of obedient children, as by Gods grace we shal endeauour herafter to performe. In the meane space we do render your fatherhood immortal thankes, for so great a benefit and these not outwardly only from our mouth, but inwardly from our sincere harts,Marke these vvords and consider their doings. which (we trust) the end shal proue. One thing only remaneth to be considered (if your fatherhood by your wisdome should not thinke of it) which is, that this reconciliation of ours so happily begonne shal so much the better be made perfit, by how much the longer F. Persons remayneth amongst vs & by how much more ample authority he shal obtayne to dispose according to his wisdome of our affayres. Christ Iesus keep your Fatherhood long in health, this 17. of May Anno, 1597.

body.head: Tho. Hil. Cuthb. Troloppe. George VVolley. Anth. Champney. Edvv. Tempest. Edvv. Benet.
body.p: THus wrote those Priests at that tyme that were pres â¢ nt and witnesses of F. Persons maner of proceeding in that actiÅ whome now our angry brethren do call euery where the Author and Architect of their troubles and molestations, which yet we cÄnot see nor gesse wherin they may meane it except only for that he hath stayed them from some precipitations as he did these in Rome, but of this more afterward. Now what the most Reuerend F. General for his singular wisdome piety and loue towards our nation hauing compassion of them in particular did answere to this letter of theirs euery man may imagine especialy considering that some few dayes before being put in hope only by the letters of F. Alphonsus Agazarius Rector of the Colledge and of F. Persons,F Claud. Aquav. his letter to F. P. the 2. of May 1 â¢ 97. about the peace of the Coll. that there was probability & some likelyhood, that an end might be made of these troubles, he wrote backe with great contentment, saying to F. P. among other things these words in spanish.

p.hi:
If God of his mercy and for the good of your countrey do assist yow in this worke as he hath
done in others hert â¢ fore, so as yow make an end of those discords in the Colledge, I shal esteeme it for no lesse a benefit to your nation, then the first erection and foundation of the same.
p.note: The Co â¢ O â¢ yuares.
p.hi: This L. Viceroy desyreth much to see yow here shortly, & I haue comitted the matter to your owne consideration for the tyme what wilbe most comodious.

body.p: Thus the good man wrote to F. Persons, wherby we may see his sense and feeling of this our discord, but to the forsaide priests, he wrote a very effectual answere at the end of the same moneth in these words: Reuerendi in Christo dilectissimi.

Quantum mihi consolationis attulerint litterae Vx, &c. F. Claud. Aquau. to the English priests about the peace 31. of May 1597. Reuerend and most dearly beloued in Christ, how great consolation your letters brought vnto me, by which yow do giue me newes of peace restored in your Colledge, yow wil easily conceaue, I doubt not, of your selues who are not ignorant how greatly I haue euer desyred the same, and how sollicitous I haue byn to restore it. VVherfore I am hartily glad and do giue thanks to God, who yeilding at last to all our desyres hath turned the former troubles into so great tranquillity, as yow wryte, and by his benignity hath made yow to vnderstand and feele by the effects themselues, VVhat difference there is betwene
the turbulent spirit of dissention past, and this gentle and sweet spirit of peace and concord which now yow possesse. This benefit & ioy wil not be priuate to yow alone, but wil pertayne also to all your contreymen with whome yow labour, and to your countrey for which yow labour; of which countrey yow must thus conceaue, that whatsoeuer help or cÅsolation yow purpose by Gods assistance to procure vnto it, and whatsoeuer spiritual help or assistance she may expect at your hands,A very graue and true speech. that can no wayes be performed but by vnion among your selues, nor any way so readily ouerthrowne, and broken as by dissention and perturbation of mynde one towards the other. VVhich thing by how much more euident it is in it selfe so much the lesse am I to labour to persuade the same vnto yow in this place, or to exhort yow for the tyme to come to auoyd withall possible diligence this dangerous rocke of your spiritual shipwracke by conseruing vnion most firme and stable among yow, which to be your owne wil and desire also I do vnderstand by the letters as wel of F. P. as also of F. Agazarius, and do take infinite comfort therby. VVherfore touching me persuade your selues thus, that yow shal fynd my hart the selfe same vnto
yow, that it hath byn alwayes, & not only to put out of memory all distastes past, but to seeke all occasions also while yow go forward in this course, wherby my old affection and loue towards yow (wherwith in the bowels of our Sauior I haue euer embraced yow all) may be encreased, if it be possible, vvith new addition of good wil, and study to do yow good. And for that I hope that we shal see togeather very shortly, and talke of these matters in presence, I do here make an end, beseeching almighty God to replenish yow all most aboundÄtly with the gifts of his holy grace, whome he hath ioyned so mercifully togeather with the ioyful bands of his holy peace & charity.

closer.signed: Your most louing brother & seruant in Christ. Claudius Aquauiua.

div.p:
Thus wrote that good and blessed man, who no doubt but hath the same sense in our affayre styl, and wilbe much more afflicted then euer, when he shal heare of these our new and most exorbitant excesses in that vice of tumultuation, which here he so much detesteth, and disuadeth, and his exhortation being such as it is (and he so great a seruant of God, as all men know
him to be) ought to worke deeply in the harts of such of our brethren as haue not cast of al respect, as we trust none of them haue done or wil doe.

But to go forward in our narration, one of the foresaid 6. priests that had wryttÄ to the said F. General hauing byn most vehemently against the Fathers before in the styrres of the Colledge (though vpon error, and euil informed zeale, as may be supposed, for that we heare not, but that he hath behaued himselfe wel since) wryting a letter two dayes before the former vnto his frend M. D. Kellison in Flaunders now Vicepresident of the Colledge of Doway, amongst other things saith thus:

p.note: F. Thom Hils letter to D. Kellison 15. of May 1597.
p.q:
This vnion of ours, the most R. F. P. wel knowing the inconueniences that might ensue to our Colledge and Countrey by our disagreement, tendred so much that he could not contayne himselfe where he was, but came to Rome as he confessed secondarily, but as I thinke (to his praise be it spoken) principally to set vs at peace. Being comen to Rome we saw so much prudence, piety and zeale of our peace and common weale redound in his countenance and behauior (which I perceaue was farre greater in his hart) that he was most welcome vnto vs: in so much
as we durst almost to haue committed all our matters into his hÄds without any further trial, &c. And againe. The sunday before the feast of our B. Sauiours ascÄsion F. Persons made vs a most memorable sermÅ, promulgated the peace collauded our endeauors, exhorted vs to confirme that which was begone, and to frame our conuersation accordingly. This done he communicated the schollers, and vpon the assension day made vs another sermon, and comunicated the schollers againe. And further a little after (for it were to long to put the whole letter) all the inconueniences are now remedied, by this most sweet and indifferent composition, I say a most true composition wherin we haue condescended the one to the others reasons without all partiality or passion wherin I cannot but highly commend F. Persons exceeding charity, prudence, patience and equality, &c.

div.p:
Thus wrote he from the Colledge who had byn most earnest in the diuision before, and from other places abroad diuers others wrote no lesse; namely M.D. Gifford deane of Lisle in Flaunders, of whose letter wryttÄ the tenth of Iuly 1597. vnto M. Edward Tempest in Rome, we haue seene an extract vnder the said M. Tempestes
hand. VVherin the said D. giueth greate thankes first to the blessed Trinity for this peace made; beginning with these wordes: Benedicta sit sancta Trinitas & indiuidua vnitas. The sum- of D. Giff. letter to M. Temp. about the peace 10. of Iuly 1597. &c. And then many high prayses of F. P. saying among other thinges: that God had comforted him and all other good, who had prouided a Iosue in place of Moyses, a Dauid in steed of Ionathas, &c. that is F. P. in steed of the good Card. dead, exhorting all to peace and vnity for the tyme to come.

This passed at that tyme, and so continued all that Sommer following, and when in September they were to depart towards England I meane the cheef of those that had byn troublesome in the Colledge they went to take their leaue of his Hol. and one of them made, a very pithy (though breefe) speech to his Hol. about this matter, promising quietnes and all obedience for the tyme to come.The Popes speech the 3. of Sept. 1597. By which occasion the Pope geuing them first a vehement reprehension for troubles past, exhorted & cÅmanded them there with like instÄce to be at peace, for the tyme to come both among themselues and namely with the fathers of the Society.The letter of M. Ed. Bennet frÅ Antvverp 20. DecÄb. 1597. And so they promised not only while they were in Rome, but also from Flanders in their way towards England, confessing to haue receaued great
curtesyes of the Fathers there, namely F. Holt, by commendations of F. P. letters.

Thus the matter passed then, and albeit afterward though new disorders committed by some of the former troublesome left in Rome, some restraynt and punishment was layd vpÅ them, which F. P. could not altogeather let & hinder, for that by their owne faults it was made publike, yet did he seeke to moderate things, all that he could, as the Cardinal. & officers by whose hands matters did passe, haue testified. and his Hol. himselfe wel knoweth. The disorder was, that diuers of them accustomed (as it seemeth) before during the formet troubles to haunt Tauerns, and such other disorderly places in secret, were said to giue out (for better couering their actions) that they were Germayns. This appeareth by a letter yet extÄt of Card. Madrucius Protector of the Germans vnto Card. Caetan of the 28. of September 1597.Card Mad. letter to Cardinal Caetan 28. Sept. 1597. which beginneth thus. Habiano inteso, &c. VVhervpon his Hol. causing the Iustice to watch tooke certayne of the English Colledge. And wheras they should haue byn carried to publike prisons, F. P. made such labour, as they were retyred only to particular chambers of the Engl. Colledge, & therin their cause hard at the appoyntmÄt of his Holines by
two Card, Caetan and Burghesius, Protector and Viceprotector, and the examination to be made by his Hol. Fiscal Signor Acaritius. This is shewed by two letters of the said Cardinals vnder their hÄds & seales which we haue seene, the first of the 28. of Sept. the other of the first of October 1597. And wheras some for these and other eccesses were to be dismissed the Colledge,F. P. charitable and curteous dealing tovvards thÄ that had offended in Rome. F. P. procured that it should be donne without infamy, & to be sent only to other Colledges in Spaine and Flaunders there to be wel and kyndly treated, allowing also to each of them for his iorney both new apparel and 25. Crownes in gold, for viaticum he that had least. And all this appeareth by two other letters vnder the same Card. hands & seales yet extÄt the first of the 14. the other of the 22. of October the same yeare.

And when afterward D. Barret wrote wel and gaue frendly relation of some of their behauiours in Doway, that were sent away from Rome F. P. procured from his Holines and from the Protector dispensation for such of them as were not Priests to take holy orders and such as were priests to haue facultyes to be sent into England, as if these disorders had neuer fallen out, yea though some of them had begone to be troublesome againe. And this appeareth by
diuers letters both of Cardinal Caetan him selfe while he liued, and Cardinal Farnesius that succeeded him in the Protection of England, and of Cardinal Burghesius ioyned with them in commission for matters of our countrey, all which letters in fauour of the said priests and schollers F. Persons procured. And both D. Barret when he was aliue, and the other Doctors and Auncients of that Colledg yet liuing togeather with ther president that now is can & do giue testimony of this. And we know diuers our selues that haue receyued these benefits and good offices at his hands, and do presume they wil not deny it.
And thus much for F. P. and other Iesuites dealinges in the troubles of Rome. For other matters we shal examine them in their proper places afterward.

div.head: OF THE TROVBLES raysed among Catholike prisoners in the Castle of VVisbyche: who were the beginners and continuers therof: and of the most vntrue and sclaunderous narration set downe in these Libels about the same. CAP. VI.
div.p:
INto noe one matter more vnwillingly do we enter, then into this of the Castle of VVisbich, which hath byn held hitherto by Catholikes in greate reuerence, as an house of Saynts, and sacred seruants of almighty God confessors and martyrs for these many yeares. Yet for that the common enemy of mankynd spareth not to enter euery where, and the holier the house, the sooner is his hand, and foote therin (as for Monasteries & Eremitages do testifie Cassianus Palladius, and other wryters, and for prisons of confessors and martyrs it is euident by S. Cyprian, Eusebius, and like authors) for this cause we must haue patience also, and not be scandalized by that which hath fallen out in this prison, seing it hath byn to the probation of good men, and wilbe also to the correction of euil in the end, and in the meane space, yt behooueth
euery man for his owne satisfaction & light in the cause to informe himselfe equally, & without passion, of the truth, which we shal endeauour here to put downe vpon authentical informations and originals against a long and sclaunderous narration wrytten (as is supposed,D. B. and by many euident arguments most probable) by the proper pen of the cheefe authors of all these broyles as after shal appeare.Lib. lat. pag. 11. The summe of the narration is this. That when that Castle was in greate peace and rest, the Iesuits desyring to haue dominion ouer priests, procured, presently after the death of Cardinal Allen, and Card. Toled, that one F Edmond VVeston a Iesuite, being in prison should get voyces to be made Superior of all the rest which were to the number of 33. VVhich being done, by the voyces of the maior part of the company, and certayne rules of orderly liuing for a shew being prescribed (albeit he for dissimulation refused it) yet at length by commÄdment of his superior, he tooke it vpÅ him, wherat others repyning there beganne a diuision and separation among them, wherof many disorders and incÅueniences succeeded, which these our discontented brethren (if we may beleeue these libels to haue comen from them & that they would
euer wryte so manifest calumniations) do most odiously lay vpon the Fathers, and principally vpon the ambition of this F. Edmund, which no man of indifferency knowing his person, wil euer beleeue, but rather reiect all (as we do) for a most maleuolous and vindecatiue fiction, if he consider the notorious improbabilityes feigned in this affayre.

F. Ed. VVeston novv in the Tovver by procurment of the factiÅs.For as concerning F. Edmund, whome they haue caused to be layd vp in the Tower, and now seeke to defame, by these libels, and whome they make so ambitious of gouernmÄt in a poore prison, as by amplificacion they tel his Hol. in one part of their narration:Pag. 13. that posterity wil not beleeue, what obstinacy was vsed to get this gouernment. He is knowne in all England to be a very graue, learned and mortified man, and now aboue 15. yeares in prison for Catholike religion, which he hath passed with such extraordinary edification, in humility, mortification, prayer deuotion and other such vertues, as not only Catholiks but also heretikes that know himâª do esteeme and respect him, especially, for his great seuerity vsed alwayes towards himselfe, and mansuetude towards others in his maner of lyfe, wherof we do assure vpon our consciences, that we do know and partly haue
hard by others, many excellent thinges of his rare vertues,Se the relatino of VVisbich & Framingham mÄse Iunij 1601. which are not conuenient here to vtter he being a liue; yet one thing among many we shal say, which a certayne reuerÄd priest related vnto vs, that liued with him aboue a yeare not only in one prison, but in one chamber also, auowing that F. Edmunds perseuerance both day and night in prayer, was such, as he neuer saw him in bed all that tyme, except only a litle, when he was sicke, nor euer slept, but eyther standing or sitting at his prayers, in which he would often fal downe but ordinarily sit downe vpÅ some resting place, while the force of sleep did ouercome him, and then returne to his prayer againe.

This then being the mans lyfe both in the Clinke in London (where this priest liued with him in the yeare 1587) as also for 7. or 8. yeares togeather afterward in VVisbich, vntil the yeare 1595. when these styrres beganne, how can it be imagined, that this man would so ambitiously seeke gouernment ouer his fellow prisoners, or that the rest of the Iesuits, especialy his prouincial (as these men cal him) should so carefully procure the same, especially being but an Agency to se certayne rules for good order kept, without title, place or Superiority, as themselues afterward confesse,
what profit could the Iesuits,M. Bag. in his letter to his frÄd 1595. get therby? what preferment, or what other probable reason can there be to make this fiction likely? we shal tel therfore breefely how the matter passed, and shew the proofes we haue for certainty therof, and then let the reader iudge how farre passion and malice hath carried these mÄ to publish so sclaunderous and opprobrious vntruthes vnto the world in print.

A breefe narration the cÅtrouersie of VVi â¢ bich.The summe of all yow shal heare partly by a particular relation of diuers graue mÄ which we haue receyued in wryting from VVi â¢ bich and Framingham, since these libels came out and the witnesses were present at all the parts of this tragedy, and partly also b â¢ diuers other authentical letters and wrytings, as yow shal see in the prosecutiÅ of this story, which passed thus: Some two or three and thirty Catholike prisoners liuing togeather in the said Castle of VVisbich in great peace and contentment as before hath byn shewed they led a collegial and heauenly kynd of lyfe, both for inward vertue and external edification, theit prayer was frequent and earnest, their study was continual meditation of the holy scriptures and other exercises appertayning to vertue, they liued in common both for their diet and distribution of
almes that was sent vnto them, they were present daylie at publike and priuate litanyes, & at some lesson or conference of cÅtrouersies & cases of cÅscience for better instructiÅ of their iudgmÄts their cÅuersatiÅ was sweet both in words and countenance, their behauiour holy, and all this by the direction cheefly of the forsaid seruant of god F. Edmund weston, who was the only priest of the Iesuits order that liued amongst them, and this endured (as we say) for diuers yeares, vntil at last M. MethamM. MethÄ. an auncient confessor, a most blessed man (admitted also as we haue heard vnto the Iesuits order, while he liued in prison) was called to heauen who hauing a great sway with all the company for his holynes and wisdome, held them in peace while he liued, in whose place he being dead) some others of farre different spirit, entring, and namely two Doctors, the one of Diuinity made in Italy (but not with his Superiours allowance,D.B. as farre as we vnderstand) being at discord with them; the other of Phisicke, of as hasty nature,D.N. as the former was vnquiet, gayning also to them a third of no lesse fiery condition then the other two,M. Blu. but venerable vnto that tyme for his former sufferings, and for his great frendship with M. Metham,
if these mens peruerse tompany had not wholy chaunged him.

And albeit these three did hardly long agree among themselues, but had their priuate cÅbats (as such men are wont to haue) yet neyther of them being a frend of discipline and order, they quickly had some followers, to bring in and maintayne liberty and dissolution, so as in litle tyme after (Cardinal Allen being dead, and no Superiour left in England to restraine or controule them) the whole good order of the house was altered, and braules, dissension, f â¢ lling out, fighting, idlenes, banketting, playes, and other dissolution was brought in, which the better part seeing and complayning of (and especially the good F. aforesaid) and no hope left of redresse by way of admonition;See the letter of complaint of 18. priests of VVisbich against this dissolution anno 1594. after set dovvne. he resolued to liue alone to himselfe, without medling any more with any matter, or going forth of his chamber, yeilding this reason, that he being a religious man, could not with a safe conscience liue among such a cÅpagny as comytted these disorders with open profession to perseuer therin.

The causes of retyrmÄt and reformation of some in VVisbich.VVith this fact, those that were good and vertuous resolued themselues to retyre also, and to make vnto themselues, certayne easy & cÅodious rules fit for secular
priests to obserue in the state they were in, but yet so as none should be forced thervnto, but such as would willingly put thÄselues into this Academy or congregation according to the fashion and example of those priuate congregations of our Lady allowed by the Sea Apostolike in diuers countreys. And with this mynd and purpose 19. of the forsaid company wherof 18. were secular priests, and one ancient gentleman an old confessor,M. Tho. Pounde. agreed togeather to haue a certayne orderly forme of lyfe for the tyme to come. And to this effect gathered out amÅg themselues some fit rules to liue and gouerne themselues withal. And to the end they might haue some directors in this good worke, they chose by common consent F. Edmund for that office,The letter of 18. Priests to F. G. 7. Feb. 1595. who refusing vtte â¢ ly the thing they all wrote most earnest letters to his Superior, residing in England, who albeit he would not agree, that any wayes the said F. Edmund should be their Superior, yet for their direction in this spiritual course of lyfe (as in Italy & in other places he had seene exercise) he yeilded so farre vnto their requests being often vrged by their letters, that he should be their director, but with these three limitations.Three restraints of F. Ed. authority. First that he should not be called their Superior, but
their Agent. Secondly that he should haue no voyce in determining any thing, especially for the reprehension or punishment of any man that should offend against the rules of that congregation, but that all should be done by the voyces of the maior part without him. Thirdly that he should not take any place or precedence at the table, or els vvhere; in respect of this office.

But all these limitations did not content the other, who would haue no rules, and were 13. in number, who interpreting this to be their disgrace impugned the same mightely calling it a schisme, separation & plaine Donatisme,Se M. D. â¢ ag letter aftervvard. Arrianisme, Anabaptisme, & other such contumelious, scoffing at the rules, and detesting them that professed any obseruation therof, and hervpon great scandal grew, and many letters were wrytten about England of this diuision, & scandalous dissention. For which cause a very reuerend, ancient, and learned man (now one of the 12. Assistants) with another priest being entreated to go thither,M. D. Bauand. he could in no wise accord the lesser part to accept of any rules at all, but was contemptuously handled by them, and in heat of contention thrust out of the gate, yet not long after againe two other priests (wherof
one was doubted to fauour their faction,M. MÃ¹sh. M. Dudley. & so hath shewed himselfe since that tyme) going thither assisted with earnest letters of F. Garnet Superiour of the Iesuits both to F. Edmund and the bigger part ioyned with him, that desyred rules & order, exhorting them to yeild in what was possible to the other, they preuayled so much, as both parts accorded, not vpon the former rules, but of others of lesse moment, and lesse liked of by the more zealous, but yet yeilded vnto for peaces sake, so as some order might be held. But when soone after the disorderly felt themselues restrayned also by these rules from many thinges, vvhich their passions would do & say, they brake in like maner from these, and deuising a sleight to get out of the greater parts hands the authentical copy therof which they had (for each part had an authentical copy giuen them for better obseruance therof) they ouerthrew all againe,Peace made but endured not. and made a greater broyle and tumultuation th â¢ n euer before inuenting quarrels by clamors of disputation contention and otherwayes to vex and molest the better side, accusing them also of heresy false and scandalous propositions, and other such like inuentiÅs to terrifie them from exacting any rules any more. VVherby the other were enforced
to retyre themselues againe to their priuate maner of conuersation, for feare of some worse scandal (seing the violence vsed) might fall out.

These 13. then that were of the other party (or rather some two or three heads, that incensed the rest) beeing most violÄt & passionate men,M. VVigges Se the relation of VVisbich 1601. as they shewed themselues to be by beating a priest of the other side and defending it ro be scarse a venial synne; fel to more outragious dealing then before, and among other things, they ioyned with the ialour, being an heretike, and by that meanes vexing and afflicting the other side extreamly both in word and deed wryting also diuers treateses with most vntemperate and furious woords, which are yet extant,D. Norden. vntil God stroke one of the cheefe actors in this kynd with a strange accident of repressing his tounge by dumnesse vntil he died.M. Ithel. Another of them plaid the Apostata, and made himselfe chaplayne to the B. of London, with whome he is to this day. Two more brake out of prison, but one was taken againe. To other passed to the better side, so as they remayning only 7. were yet so deuided among themselues as in the yeare 1597. one wryteth, that they did eat and take their diet in 4. seueral places,F Edm. in his letter to F. O. 1597. hauing notwithstanding first
driuen out of the common hal, by help of the ialour, the other part, though farre the greater.

In this sort then the matter standing,The discÅtented of VVisb ioyned vvith the discontent in France and Flaunde â¢ s. these imprisoned men ioyned presently with the relikes of the forsaid faction against the Cardinal and Iesuits, that were not only in England but in France also & Flanders, as appeareth by diuers lettres betwixt that place and Paris where now the cheefe of that faction were retyred, for that the Iesuits were driuen out, and the Cardinal dead; and to Flaunders they sent a special man, who had bin seditious,Robert Fisher Se his confessiÅ 8. Marc. 1598. and a greate dealer in the Roman stirs and was sent into England to mooue the like there, vnto whome they gaue both money and commission to deale with all heads and members of the foresaid faction, and by their aduise to publish an infamous memorial against the Iesuits conteyning many accusations of their doings in EnglÄd, and all this in respect of one only priest that was a Iesuite in the aduerse part.

These men also were the fitst, or with the first, who opposed themselues afterwards to the Archpriest, when his Hol. order came by letters of the Protector to appoynt him, and when after the same was confirmed by the Breue they weare the
first that appealed from it.As appeareth by the appeale. And lastly some of them are presumed to be principal doers in these last prynted libels especially the latyn, which is knowne to be wrytten the most part (if not all) by M. Bagshaw, as both the phrase it self and diuers particulars set downe therin (which are otherwayes extant vnder his hand) do testifie; as also diuers contemptuous insolent, and contumelious lettres wrytten to the Archpriest in name of 5. or six of them do sufficiently testifie,Se their letter 19. of Ian, 1601. his spirit to haue byn the author, which hauing byn tryed by experience, of all places where before he lyued, both in England and out of England, to be most turbulent; no maruaile though he had byn able now thus to shake and ouerthrowe the peace of a house that had no Superiour to pacifie or to correct (at least none that he wil acknowledge) and the temporal Superior that is, standeth wholy with him and for him in this behalfe to nourish this diuision and afflict the other part, that be constant and most exempelar confessors, by whose help he procured some dayes past (as is more then probable and seemeth most certaine) The forsaid good F. Edmund with the other ancient gentleman confessor before named; & some els; to be remoued from VVisbich
to the Tower of London with euident daungers of their lyues. And what he and his compagnion, and their consorts in this faction haue negotiated of late with the B. of London, and other persecutors, both for the printing of these libels and other afflictions of good Catholikes, that mislike their doings, many men do feare & suspect, and tyme wil tel vs further.

This then is the true summe of all that which hath passed in the Castle of Wisbich for these 6. or 7. yeares since these people began to breake the peace, and to rayse tumults there. And now it would remayne, that we should go about to proue all these particulars, not only by the present relatiÅ sent vs from thÄce, testified by diuers graue men that haue seene the matters passe by their owne eyes as we haue said, but by other more ancient letters and wrytings also, wherof we haue good store, that came forth as the thinges themselues fel out. But for that it would be ouerlong to recyte thÄ at large in this short Apologie, we are resolued to reserue that to our second narration, and in this place shal only touch the cheefe heads of the proofes that we haue, putting as it were for a preface the first lynes of the forsaid relation, intituled. The
true ground of all the disquietnes of VVisbich, gathered and conferred this yeare 1601.

p.note: The sÅ«me of the narration sent from VVisbich and FraminghÄ 1601.
p.q:
In this narration they say, that after the death of the most reuerend L. B. of Lincolne, L. Abbot of VVestminster, and the rest of old Fathers, there liued in VVisbich Castle more then 33. prisoners, wherof two were lay men, the rest priests religious and secular in great quietnes, peace & loue with great edification to others, and spiritual profit to themselues good exercise of learning was practised, as disputing in controuersyes and cases of conscience, conferrence in scriptures and exhortation, studying also of the tongues both Hebrue and Greeke, but who was the Author and promotor of all these exercises but F. EdmÅ«d, who read the greeke and hebrue tongues, was moderator in disputations, and when straungers came was alwayes ready to comfort them, though it were vpon a suddaine, with his pious exhortations, & who were the cheefe actors or doers in these exercises, but such as loued F. Edmund and were directed by him, not any of those that since haue prooued factious; For although some few of them in the beginning came to those exercises, yet were they soone weary of wel doing, and the burthen of all did
ly vpon 6. or 7. special persons, who alwayes for his vertues honored F. Edmund.

div.p:
Hitherto are the words of the said relation, and this that followeth we do abridge, taking the cheefe poynts only for auoyding prolixity. They say then that all the company in that tyme of peace, hauing no special superiors, referred themselues & their affayres to the directiÅ of three men, who were F. Edmund, M. Metham, and M. Bluet, which last was in very good tune all the tyme that M. Metham lyued, for the great respect he bare vnto him, & that he shewed euer a special dislike of the behauiour of M. Bagshaw, for the vnquiet spirit he saw to be in him, and continual quarrels he had with euery man being informed also of the great garboyles he had raysed vp as wel in two colledges of Oxford, where he had liued,Baliol. colledg Glosterhal. as also in the Roman Colledge, from whence he had byn expulsed by the Protector Card. BoncÅpagno his owne hands. And that M. Metham had so great dislike of the mans restles, turbulÄt nature, as he said he had a wyndmil in his head, and was once determyned to haue cÅuented and shamed him before the whole company, if F. Edmund by his intercession had not letted it, yet that others (and namely M. Stranguige) seing no remedy how
to represse him by authority, procured against the opinion of many other, that he should be preferred to be one of the forsaid cheefe dealers, therby eyther to gaine or quiet him. But he was deceaued, for after he proued worse, and was so ful of braules with all men, as his ghostly Father being a quiet man was forced to giue him ouer. And at that tyme M. Bluet & he were greatly out; he reporting euery where in corners most contumeliously of M. Bluets hasty rude and fiery nature, and M. Bluet protesting that he would trounse him (for so were his woords) and this falling out grew to such excesse one day in a good priests chamber, that had byn long sicke, & liueth yet to testifie the same, that good F. Edmund was forced to fal vpÅ his knees, & with much intreaty made thÄ frÄds againe, but afterward M. Bluet lacking his old stay of M. Methams good counsel and falling into many impatient words and deeds dayly by age and wearisomnesse of so long imprisonment,The occasion of frÄship betvvene M. Bag. and M. Bluet. in so much as he would not only reuile and threaten men, but strike & beat them also, as occasion was offered. M. Bagsh. tooke this occasion to gaine the old man by flattering him exceedingly & excusing and defending his excesses, which good F. Edmund not being able to do in
conscience nor thinking it expedient for edificatiÅ of the house (though yet he bare also much) M. Bagsh. by these meanes grew in by litle and litle with M. Bluet, & set him quite out with F. Edmund which was the very beginning and foundation of all our spiritual miseryes and dissentions, for so much as hence forward F. Edmunds godly exhortations were contemned by them and theirs, yea M. Bagsh. would not only deryde them, but go about also to picke out matter of heresy against them. And consequently, the more he preached order and discipline and the like, the worse some men were, thinking it a comendation not to follow Iesuites doctrine or obseruatiÅs, which they went about by all meanes possible to bring in contempt.

This then beeing the cÅdition and state of that company it is easy to consider, what great disorders would presently ensue in life and conuersation, which yet is seene more particularly by a common letter of the better sort of priests, subscribed by eighteene hands, and wrytten in Ianuary in the yeare 1595. to F. VValley alias Garnet Superiour of the Iesuits in EnglÄd, wherin they request his helpe and counsel (hauing no lawful Superiour at that tyme of their owne, to whome for that purpose they
might make recourse) how they might best auoyd the greate inconueniences that ensued by this disorderly lyfe brought in by a few, and preuent the great scandal that was like to fal vpÅ the whole Catholike cause, by their publike discredit, yf spedy remedy were not taken, for that the heretikes eyes were bent vpon them, and would not lese their aduantage therin, if matters passed forward as they did.

And for more perspicuityes sake, they deduced all their disorders to ten principal members, disguising notwithstanding their speech by general tearmes, least it might fal into the enimyes hands; & touching no man in particular. The first wherof was, in these woords:Ten heads of disorder in VVisbich brought in by seditiÅ. Otium & languor, atque Ã bonis studijs, & virtutum exercitijs magna cessatio: Idlenes and lasynes, & a great ceasing from good study and exercise of vertue. The second was: Quotidianae rixae, iurgia, &c. daylie brauling, chiding, cÅtumelious slÄders, &c. The third: Pugnae & vsque ad sanguinis effusionem, dimicati â¢ nes, fighting among themselues, and buffeting euen to the effusion of bloud, &c. Then followed Clerico â¢ um percussiones pro leut aestimatae. Beating of priests litle esteemed or rather defended. And then againe: Conuiuia, commessationes, compotationes, &c. Banqueting, eating, cÅpotatiÅ, &c.
and so passed they forward vnto ten heads of different disorders, or euident suspitions and perils therof, which for breuities sake we omit.

Now then matters standing in this case, we aske euery good and indifferent man, desyrous to saue his soule and to be out of these broyles, what he should do in this case, if he had byn in it. For as for Superior there was none to make recourse vnto but heretikes, that would laughe at it, and comend th â¢ worse part; and for priuate admonitioâª or exhortation they were not capable of it, but rather more incensed, and more resolute to be reuenged, eyther by way of the ialour, with whome they could do all, or by their owne hands. So as when M. VVigges an auncient master of art, and priest,This is tetified by the former vvryten relation frÅ VVisbich this yeare 1601. spoke but one word in misliking of certayne ouer hard speaches and dealings of M. Bluet, towards M. Ithel another priest, he was beaten twise by the said M. Bluets fist, as all can testifie that were then present: so saith the relation.

The only way then which those good men could thinke of for auoyding the inconueniences a foresaid was to make certayne rules of honest and ciuil conuersatiÅ among themselues with some head or director for better obseruing therof which
they desyred might be the forsaid F. Edmund; and so with all their voyces agreing togeather, they elected him, but he vtterly refusing the same, they made recourse vnto his Superior by a comon letter in latyn, subscribed with all their hands, which beginneth thus:The letter of 18. priests to F. Gard. 7. Feb. 1595. Contulimus inter nos ab heri & medius tertius (venerande Pater ac frater) de meliori disciplina, propter ea quae emerserunt apud nos intra septennium, vel mala, vel species mali, vel aperta scandala, &c. VVe haue conferred among our selues these dayes past (venerable Father and brother) how to bring in some better discipline for auoyding of these euils, or appearance of euils, or open scandals, that haue fallen out among vs within these 7. yeares, or at least wayes to auoyd the peril of such scandals. And truly we do not find our iustice to be such, nor our lyfe so inculpable (would to God it were) as we may securely rest our selues vpon that confidence of Saynts, lex non est posita iustis. Lawes are not laid vpon iust men, but rather beeing taught by experience for our owne weaknes, by the euÄt of diuers great incÅueniences, emulamur legem, we do emulate and desyre to haue a law, & quidem legis animam ipsam iudicem, vindicem, censorem; we desyre not only a law to be bound vnto for direction of our lyfe, but the life or soule it
selfe of the lawe, that is a iudge, a corrector and censurer ouer vs. And whome thinke yow, do we desire for this? Your Edmund only or rather ours, &c.

This and much more they wryte in that letter alleadging many reasons of their demaund, and how that F. Edmund had wholy refused, and could not be persuaded vnto it, but yet that without his yeilding therin eyther by entreaty or commandement, it was impossible for them to liue in any quiet or security of conscience. And to this petition were subscribed 18. hands all secular priests to wit.

Vnto this most earnest petitiÅ F. Garnet after some dayes deliberation and comending the matter to God yeilded, with those restraynts, which before haue byn specified that he should neither be, nor be called Superior, or haue any place power or authority
aboue the rest, but only to direct them, not knowing or suspecting at that tyme (as after he protested by letters to D. Bagsh. himselfe, and to his General in Rome, to whome he wrote therof, and sent this petition of the priests) that any offence would be taken hereof or any such broyle made about it, as after ensued; but rather that by litle and litle all would be of this Society or Academy and liue vnder rule, when they should see the sweetnes and decentnesse of it, as in other places it fel out dayly.

But on the other side this reformation being taken as iniurious to them, did by all meanes seeke to discredit and calumniate this holy and quiet purpose of their fellowes, especially the Doctor, who spared not his pen in dilating this argumÄt to his purpose. For wryting to a certayne frend of his soone after the new orders were appoynted he sayth thus:The cÅtumelious vvryting of D. B. of the rules for ciuil life & conuersation in VVisbich 1595. Among vs there is made (as some call it) a separation, or (as others thinke and feare) a schisme, vnder pretence of making a new common wealth, cum meliori disciplina. The forme therof is popular, the worst of all other, wherin any one is as good as another, and commonly the worst (things passing by factiÅ of voyces) better then the best. A forme of any thing we can learne or heare without example in the habitable world,
except the Cynedrical cÅgregations of Geneua, and the like. And therfore (belike) to make a shew of a Monarchie or mixt common welth of all the multitude, one is made an Agent with certaine vncertaine assistants, an vnvsual fornisecal and prophane name, smelling of nouelty, and farre vnfit for the contemplatiue quiet of imprisoned Catholikes.

Thus he beginneth his letter, and is very long, infarced euery where with very contumelious speeches and malitious interpretations of the playne and simple meaning of his brethren priests, by which yow may discouer much his mynd and spirit. And among other poynts he censureth F. Garnets restraint and limitation of F. Edm authority before named (which rather in reason he should haue commended) in these wotds: For regard of some whome he doubted eyther to mislike, or not to be priuy to this conceyted Agency, or that humility in him, and the Agent his inferiour at least might appeare, the authority of the Agent was limited by him to be but a meere direction to others, without any power in himself, and he confusedly permitted to the arbitrement of the multitude, Consider his head that findeth out so many creekes in a â¢ laine highe vvay. so that it is very doubtful and intricate, and diuersly debated & sentÄced, whether the multitude be aboue the AgÄt, or the AgÄt aboue the multitude, & it would require an Oedipus to extricate vs from that circularity wherin vertigiuous heads may inuolue themselues,
from the Agent to his Superior, from his Superior to the multitude, from the multitude to the Agent.

Lo heere what difficultyes this man hath found in the obseruation of a few, breefe, playne and easy rules for praying, studying, going to litanyes, quiet conuersation, peaceable meeting in thier refectory, reading at the table conference of learning, going to bed and rysing with some order, & other such like. VVho doth not see rhe mans nature and condition by seeking out those knottes in so smoth a rushe? But he goeth further then this, for as they wryte from wisbich that he was wont to bragge among them in tyme of peace, that when he would vex any ministers in Oxford, he drew their ordinary faults to felony, and afterward falling out with F. Edm, and others, he sought alwayes to wrest their words to heresy.Malitious maner of dealing in the Doct. So here now remembring that clause of the heretical Statute and oath against spiritual authority & iurisdiction of the Pope, expressed in the words: Forrayne authority and external iurisdiction, he goeth about to draw therunto this Agency of F. Edm. for that he dependeth perhaps of a forrayne Superior, that is, of his General in Rome, as he doth also afterward draw to like daunger or calumniation of forraine Iurisdiction,
the authority of the Archepriest comming from his Hol. and therfore he saith here immediatly after the former words: I wil suppose, we might safely admit such forraine authority, I wil not cast any daunger or difficulty in sending or resending letters I wil not accuse any of our selues to haue Italianated humors and idle heads, &c. Do yow see heere that he would bring men within the compasse of the statute of Premunire or treason, for admitting a few rules made by themselues for more orderly conuersation? wherof I see no other reason or pretÄce, except it be that which we haue now said; for that F. Edm. the director hath a Superior in Rome: who would beleeue that paission could carry men to such extremityes.

But yet it is more wonderful to consider his cauilling at the very lawes and rules themselues first in general and then in particular, wherby yow may see his humour who talketh so much of Italianated humors he hauing byn also himselfe in Italy & dismissed thÄce as yow haue hard for his ouer troublesome English humors.

Thus he wryteth of the rules in general.D. B. His egredious cauillations at the rules. The lawes of this common welth to which euery free denizen at his infranchising must subscribe, before witnes, do not only in themselues
want the qualityes of good lawes, which ought to be honest, iust, possible, according to the nature and custome of the countrey, fit for the tyme, and place, &c. But are ful of absurdityes and contradictions, the causes of them are most wicked, idle surmises, and vncharitable, suspitions, &c.

And this in general which yet is spoken without all groÅ«d for in the rules there is no mention of any such matter, but are most modestly and charitably wrytten, nor can he (comming to the particular) find any least ground, wherby to giue colour to these calumniations, as yow shal heare by his owne words: For thus it followeth in him immediatly.

In particular (sayth he) after a preface of fayre general tearmes vsual to the very worst deuises that euer haue bin, And to the best also. there is in the first and second lawes a stopping of reprehentions, contradictions and iudgments concerning this new platforme. And in the second law the maker could no longer hold, but to ease his mynd and shew his greefe and descrie his end, must needs promulgate, that euery one besides him which should say grace, A very heynous offence for priests to sit at table as they come. and by that title sit highest, should sit promiscuously, a thing not practised in any orderly place in the world, a disgrace to all degrees of learning, And fit for Anabaptists, a seditious mutiny and confusion against the seueral orders of the church, a contempt of Reuerend age, and therfore to be left
to the reuiued Arrians, whose saying that is, nostra secta nÅ curat canos: a bayte to draw inferior men by hope of a shew of eminency now and then, which otherwise by their place and perhaps desert should comonly be obscure, and therfore a necessary cause of diuision against those which would not consent to such absurd inouations.

Thus and much more he reueleth vpon this poynt. And consider we pray yow the mans, talent in picking quarrels, and setting debate, in that he can find so greate inconueniences absurdities and so heynous crimes in priests siting at table as they come, which is vsed in al modest and regular congregations in the world, and all this styrre to make roome to his Doctorship, which God knoweth in what corner of the world he gate it, and how worthily; but certaine it is, as farre as we are informed, by ordinary comendation of his superiours he had it not; And this being the greatest quarrel or inconuenience that he could finde in all these rules, to wit, that priests should sit promiscuously at table as they came, yet doubting least men would laugh at it, he seeketh an other quarrel, as though it were an vnworthie thinge for men of his dignity, and his fellowes to be limited to any rule at all though neuer so willingly taken vpon thÄselues. To which
effect he goeth forward with a supposal, saying.A lofty cÅsideration of the Doctor fraught vvith pride and vanity. And were there no inconuenience in these lawes, yet the indignity of them, is much to be wayed, for what can be greater then to make priests sent with more then ordinary or episcopal authority to be tyed to the pleasure of such as be not their Superiors and to be prescribed by the orders of others, who should be better occupied in ordering themselues, &c.

Lo heere vanity, pride and emulation, which are the very grounds of all these styrres. His meaning is that these orders come from the Fathers of the Society who comonly do labour euery where to bring in good orders. But in this poynt there are extant diuers letters both of F. Edm. him selfe vnto his General in Rome and to F. Oliuerius Manarreus in Flaunders, and of F. Garnet as wel to the said General as to M. Bagsh. himselfe, wherin they testifye, that these rules came not of them, but of the priests themselues, which being modest and moderate, and not made for religious men but for laudable cÅuersation of Secular priests, no man was forced vnto them, but he that would; and none condemned or iniured that would not:The letter of F. Edm. to F. General Claud. Aquau. 27. Marc. 1598. Omnibus visum est vtile consilium (sayth F. Edm.) It seemed a profitable councel to all those good priests to appoynt to themselues a certaine forme of lyuing,
not for necessity, but for good order and edifications sake, wherfore a most easy and breefer rule was agreed vpon, all did like of it, al did subscribe, none were excluded, but all were admitted that would, neyther were any condemned that would not, but euery mÄ left to this owne liberty without constraynt, impulsion or preiudice to any.

Thus wryteth that good man & much more (for his letter is large) confirming all those poynts that before we haue touched both of the outragiÅs speches of M. Bagsh. calling him and the rest Anabaptistes, Donatists, reuiued Arrians, Cynedrical Geneuian congregations, and the like, for their resolution in this behalfe to admit rules and order, as also he mentioneth the peace afterwards made, with the breaking forth againe with more violence then before, M. Nordens vntemperate disputations with M. Archer a priest; about the permission of dishonest women in Rome, and in other cÅmon welthes, whether it be a toleration only, or also an approbation: Moreouer of the dreadful death of the said NordÄ,27. March 1598. & other points before mencioned, which very poynts the said F. wrote also by another large letter of the same date to the forsaid F. Oliuerius in Flaunders.

F. Garnet also in his letter of the 8. of September 1595. to M. Bagshaw professeth
that he was not the Author, nor yet counselour of the former seperation in VVisbich, though if he had byn in the sense there set downe, which was nothing els but to counsel them, to liue more reclaymedly, and with lesse clamors he sayth it had byn iustifiable by more reasons of spirit & good order then any man of a good spirit can impugne,F. Garn. letter to M. Bag. 8. Sept. 1595. in ansvvere of his of the 27 of August. but yet he denyeth that he was the author. Separationis vestrae author nÅ fui (sayth he) nÅ cÅsultor, nÅ approbator, &c. I was neyther author, consultor, nor aprouer of your separatiÅ.
