For proof wherof, I cal to witnes not only my owne letters to your cÅpany, but theirs also to me, & the most grauest priests amÅg yow who without asking cÅcel or approbatiÅ of me, after mature deliberation among themselues did determine most firmely to haue rules and liue in order, and of me they required only that I should yeild them F. Edmund to be their Superior and iudge of their controuersyes, chosen therunto, as they wryte by all and euery one of their voyces, but yet he most constantly denying to take the same vpon him, which I granted vnto them at the end, though not that he should be eyther Superior or head, or iudge or rector, but only as a regular man amongst them, that would liue in rule, and as an obseruant man of discipline
among them that desyred discipline, that he should be first in labour & paynes and watchful for the comodityes of all; and if yow wil haue it so, that he might be a spiritual father to such as desyred to be his children, &c. This was all I graunted, and for this I hope with equal iudges I shal not be condemned of any great fault or wickednesse.

This and much more wryteth the said Father to M. Bagshaw, which for breuity wee passe ouer, & many other letters, which wee might heere recyte, and wil come to speake breefly of the peace and compositiÅ made among them by two priests assisted with the letters of F. Garner,F. Garn. concurrÄce to the making of peace in VVisbich. who hauing wrytten very effectually both to all the cÅpany in general, and to F. Edmund in particular, that they should by one way or other make an ende of this controuersy; the issue was, that the better part were content, so that some forme of discipline & good order might be kept, whervpon all the former rules being layd a side and abolished, there were new made by consent of both parts, to which all subscribed, leauing two authentical copies the one with the one side, and the other with the other, which two sides were now made one, and all revnited with great ioy and consolatiÅ:
And that the better sort meant playnly and sincerely and from their very harts, appeareth by a very spiritual letter of theirs wrytten to F. Garn. with the 18. hands, before mentioned, subscribed vnto it, the very same day that the peace was made, wherin they shew their great ioy and contentment, the aboundance of teares which they shed, and other like circumstances, and among other things they say thus: Scandalum (quale fuit) generauit disciplinam, The letters of the quiet part in VVisb. to F. Garn. for the peace made 8. Nou. 1595. & seperatio mensae, concepit vnitatem, & perturbatis ordinibus enixa est tandem discordia pacem, &c. This scandal (such as it was) hath engendered discipline, and our separation from the table, hath conceyued vnity of harts, and discord by troubling of all orders, hath brought forth at length peace, &c.

Thus they say wherby we may see, that these mens meaning was only to haue some order and discipline. The otherside also wrote to the same effect, and especially M. Bagsh. in the name of the rest, whose letter beginneth thus:M. Bag. letter to F. G. 8. Nou. 1595. Vidi fratrum meorum ad te (Reuerende Pater) scriptas literas plenas gratijs, gratulationibus, gaudijs, &c. I haue seene the letters of my brethren vnto you (ReuerÄd Father) ful of thanks, gratulation, ioy, nor do I thinke myne lesse needful, for that they haue wrytten, but rather more, &c.
and then after some narration he addeth: Gratulor tibi preces pro nobis effusas, litteras sollicitudinis, synceritatis, charitatis plenas, &c. gratulor tibi Edmundum nostrum qui in hoc negotio componendo, If this be true, then are they great slaunderers he vvryteth of him aftervvard, in the latyy booke pag. 14. 15. 16. & 17. & obedienter erga te & amanter erga fratres, & propter ea, quae foris sunt, prudenter se gessit, &c. I do congratulate vnto yow, the prayers which yow haue made for vs, your letters ful of sollicitude sincerity and charity, &c. I do congratulate vnto yow our F. Edmund, who in composing this busines hath behaued himself both obediently towards yow and louingly towards his brethren, and prudently towards them that liued abroad, &c.

M. Mush also wrote at the same tyme a very kynd letter to F. Garnet,M. Mush. and M. Dudl. to F. G. 8. Nou. 1505. in his owne and M. Dudleys name, which is yet extant vnder his owne hand and beginneth thus: VVe hauing now ended all these contentions, &c. He goeth on thus: The mortal enimy is ouercome and driuen away and a perfect reconciliation of harts is made, and we two your owne children and seruants greatly reioyce, and thinke our selues exceedingly bound vnto yow, in that yow so willingly imployd vs againe in this affayre, and concurred and assisted vs so sincerely by your sweet letters, wherby we assure you the most of our difficultyes were remooued, &c.
And no doubt the victory had not byn gotten, vnlesse yow on the mountayne had feruently lifted vp your hands to heauen, and assisted with the charitable fellowshyp of deuout brethren and frends;Consider hovv contrary this is to that they vvryte in these later libels. your owne good desyres, and our endeauors, with most zealous prayer, and clamors to God, and his triumphant saints in the celebration of their comon feast, good newes therfore yow receyue, the blessed fruite of your blessed desyres and paynes.

These were his words at that tyme, which yf they be true, then are many other things very vntrue, which appeare vnder his name in these late libels, for that they are quite contrary to these. And wheras heere in this letter, he maketh a very earnest and spiritual exhortation to peace and vnion, shewing the great and damnable daungers, that ensue of the contrary, now he seemeth to haue forgotten that, by his later doings and wrytings, in these libels, tending expresly to manifest sedition. The note wherof, and of his vnconstancy herin, must needs be greuous to al his frends. M. Bag. also contradicteth himselfe notoriously in this letter, for if it be true that he wryteth a litle before of F. Edmund that he behaued himselfe so wel in making of this peace; with what
truth or modesty can he tel all the world now in print,Lib. la. pa. 20. that Father Edmund was so vnwilling to do it that he sayd he would rather cast himselfe downe from the Castle wals, and that he was so astonished by the very treaty therof, as he was mute, and besides himselfe: and this calumniation being come to the eares of those of VVisbich, they do exclame vpon it, as a most iniurious and notarious ly, as by their late wrytten relation appeareth.

The same relation also doth vtterly condemne the false accusations, layd vpon M. Archer a venerable priest (whome since they haue caused to be put into the Inquisition of the Tower of Londen) as though he should haue said that Lupanaria Roma approbantur, &c. and other such fond and absurd propositions, which they haue fayned against him and set downe in their latyn booke which (as we are informed) he neuer said, but this rather that at a certayne tyme hearing M. Norden say that toleration could not be without approbation, vsed this argument ad hominem to confute him ergo Lupanaria Romae approbantur, quia tollerantur. VVhich instance, the other being not able to answere, tooke an occasion of large calumniation, set on and egged by M. Bagsh against the said priest. And for that F. Edm. would haue ended
the matter by explicating the priests meaning, both doctors tooke also against him, as they would haue wryten whole bookes and treateses therof, had not God taken vp the controuersy, by cutting of M. Norden strangely; as before hath bin said.

But now there remayneth only to say a word or two how this peace being once so solemnly made was broken againe. The cause I haue noted before for that they would be vnder no rule: and the present relation of VVisbich,The true cause of the breach in VVisb. after the peace making. seteth it downe in these words: D. Norden (say they) hauing, bin mulcted oftentymes by force of the rules, for his fowle tonge, and lastly desiring to see the Authentical Copye which was in the hands of the better part: when he had got them into his fingers (notwithstanding he had promised vpon his word to restore them faithfully) he ranne away with them to D. Bagshawes chamber, and so after they could neuer be put in vre againe.

The relation of R. Fisher vpÅ his oath about the nevv breach in VVisb.This reporteth that relation, but Rob. Fisher that had byn one of the cheefe troublesome in Rome and afterward much imployed by thÄ in EnglÄd or els where, in fauour of their faction, he coming afterward to Rome, and being examyned by the Popes Fiscal, vpon his oath, he tould this tale somwhat more largely, to wit. That when M. Bagsh. and his part, were
weary of the said new rules, they fayned an occasion of doubt whether M. Thomae Pound his name, were in the original or noe, which being shewed, M. Norden snatched the same,Se the examination of R. Fish. 12. March 1595. and would not restore it, saying: Iam lex nostra in manibus nostris, now our law is in our owne hand, & then (sayth he) they sent me into the north Countrey to M. Mush and M. Dudley that they should burne or deface the originals, &c. And then these rules being cast aside, discord began to grow daylie more and more, and I both saw and hard many things, vnworthy of their calling. But those of the part of M. Bagshaw did seeme to beare themselues much more insolently, both in words & deeds, then the other side.

Thus he sayeth with a long narration of particularityes, which I omit, or rather remit vnto our other Apologie. The principal points are that he saw such disorderly behauiour in that side, which he fauored, and conuersed with all, that he began to doubt what to say or thinke of their cause. For he saw them so familiar and in credit with the Ialour and his wife, such banqueting, such scoffing, and inuectiue speech against the other side (with whome they would not suffer him to treat at all) as he was litle edified therby, and
began greatly to doubt. And of the other side he saith, that by their countenance and behauiour, they seemed much more humble, quiet, deuout, and mortified then the rest. And further he saith that once among other tymes, he walking in the court with some of both sides togeather, he saw M. Norden speake twise or thrise in the eare of M. Christopher Southworth (a graue priest & knights sÅne) wherwith he seemed to be somwhat mooued, but had noe remedy, because no other man hard it; but afterward M. Norden told both Fisher and others in the presence of D. Bagsh that he had called him knaue, and arrant knaue in his eare wherat they laughed merily. which is not discrepant from the complaynt of another priest, wrytten from VVisbich the same yeare, who testifieth that the same Reuerend and worshipful priest was called knaue,M. I. G. the 14. Iuly. 1598. & Montebanck, by one of the said two Doctors in the presence of two priests come from abroad, for that he had giuen good and spiritual councel which was deryded. And the like liuery of knaue was giuen to an other priest by one of the Doctors followers, as an ordinary liuery vsed to be giuen by them.

Thus reporteth Fisher in his answere
ministred to him in these words: Quid sentiret in conscientia & coram Deo & sub iuramÄto iam praestito de vtriusque partis hominibus & rebus. VVhat he thought in conscience and before God and vnder his oath already taken of the men and affaires of both sides in VVisbich, and after confirmed all with these woords: Ego R. Fish. ita dico, iuro & ratifico. And all this is confirmed againe by the subscription of his Hol. officier. Ego Acharitius squarsionius, &c. VVhich we do ad for more credit of the matter, & for that we are to cyte diuers things out of this confession of Fisher in the chapters following. This last relation also of VVisbich hath one thing touching the good fellowship of those of the Doct. side, wherby may be discerned their disposition, and this is: that when M Mush came to make the peace, he being led about saith the relation to see the orders of this lesser nÅ«ber, was shewed 6. or 7. butteries for 13. persons they not suffering the 20. to haue any. And further the party that directed him, after he had shewed him all these, he brought him to a chimney where also there was good ale, and said here is an other buttery, nay said M. Mush there is the diuel, wherof that place was called afterwards me â¢ ily by some; the diuel in a corner.

By this then it is easy to see how and why began againe the new breach betweene men of different spirits and dispositions which breach hath continued vntil this day from worse to worse. And albeit now they are not aboue 5. or 6. at the most yet by their obstinacy, fauour of the councel, help and assistance of the Ialour, they do afflict and keep vnder all the rest which are not of their humors, and do seeme to be the heads and cheefe abetters of all this later sedition in England, and especially against the Archpriest, to whome as the other side of their fellowes did presently yeild obedience at the first comming of the Card. lettres,The ready submission of the good in VVisbich to the â¢ opes ordination to the Archp. 31. Sep. 1598. Se their appellation of VVisbich. as appeareth by an instrument vnder their owne hand and of the last of Septemb. 1598. subscribed by 19. hands: so these other were of the first that rebelled against him vpÅ the Cardinals letters and the first that appealed from him after he was confirmed by this Hol. Breue, and these most insolent of all others that haue wrytten contumelious letters vnto him,Se the letter of D. B. and his party to the Arch 19. Ian. this yere 1601. in one of which they accuse him without all modesty or ground of truth (where he had wrytten to them that he knew no greeuances giuen by him except good summes of mony in almes) that he had sent ouer into FlaÅ«ders aboue 2200. poÅ«ds gathered
in almes without sending any portion therof to them, which the Q. officiers meting withal got the same by confiscation, a matter deuised without any truth in the world and much vnworthy the modesty & christian humility that ought to be in cÅfessors of Christ towarde their lawful Superior. But all this is thought to come principally & originally from the restlesse humour of one man before mentioned, whome the late relation sent from VVisbich, calleth the very author, promoter, and practiser of all sedition, which both his former life and present actions seeme much to confirme, especially by these later libels,The hur t done by D. Bag. in VVisb. if he were the principal man in wryting and setting them forward, as is commonly beleeued (at least wayes for a great part of them it seemeth certayne) and the very last cÅtumelious letter that we haue seene wryten to the Archepriest and signed with his and some other handes (by his induction as is presumed himselfe beeing first in the number) there is exceding great excesse of vndutiful spech and besides other oprobrious tearmes in the wryting it selfe, they subscribe thus. Vincti Christi peripsema tuum. A cÅtemptuous letter of the troublesome in VVisb. to the Archp. 1601. VVe imprisoned for Christ, but your outcasts (a most vndecent subscription for subiects to their Superior) this we say is
presumed to haue come only or principally of M Bagsh spirit, for that we cannot thinke so vnreuerently of some others following him in subscribing their names to that letter as they would euer haue invented such a subscription of them selues, nor indeed should neuer haue yelded for their credits sake, to such a thing inuented or wryten by another. But here, to our greefe,Psalm. 17. Ecccesia. 13 we remember the saying of the holy ghost: cum sancto sanctus eris, & cum peruerso peruerteris. It is a hard thing to touch pitch and not be defiled (as the scripture sayth) or to conuerse much with a peruers spirite, and not to receaue hurt or peruersity therby. VVe beseech almighty God to giue him a better spirit, and to open his hert, and others by his example to see the dangerous and damnable course that is held in this maner of proceeding. And with this we end for this tyme our narration about the matters of VVisbich.

div.head: OF THE GENERAL troubles and disquietnes raised amongst English Catholikes in Flaunders and England during the former styrres in Rome and VVisbich: and how the one gaue hand to the other: and all proceeded from different members of the selfe same faction. CAP. VII.
div.p: IT hath byn often signified before how that the contradiction or faction opposite to Card. Allen and his frends, namely the Fathers of the Society, and others ioyned with them both of the Clergy and laytie (which contradiction began and continued for many yeres during the Cardinals lyfe, as in the first and fourth precedÄt chapters hath byn declared) this same presently vpon the Cardinals death brake forth ioyntly, and with much more violÄce then-before in many places at once, the one lending hands to the other, and conspiring to kindle or encrease this flame. And as for Rome and VVisbich two particular places, we haue now seene the beginning and progresse therof in the 5. and 6. Chapters. Now we are to relate breifly what passed more generally in Flaunders and England.

The beginninge of the trroubles in Flaund. Cap. 1. & 5.And for Flaunders it hath appeared by our antecedent relation, that from the yeare 1588. and 1589. when the heads of the opposition in Paris (wherof before mention hath byn made) by occasion of the warres in Fraunce or for other causes passed to liue in Bruxels, there was neuer quietnes during the Cardinals lyfe: for that there began presently the great and vniuersal plot against the Cardinal and all his,Cap. 4. appoynted for all courts christian and discouered by the forsaid letter of M. Morgan to the B. of Dumblayne, which before hath byn alleadged. And the very next yeare after to wit 1590. began the warre against F. Holt,Cap. 3. as one of the Cardinals principal frends and correspondents in Bruxelles. And this appeareth as wel by M. Ch. Pagets letter before alleadged, to F. Creswel of the 8. of August. 1590. as also by the same M. Pagets letters to the Cardinal himselfe, and his answere thervnto, which we haue cyted also before.Cap. 4. After this insued continual troubles and garboyles in that place; M. Morgan was layd in prison M. Hugh Owen was hurt, and besides that a certaine inquirye and secret inquisition was procured against him, M. Th. Fitzherbert was put also in peril by the false accusation of a condemned Frenchman. Poly and Moody,
two openly supected for spiery ran in and out betwene England and Flaunders D. Dethicke was discouered to haue wryten a letter to the L. Treasurer to be called into England to open great secrets by word of mouth. In which letter amongst other things was this:D. HÄ. Dethicks letter 21. NouÄb. 1590. to the Lord Treasurer. I could giue great reasons to prouo â¢ e the Q. Maiestie and your honors speedy sending for me, but this only may suffice that I wil aduenture my lyfe and loose the same if your honors paynes be not recompensed by my conference and speech, when I am present before your honors.

Moreouer Sir VVilliam Stanley being gone into Spayne, his whole regiment was set in diuision, but especially against F. Holt, one of their best frends both to themselues and their Colonel, wherof one wrote in those dayes thus:The letter of M. R. V. 12. Octob. 1591. to F. Cresvvel. F. Holt was heere two dayes past, &c. The malecontents of the Regiment do deale in speeches very iniuriously with him, farre vnfitting such as they would seeme to be, some haue not let to say, that it may be doubted, whether his intention and course be direct for the seruice of God and his cause, &c. God forgiue the suggestors, much deuise hath bin vsed to make the number concurre in one, vpon hope, that the greater multitude, would be more respected, then the equity of the matter, &c. There dealing towards M. Owen is little different in speeches, though otherwise in deedes somwhat
worse; as his late hurt may witnes, God send them more c â¢ arity towards thei â¢ frends, &c.

The troubles in Rome before the Cardinals death.And by this we may see partly the state of Flaunders, and that the very like troubles and diuisions were wrought at the same tyme by negotiation of some of the same instruments in Rome also, may appeare by a certaine letter, which we haue seene, from Sir Francis Inglefeild to the Rector of the same Colledge wrytten in the same yeare to whome he sayth thus:Sir F. Inglef. letter to F.C. 17 Aug. 1591. I do pray our Lord to giue yow fortitude of mynd and health of b â¢ dy to sustayne the ingrate persecutions which our Lord suf â¢ ereth to be layd on yow for yo â¢ r probatiÅ, & increase of merit, & that they do not â¢ cary nor tyre yow in drawing the plow which he hath put to be houlden by your handes. Diuers are the crosses and a â¢ flictions of this l â¢ fe, and these sem â¢ ng designed to be yours by Gods ordinÄce take comfort therin for our Lordes loue, & laughe to scorne the malice of the diuel & peeuish temptations of his instrumens, and thanke our Lord highly for the same, since all â¢ il proue glorious vnto yow in his sight, & honorable also in the sight of wisemen in the world, &c.

Troubles in EnglÄd. The Card. letter to M. Mush 16. March 1594.And thus passed ouer matters vntil the Cardinals death an. 1594. In which very yeare, as before hath bin noted this sedition and emulatiÅ was brought on so farre also in England, as his grace was forced to
wryte an earnest letter there about which before we haue cyted in the fourth chapter, whereby it is euident that these matters were in brewing, yea set on foot long before the Cardinals death, though after his descease, they attempted matters more openly, and without restraint, and namely in Flaunders (wherof now we handle) as appereth by diuers memorials exhibited soone after,The mem. of M Ch. Pag. & his frends to the B. of Cassano 9. Sept. 1595. and among other one of M. Ch. Pag. and his frends against F. Holt, M. Owen and others, which we haue seene vnder his owne hand, wrytten to the B. of Cassano the 9. of September 1595. subscribed by 8. hands, wherin they say among other things: VVe vndernamed, thinke our selues bound, for discharge of our dutyes, towards God and his maiestie, and for procuring reformation of that which concerneth our countrey and nation so deep to addresse our selues hereby to your lordship and earnestly beseech the same as one who for his wisdome, experience and credit is sufficient, and for especial loue and affection towards vs do assure our selues wil be careful both in Rome, Spayne and heere to make knowne our gteefes and those disorders, and imploy such meanes for remedy herof as we may reap that fruite we desire, and your Lordsh. enioy that honor
that so worthy an act deserueth. And further we beseech your Lord that it wil please the same in Rome, as the person most fittest to ayd and assist vs in that which shal be for the good of the general,This is cÅforme to M. Morg. distributiÅ of nevv AgÄts mÄtioned before in the 4. Chapt. and our particular, and also to diuise that in Spaine and heere some may be placed with the Kings Ministers in credit, who may faythfully & truly as occasion serueth informe, &c.

By this memorial a man may eas â¢ ly see, what was purposed for placing of Agents in diuers courts to wit the same which M. Morg. six yeares before declared to the Bishop of Dumblayne. And that indeed this memorial to the B. of Cassano was but a preample to that which they were to attempt in Flaunders against Father Holt M. Owen and others, which appeareth also by the letter it selfe, which M. Pag. wrote togeather with his memorial to M. Thom. TrogmortÅ his correspÅdent then in Rome, wherin among many other things he saith thus;M. Pag. letter to M. Th. Trog. 22. SeptÄb. 1595. I must tel yow plainly that they cognotably; and if we do wel, we must open roundly and boldly our greefes to our Superiors, for our silence bredeth our condemnation, and increaseth their malitious boldnes. VVe haue wrytten to my Lo. of Cassano, by the which
yow may see, what it is we desyre. I keep the original, because it may be lost, & send the copy. I pray yow desyre his Lo. to answere the letter as if it were the original. If there be not order that it may be knowne, how the K. and his ministers here be abused, we shal euer liue in disgrace and greife, we meane, whÄ the Count Fuentes returneth, to open our greifes freely. I vnderstand by M. Th. Fitzherbert, that he saw a letter wrytten from Rome, how the schollers that haue styrred against their Superiors be put to pennance,The B. and schollers are egged on by this nevves. and that one of the principal causes of their motion was, that they would haue had my L. of Cass. as the Card. to haue dealt in their affayres, which his Hol. in no wyse would accord vnto, which is heere reported a great disgrace to my L. of Cassano, &c.

Thus he wrote and then after a dissuasion vsed that my L. of Cassano should not depart from Rome to his Bishoprike in Calabria (as it was reported he must) and that in no case M. Throg. should go with him, for that his stay in Rome imported more, then he could wel imagine he sayeth thus: yow shal leese therby a notable occasion to do your countrey good,This semeth some preferment secretlie procured. and perhaps your selues more then yow are aware of. I may not tel any particulars, but I hope before this
come to yow, yow shal heare in particular what it is I meane; vse your selues discretly and very secretly, &c. M. Owens matter hangeth in suspence til the Counte come; the commissioners be this day examining Bruse, who is in the same prison, wh â¢ re Moody is, &c. My Lo. of Cassano and yow must deuise that the Card. de Austria be informed,Sir F. Inglefield & others in Spaine discredited. that he take no heed of the informations giuen of the English in Spaine, for then he wilbe abused, &c. Yf by my L. of Cass. meanes the Embassadour of Spaine there might be mooued, that yow might be placed about the Card. in some honorable place, eyther of his chamber, which wilbe hard, or els to be as it were Secretary of the English & Scottish affaires, which were a dignity to make yow knowne, I could wish yow did come hither again, for so might yow be an instrumÄt to your frÄds and contreys good, &c.

By this and other poynts of his letter a man may easily perceaue, what was meant, and how the troublesome schollers in Roome were hartened also from Flanders. And soone after besides all former complaints and memorials, there came forth a most terrible one subscribed with 9 handes (for now, they had gotten one more to their former number) CÅtra Hugonem Oenum,
confederatos{que} eius, tam hic, Another mem. in Fland. to the nevv gouuernours after the Prince of Parma his death. quam in Hispania vitam degentes: against Hugh Owen and his confederats, liuing as well heere (in Flaunders) as in Spaine. And what were those confederats thinke yow, but the Cardinals cheefest frends while he was aliue, to wit St. Franc. Inglefield and other gentlemen in Spayne, St. VVilliam Stanley, M. Tho. Fitzhe â¢ bert, and others in Flanders, togeather with the Seminaries, Iesuits, and other cheefe of the Clea â¢ gie, yet did they oppose against him 11. Articles, as in the said memorial appeareth, bearing date the 28. of May 1596.

Two other particular memorials were exhibited with articles against F. Holt.Memorials against F. Holt. The first had eight articles, the other 30. partly touching himselfe and partly other men. VVhervnto the good F. answered with great meeknes and sincerity before Signor Giouan B â¢ ttistade Taxisâª now Embassadour for the K, of Spayne in France, Se the treatese in latin intituled: Articuli perquosdam Anglos imputati P. Gul. Holto & cum Responsit 1596 and F. Oliuerius Manarreus his Prouincial 22. of Decemb. 1596. & was with great cÅmÄd â¢ tiÅ declared free from all imputatiÅs; And this was testified by the Card Gouuernours owne letters extÄt to be seene, & this reward receyued that blessed man, at his cÅtreymÄs hands for all his labors and exceeding great paynes taken for them in those parts & els
where,P VVillis Hovvlts Deathe. which God the iust rewarder of all mÄ seeing tooke him from them to reward him in heauen. He died at Barcelona in Spaine in the yeare 1599. And one that went with him in that iourney and saw both his lyfe and death,The letter of Iohn Poole to F P the 19. of Maye 1599. and hauing had a hard opinion of him before by the said clamors of the factious, wrote such a pious relation of him after his death, as may much edify any man, and himself had neuer greater scruple in his lyfe, then for that he had conceaued so synistrously of so godly a man vpon other mens reports.

And wheras by continual clamors exclamatiÅs, infamations, suspicions, accusations, sinister interpretations of his doings (which is the arte that these men haue to vex and weary Gods seruants, and now do practise the same against F. Persons) they had filled all mens eares with infinite intemperate speches;Se an infinite company of most iniurious letters vvrittÄ against F. Holt by M Ch. Pag. DG. DH. V. T. and others. An. 1595. 96. & 97. vvhich are yet extant both in Engl. & latyn, and vve haue seene thÄ, & they do remayne for a lÅger narration. yet was the good man as quiet as if nothing had byn done or said against him. And being called away afterwards by his Superiors to be imployed more necessarylie in our contreyes good, he said merily to a frend of his (as we are credibly informed) that all this noice neuer awaked him nor let his sleepe. And wheras also while he was in Flanders, it was said and wrytten as wel to his Hol. and his general,
as to other great men, that his being there was the only cause of trouble and disagreement: The contrary hath appeared by his departure, for that no quietnes indeed could euer be amongst Engli â¢ hmen in Flanders, vntil those that were the true causes of troubles, retyred themselues to Paris whence, since that tyme, they haue giuen hands to all the discontented both in Engl â¢ nd and els where, and namely to such priests as by litle and litle, for one cause or other haue byn drawne to participate of their opposition and faction against the F. of the Society.

But as in the controuersy against F. Holt & others in Flanders,Se D. Barrets testimony vvith 7. other of the Seniors of that house of Dovvay 12. Nouemb. 1596. And another larg testim. of D. Stapl. D. Pearce D. VVorthingt. vvith 120. hÄds more out of Fland. 12. Decemb 1595. And many other from diuers other places, all crying out against these factious. these few had against them all the body of our Catholike nation, as by many memorials, testifications, & publike subscription of hands, of euery sort, order and community of English Catholikes doth appeare to this day; So fareth it now in England, where a very few at the beginning, partly vpon stomake, and auersion or rather discontentment, partly of ambition vnquietnes of spirit and desyre of contention (as by their doings may appeare) they began to oppose themselues against the whole streame of other Catholikes deuising particular wayes for their owne prefermÄt. And since that tyme haue
drawne in diuers others, one vpon one motiue, another vpon another, some for prefermentâª some for discontentment, some for other occasions to take their parts, & being once engaged, to leap with them from an inch to an ell; and from a litle slyde, to a headlong precipitation. And this is the true state of the question. Let vs declare breefly the way and path how they came into this pit.

VVe haue vnderstood by Cardinal Allens letters before mentioned, wryttÄ vnto M. Mush the yeare he died, how he had vnderstood of a certayne emulation & diuisiÅ begon in England by some priests against the F. of the Society,Hovv this last seditiÅ in England began. and perhaps he perceaued the same by no meanes more then by himselfe, his spech and behauiour while he was at Rome with him the very same yeare. For albeit this man gaue out euery where that he went to Rome to enter into that order,M. Mushes voiage to Rome. which many yeares before he had pretended, yet others that knew him better did soone discouer his alienation from them, and that he pretended perhaps by his iorney to Rome to get some other dignity. But returning into England, as he went forth, and the Cardinal soone after dying he ioyned with another of his owne humor,M. Iohn ColingtÅ. that had left another religion, namely
the Carthusians, and they two with some few other, determyned to make a certayne new Hierarchy of their owne, calling it an Association of Clergy-men with two Superiors as it were Archbishops the one for the South and the other for the North with certaine rules and deuises impossible to be obserued in England, whiles tymes and matters do remayne as they doe. But yet these men and a few other, that were the plotters, so busied themselues in this imagination of Superiority amÅg thÄselues with offices and dignityes therin designed, as they gaue molestation and matter of suspition to the rest of the priests, that were of quiet conuersation, all appearing to tend to trouble, ambition emulation and sedition.

But it shalbe better perhaps that we set downe this in the very words of six of our reuerend brethren priests Assistens of our most Reuerend Archpriest, who being required these moneths past by the Nuntius Apostolicus in Flanders to wryt vnto him the true causes of these stirs (especially of the late appellation from the Archpriest) with their iudgements & opinions therof, as also of the remedy, they answered him with great sincerity and modesty, first shewing the greefe they had in
wryting any thing touching their brethrÄ, and then excusing the matter what they might; they say thus.

The ansvvere of 6. AssistÄts to the NÅ«tius in FlÄders 2. of May 1601. Hebr. 11. VVe are forced to repeat some poynts past, some yeares gone for better vnderstanding the matter in hand. VVherfore first wheras no man ought to take honour to himselfe (as the Apostle saith) but he that is lawfully called therunto, as Aaron was, these our brethren that are now the cheefe among these appealers, being not contented as it semeth with their owne condition, but desiring higher estate, went about some 4. or 5. yeares gone, to make a certaine association or gouernmÄt among themselues, and this without any consent counsel or notice (so farre as we vnderstand) of any Superiors eyther from the Sea Apostolike or other wayes, and this to the preiudice of others, yea rhe most part of our brethren, reclayming & misliking the same as sauoring both of presumption and ambition, and they passed so farre in this matter, as they set forth certayne rules of this sodality which we haue in our hands vnder these Titles: of Rectors, Chapters of the nevv cÅstitutiÅs of the association. of Assistans, of the Secretary, of those that are to be admitted or expelled, of Residences, of Controuersies to be composed of geuing suffrages, of Appellations, of Obligations
and punishments, of keeping secret, and the like, and then they sent their messengers about to all ptiests to accept of these rules and to giue their names, and to adioyne themselues to this Association. Further more it was ordayned, that there should be two gouernours of this body, one in the South part of England, and the other in the North: yea these two taking themselues as it were named for Bishops did wryte two destinct formes of rules, each one for his owne prouince;Diuision follovveth presently vpon singularity. but this new kynd of gouernmÄt made among them selues, being established by the authority of no Superior but ministring infinite matter of emulatiÅ and contention, and impugned also by the most part, as a thing borne in hast, or before his tyme; it fel againe quickly: but then followeth another tÄpest, which was a most detestable memorial wryten and giuen vp to his Hol. in the name of the English Clergy,The mem. sent ouer by Fisher. against the fathers of the Societe, liuing in England, wherof who or how many were the authors, we cannot certainly say, but all men do suspect; that it came frÅ the same shop or forge (though secretly) which the former platforme of Association did. This infamous libel the most of all our secular ptiests not only denied
constantly to be theirs,The Priests vvrite in defence of the Iesuites in great store. but confuted also all, and euery article therin conteyned, and by their common letters to Cardinal Caetan our Protector, they deliuered these good Fathers from those vnworthie slaunders and calumniations.

Thus farre do relate the whole matter, these R. Brethren of ours. VVherin first we see, that the discontented which so much do mislike and reprehend the institution of an Archpriest ouer vs with Assistens by his Hol. order did notwithstanding like of Rectors and Assistants chosen of themselues without his Hol. yea without any mention made at all in their constitutions, that the same should be confirmed by his Hol. And in their chapter of appellations they decree thus:Rules of the North Cap. de Appel. That no appeale shalbe made f â¢ om the sentence of one company to them of another countrey, but all the brethren shal content themselues with the iudgement of the Fathers and Assistens, or more part of the company where he shal be, &c. So as there is no appeale left to Rome or other place for which yet they accuse the Archpriest (though without cause) that he would let or hinder now vnder his authoritie.M.B. contradiction to himselfe see cap. 6.

And moreouer M. Bag. discourse of indignityes before set downe for priests comming
with more then Episcopal authority to be tyed to rules, is heere checked, and his forrayne authority wheron he stood against the rules of VVisbich (if any be) is not heere stood vpon. So as we see, that the selfe same matters, or the very like comming from lawful Superiours and by orderly meanes, are reiected, and exclamed against, but coming neuer so disorderly from their owne inuentions and priuate diuises are magnified and imbraced; And this can worke, selfe-wil and loue of our selues.

Touching the detestable memorial heere mentioned drawne out and published against the Fathers of the Society,About the memor. brought ouer by Fish. 1597. at the very same tyme, when this association was in making, therby to discredit the said Fathers, against whome diuers good priests did suspect this Association in part to be deuised, it began thus: Breuis declaratio miserrimi status Catholicorum in Anglia. A breefe declaration of the miserable state of Catholikes in EnglÄd. And thÄ he putteth downe 11. sorts of calamityes and miseryes which Catholikes suffer, all at the Iesuits hands. The last two wherof (by which yow may iudge the rest) are these: That Iesuits do hate & contemne our vniuersity men of Oxford and Cambridge: & that Iesuits are more hurtful to Catholikes
then heretikes themselues. And for that we haue seene the former Assertion vnder M. Bag. owne hand giuen to M. Charnocke at his comming to Rome, and that Cardinal Sega in his preface of the Visitation doth testifie that some schollers had troubled the Roman Colledge about the yeares 84. and 85. &c. (at which tyme,Card Seg. in praef. Visitat. An. 16. & 96. if not somwhat before we vnderstand M. Bag. was dismissed thence for his troublesome spirit) with a certaine calumniation that Iesuites were no frends to vniuersity men, we ghesse that this article came from him, nay rather we are sure of it, for he gaue to the said M. Charnocke 11. points in so many lyues to be obiected in Rome against the Iesuits, which we haue yet vnder his owne hand, which poynts indeed are nothing els but these articles of Fishers memorial inlarged, and in some wordes & order altered,D. Bag. CalumniatiÅ about vniuersity mÄ â¢ efuted. for his last poynt is this: The special disgrace of graduats and vniuersity men. VVhich how euidÄtly false it is euery man seeth that considereth eyther the number of English vniuersity men which they haue or haue had, amongst them of their owne order in these dayes: as F. Heywood, F. Persons, F. Holt, F. Howlet, F. VVeston, F. Garnet, F. Cornelius, F. Blunt, F. VVarford and diuers others. Many also haue
liued in the Seminaryes with them most vertuously and with great edification, much esteemed and fauored by Iesuits, notwithstÄding they were vniuersity mÄ, as M. Sherwyn, M.D. Haddocke, M. Rishton, M. D. Barret and others in tymes past. And for the present, there are very many both vniuersity men and graduats of both vniuersityes in all the Seminaries, and are greatly made of by the Fathers, if their vertue answere to their degree. But if any man should be so turbulent, as this man sheweth himselfe in his former wryting, accusing men of Arrianisme Donatisme and other heresyes, for that they giue them not alwayes the higher end of the table (especially among priests, and diuers that are his auncients) no maruayle if such graduats be troublesome to Iesuits, that are men of otder.

And this might be sufficient for this whole matter which now we haue in hÄd, but only thar we thinke good to ad a litle more about this memorial of Rob. Fisher diuised by the seditious in EnglÄd and sent ouer to be dispersed,Of Fishers going into England & returne. and published by the forsaid Fisher, who hauing byn one of the most exorbitant disorderly fellowes in the Roman styrres was dismissed thence or rather sent away cunningly by the troublesome,
as by his and others confessions appeareth; partly to be rid of him, but espetially to rayse vp rumors in England, of whose proceedings and slaunderous tales divulged there against the Iesuits, whÄ many letteres had bin wryten out of England, at last he was sent backe againe in the yeare 1597. to Liege, at what tyme D. Barret lying at the Spaw for recouery of his health, and afterward comming to Liege wrote thus to Rome.

D. Bar. letter to F. P. 10. Aug. 1597. about R. Fisher.Very louing and reuerend Father, this I wryte at Liege, where I am in my way homeward. There passed by this towne one Fisher, that was sent by the seditious schollers into England, from hence he wÄt to Bruxelles, thence to Lisle, and so to Doway, and thence to Cambray. He hath bin as I am informed in euery shire in England to styrre vp men against Iesuits and Spaniards, which he vttered to a good man in this towne. I maruaile he escaped at Bruxels, seing they are aduertised out of England of his secret conference with a cheefe man of the councel of England & with Sacheuerel the Apostata in the said councelors house. Heere he tould one in great secret, that he was to go to M. Ch. Pa. and D. Gifford, and to M, Morgan about matters of importance, he said also that
they were in good hope to haue liberty of conscience in England in case they might get the Iesuits thence, no doubt this is one part of his busynes, he left his bag at Liege, and I haue seene it, yet nothing of importance therin,This note vvas rather brought out of England. As after vvil appeare. sauing a litle compendious note of all their Articles against the Iesuits at Rome which he carried with him to dilate to the faction in England as appeareth, for it is very old and almost worne out, I am to go to Bruxels and to make meanes to haue the man examined, in case he may be found; before he returne to this towne, for he is to come backe hither, & to one in this place, he was at his going into England earnestly commended by D. Gifford, &c.

Thus much wrote D. Barret from Liege of Fishers comming out of England; and soone after appeared in Rome against the Fathers in England the infamous memorial before mentioned, and one copy was sent to a great man by D. Hugh Grifith Prouost of Cambray and nephew to my Lord of Cassano, and a principal doer in all these stirres and troubles while he liued; as the world knoweth, &c. in whose howse the forsaid memorial was wryten as after wil appeare. And some monthes after that againe, went to Rome Rob.
Fisher himselfe more then halfe conuerted (as he said) vpon the experience he had had of the bad and vnconcionable dealing of the factiÅs euery where.Fish going to Rome & his examination there. VVhervpon his Hol. being informed by the Protector, that he was arriued and had willingly offered himselfe at the Fnglish colledge gaue order to his foresaid officer Signeur Acaritius to examine him, which examination beginneth thus: Examen Rob. Fisheri in choatum die 8. Martij per R. D. AcaritiÅ« visitationis Apostolicae Fiscalem ex CÅmissione S. D. N. &c. The heades of Fishers examynation. VVhich examination endured for diuers dayes and euery dayes examinatiÅ is set downe distinctly, wherin his education, countrey, study, his comming to Rome, and departure from thÄce and such other points as those officers are wont to make their interrogatories of are set downe, not necessary here to be handled, but in general we may say that his narration conteyned a long and particular declaration, of the beginning, progresse, causes, authors, agents, participants, & fauorers of all these troubles that he had bin in, both in Rome, Flaunders, and England, with whome he had bin or dealt most in Flaunders who did help and animate him to go into England, or commend him thither, and to whome, who
gaue him money for his iourneys and the like. And albeit we wil not affirme all to be true which he said, yet many things are such as they could not be wel fained and are confirmed otherwise, and the speaking voluntarily vpon his oath must be presumed to haue had some care also of his conscience, &c.

The whole examination is to long to sett downe heere contayning a good number of sheets of paper & therfore we reserue it to our larger Apology, if need shalbe, yet shal wee touch a poynt or two as he sitteth thÄ downe:Fishers narration.
Being at London (saith he) I went to the Castle of VVisbich, and asking of the porter to speake with M. Doctor Bagshaw, presently without difficulty I was brought vnto him, who after I had tould him in secret my true name,In examine Fisher â¢ 11. Matt. 1597. fol. 30. he embraced me, and said it was wel that I asked for him for if I had asked to speake with F. Edmond the Iesuite or any of his part I might chance to haue byn taken and sent backe to London, as it happened to one of late, wherby I vnderstood the Doctor to be in fauour with the keeper, as himselfe tould me afterward more cleerly, and that there were two factions amonge the prisoners one sticking to the said Father Edmond (which after he vnderstood
was much the greater) and another ioyned to him, whervnto the keeper did also fauour,D. B. f â¢ miliarity vvith the keper. and did vse so much confidence with the Doctor as he conferred with him the letters that came from the councel, which happened also once, when I was there for that being inuited to a banquet by those of his side (wherin I remember we had a swan among other meats) the keper came in and said laughing, what so many papists togeather? and so departed, and D. Bag. could not be at dinner with vs for that he was busy with the Keeper consulting about a letter come from the Councel as himselfe tould vs when afterwards he came to vs. The keepers name was Medley, and is said to be kin to Secr. Cecil, and a very earnest heretike, yet made so frÄdly to me by conuersation as albeit he knew me to be a Catholike, and both saw and spake with me diuers tymes in London, yet did he me no hurt, but rather being taken once by chÄce, I was deliuered againe by the procuremÄt of his seruant.

p.q:
But after I had proposed to D. Bag. & to those of his part (for they would suffer me to speake with none of the other) the opinions of those of our syde out of England, that the Iesuits should euery where be cryed out against, & complaints framed
against them,A consultation to haue the Iesuits cried out against. they liked it wel but first they would haue me to goe downe to some Northen Prouinces to conferre the matter with M. Iohn Mush and others of their side, who liked not the matter for the present, partly for that lawful proofes of such complaints could hardly be had, and partly also, for that their new association (which then they pretended) would seeme therby to be a matter of emulation only against the Iesuits, and so there passed 8. or 9. monethes in this diuersity of opinions betweene them, and I went 7. or 8. tymes frÅ the North parts to VVisbich, Cambrige & London about this affayre, hauing money giuen me for my voiages partly by M. D. Bag. and M. Bluet,These almes of Gathol might haue byn better imployed thÄ in seditiÅ. of whome I had 40. crownes at one tyme 20. at another, 30. at another, and other summes which now I remember not, partly also of M. Mush and others, who gaue me both money & diuers horses, and at London I lay comonly with M. Charnocke, otherwise called LÅg, and M. Medcalfe; albeit the three chefe men to whome I was comended out of FlÄders, were M. Christopher Bagshaw, M. Rob. Dolman, and M. Iohn Colington, &c.

Among other things which M. Pag. cÅmitted to me to be handled in England against the Fathers, was that wheras the confessarius
of the Card. Archduke was a dominican friar,A plot of â¢ . Dominicans to be opposed against Iesuits. it seemed good to him, and those of his side in Flaunders, that there should be called from Spoleto in Italy one F. Thomas Foster an Englishman of the same order to reside in Flanders, as companion to the said Card. confessarius, and that wheras there was in Spayne an other English friar of the same order named Paulus,This is a quiet man lyuing at S. Lucars & vvil not be dravven to any such faction. he should be drawne to the court of Spaine, and a third sowght out to be sent to Rome, to oppose themselues in all these places against the Iesuits, which being proposed by me to D. Bag. and his company they liked wel the matter, but that they would besides this, haue some of diuers orders also sent into England, to strengthen their parts there, against the Iesuits & their frends, &c.

div.p:
Thus farre wryteth Fisher, & moreouer he sayth that those of VVisbich tould him certaine things to be related to some in Flanders, as to the Earle of VVestmerland, touching a gentlewoman of his kynred defamed by Iesuits, and to M VVilliÄ Tressam, of the like iniury done to his brother Sir Thomas by the same men,Deuises to procure enimyes to Iesuits. which yet he vnderstood to be false before he came forth of EnglÄd, for which causes & others, and for that he saw them so disordered, &
fauoured by heretikes, both in VVisbich, London and els where, he began greatly to doubt of their course. He told also that wheras he brought certaine letters vvith him in latyn intituled thus: Copia litterarum Catholicorum in Anglio degentium, they vvere wrytten only by D. Bagsh. who yet desyred to haue them giuen vp to the Pope, in Catholikes names. And finally he saith that he wrote the forsaid memorial against the Society in D. Hugh Griffith his house Prouost of Cambray at his request, in the name both of himselfe, M. Pag. and D. Griffith,VVhere the mem. vvas vvrytten and by vvhome. whome he said to be desyrous to haue such a memorial, and that he penned it according to that he had heard in England and other where against Iesuits without great care, whether the things therin contayned were true or not, & that the said D. Hugh did often tymes giue him money, willing him to be of good cheere and hold on and wryte to those of the faction in England that they should spare for no expences to cÅtinew, for that he would beare the charges both of letters and messengers, &c.

He saith further that he had in commission from them of England to tel M. Pag. D. Gifford, & the rest that they should endeauour by all meanes possible to haue
the Iesuits called out of England, or at least F. Garnet to be depriued of his gouernmÄt ouer them.D. Bagsh. pious endeuors. He brought letters also of D. Bag. to the schollers in Rome exhorting them to hold on in their stryfe against the Fathers and the more to exasperate them, he said it had byn published by the Iesuits that some of them had byn openly beaten with roddes in Rome, which letters he gaue to some of them in Millan where he met them in the moneth of Nouember. Neyther was it knowne at his departure from England, that peace was made at Rome, or that F. Persons was come thither, albeit D. Bag. and his frends seemed to feare it much.

This and much more deposed Fisher tactis Euangelijs (as the examination saith) which we shal reserue to a larger & more particular relation hereafter, but by this any indifferent man may see how matters stand, and where the ground of all troubles and dissentions lyeth. All is but a conspiracy of euil humors against them that do better then themselues, and euery man that loueth his soule wil soone descrie the same. Religion is not sought by this faction, but reuenge and satisfaction of bad appetites, which his Hol. cleerly perceauing, tooke
order first in the Roman colledge, and then in England for remedy therof: as hereafter yow shal heare.

div.head: HOVV HIS HOLINES hearing of the former disorders & contentions did resolue to make a subordination and Ecclesiastical Hierarchie in England vnder the gouernment of an Archpriest, and 12. Assistents; & how the same was ordayned, and intimated by the Protector, and called in question by some of our discontented brethren without reason or necessity; and how great troubles haue ensued therof. CAP. VIII.
div.p:
WHen his Holâª heard the former state of matters in England, Flaunders and other places, and of the murmuratiÅs of some against the Fathers of the Societye, set downe as wel in the foresaid contumelious memorial,See the letters of the northen priestes 24. Mart. 1598. & others 20. April. and others after 30. Iulij, and others of the South in great number 18 May, & of the quiet sorte of VVisbich 27. Martij 1598. as by diuers other letters, and relations, which came to the Protectors sight, and by him was related to his Hol. and namely when he receaued great store of priuate and publique letters out of EnglÄd against the said memorial of Fisher,
and some one with aboue 100. hands at it, other with 40. and 50. all in fauour and commendation of the Fathers their labours and behauiour in England against the said slaunderous memorial, and many other in seueral letters of principal men which are yet extant, when also diuers of these did expreslie demaund some subordination, and gouernment, of seculer priests to take away this emulation of some fewe against the Fathers,F. VVilliÄ Baldvvyn. M. Iames Standich, 1597. and that two lately come out of England at this verie tyme, one a Iesuite, the other a secular Prieste, each of thÄ vrging the same in behalfe both of the one & the other order; his Hol. after mature deliberation resolued to yeild thervnto, hoping hereby to quiet all, aswel for that the seculer priests should by this meanes haue gouernours of their owne, as also for that the Fathers by all liklihood should remayne free,The reasons, and manner of his Hol. resolution. from all matter of calumniation, about gouerning seculer priests for the tyme to come.

This being determined to make a subordination, we vnderstÄd that his Hol. tooke tyme to consulte for some monethes with the congregation of Cardinals of the Inquisition, what mÄner of gouernmÄt it should be for the tyme present, and by what meanes it might be best instituted without any
great innouation of matters in England, so as the state should not be exasperated therby against the Catholikes, in which tyme also he willed informacion to be procured out of England of the fittest men for gouernment, as it was done, and diuers letters are extant of their opinion therin, though these vnquiet perhaps were not demanded in particuler, neyther was it needful they being so smal a parte of the English Cleargie.

In Rome also, the opinions were asked by the Protector of the principal Inglish that resided there and could best informe, as namely F. Persons, that had often aduise from thence, F. Baldwyn lately come from England. M. Doctor Haddock, M. Martyn Aray, M. Iames Standish, and others that had labored in the English Vineyard, as also M. Thomas Allen, nephew to the late Card. and diuers els, who concurring with the opinion of letters comming out of England, as also with diuers other principal men that wrote therof from Spayne, FlaÅ«ders, and other places both of the necessitie of some subordination to be made and for the fitnes, and sufficiencie of M. Blak wels person, his Hol. resolued according to their opinions, and informations in these two poyntes, to wit, to appoynt a gouernment,
& that this man should be the gouernour, though for the third about the kynd or manner of gouernment,VVhy his Hol. appointed no Bishoppes. he iudged not expedient for the present to appoynt any other but an Archpriest (an ancient dignitie in the church of Christ) least if he should haue begunne with Bishops he doubted very probably, that it would haue caused some great motion in England, for auoyding wherof he resolued also for this first tyme not to write himselfe any Apostolical letters, but to commit rather the Institution of the matter by special order to the Protector to be done in his name.

Loe heere then the groundes of this his Hol. resolution so farre as we are informed by thÄ that were priuie thervnto, & by this are ouerthrowne all those cauillations, & suspicious coniectures which our discontented brethren in their late bookes haue set foorth about this meaning aswel of his Hol. and the Protector, as of those also that gaue informations, for procuring of this authority, sinistrously interpreting the one, and the other. For first we see heere that the necessitie of our diuisions, & emulous proceedings one against an other did enforce, both Catholikes to desyre some subordination amongst priests, and his Hol. to yeild thervnto.

For so long as our Cleargie proceded in the spirite of humilitie, obedience, peace, and vnitie, there was no need of Superior, for that euery one was a rule, and lawe to himselfe:Act. 6. but crescente numero discipulorum factum est murmur Graecorum aduersus Hebraeos, &c. when the multitude of our priests encreased, and the former spirite in many of them decreased, there beganne presently murmuration, and emulation against the Fathtrs of the Society, as though they only did hinder vs, who indeed were and are the men that do principally helpe vs both in word and lyfe, and so long as we were content to learne: but some comming out of the Seminaries (where they had byn vnder the Iesuits) with lesse or worse spirite then were to be wished,Beginning of emulatiÅ against Iesuites in England. drewe others to emulate them, whom before they had obeyed, for auoyding wherof it seemed in all good mens opinions (and the Iesuites aboue the rest) that the only or chief remedy would be to haue this subordination of secular Priests among themselues, wherby the other might remayne foorth of all occasion of contention, and thus much for his Hol. motiue to institute this Hierarchie or subordination.

But for the manner of procuremÄt therof
it was as before we haue said, not only by F. Persons, and the Iesuits sollicitation (as our brethrÄ complayne) and much lesse for particuler ends of their owne as these later libels iniuriouslie do enterprete) but by the sute of secular Priests thÄselues, as appeareth by their seueral letters yet extant, and the heads of these that are now vnquiet were so feruent in this poynt to haue a subordination, and gouernment among themselues, as without all Superiors Authoritie they would haue set vp their AssociatiÅ which in the former chapter yow haue heard by the testimony of six of our Assistents whose wordes also we thinke conuenient in this place to put downe to shewe how wrongfully F. Persons, and his Society are accused to haue procured the subordinatiÅ against or without the clergies wil, though they deny not to haue byn desirous of it for the causes before mentioned. The Assistents words are these.

The letters of six assistentes to the Nuncius in Flaunders 2. of May 1601. Æ²ide suprÃ cap. 7.
Post hoc rursus cum res nostra mirum in modum turbarentur, neque esset inter nos aliquis Superior, &c. VVhen after this againe (to wit after the former association begun, and the memorial of Fisher spread abroad to defame the Fathers) when our matters were very much troubled, and that no Superior
was amongst vs, which by authoritye might represse these stormes; it seemed good to some godly priests with the consent of the most parte of the rest, to write vnro his Hol. beseeching him that for taking away or restrayning the audations libertie of some fewe in gathering conuenticles, erecting of sodalities,Hovv and vvhy the subordination vvas demanded by priestes. divulging of infamous writings against their brethren, and troubling many wayes our publique peace, and for establishing of some good ecclesiastical discipline, and cÅseruing mutual concord among vs, it would please his Hol. to thinke vpon some kynd of subordination among vs, which his wisedome should iudge best, and confirme the same by his authoritie, which after was performed, for that his Hol. hauing taken mature deliberation vpon the matter, gaue expresse order to Card. Caetan our Protector to satisfie our demaund, who appoynted vs a Superior vnder the name of an Archpriest geuing him Apostolical faculties, & adding 12. Assistents whose counsel in gouernmÄt he should vse.

Behold heere F. Persons, and the Iesuites deliuered by the testimonie of our owne men from al the imputations, exaggeratiÅs, and sinister interpretations throughout these whole late libels, layd against them,
for their procuring the subordination seing heere it is freely confessed that it was demaunded by Priests themselues with the consent and priuitie of the more parte of all the Cleargie,See the letter of 6. ancient priests the 13 of Sept. 1597. of which priests (the most ancient, and graue among all the rest) there are diuers letters yet extant demaunding this poynt.

And moreouer we are most certaynly informed, that wheras euery where almost these libels do charge F. PersÅs most bitterlie, that he would in no case haue a Bishop, or Bishops erected in England, the truth is quite cÅtrarie, he being knowne to haue laboured for many yeares, while Card. Allen was alyue that some Bishops might be appoynted, and sent Apostolically into England, and for that one chief difficultie vvas about their maintenance, he procured afterward being in Spaine, in the yeare 1591. that the good old Bishop of Iaen Don Francesco Sarmientos a great benefactor of the Seminaries & PatrÅ of Englishmen was cÅtent to offer the charges of mayntayning 2. or 3. Bishops to be sent thither as appeareth by his letter written the yeare after to F. Persons,The letter of the B. of Iaen offring to mayntaine some Engl. Bishops, An. 1592. which he signifyed to the Cardinal in Rome.

And at this very tyme when the matter was in deliberation in Rome about this
English Hierarchie to be appoynted vve vnderstand that F. Persons did demaund two Bishops,The tytle of this memorial vvas, rationes Episcopis duobus Anglicanis, An. 1597. and gaue vp a writing to his Hol and to the Cardinals of the Inquisition to his effect, which is yet extant, and we haue seene the coppie cÅteyning 9. reasons for graunting the same; the first wherof standeth in these woordes, Ad roborandos Catholicorum animos in ferendis persecutionibus, Episcopienim arietes gregis in persecutionibus antiquis diccbantur. To strengthen the hartes of Catholiques in bearing persecutiÅ for that in tyme of ancient persecution Bishops were wont to be called the Ranimes of the flocke, &c. The second was, ad conferendum Sacramentum confirmationis quo corroborentur in praelio, &c. To administer the Sacrament of confirmation wherby Catholikes in this persecution may be strengthened, &c. VVhich writing of his no doubt is yet extant in the holy office to defend him from this calumniation that he and his can not abyde Bishops.

And besydes all this we vnderstand that he procured Card. Caetan the Protector to go in person to all the Cardinals of the Inquisition, and he with him, to make them capable of these reasons,Hovv much F. Persons is abused. & this do both his Hol. and they know, and the foresaid seculer priests then in Rome, and yet liuing, can
testifie, wherby may be seene how this good Father is vsed, for his labours taken in our country affayres, and euery thing cÅstrued in a false and contrarie sense by these maleuolous.

VVel this then being resolued by his Hol. that he would haue an Archpriest appoynted in England whÅ all the rest should obey, he gaue commissiÅ to the said Card. protector,The Card. Protector letters for the institution of the Archp. 7. or March. 1598. to institute the same in his name, which he did by his letters patents bearing date the 7. of March 1598. writing the said letters in most pious, and effectual mÄner, shewing that it was by his Hol. especial order and commandement, by these woordes Speciali mandato nobis iniunxit, his Hol. hath ordeyned this vnto vs by a special commandement. Shewing also that his Hol. was moued herevnto, by the reasons aforesaid alleaged by the Priests, Rationes ab ipsis sacerdotibus pro ea re redditae Smo. D. N. probatae fuerunt, the reasons alleaged by priests for this matter were allowed by his Holinesse.

And finally after the whole institution set downe, and motyues therof, with the order, authoritie, faculties, helpes of Assistents, and other particularities, he concludeth with a most pious declaration of his Hol. and his owne desyre, wil, and intention
of our publique good, and peace to be conserued by this meanes, which comming from so high a Superior, and directlie from Christs Vicar himselfe, we do wonder how it tooke no more effect within the hartes of our brethrÄ that impugned the same. His wordes are these.

p.hi: Illud denique vel in primis scire debetis,
p.note: A very effectual speach and exhortatiÅ of the Protector.
p.q:
Lastly yow must know this aboue other poynts (which before also we haue touched) that the chiefe desyre of your most holie Father, and myne also, & both our intentions do go to that end, that Ecclesiastical discipline, so farre foorth, as the conditions of tymes and men wil beare now in England, may be conserued in your cleargie, & aboue all other things peace and vnion of mynds, and concord among brethren and priests, & namely with the Fathers of the Society, which do labour together with yow in the same vyneyard, which his Hol. himselfe vouchsafed of late to commaund both earnestly, and instantlie in my prefence,His Hol. detestation of factious â¢ gainst â¢ esuite, & the reasons vvhy. to certayne priests that went hence into England. Neyther did he this without most iust cause; for wheras those Fathers not only heere, and in other places do labour incessantly for holding vp the English cause, both by erecting Seminaries, instructing your youth, assisting such as are in need, &
by many other wayes helping the same, but also in England it selfe do attend to the same workes of charitie euen to the shedding of their blood, as experience hath shewed, and wheras they neyther haue, nor do pretend to haue any parte of iurisdictiÅ or power ouer seculer priests for to geue them any molestation at all: it must needs be iudged, a most manifest guyle, & deceyt of the deuil for ouer-turning your whole worke, that any Catholike should exercise or styrre vp any emulation against them, wheras contrarywise they should be imbraced with all loue, and reuerence by yow priests, to the ende that they may go forward with more alacrity in doing good offices (as hitherto) vnto all priests, so as this most holy worke of yours may be promoted with conioyned hands and hartes of all sydes. VVherfore if any man should be found, that would goe about to weakÄ this concord betwixt yow, him yow ought to note according to the Apostles commandement,1. Thess. 2. which is also the intention of the sea Apostolique,VVe beseech out Brethren to consider vvel of this spech. &c. VVherfore to make an end I do not know what words I might better vse vnto yow then those which the Apostle so often vseth to his schollers in a like cause, and perhaps not vnlike occasion and tyme.

div.p: Be of one mynd, Rom. 12. and haue peace among your selues, and then againe much more instantly,Philip. 2. If there be any bowels of commiseration in yow fulfil my ioy in this thing that yow be of one mynd, and that yow haue the selfe same charitie in your hartes, and iudgment in your vnderstanding doing nothing for contention, nothing for vayne glorie, but in humilitie esteeming euery one an other supior to himself, &c. And if yow obserue this rule,VVordes to be considered. & exhortation of the Apostle, all goeth safelie with yow, & your enterprise wil be glorious as hitherto, but if by any deceyt of the cÅmon enemy yow suffer, your selues to fall from this constancie of vnion among your selues, your and your countryes cause wil runne into great daunger of shipwracke which God forbid, and defend yow euer, and I do recommend my selfe most hartelie to your prayers most deare Fathers, and brethren cÅfessors of Christe. From Rome the 7. of March 1598.

Now let all good Cathol. tel vs what tÄder harte there is which this kynd & godly speach of our highest Superior vnder his Hol. would not moue, especiallie in such a matter as is so necessarie for our selues, so seuerely cÅmaÅ«ded by Christ & his Apostles, & so instÄtlie vrged by his supreeme Pastor, as by the Protectors testimony is heere auowed,His Hol. Breue April. 6. 1599 and by his Hol. owne Breue is afterward
confirmed, wherin he auerreth, that all this wrytten by the Cardinal and euery percel therof, was by his order, consent, proper motyon and commandement written, ordeyned, and sent into England.

But what? did this satisfie or quiet thÄ that had resolued to be vnquiet? no (God wote) but presently in steed of saying, let vs obey, let vs be quiet, and serue God in concord,S. Bernard. de precepto & dispensatione. they began as S Bernard sayth of disobedient men, primum dubitare, haerere discutere superioris mandatum, & tandem contemnere. First to stagger and doubt and then to discusse their Superiors commandement and lastly to contemne it. Let vs heare the testimony of our forsaid reuerend brethren before mentioned who were present at the matter, and sawe whar passed, when the said institution of the Archpriest came into England, and was promulgated by the foresaid prudent and godly letters of the Protector.

p.q:
The testimony of 6. Assistents about the maner of proceeding of the vnquiet vpon receyte of the Protectors letters. Sed nec hoc (say they) valuit, hos eosdem in officio retinere, &c. but neyther this publication of the said letters was able to hold in order these men, but rather to the contrarie, that which was ordayned for conseruation of our peace by the highest authoritie that is vpon earth, was turned into matter of greatest discord, for wheras all
others without any excuse or tergiuersatiÅ, accepting the Cardinals letters, and subiecting themselues presently to the subordination appoynted, these selfe same men, which had bin authors before of ordeyning newe associations would not submit themselues to this order of his Hol. but did cry out that the Canonical electiÅ of their Superior did pertayne vnto them, and that this new Superior vnder the name of an Archpriest neuer heard of before, was thrust vpon them by surreption from his Hol. wherupon they began presentlie to detracte from the credit of the protectors letters to make conuenticles a newe and to encrease the number of their faction by all meanes possible, deuising strange wayes for the same. And albeit they were oftentymes warned both seriouslie, and fatherlie by our most reuerend Archipriest to be quiet, and desist from these tumultes & to obey the order geuen by his Hol. yet could he neuer preuaile with them, and at lÄgth they sent two of their owne to Rome, with certayne informatiÅs forged of thÄselues both against the Protectors letters, the Archpriest, and the fathers of the Societye, &c.

div.p:
And thus much of the fact of our discontented b â¢ ethren about which there are
many circÅ«stances, that do aggrauate much no doubt the offence if we would stand vpon them, but we desire rather to haue them forgotten, as the facte it self also, if at length they would amend it, but what now the good & obediÄte? what did they? whose enterest was as great in the matter as these men could pretend, & much greater also, for that they were farre the greater parte, and of more antiquitie, and accompte, and did make in deed the true body of all the English Cleargie, of whom we see heere,The contrary behauiour of the quiet, and those that vvere the true body of the English Cleargie. first by this relation of the Assistents that they receyued the matter with great alacritye, and presentlye obeyed, & testified the same out of hÄd by their letters both publike, and priuate, which (alas) if the other had done so to we had had peace in our English Church at this day, and so many great sinnes, and scandals had not insued, as since haue fallen out by these mens contradiction and singularitie we might set downe heere a great company of letters, both learned prudent humble and pious, which were wrytten by graue priests out of the most shyres, and prouinces of England testifying their liking and approuing both of the subordination, and particularly of the person appoynted for their head, as for example
one of the 25. of Octobre 1598. with 31. hands of the most ancientest priests with in England subscribed therunto:A cÅmon letter of 31. priests, for gratulation of the Superior appoynted Octob. 25. 1598. wherin among other things they write thus to his Hol. and the Protector.

Huc etiam accedit quod ad hoc munus obeundum cum virum nobis praeficiendum curauerit, qui propter virtutes suas singulares, eximiam doctrinam, usorum suauitatem, & longam reram nostrarum Anglicarum experientiam Ã nobis omnibus semper fuit habitus vir optimus, & ad publica nostra negotia tractanda maximÃ¨ idoneus. To this is added (besydes other reasons we haue to like of this gouernment) that your grace hath procured vs such a mÄ to be made our Suriour in this office who for his singuler vertues, excellent learning sweetnes of manners, and longe experience of English affayres was euer coÅ«ted by vs a most good man, and most apte to handle our publke affayres. And agayne, Suauisimam inter nos gubernationis formam, & patriae nostrae in hoc rerum stata accomodatissimam instituit. His Hol. hath appoynted amongst vs a most sweete forme of gouernment, and most fit for our Countrie, in the state of things that now is. This wrote they, and we forbeare to set downe their names for diuers inconueniÄces that might insue therof, yet the first it Ioan. Bou. and the last Ioan Rob.

An other letter of an other shyre vvith 14. handes, 20. of NouÄb. 98. about the Archpriest.An other letter we haue seene of the 20. of Nouember 1598. out of another Prouince with 14. hands set vnto it, the first being Ioan Mick, the last Ia. For. who after many thanks for the subordinatiÅ appoynted do say thus amongst other things. In quo Sanctitatis suae vestraeque EccellÄtiae meritÃ² gratulamur, quod huiusmodi virum caeteris praefectum habeamus cuius non modo d â¢ ctrinae praestantia rerumque longi temporis experientia inter omnes emineat, sed & morum integritas ipsiusque naturae suauitas facilÃ¨omnes in sui amorem ac venerationem pertrahat, in cuius electionem omnes ex animo suffragamur, eique obedientiam vt par est libentissimÃ¨ profitemur. A third letter out of an other shire 1. Decemb. 1598 about the same.An other letter we haue seene of 12. hands from an other shire, the first being R. Barck, the last Cuth. Craw. of the first of Decem. 1598. VVherin after many thanks
yealded to his Hol. for the troubles ended in Rome, they say thus. Testis est Anglia vbi non minore cura eidem inuidiae & discordiae mal â¢ consulitur dum nobis presbyteris Archipresbyter praeficitur, & tali officio vir dignissimus elegitur, qui non solum omni virtute, sed etiam omni literarum generi excultus, & ingenio mitissimus sit. England is witnes (of his Hol. zeale in extinguishing dissentiÅ amÅg vs (where with no lesse care then at Rome order is taken to extinguish enuie and discord, while ouer vs priests there is an Archpriest appoynted, and such a man chosen to the office as is most worthy therof, as not only adorned with all kynd of vertue and learning, but of most myld nature also to gouerne vs.

And of this kynd of letters we could alleage many more if we would stand vpÅ it, but then desire of breuitie maketh vs to cut of much in this kynd, for that there are extant sundry other testimonies of the iudgemÄt of our brethren by the grauest & learnedest priests of England as wel about the matter it selfe as the man and his worthines for this Prelacie,The vvorthyues of M. Blakvvels persÅ. and no doubt but if all the Catholikes of our nation both with in and without England were asked their opinion in this affayre, they would in no one thing more cÅdemne these our vnquiet
brethren then in going about to deface, & discredit as they do in these their libels so eminent a man of their owne order as M. Blakwel is, and alwayes hath bin accompted, and this only for that he liketh not their passionate, and turbulent dealing in raysing, and continuing discord.

But now it shal not be amisse perhaps in this place to heare brieflie what reasons, these men can alleage for their dissenting & dissagreeing from the whole body of vs their brethren in this fact, which reasons may be gathered out of both these two late books the one in English the other in latyn though confusedlie,Reasons or pretenses of the vnquiet, for not yealding to the rest. & tumultuatiouslie set downe in both; and in no one place distinctlie and in order, but in effect they are these that do ensue, and as nigh as we can, we shal set them downe in their owne wordes.

1. Reason.First then they say that this authority was gotten by wronge, and false information, and instance of the aduerse parte only, against their wils and without their knowlege contrarie to all equitie and iustice, pag. 3. But this hath bin euidently proued to be false a litle before by diuers sufficient testimonies & as for their wils, and knowlege they beeing so smal a parte as they were of the whole body it was not necessarie in particuler for his Hol.
or Protector to require the same as all men wil see.

Secondly they alleage, that they doubt,Their s â¢
cond pretense. whether this ordination came from the Pope himselfe or no, seeing there came no Breue nor Bul, wher about they aske this question concerning vs.Pag. â¢ 2. VVhy should they be so vnwilling to procure or suffer to be procured some Bul or Breue for the confirmation therof if it came from his Holines? Ibidem pag. 5.

But this question and reason theron depending is now answered,3. Many reasons together. for that a Breue was procured, and not much more esteemed by these men, then these the Cardinals letters, as appeared by the effect, and that they in this very booke do cal it in question also, how it came forth; saying, that they do not know out of what office it was procured by F. Persons meanes.
