Other reasons of theirs are, that the Card. letters Patents are not sufficient to geue the matter credit, that he hath byn found partial towards the Iesuites, that he is not their lawful Superior & the like. But these things are easelie answered, for who doth not know what a Cardinals testimony in any Christian Catholike court is worth? especiallie a Protector testifying, and professing in his letters patents to do it, ex speciali mandato Smi. as this man doth in his letters, and wheras these men say and
repeate often that a Card. is not to be beleeued in such a matter except he shewe the letters of his Hol. let them heare the testimonie of the Canon law, Coppies of discour â¢ es, pa. 7. 11. 12. &c. and writers theron against them, who do attribute much more credit to Cardinals then this, saying, Octauum priuilegium quod Cardinali asserenti se legatum, Gloss. in extrauag. execrab. lon. 22 de prehendis & dignitatibus. tit. 3. creditur absque litteris 97. distinctione C. nobilissimus. It is the eyght priuilege of a Card. that his credit is so great that if he should say he is the Popes Legate he is beleeued though he shewe no letters, which is a farre greater case then this of ours is.

But not to stand vpon these matters it is a foule thing when for couering our owne wils of not obeying we seeke holes in the cotes, and authoritie of our Superiors, as these men do both against the Card. Protector his authoritie and person, as also the Archpriest, yea and his Hol. also in couert wordes, and so farre as they dare; perswading the people,In both books but specially the Inglishs and almost in euery pag. that he hath beleeued false information, and thereby appoynted a subordination most inconuenient, not heard of in the Church before, and that it is against all equitie and Iustice, & that his Hol. could not lawfully appoynt itâª without their consents, and that the meanes, by which he had appoynted it, is insufficient, bynding no man to obey it; all which must needs argue great insufficiency, defects, and lacke of consideration
in his Hol. proceeding, which is the poynt these men would perswade the people, for discrediting of the thing it selfe. And the like we haue shewed against the Cardinal before. Cap. 2.

And as for the Archpriest their immediate Superior though in wordes they acknowledge his authoritie, saying, in the preface of their booke, that it is an error to thinke that they do not acknowledge M. Blakwel for their Archpriest and Superior, In prefatione ad l â¢ ctor â¢
yet do they seeke by all meanes possible to discredit both him, his authority and person. And here in this place they wil needs rayse a certayne cauil against him saying, that he doubled in his speach with M. Coleton, and M. Charnock (for of their two relations only all these matters are raysed against him) when at the first cÅming of the Card. letters,Coppies ãâã pag. 15. and instructions he conferred them confidently with these two, who so dewtifully interpreted his speaches as first they said he was contrarie to him selfe, and affirmed his instructions to haue come from Rome together with these letters (which is most true, and they are to be seene vnder the Card. hand and seale) and then that he confessed some of them were made in EnglÄd which we cannot apprehend how it could be spoken.

Moreouer they gaue out amongst their frends that he had spoken an heretical proposition,Deuises to discredit M. Blakvvel vvith accusatiÅs in the Acr. whervpon M. Bishop told the same in Rome as appeareth in his examination affirming to haue heard it of his fellow M. Charnocke, who yet as farre as we vnderstand did set downe nothing therabout in his depositions, and in this later English libel agayne diuers tymes mÄtyon is made therof by a certayne censurer intituled M. I. B. commenting vpon a letter of F. Persons, but nothing affirming or denying, but only entertayning the speach that an heretical proposition had byn obiected, or spoken of at Rome against the Archpriest, and the proposition (for sooth) was that M. Blakwel should say vnto thÄ, that they could not appeale from him to the Pope himselfe, which if M Blakwel should say, as we are sure he did not in the sense they take it, yet many men in the world may say this in diuers causes wherin appeale is cut of by his Hol. consent, & order, and if M. Charnoke in conscience had thought this to haue byn heresie or heretical he was boÅ«d vnder payne of excÅmunicatiÅ, especially being in Rome to haue prosecuted the matter, & not hauing done so, and yet procuring in these late libels to renewe the speach therof agayne, it is easely
seene that their intention is only to discredit the person of their Superior in what they may, which is a bad kynd of obediÄce especially among priests, that professe so high a vocation as ours is.

Other reasons they alleage or insinuate of their not obeying,Coppies of disc. pag. 6. 14. as for that it is a forrayne Authoritie, and subiect to danger of Premunire, that his Hol. cÄnot do it lawfully without their consents, that the election perteyned vnto them, and the like. These I say are such as we are ashamed to handle for that they shew worse disposed myndes, or at leastwise lesse careful of their owne credit among Catholike men then we would wish.

And these reasons are set downe & printed in two of the first treatesies of this English booke, intituled copies of discourses which were written before the Breue came foorth for confirmation of the Archpriest, and consequentlie it seemeth strange to vs why they were now printed after the Breeue is foorth, and hath not wrought that effect for quieting them, which there they promise.

But now after these treatises insueth an Epistle of M. Anto. Champneys,M. Anto. Champneyes Epistle greatly misliked. which we could hardly beleeue to be his, if he had not suffred his name to be put downe in prynt to the same, for we had greater opiniÅ both
of his discretion, learning & modestie, then that he would vtter such things as in this epistle are conteyned, especially matter of so much gawle against the Fathers of the Societye, vnder whÅ he hath byn brought vp, and of whose order for diuers yeares (as we are informed) he sought to be, but these cÅmonly are worst when they leese their spirite, seeking to pacifie the remorse of their owne conscience by deuising defects against them whom they lefte, and so in this epistle he payeth all his former obligations vnto them by as hateful speaches, as commonly any enemy could vtter, but leauing this we come to the poynt it selfe, wherin he sheweth as litle sound Iudgement of learning, as any other that had his hand in this booke.

For first he wil needs take vpon him in this Epistle to proue, that he and his fellowes had great reason in doing as they do, & that it neyther was nor is any synne or disobedience at all,Pag. 21. The large definition of disobedience deuised for excuse of the trouble some. for (sayth he) to disobey is to resist, contemne, and impugne the knowne commÄd â¢ ment of a Superiour, for which he cyteth S. Thom. 22. q. 104. art. 1. & q. 105. per totÅ«. but heere we would aske M. Champney that came so late from his study, whether to euery sinful disobediÄce yea mortal synne, it be needful that the disobedient should
resist, contemne, and impugne, &c. or whether S. Thomas in these places by him alleaged doth defyne any such thing, and not the playne cÅtrarie, for if it be true that no man doth synne by disobedience but he only that doth resist, Gen. 13. contemne and impugne his Superiors commandement how was Adams offence so greatly punished in him, and his posteritie wherin yet we do not read that he did resist, contemne or impugne the commandemÄt of God almighty about the aple, but only did simply disobey by eating the same which was forbidden. Neyther do we read that Acan in the spoyle of Ierico did resist, Iosue. 5.6.7. contemne, or impugne the cÅmandement of Iosue, that nothing should be touched or saued of the goods of that towne, but being delighted with some parte therof held it to himselfe.1. Reg. 13. & 15. And the like K. Saul afterward in sparing the Amalekites, & retayning some parte of their goods, & yet was the former by Gods expresse commandement put to death, & the other reiected from his Kyngdome for these disobediences, And Samuel said vnto him, Quare non audisti vocem Domini? why didst thou not heare or obey the commandement of God vttered by me? He did not say, why didest thou resist, contemne, or impugne, which is not only disobedience, but rebellion, and obstination of which obstination
S. Thomas in the question by M. Champney cyted;D. Thom. q. 105. act. â¢ . ad. 2. affirmeth to be synne against the holy Ghost. Non omnis inobediÄtia (sayth he) est peccatÅ« in SpiritÅ« SanctÅ«, sed solum illa cui obstinatio adhibetur. Not euery disobedience is synne against the Holy Ghost but that only whervnto is adioyned obstinatiÅ.

VVherfore according to S. Thomas doctryne declared also by other schole men, & most briefly and clearly by Caetan in his summe,Caetan in in summa verbo obedientia. a mÄ may commit damnable synne by disobedience two wayes; first formally, and properly,Formal disobedience. when he resolueth not to obey, which includeth contempt, & of this meaneth S. Thomas when he sayth ad inobedientiam requiritur quod actualiter contemnat quis speciale preceptum, it is required to inobediÄce (formally taken) that a man do contemne actually the particuler precept of his Superior, q. 105. art. 2. ad 1. but yet marke how Caetan doth explicate these wordes, idem est (saith he) contemptus precepti, Caetan ibid. & nolle ex intentione obedire praecepto. It is the selfe same thing to contemne the precept of our Superiors, as to haue entention not to obey his commandement. By which we see that neyther in this proper and formal kynd of disobedience is it needful that a man do openly resist contemne or impugne, but it is sufficient, that by one way or other he hath an
intention not to do that which is commÄded, so that M. Champ. teacheth vs very absurdlie, that no man disobeyeth sinfully except he resist contemne and impugne.

And as for the other wordes in his definition of disobedience that it must be a knowne precept, &c. true it is, that S. Thomas sayth:Ibid. vbi supra. Voluntate Superioris intellecta, &c. The subiect must know the wil of his Superior, otherwise he cÄnot be said truly to disobey him, but he addeth in the same place, that there is praeceptum tacitum vel expressum, a secret or manifest commandement, and that it is sufficient to bynd a man vnder synne to obedience, vt voluntas Superioris quocÅ«que modo innotescat, that the Superiors wil by any meanes whatsoeuer do appeare (which goeth harde with our mens facte) and further adding presentlie that the obediÄce is so much the better,D. Thom. q. 104. art. 2. in corpore. quantÅ« expressum praeceptÅ« obediendo praeuenit, by how much more a mÄ doth preuÄt by obeying the expresse cÅmÄdemÄt of his Superior, when he knoweth or gesseth at his Superiors wil or inclination.

And this is S. Thomas doctryne of this first kynd of formal obedience wherby let any man cÅsider the different spirite of S. Thom. about ready willing and simple obedience, from those our brethren who in their first preface to the Reader do make a long
speach,A perilous & scandalous doctrine of our brethrÄ about obedience. that authoritie of Superiors is not a sure rule of truth to be followed without examination, &c. VVherof we haue treated before in our second chapter.

And heere agayne another discourser of these men beginneth thus, To buyld sure (sayth he) I lay this foundacion, that it is neyther piety nor true obedience at the first sight to admit any authoritie, Pag. 9. but such as is orderly procured, & lawfully promulged, &c. but who shal be iudge of this? and when wil there be an end of contention if euery subiect follow this rule to examyne his Superiors ordinances, whether they be orderly procured, or no? who seeth not where this spirite wil end?

VVe might alleage heere the whole course of anciÄt holy Fathers sayings about prompt ready and simple obedience most opposite and contradictorie to this vayne of doctryne of these our brethren, and he that wil see the true meaning of S. Thomas his sense about this matter in the very same place cyted heere by M Champ. quite contrarie to the others words, and meaning, let him read his expositors and among other F. Greg. de ValÄtia a famous learned man of our tyme,Greg. de VÄlent. 2. 2. q. 104 disput. 7. puncto 2. de obed. who setteth downe this rule out of S. Thomas 2. 2. q. 104. art. 5. In ijs omnibus & solis subditus tenetur obedire suo superiori de quibus non euidenter constat, aut esse contra
preceptum diuinum, vel alterius superioris preeminentioris, aut esse talia quae excedant limites, potestatis & authoritatis Superioris in subditum. A subiect is bound to obey his Superior in all these, and only these things wherof he hath not euident knowledge that they are contrarie to Gods commandement or to the commandement of some higher Superior, or that they are such things which do exceed the limits of the power and authoritie which the Superiour hath ouer his subiect. Marke heere that a man is bound to obey in all, wherin he hath not euident knowledge to the contrarie, which is quite opposite to our mens doctryne which teacheth to doubt discusse and examine.

But let vs see what this learned man doth inferre vpon this rule of S. Thomas, receyued as he sayth by all diuines.The first Corollarie of F ValÄtia about obedience. Primo sequitur (saith he) &c. It followeth first that it is not necessarie for bynd â¢ ng a subiect to obey his Superior, that the subiect him self do see or vnderstand the thing to be good that is commanded or that it is conteyned within the limites of his said Superiours Authoritie, but it is sufficient to bynd him that he doth not know euidently the contrarie; to wit that it is eyther euil, or without the limits of his Superiours authoritie. And we take euidenly in this place to be that, not which may seeme so to the subiect only who may perhaps be blynded
herin with passion, but that which shal be so iudged by other good and learned men, &c. Secundo sequitur, The secÅd Corallary of F. ValÄtia. &c. It foloweth in the second place out of this rule (saith he) that it doth not appartayne to the office of a subiect that he enquire or seeke out whether it be good, and expedient that which is commanded vnto him and his obedience shal be much more persect if by the only authoritie of the commander he do perswade himselfe that to be good and expedient which is commanded without further inquisition.

The third Corollary. Tertio sequitur (saith he) It foloweth thirdly out of the said rule, that the dout of the subiect about the rightnes, or iustnes of that which is commanded nor his opinion against it, whether it be probable, or improbable doth deliuer him from obligation to obey. All which this learned mÄ proueth both out of Scriptures and anciÄt Fathers, namely S. Hieron. Epist. 4. ad Rust. cap. 7. S. Basil. constitut. monast. cap. 23. Cass. Collat. 2. Cap. 11. S. Greg. lib. 2. cap. 4. in lib. 1. Reg.
From which doctryne and spirite of ancient Fathers, our men running vpon passion, we may see whether they runne.

And all this now is about the first kynd of formal disobediÄce, wherin there must be some actual contÄpte with reflexiÅ, which is as out of CaetÄ yow haue heard an intentiÅ not to obey, & would to God this also were not to opÄly seene in this fact of our
brethen, and their perseuerance therin.

But now besydes this there is an other kynd of material disobedience, when a man leaueth to do that which is commanded, not with intention, or reflexion,The secÅd kind of disobedience vvith is material & not formal. that he wil not obey or doth contemne this Superior, but only that he doth eyther omit that which was commanded, or do some other thing contrarie therunto, and in this kynd is it to be presumed, that the disobedience of Adam Acan Saul, and others were, wherby we see, and all deuines do hold that this kynd of disobedience also may be a heynous and mortal sinne, according to the qualitie of the matter and meaning of the Superior, that is to say, as all schoole men do note, the greater the Superior is whose precept is pretermitted (though not resisted or impugned) and the more important the matter is wherin this pretermissiÅ happeneth, and the more earnest,D. Thom. Caet. & alij vbi supra. and intensiue the said Superiors wil is to haue the matter exactly obserued that is commÄded; the more heynous, & dÄnable is the sinne of disobedience, whether it be in the first kynd by actual contempt, and intention not to obey, or in the second kynd of material disobedience by pretermission, and let vs remember also stil with S Thomas before cyted that it is sufficient the Superiors
wil do appeare quocunque modo by what meanes soeuer.

VVel then all this being presupposed, and all heate of partialitie, and passion layd asyde we would aske our brethren in their consciences before God,A serious question proposed to our discontented brethren. and as at the day of iudgement they wil, and must answere truly, and sincerlye, when they had seene, and read ouer Cardinal Caetans letters Patens, wherin vnder his hande, and publique seale he testified to them & the whole world that in respect of the diuision and dissention raysed in England betweene Priests and Iesuites, or priests, and priests vpon that or other causes, and fot continuation of discipline, vnion and concord. His Hol. had resolued to make a subordination, and had by a special commandement inioyned the same to him to be performed by his letters, and knowing futther that his Hol, not many monethes before (which the Cardinal repeateth in his letters) had told the very same tale vnto diuers of thÄ at their departure from Rome; about these diuisions, exhorting, and charging them most straytlie to haue vnion, & peace with all, and namely with the Fathers of the Societye, making the very like exhortation to them, which now the Cardinal did. All these things (we say) concurring,
and many others, as wel letters from Rome, as men that came from thence testifiing this acte, & meaning of the Pope, and the very probabilitie, and moral euidÄce it selfe being so cleare that no Card. would euer dare presume to do or attempt so publique act vnder letters patents, and that expresly in the Popes name without sure commission, heere we say let our brethren tel vs sincerelie and without passion was this moral certayntie of the Popes wil or not? or was this sufficient knowledge to bynd vnder sinne to obediÄce or no? was a Cardinal Protectors letters Patents testifiing his Hol. cÅmandement therin enough to the condition required by S. Thomas. Vt superioris voluntas quocunque modo innotescat. That our Superiors wil do any wayes appeare, but we wil not vrge this any further heere especially seing F. ValÄt. his doctrine set downe: before out of S. Tho. doth most clerely conuince them. And therfore we leaue it to God and their consciences to answere one day before the high Iudge, where shifts wil haue no place. VVherfore to say a word or two only to the decree of the venerable facultie of diuinitie in Parts, alleaged heere by M. Champney to ptoue that they committed no sinne at all in this fact (for they wil needs iustifie thÄselues
in euery poynt) we nothing doubt but that if those reuerend learned men had bin indifferently instructed in the case how it passed,About the decree of the Doctors of Paris, affirming this sedition to be no sinne they would haue bin of a farre other mynd and iudgement then to cleare such a facte, that hath caused so many sinful scandals, from all kynd of sinne what soeuer.

And to make this playne let vs repeate the words of the decree it selfe heere set downe by M. ChÄpney together with the wrong and defectuous information geuen them so farre forth as it concerneth sinne, for of the other point of schisme, we wil not talke at all, and are sorie that euer it was mentioned or brought in question, vnquiet people hauing taken occasion hereby to continue contention and to make more brables then were needful, our question is then only whether any sinne were committed? wherof also we wil not presume to determine any degree of sinne, but leaue that to God, and to the offenders consciences. The decree then of the Sorbon Doctors, and state of the question proposed vnto them was this.

The state of the question proposed to the doctors of Sorbon vvith their resolutiÅ about sin Coppies of discourses pag. 39. In the yeare of our Lord 1600. vpon the third of May, it was proposed to the facultie of deuines of the vniuersitie of Paris that by the letters of a most Illustrious Cardinal. An
Ecclesiastical Superior was constituted in a certayne kyngdome with the title and dignitie of an Archpriest to haue authoritie and iurisdiction ouer all other priests resyding in that kyngdome. This Card. did also declare in those his letters, that he did it according to the wil, and good liking of the Pope, notwithstanding many of these priests refused to subscribe to the authoritie of the said Archpriest before he had obteyned letters from the sea Apostolike conteyning the tenure of his confirmation, as wel because that kynd of gouernment was altogether new in Gods church, and hitherto neuer heard of, that an Archpriest should haue charge ouer a whole kyngdome, and such iurisdiction ouer euery priest in that realme, then also for that it seemed to them by certayne wordes of the Cardinals letters, that the Archpriest, and his authoritye was graunted by false information, then lastlie because they noted great partialitie in the choise of the Archpriest, and of his counsellors. Vpon which and some other reasons these priests sent messengers to the Pope for laying open vnto him these their difficulties, and therwithal to signifie their greatest readines, as in this matter so euermore in all other to obey his Holines.

This was the information; which being
thus layd downe,M. D. Cecil M. D. Bishop. and two of their owne syde there procuring to be Doctors also (if already they were not) and no man of the Archpriest syde to reply or tel the tale as it ought to be, no maruaile if these Doctors that were chosen out to meete in the Senior Bedels house about this matter (for so is set downe also in this printed booke) did more lightlie ouer passe the matter, and determyne according to the sinistrous information they had, that they committed no synne at all in that facte in it selfe considered. VVhich last wordes notwithstanding they added prudentlie; for that they knew not what scandal, euil example, sedition, and contention and hurt to the common cause had ensued therof, and therfore they determyned only of the facte in it selfe considered and according to this information geuen them.

Diuers fautes & falshoodes in the information geuen to the Doctors.But now ponder further we pray yow, the fautes, and falshoods of this information. First they say by the letters of a most illustrious Cardinal. Not telling them that he was Protector of the Nation, which doth much encrease his credit for matters touching the country vnder his protection. Then they say, that this Cardinal did also declare in those his letters, that he did it according to the wil & good liking of the Pope, but they tel them not that it was expresso mandato. By his Hol.
expresse commandement which the Card. setteth downe clearly in his letters. Thirdly they conceale an other thing vttered also in the Cardinals letters, to wit, that a subordination was demanded by priests letters to his Hol. and that his Hol. had allowed of their reasons.

Fourthlie they say, that many of these priests refused to subscribe, as though they had byn a great multitude, or the maior parte which was most false, they not being the twÄtith parte at the beginning; of those that admitted the gouernment, and if they haue encreased their number since, it hath byn by as false informatiÅ as this was to the Doctors of Paris, and by perswading them to the participation of their libertie and freedome from all gouernment, which is a sore baite for yong men as all the world knoweth.

Fifthly they say that they refused only to subscribe to the authoritie of the Archpriest before he had obteyned letters from the sea Apostolike for his confirmation, as who would say, that this being done they meant to be quiet, and as though in the meane space they had behaued themselues obedientlie, and moued no troubles, no man being there present of the Superiors syde to enforme the good Doctors of the contrarie, & of these mens
tumultuous behauiours, to wit what reuel they kept through-out England by writing,The tÅ«multuous behauiour of our brethren at their first denyal to admit their Superior. sending, and perswading against the Popes ordination, what conuenticles, meetings, and tumults they made to drawe men to their parte, and to make a faction. VVhat reasons they inuented to discredit the Protector his letters and person as also the Archpriest their immediate Superior appoynted, what terrors they cast into lay mens heads of admitting forrayne authoritie from the Pope, which tendeth to a worse consequence then all this.

Further no man was present in Paris to tel the Doctors how false that clause of information was, that it might seeme by the cardinals letters, that the Archprists authoritie was graunted by faelse informatiÅ, or that partialitie was vsed in choise of him & his assistÄts, and that their messengers to Rome were not sent (as they pretÄd to be enformed only of the truth of his Hol. wil (wherof in reason, and moral probability they could not doubt seing the Cardinal Protectors letters Patents for the same) but rather to contradict, and make a broyle in Rome as they indeuored after their arryual theare. And as for the offring of their greatest readines, which they tel the Paris Doctors that they sent to Rome to signifie to his Hol. both in this and
all other matters, the euent doth shewe how truly it was meant, for that after the said messengers had byn at Rome, The obstinat proceedings of our discÅtented brethren. and learned his Hol. wil and determination agayne both by their owne restraynt for resisting the same; & by two Cardinals Iudicial sentence in that behalfe against them, did eyther they or their fellowes in England obey, or follow the Popes wil any thing more then before (though for a shewe for some litle tyme they seemed to accept of his Breue, but soone after brooke foorth agayne to far worse and so haue continued til his day). Or haue they not bin more turbulent, and tumultuous then euer before? doe they not in these libels goe about to discredit his Hol. new Breue it self as before hath bin noted, saying, that God knoweth out of what office it was gotten by F. Persons meanes?

If then any man had byn present in Paris to enforme truly those learned men of these,Copy. of disc. pag. 82 and other such poynts appertayning to this fact; and aboue all of their pryde and arrogancy that being scarfe 10. against 300. at that tyme, they durst make so daÅ«gerous a diuision among Catholikes in the sight of the common enemy, and in tyme of persecution, and that by no means eyther of authority or gentle perswasiions
they could be brought to dessist from so dangerous a course; wherof infinite hurtes, scandals, and other damages, haue and do ensue daylie, If any man (I say) had proposed the state of the question in this sorte is it likly that so learned and Godly Cathol. mÄ would haue defyned that their facte had incurred no sinne at all? And yet is their definition (as before hath bin noted) so limited that they determyne only of the facte in it selfe, and this also according to the present information giuen them excluding all other circumstance & considerations that do or may aggrauate the same, so as in very deed very litle reliefe cometh vnto our brethren by this definition of Paris, & wel they might haue spared to prynt it, but that M. Champney would make a vayne florish with the ostentatiÅ of an Academical sentÄce, which hauing no more substance for him and his, then heere hath bin noted, the rest which he hath in this Epistle shal be considered of afterward agayne in a due and conuenient place. And so for this matter we end.

div.head: HOVV AFTER THE first cÅtradiction made by our Brethren against his Holines ordinance about the Archpriest by the Protectors letters, they vvent forvvard, and sent a couple to Rome, and vvhat happened to them there: and hovv his Hol. confirmed the foresaid ordinance and Protectors letters vvith a nevv Breue. CAP. IX.
div.p:
WE haue shewed in the former Chapter with how great singularity and litle reason our discÅtented brethren, being so few, and such as they were opposed themselues at the beginninge to the first institutiÅ of this Hierarchie, ordained by his Hol. and against the whole body of our English Cleargy besides themselues admitting the same. Now it remayneth to consider with what resolution & obstinacy they haue prosecuted this their deuision, notwithstanding all the meanes vsed to diuert them from it, and quiet thÄ both by Superiors commandements and frends persuation. And first of all about this point is to be noted, that if our said brethren had meant plainly and sincerly (as
often they do professe in the two first discourses of their English booke intituled Copies of discoursss, &c. and in their information to the Doctors of Paris they do avouch the same) to wit, that their scruple was only whether this matter came frÅ his Hol. or noe? and whether Cardinal Caetan the Protector abusing the Popes name had appoynted it of himselfe,A false pretence. and that they differed only to concurre with the rest of their brethren, vntil they might be a certayned of this poynr. If this (I say) had bin so, and not only a cloke or pretence to couer their designmÄt of making sedition, it had bin a very easy matter to cleare the doubt by many wayes, yea without sending any to Rome, for that so publike an act as this vnder a Cardinals letters Patents might haue easily bin enquired of without messengers; & one letter of their owne eyther to his Hol. himselfe or to Cardinal. Aldobrandino his nephew or any aquaintance of theirs that was in Rome might soone haue procured them a certificate of this matter if they had byn desirous to haue knowne the truth. Yea further no man was there if the contrary part it selfe, which in his behalfe would not haue endeauored to ptocure them satisfaction.

But when it was seene and vnderstood that they rested not heere, but intended a further diuision, and that by geuing out, that they would send mÄ to Rome to cÅtradict and ouerthrow the whole, they sought to hould men in suspence from obeying their Superior, and to terrifie others, least it might be recalled that now they admitted, & that they sought by all meanes possible to cal in question and discredit, both the Cardinal his letters, authority, and person, yea the fact of the Pope himselfe, affirming that he could not do it without thÄ, except he violated the Church Canons. And lastly that this authority was an externe or forraine iurisdiction & cÅsequently the admission therof subiect to the law of Premunire. VVhen these things (I say) and such like were hard of tending to manifest disobedience diuision and sedition, thÄ did men of iudgemÄt see and discouer, that the former pretÄce of informing them selues of this Hol. wil, was but a maske to couer their further intentions, as since hath appeared,M. VV. Bishop. M.R. Charnock. and their owne two messengers discouered the same in their depositions at Rome, as a little after shal appeare.

VVherfore his Hol. being at that tyme in Ferrara and aduertissed from his Nuntij aswel
in FrÄce as FlÄders, as also by diuers other principal English both in Engl. & the low coÅ«tryes of these attÄpts and intents of these troublesome people, and considering what had passed a little before in Rome, the obstinacy they had shewed in their styrres there, and seeing further many letters comming daylie to the Protector; of this matter; he was not a little moued therat, and calling to him one day F. Bellarminus (now Cardinal) asked him if he had heard any thing of this matter from Rome who denying to haue hard, his Hol willed him presently to wryte to F. Persons therof;F. Bellarm. letter to F. P. about the Popes discontÄtment 17. Octob. 1598. requiring him to send some information of the particulars, adding further that his Hol. so greatly misliked their troublesome fact, that he had told him that if they came to Ferrara, he would cause thÄ to be imprisoned. This letter was of the 17 of October 1598. which letter F. Persons receauing sent it presently downe into Flaunders to meete the messengers if they came that way, to the end that vnderstanding therby the great mislike which his Hol. had of their iourney, might detayne thÄselues somwhat in their enterprise begÅ. But they passing by FrÄce met not with it nor with the Pope at Ferrara at least wise so as they might haue audiÄce of him, or he
know of their beeing there, but presently at their cÅming to Rome, which was the 11. of December as appeareth by F. Persons letter to M. Bishop the 9. of October 1599. about this matter (and these men haue caused the same to be printed to their owne disgrace as all indifferÄt men reading it wil see,The Messengers arriual at Rome 11. Decemb. 1598. notwithstanding the malitious commentaryes they make vpon it) the same F. imparted with them all that had passed, persuading thÄ by all means to desist from their enterprise in contradicting his Hol. ordination, assuring them for other matters touching personal satisfaction; eyther in respect of the Archpriest or Fathers of the Society, they should haue it fully, if they brought with them any iust complaint, and the same offered them also the two Cardinals Caetan and Burgesius Protector and Viceprotector, but they presisting in their purpose to wrangle, and going about to misinforme diuers principal men in the citty of the affayres of England and diuisions, there, and namely the Commissary of the Inquisition and others who were so much scandalised by this contradiction as they professed,The scÄdal that grevv in Rome vpon the messengers spech vvith strangers. that wheras hitherto, they had had a good opinion of English affayres, now they begÄ to doubt of all.

These things (I say) comming to the Protectors eares & by him related to his Hol. who now was come from Ferrara and remayned with the memory of informations he receyued there from other parts, he resolued to restraine this scÄdalous maner of proceeding and the hurts therof ensuing to the English cause, by cÅmanding these troublesome Agens to be retyred to the English Colledge there to be examined quietly and comodiously by one of his owne officers to see what they could say, Signor Acaritius squarsionius Canon of S. Iohn Laterans. or what they brought with them worthy of so long a voyage, or of so much noise as they had made by the same.

This then is the haynous fact which our discontented brethren since that tyme haue so much exaggerated throughout the world by clamours, and do at this present both amplifie and vrge in these their books against his Hol. the Cardinals and especially F. Persons as the author and Architect of all (for so they tearme him euery where) indeuoring to bring the enuy of that which they dare not lay openly vpon his Hol. and the Cardinals to fal vpon him, wheras not withstÄding, as presently shal be shewed, the cheefe informations against these men came from others and not any way from F. Persons but rather that he (notwithstanding
all their stomake and malice against him) serued them for a moderator and mittigator both of their imprisonment, examination and sentence against them, as appeareth by the particulars set downe in his former letters to M. Bishop himselfe,F.P. letter to M Bish. 9. Octob. 1599. Â§. 10. 11. &c. and we shal also proue it more particularly in this Chapter.

And first who doth not see that it is an ordinary art of all malecontents, and such as doe or deserue euil, to lay their il successes vpon other men, and when they dare not do it vnto princes or suppreme magistrates themselues, they accuse commonly such and such particular men, as they imagine to haue procured the same, or iudge to be against them, or mislike their doings.The fashiÅ of all malecontents to accuse other men for their ovvne defects. But this euery wise man seeth to be but a shift & figuratiue maner of speech to accuse the said prince or magistrate vnder another mans person, or as the saying is to wound them through other mens sides, seing it should be a great blot to their wisdome and authority to gouerne themselues by the passion of any particular mÄ, especially in this our case, his Hol. and the two Cardinal being so learned and wise would neuer haue bin brought by F.P. persuasiÅ (if he would haue persuaded thÄ) except they had seene greater ground then
his will or words alone; and afterward when they were retyred, and his Hol. had appoynted a speciall officer to examine them, and to bring the said examinations vnder their owne hands and others to be vewed by the Cardinals and his Hol. most certaine it is if these mÄ had brought with them any substantial or iust matter, for their contradiction and comming to Rome, they should haue had iustice, & if not the falt should haue bin theirs and not F. Persons which had no voice eyther in the sentence giuen or vew of the said examinatiÅs. VVherfore to cry out so much of iniustice done thÄ both in their imprisonmÄt & the sentence giuen against them, and yet not to accuse his Hol. or the Cardinals but F. Persons only as though he and not they had done it, or that he gouerned them, is a cauillation which euery chyld can discouer. And yet for better declaration of the one and the other of these points (to wit as wel for their imprisonment as that which ensued therÅ) we are enforced heere for defence both of his Hol. the Cardinal protectors and other officers much slaundered therby to enlarge our selues a littel further in this place.

And first concerning his Hol. intention to imprison them in Ferrara if they had
come thither which our brethren make to be a strange and vnreasonable matter, that his Hol. (say they) should determine to put two priests in prison for comming to Rome with so greate aduenture and daunger of lyfe about matters of the Church, and this before he hard them, Copy of discorses, pag. 74. 75. what they had to say, or saw them. This, I say, is a pore obiection, for if they came to trouble the Church of EnglÄd with neuer so much aduenture or if these things were true, which before we haue mentioned to haue byn wryten out of England against them, to wit that they went about to set diuision and to discredit both the protector and his Hol. in their subordinatiÅ appoynted then might he wel determine to restrayne them for this disobedience at their first arriual, and yet heare them also afterward, if they had any thing to say, and this is a course vsually held in all princes courts of the world at this day.

But now let vs see what other letters also there were from principal English men in Flanders and other places; out of England,Principal English men vvrote to Rome against the tvvo messengers. requyring iustice and some seuerity at his Hol. hands against theese priests for their audaciÅs and scÄdalous attempt to disturbe the peace of the church of England. And surely though the least part perhaps of
those letters haue not come to our hands that were wrytten to his Hol. or the Protector in this behalfe, yet by those that we haue seene, the sense and feeling of all good Catholikes of our natiÅ may easily be perceyued in this affayre.

M.D. Stapleton.And first for M.D. Stapleton the learnedest man then liuing of our countrey, and whome his Hol. at that very tyme was in purpose (as is thought) to haue preferred to higher dignity, and consequently vvas like most to respect his opiniÅ heerin, what he wrote to Rome of this faction may appeare by his owne testimony alleaged before though the good man were dead as we thinke before these two came into FlÄders or very soone after;Cap. 4. but diuers other principal men with whome he agreed in sense and iudgement wrote to Rome some moneths before these men came ouer wherof we haue seene 17. hands to one memorial demaunding iustice against these seditious people and their partners in these woords: Salus publica quae pacem cum tumultuosis non facilÃ¨ admittit, The letter of 17. Engl. men to F. Claud. Aquau. the 18 of March 1508. against the factious. Ã nobis poscit vt prae caeteris omnibus virtutibus iustitiam quaeramus qua sola respublica sustentatur, & sine qua impossibile est habitari ciuitatem, vt post philosophum Diuus docet Augustinus, cuius & illud elogium auribus nostris continuo
insonat; iustitiam cum feceris, fac & pacem. The publike health and Saluation of our cÅtrey which doth not admyt peace with tumultuous people demaundeth at our hands, that we should sue for iustice (at this tyme) aboue all other vertues, for that the cÅmon welth by her is sustayned, and without her no citty can be inhabited, which besides philosophers S. Augustine also doth teach vs, whose speech soundeth alwayes in our eares, where he sayth: VVhen yow do iustice, yow shal make also peace.

This was the entrance into that memorial which is somwhat large, alleaging diuers reasons wherby to mooue his Hol. to punish examplarly some of these vnquiet people, who so greatly troubled our English cause both in Flanders & EnglÄd, naming some also in particular whome we are content to passe ouer with sylence at this tyme. And this memorial was wrytten some monethes (as hath byn said) before these two messengers came ouer into Flanders, but their negotiatiÅs in EnglÄd were hard of and knowne, and 17. hands of those that liued in Bruxels were subscribed to this memorial to wit 6. priests & 11. gentlemen in this order.

This memorial then being thus wrytten and by such men, might easily styrre vp his Holines (if it came to his hands as it was intended) to take some more resolute course with these messengers of new tumults, when soone after he vnderstood they were comming towards him, but much more when he receyued fresh letters from the same or like men of our nation to the same effect, when these messengers were in their way indeed, for then diuers zealous men wrote againe very earnestly; and first of all the President and Doctors of the English Colledge of Doway as soone as they hard of their coming into France wrote these woords vnto the Protector.

body.p:
Intelleximus nuper pro certo, &c. The letter of the president and Doctors of Dovvay to the Protectors against the tvvo messengers 25. Octo 1598. VVe haue vnderstood of late for certayne, which before by vncertaine rumors was brought vnto vs, that two priests; Bishop & Charnocke are gone forth of England towards his Hol. to perturbe the comon peace & cÅcord of our English Church vnder this pretence that the subordination most wisely and wholesomly instituted there by his Hol. and receyued with the applause of all good men doth not please certaine of them to wit eyther those which vpon a certaine emulation do take it ill, that themselues are not put in dignity, or els, which is vvorse, through the desyre of faction do styrre vp discord They are sufficiently knowne to vs, and some of them are said to haue had their parts in those late Roman broiles which were so troublesome both to his Hol and your grace and ignominious to our nation. VVherfore seing that by no example, nor by any peril, into which they haue cast both that RomÄ Colledge & our publike cause of our countrey, they will amÄd, neyther are moued to a better mynd by any thing or remedy hitherto vsed; and seing they wil not yeild eyther to his Hol. or your wil and authority but by force, our opinion is (yeilding alwayes to a better) that some example of seuere correction
should be vsed vpon these two, to the end that other of the same faction and boldnes should be held in their duty, &c.

dateline.date: Duaci ex Collegio vestro Anglicano 25. Octob. 1598.

closer.signed:
Illustrissimae Dominationis vestrae Serui in Christo humillimi.
D or. Richardus Barettus. Praeses.
D or. Laurentius VVebbus. Collegij Assistentes.
D or. Guliel. Harisonus. Collegij Assistentes.
D or. Matthaeus Kellisonus. Collegij Assistentes.

div.p:
And besides this community of the most principal men of our Cathol. Cleargy out of England, diuers particular men also of the same quality wrote to the same effect to the Protector, and by him to his Holines, wherof we shal alleage only heere two or three for breuityes sake. M.D. VVorthing, to now President of the foresaid Colledge,M. Doct. VVorth. letter to the Prot. 30 Oct. 1598. but then residing in Bruxelles as assistant in English affayres with his Hol. Nuntio wrote this that followeth: Etsi non dubitem, &c. Albeit I do not doubt but that your grace hath byn aduertised by many principal Cathol. mens letters of our nation of the attempts of a certaine few seditious in England against the authority of the Archpriest instituted from his Hol. by your letters and how that two of the principal
of them, are in their way to Rome to contradict the said authority & iurisdictiÅ by calumniations and clamors, yet haue I thought it also my duty, being appoynted to be a consultor in our countreys affayres to his Hol. Nuntio here to wryte somwhat also of the same matter. VVherfore my opinion is (if it be of any valew) that this very first beginning of this new sedition be repressed by his Hol. with some seuerity, least it take deeper roote. For if those captaynes of new trobles do fynd any fauour or toleration of their attempts in Rome, they wil styrte vp great stormes in EnglÄd, but if they be kept downe with some sharpnes now at the beginning all wilbe quiet, &c. Thus he wryteth and much more and we leaue out for breuityes sake many good and substantial reasons which he alleageth for the same.

M. D. Pearse also Doctor of Sorbon as before hath byn touched, and consultor in like manner with Doctor Stapleton and D. VVorthington to the said Nuntius Apostolicus in Flaunders in all English affaires and D. Cesar Clement, that succeeded D. StapletÅ in that office, & Doctor Richard Hal a very graue ancient learned man, Canon of S. Omers: and some others are said to haue wrytten most earnestlie and grauelie to the
same effect, and we doubt nothing therof knowing the men as we do (though we haue not the copies, of their letters at this present) but yet cannot we omyt to alleage one peece, of a large godly & zealous letter which M. Licentiate VVhright deane of Cortrac in Flaunders a man of knowne learning and merits who wrote about this matter vnto the protector in these words:

p.note: M. Licent. vvright his letter to the Prot. 10 Nou. 1591.
p.q:
Your grace I know doth wel se how great mischief this matter is like to bring vnto our English Church if it be permitted, and how great trouble and molestation it wil breed vnto your grace (in gouerning vs) except as we hope remedy be put by diligence at the beginning. For this disease is so much the more daungerous by how much the more secretly it infecteth. This truly I can affirme vnto your grace that the true and zealous defenders and propagators of Catholike religiÅ in England do receaue more hurt and hinderance in the cause from these false and factious brethren, then from the open enemyes themselues, and no maruaile for that these men being priuy to all their secrets are no lesse malitious against them, then the very heretiks themselues, &c. And then after diuers other reasons alleaged he saith
of the Archpriest thus:His testimony of M. Blackvvel the Archpriest. I haue knowne the Archpriest for this 30. yeares, both in the Seminary of Doway and els where, and I haue knowne him to be euer a learned mÄ, pious, wise, peaceable, humble, and vpon whome no least sparkle euer of lightnes, faction, or other vice hath byn knowne to light, and such a man as in the whole disvnited litle flocke of these ambitious people is not to be found the like, &c. yet if his Hol. would be enformed better of the truth of things how they passe in England, vve besech your grace to suggest, that informatiÅ be taken not from these turbulÄt & factious people that seeke to ouerthrow all, and are not faithful in their relations, but eyther out of England it selfe from the grauest and most knowne Catholikes, or from them that be of the same quality in banishment in these parts, and are knowne to be voyd of faction and ambition, or at least wayes from his Nuntius in Bruxels vpon diligent examination of the truth, &c.

div.p:
By these then & other letters that came to his Hol. or to the Protector about this tyme and were related to his Hol. by him, euery man may se whether he had iust cause to be moued or no, and to resolue to restraine them at their arriual, but much more, when after 17. or 18. dayes stay in
Rome as before hath byn said, they could not, be induced by the protectors persuasion to any quiet course at al. It may be seene also how vniustly they do calumniate and accuse F. P. as the cause of all their trouble, cÅsidering these letters were wrytten from Flanders vpon the two messengers first coming ouer so as F. P. had neyther tyme to procure these letters from Flanders. Neither is it likely that men so graue, learned, and wise as these are, would be induced by another mans request to wryte such letters vnder their owne hands to so great personages, and that in so important a matter, except they had thought, as they wrote and their iudgements had byn conforme vnto their letters. And thus much of the first point about their imprisonment. Now to that which ensued.

â¢ . Persons letter relating the storye of the messengers treaty in Ro. 1599.There is extant a letter wrytten by F. P. to M. Bishop of the 9. of October 1599. conteyning a certaine breife recapitulation of the principal poynts that passed in this action of the two messengers restrayned in Rome, the examination and the sentence giuen against them to satisfie the manifold calumniations and odious exaggeratiÅs made by these men in diuers countreyes against the proceeding of their Superiors which letter the discontented haue
set forth in print in one of their late libels, we know not with what reason, but only as they haue done other things to make a shew with heaping matters togeather, for that the letter proceedeth very substantially, referring it selfe in all points to originals and publike testimonies. And albeit these men haue published two answeres to the same; the one of M. Bish. himselfe, the other of a censurer, calling himselfe M. I. B. yet neither of them answereth any one substantial poynt conteyned in the letter with satisfaction of a iudicious and indifferent reader, as wil appeare also by this which heere we are to set downe, offering for proofe therof eyther the publike testimonyes of his Hol. the two Cardinals Protectors, Acaritius the Popes fiscal, & other parties that were actors or priuy to the cause, or els the depositiÅs of the said messengers themselues vnder their hands and oathes, or finally the witnes of the whole English Colledge and nation that know what passed in this matter, which is another maner of proceeding then to publish things in corners by way of libels without any further ground of truth, then the wil of malice of the publisher.

First then touching the occasion of their imprisonment and his Hol. resolutiÅ therin,
sufficient hath byn said before in this chapter. And as cÅcerning the benefit they had by being restrayned in the colledge rather then in any other place, both in respect of lesse infamy, sauing of charges and infinite other inconueniences, euery man wil, that is not ouer passionate, easily discerne. And as for their courteous & gentle vsage in the Colledge, while they were there, and all kind of frendship and charity bestowed vpon them (excepting only their liberty restrayned by higher authority) of these and other points touched also by F. Persons in the said letter, we haue enformed our selues, and do fynd that the whole Colledge wil testifie (wherof some are now also in England) against the ingratitude of these mens cauillations.

As for the points of their examinations wherat one of them scoffeth saying: our examinations were, M. Bishop in the booke intituled Copies of discourses pag. â¢ 71. what is your name? how old? where remayned yow in England? which way came yow ouer? &c. and much such like impertinÄt stuffe to fil vp papers. Euery man that is acquainted with the ordinary forme of examinatiÅ wil see that this is but a meere cauil for that in all examinations neuer so graue or weighty these are wont to be the first and formal interrogatories. But when after they came to the substantial points of
their message & commission in deed, then was it seene how poore a iorney these men had taken, & how smal substance they had, for that which they had takÄ in hand. And albeit M Bishop in his answere to F.P. letter sticked not to auouch in the word of a priest that there was little asked them about the substantial points of their affaire,Bad shifts. yet is his owne deposition and his followes extant vnder their owne hands to the contrary, wherof we haue seene an authentical copy. Neyther is the fond shift vsed by him in this answere, and by his fellow censurer vpon the said letter of any valew with men of iudgement, but rather sheweth, that they proceede not by conscience, but seeke euasions by cauillation when they say that the Notary being a father of the Colledge might put in and put out what F. Persons would haue him, for that whatsoeuer was put in any dayes examination it was read wholy to the party examined; in his presence; and subscribed with his owne hande, and the margent so scored and registred by the Popes Commissary (and so it is extant at this day) as no one word or sillable can be added or taken away without manifest detectiÅ. And whÄ all was ended the whole was read ouer to them againe and they confirmed the same
with the ordinary woords: Ita iuro G.B. R.C.

SubstÄtial points of examinatiÅ of M B. & M. Ch. 1599.First then to talke of substantial poynts: the examination of M Charnocke beginning the 4. of Ianuary and that of M. Bishop the 10. of Ianu. 1599. and passing ouer all other demaunds which these men cal impertinent, they were asked what was the cause and reason of their comming to Rome? who sent them? what commission they brought? what poynts they were to treate? and whether they brought these by wryting or by word of mouth? how many were of their party in England?Interrogatories to the messengers. why they opposed themselues against the rest? whether they came ouer with the licence or direction of any Superior, or of themselues only, and other like poynts which no man wil deny but in this busynes were substantial.

Exam. R. Ch. 4. Ian. 5599.To these M. Charnocke being first examined answered in these words, Causa aduentus nostri haec fuit vt rogaremus humillime, &c. The cause of our comming to Rome was this, that we might beseech most humbly and with all obedience the Sea Apostolike, that this order appoynted by Cardinal Caetan for composing controuersies in England and to make peace, not being hitherto confirmed by his Hol. as we vnderstood
it is said by diuers priests and namely F. Sicclemore and others;The causes of this messange to Rome. might be mittigated or chaunged, or some other order appoynted with it, for satisfaction of very many priests who do thinke (reseruing notwithstÄding due honor to the Sea Apostolike) that by this way appoynted only the strife begon cannot so wel be ended,Quam pluribus sacerdotis. &c. but yet if it should please his Hol. to confirme this order already appoynted by his authority, and to admit no other, then are these priests cÅtent to yeild all obedience, &c. And as for the Superior appoynted; I spoke with the Archp. before I came forth, and desired him not to be offended with me, if I went to Rome about this matter, and he gaue me leaue to goe & to deale for the chaunge therof.

Thus he said, which how true or probable or coherent it is to that which since they haue said, done, and set forth in their bookes, I wil leaue to the reader to iudge, only noting out certayne poynts to be considered. And first to begin with the very last our Archp. denieth that he gaue him licence for that he saw no iust cause; but only that he would not forbid him to go to Rome, which argueth also that he held no heretical proposition, that it was vnlawful to appeale from him to his Hol. as these men
haue talked abroade. Secondly the same is much confirmed by the answere of M. Bishop this mans compartner in these words: Bis visitaui ArchipresbyterÅ« solus, &c. I visited twise the Archpriest alone and tould him of my comming to Rome, Exam. G. Bish. 10. Ian. 1599. and he asked me why? I answered to informe the Protector and to seeke a moderation of his authority. He persuaded me the contrary, but not prohibited me. Now whether it be probable that the Archpriest would giue licence to the one of these messengers and not to the other, is not hard to gesse nay the matter is clere by an expresse letter written by the Archpriest the 17. of August 1598. vnto the two messengers themselues. The letter begvnneth thus. Rationem positam iteneris vestri satis acurata consideratione perlustrauimus. VVe haue examyned with diligent consideration the reasons alleaged by yow for your iourney to Rome, and we do not fynd that yow bring any thing which in my iudgement seemeth to be of moment, &c. Thus he saith wherby we may perceue how he did allow of their iourney. But now let vs passe to the consideration of other poynts.

Exa. Rob. Ch. 15. Ian. 1599.He sayth heere that very many priests quam plures Sacerdotes were not satisfied with his Hol. order, which speech of very many priests he doth explicate afterward
what number it might import in particular, being pressed therevnto by an interrogatory in these words: Interrogatus, &c. respondit, &c. being asked what the number of Priests now in England seemed vnto him? He answered, that he could not tel for certaine, but he thought 300. more or lesse. Then being asked how many of these he did certainly know to approue this their mission, and to be priuy to the matters that should be proposed, and would stand to those things that these two should hÄdle and conclude in their names. He answered. I do know for certaine more or lesse 14. or 15. albeit I haue not had conference with them all my selfe &c.

But M. Bishop doth not arriue fully to that number in his answere to that interrogatory for hauing said also that he thought 300, priests to be in England,Exam. G. B. 12. IÄ. 1599. answereth the other part of the demaund aboue named in these words Puto me certo scire plus minus duodecim. I do think that I know for certaine 12. priests more or lesse to be of our opinion and priuy to these matters. Now whether 12. or. 15. may be called quÄplures in the number of 300. we leaue to the reader to iudge.

This matter also of the smal number of contradictors at the beginning is not a litle confirmed by the relation made by M. Charnocke in his depositions
of the first beginning therof, for being demanded who where the first beginners,Exam. R. Ch 6 Ian. 1599. a betters, and setters on in this contradiction against the Card. letters, he answered: Primos vocatos esse (quantum scio) D. Ioannem C â¢ lingtonium & meipsum, The first beginners of the sedition M. Colington and M. Char. by his ovvne confessiÅ. &c. The first that were called by the Archpriest to conferre his new authority with all were (as far as I know) M. Ihon Colington and my selfe, and we hauing read the Cardinal Protectors letters beganne to doubt not so much of the authority it selfe,Ergo not doubting yovv are bovvnd to obeye. as of the good manner of procuring it, and then some other priests meeting with vs now these, now others, we vnderstood that not only they, but some others also feared least the Archpriest would vse partiality, and therfote it should be good that some were sent to Rome to treat with his Hol. de alio modo constituendo of appointing some other maner of gouerment, &c. and the cheefe Priests that dealt with vs two that are sent, besides some other in some other place were M. Iohn Colington, M. Cope, M. Iohnson, M. Moumford, and others as they met vs, &c. Here we see how serious and graue the causes were of this oppositiÅ at the beginning, and how at the first they did not doubt of the authority it selfe nor of the Popes wil therin, as after they haue,
pretended, we see also that the priests could not be many; nor of great accompt, that resolued this embassage to Rome, against the Archpriest and the rest of the Cleargy.

M. Bishop also being asked about his mission who sent him? with what authority? why he & his fellow were sent aboue the rest? and other like poynts was somewhat troubled in answering, saying. Nescio quis fuerit, &c. Exam. G. Bish. 10. IÄ. 1599. I know not who was the first author of this mission, nor know I for certayne why we two were chosen for this mission aboue the rest. One of the Priests named M. Colington wrote to me, abyding in VVarwickshire, in the name of other Priests, whose names I do not remÄber, nor I haue not his letters; that I would come to London and I beleeue also he requyred me in those letters that I would come to Rome, and albeit I made great difficulty, yet at last I came, and found there the laid M. CollingtÅ & my companion Rob. Charnocke, and the Archpriest and my spetial dealing was with M. Colington and my sayd companion.
These are his owne words, and by this we may preceaue what an authentical mission and commission this was.

But yet further to say a word or two of the very cheefe poynt of their commission
and cause of comming to Rome, yow haue hard that M. Charn. saith and sweareth before that their only comming was, to supplicate most hÅ«bly to the Sea Apostolike, that if the forsaid order of the Archpriests authority were not yet confirmed by his Hol. as they had hard F. Sicclemore, and some other had reported, that then the same might be eyther mittigated or chaungged, or some other order appoynted togeather with it, so as now our brethren seemed not to doubt of the truth or value of the Cardinals letters, nor were not yet growne to be so bold as to affirme that his Hol. could not do it without their consents except he violated the CanÅs, See the former chap. nor that it was a forrayne iurisdictiÅ subiect to Treason and Praemunire if it were acknowledged, and other such like deuises.

M. Bishop also being asked the reasons of his coming to Rome, he enlargeth himselfe in six causes, VVherof the first is his priuate deuotion to that citty: The second to deale with his Holines for sending some Bishop or Bishops into England. The third if that could not be graunted, then to giue authority to some to vse the Sacrament of Confirmation. The fourth to confirme their new sodality or association. The fifth to compose the stryfes in VVisbich. The sixt to put in good order the Roman
English Colledge. In all which six causes, as yow see, there is scarse any one that concurreth fully with the former petition or declaration of his fellow M. Charnocke, so as they hauing come so many miles togeather, do scarse seeme agreed in the causes of their comming. And so much of this, for that it were ouerlong to runne ouer all poynts; yet this in breefe, they affirmed both of them, that as for the Archpriest, they brought nothing lawfully proued against him eyther in learning, lyfe or mÄners.A breefe Summary of the cheefe poynts of these mens propositiÅ. And the like they affirmed of the Iesuits. M. Bishop said he had hard his fellow Rob. say that M. Colington and himselfe had hard the Archpriest vtter an heretical propositiÅ, which was, that they could not appeale from him to Rome, but M. Charnocke neyther affirmed nor mencioned any such matter in all his depositions, they both agreed that the money which was giuen them by collection for this iorney was aboue 300. crownes in gold, and M.Exam. R. Ch 6. Ianu. 1599. Charnocke addeth aboue 330. and that the cheefe gatherers were M. VVatson, M. Heborne & M. Colington. M. Charn. said he had in comission amongst other poyntes for to procure that no bookes should be wrytten herafter by Catholikes that might exasperate the state of England, M. Bish.
said that he liked not that comission, but rather it should be left as hitherto, to the discretion of the wryters, adding further, that in his opinion such books as before had byn wrytten had rather done good then hurt.

About the letters tickets and scroles vvhich they brought.And lastly all their papers, letters, and scroles being exhibited vnto them by the Commissarie; wherof some, and the most part of them were wrytten before the Archpriest was appoynted, demaunding only a Superiour (and these now seemed to be against them, for that now they had a Superiour) some others demaunded Bishops in general or a Bishop, some others asked nothing in particular but allowed only in a lyne two or three, that somthing were asked of his Hol. and these tickets or scroles were directed comonly to no body, nor had any seale, nor were not made vp in fashÅ of letters nor could not for the litlenes of them, being not aboue one finger or two fingers of paper; and very negligently wrytten, so as here grew a great confusion, (a strÄge maner of dealing it seemed to Italians) and hervpon also arose a great doubt what maner of commission these men had or could haue? frÅ whome? by what meanes? for what matters? and whether all they in England would stand to all poynts
which these men heere should conclude in their behalfe?Great doubts about the comission. and whether these mens authority were general or limited? and whether they were bound vnto the poynts set downe in these tickets and letters, or might propose besides what they would of thÄselues. And finaly after much talke & wryting & wearisomnesse on all sides, no other certainty could be picked out, but that these men and their associats in England dyd only agree in cÅtradicting and pulling downe, but nothing that was probable or factible for setting vp, and so the examinations were ended vpon the 4. of February with M. Charn.The cheefe mÄ named by M. Bish. and M. Ch. of their partie. who subscribed vnto all in these wordes: Ita iuro idem praedictus Robertus Charnocus. And with M. Bish. it was ended the 25. of Ianuary, when he being willed to name the 12. priests of his party before mentioned (as M.M Dolm. M. Colington M. Buckley. Charnocke had done the chiefest of his 14. or 15.) he named for the principal M. Bagshaw, M. Bluet M. Cope, M. Heborne, M. VVatson M. Clarke and some others, and after all he subscribed also in these woords: Ita esse iuro praedictus Gulielmus Bishopus.

All this being done, and the whole processe considered and weighed wel by the Cardinals, and after related to his Holines it was resolued that the said Cardinals with
his Hol. Commissary Acaritius should go to the colledge themselues, & heare the whole processe of their depositions red in presence of the parties themselues and to see whether they had any thing els to say or wryte, for that the said Cardinals had found in their papers partly vnder their owne hands and partly vnder others in England,Different poynts found in their memorial. diuers other points proposed amongst themselues, which in their depositions were eyther not touched at all or denyed by the deponÄts as the resolute reuocation of the Archpriests authority set downe by M. Bagsh. hand in these woords: Archipresbyteratus Domini Blackuelli vtpote nec expetitus, M. Bag letter to M. Bish â¢ M. ãâ¦ã : nec vtilis futurus, est reuocandus. And againe: Hierarchia aliqua, quae solis & liberis Seminariorum suffragijs approbetur,
ãâ¦ã other hands 1595. est instituenda. The Archpresbytery of M. Blackwel is to be recalled, as neyther demanded (by vs) nor profitable for the tyme to come. And some Hierarchie or subordination is to be appointed which may be approued by the only free voyces of the Seminaryes.

Lo what a resolute law-maker here is, who recalleth the Popes subordinations in a word, and setteth vp another of his owne making, with as great facility. The same man also gaue 11. poynts to the said messengers to be handled in Rome (as before
hath byn nored) vnder his owne hand,Cap. 7. by which and by diuers other notes found in their papers, it was discouered that their heads were ful of noueltyes not only for changing the Archpriest and subordinatiÅ appoynted in England, but the gouernmÄt also of the Seminaryes, especially that in Rome, yea the chaunge of the Protector himself. And further it was discouered, by the same papers and other letters out of England, that they had particular designments to make themselues Bishops and Archbishops,Ambition noted in the messengers and their partners. whervpon in some letters it was wrytten To your LL. And a particular discourse being diuulged at this tyme vnder the hand wryting of one of their cheefe followers named M. VVatson, vvas sent to Rome while these men were there, whervnto was subscribed by another in these woords: Sic sentio VV. B

This treatese we say did plainly lay open the whole platforme & designmÄt, though these messengers in Rome would not seeme to acknowledg it, but this busy man being one of their cheefe gatherers of money for this mission, as before yow haue hard hauing set downe at length the whole plot of these new brethrens comon-wealth, concludeth the same with this earnest demaund or petition:

The platforme of the nevv brethren for their ovvne aduancemÄts set dovvne by M. VVatson, 1599. M. Bish. and M. Ch. VVe expect nothing (sayth he) but euen a general destruction if speedy redresse be not had, which can be by no way, but by Bishops and gouernours, as by general consent and humble petition we all desire it vpon our knees, whose names here follow, as wel for these two we haue made choice of to be our Archbishops, Primats or cheife bishops in authority vnder his Hol. during these tymes of schismes and heresyes, as also those who allow and giue consent, and do thirst after these gouernours, as wel of the cleargie as of the laity. And with all whome, and how many by the consent of the most & cheefe, we earnestly, wish and desyre to haue honored with Episcopal Sea and dignity to be giuen by these two at their returne with authority to consecrate them, &c.

By this we may see that these men had a good meaning to preferre themselues, & that the iorney of the two messengers to Rome was not without hope of worthie reward, seing they were to be Primats thÄselues, and to make as many other Bishops of their partners at their returne as should be thought conuenient, and perhaps this litle man might hope for a share also in such a common welth, And to shew how fit he was; it may be that he penned this worthie worke, as a Secretary of those Synods which these men held about their affayres and new deuises. And truly it is
strange to consider with what pride & resolution this yong man wryteth and determineth matters of his comon welth, condemning and contemning other men of great learning, wisdome, prety, & grauity, himselfe being knowne to haue byn but a poore lad the other day in Rhemes, not a scholler of the Colledge for a good while, but seruant to M Boast now a holy martyr, to make his bed and dresse vp his chÄber, and now as though he were another Licurgus he setteth downe the lawes of this new congregation with absolute authority beginning thus:

Great is the calamity of our tyme, and in nothing greater then this one, M. VVill. vvatsons comon vvelth to be put in practise by the contradictors of the Archpriest. that we our selues are our owne destruction, especially in these fiue general points following: All which fiue points are fiue heads of seditiÅ which he would draw priests vnto against Iesuits and other Catholiks both ecclesiastical and temporal ioyned with them; but for effectuating these things, he saith: they shal thirst euer with Tantalus and tosse with Siciphus except they ioyne togeather to suppresse 23. Machiuillian practises vsed by the aduerse part against them: The first wherof is that he and his partners are made straungers in publike affayres of the English Church. The second that they are hindred to vnderstÄd the one the other of them by permissiue
equiuocation. It may be he meaneth that this memorable vvorck of his ought to be published in print. Act. 10. The third for that a retyred priuate lyfe is commended highly as proceeding from rare mortification and humble hart, wheras the original cause is softnes of nature, and want of courage and quicknes of spirit. Another is to suppresse the memorable works of some, that they shal not be published, or at least win no praise, and to put forth any pamphlet of others with commendation of a much lesse labour. Act. 17. Another also is, that some men vse ouer much sylence which he setteth downe in these woords:Sylence greatly blamed. For that sylence is of diuers sorts, to wit of inciuility, simplicity, modesty, pollicy, arrogancy, &c. It is a special principle in this Macheuillian schoole to obserue all mens maners, words, and actions in priuate or publique assemblyes, to vrge others to speake, themselues keeping sylence, wherby eyther to haue them condemned of lightnes, and themselues commended for wisdome, or to take others tripping, &c.

This then is the second member of his discourse to wyt how to suppresse these Macheuillian practises as he calleth them, and the means is no other, but that which before hath byn set downe, that their two Embassadors to Rome; be made Archbishops, with authority at their returne to create Bishops of their fellowes, and this he proueth must be done by the example of S. Augustine our Apostle who tooke say they the same course for suppressing the
Pelagians by making him self and others Bishops, & the like wil these men do for suppressing Iesuits. And to the furnishing of this third part of his discourse and platforme for their present gouernmÄt, he putteth downe 33. articles or Canons to be obserued. In the first wherof he describeth the quality of these their new Bishops which they are to haue.The discription of M. VVatson his nevv Bishop. They must be men (saith he) of stout inuicted courage that wil not be daunted, &c. of graue, comfortable, and comely grace, in actions looks and gestures, inclyned to ciuil complements, lenity and quicknes of spirit, not of a sowre, solemne, pensiue, heauy, melancholy or dead nature, of a cleare, ready fayre and free deliuerance of spech, and not of dul stammering, homely, soft, dry or dreaming voice, and aboue all, men of great pollicy myxt with piety, wel frended and qualifyed, &c. Art. 23. Their Assistens must be of 3. sorts of persons, first a good sound linguist, 2. a perfect Antiquary or Iurist. 3.Art. 19. a schoolmÄ or wel read positiue deuine & from this office of the Assistents are to be excluded all simple soft timerous, ordinate loose light, heady rash, &c. or affected to a contrary faction, &c. and such only are to be chosen as haue both wit courage audacity quicke spirits, styrring but stayd heads, &c. more-ouer euery mÄ must be imployed according to his quality, & those that are of a courtly & gentle-manlike behauiour fit to conuerse must be imployed
in traueling abroad to winne the harts of all, and those that are experienced in the world and men of ripe wits and politike beads must haue the dealing for examining of causes, &c. And further more we must haue three two or one notary foe euery shire, we must haue euery moneth some 3. or 4. of our brethrÄ to meete in one, two or three shires, Art 4. Art. 14. as busynes shal fal out, &c.

And thus he goeth forward, in setting downe lawes and ordinances, according as that cÅgregation (belike) had agreed vpon and among other one is,Art. 18. that no religious person for they tyme to come; of what profession soeuer, shal haue further authority within these Realmes of England and Scotland, then only to say Masse and to cathechise, &c. without medling in any Ecclesiastical affayres wherin iurisdiction or potestas clauium is to be vsed, to the end, that as Englands conuersion began first by preaching and martyrdome of Seminary priests long before any religious person looked vpon our miseryes, All religious men excluded from hearing confessions in England. Art. 18. so also they may haue, as their due, the praise, merit, & triumph of conuerting the same. Behold how these men talke of praise & triumph while yet we are but in the warre, & we might alleadge much more of their vanity in this discourse & platforme of their cÅmÅ welth, but it were ouer long yet wil we alleadge a few lynes of their 20. Article, where they treat De Cathedris, that is of their ambitious
sitting in their metings (an vnfit spirit for such workemen) in these words.

p.q:
Now for taking of place,A notorious vanity in the pretending seats. although euery preist in respect of his function, is aboue any Emperor or Monarch on earth, as representing in himselfe the person of Christ,Art. 20 yet abroad in the world in publike assemblies, or priuate meetings at table or els where by the lawes positiue, canon, ciuil and common, especially the law of armes, they are to take their place in this order. First euery priest in the place where he is resident, hath the preeminence before any, except a publike officer, for saying of grace, or his office, ministring of sacramÄts or vsing any prayer or ceremony perteyning to his function 2. where two three or moe chaunce to meet, and none of them pastor of that place, then the Senior or he that hath byn longest in England beares it away except as before the other beare office, or be graduate beyond the Seas, or be of those singular good parts in himselfe, for wit, piety, pollicy, gouernmÄt & behauiour, as the rest do giue him the honor of the place,Euery scholler precheth in his order in the Seminaryes if he be once a deuine. of him not sought for or desired 3. AmÅgst the Laity a doctor of Diuinity, though no priest or a peacher allowed of beyond the seas that is a priest & hath preached in any of the Seminaryes or other
publike assemblyes there, hath heere his place aboue any knight, except a Baron. And the like is of other publike officers in the Church that are priests. 4. Euery Priest though neuer so low in office, calling, or in executiÅ of his functiÅ, yet in this that he comes now as an Apostle, designed martyr,This is a foolish vÄting, and his Hol. hearing of it may chaunce restraine some. and hath episcopal authority in soule cases, his place is equal with a knight and aboue any esquier or other gentleman that hath not some office of dignity in martial or ciuil gouernmÄt. 5. Euery priest that hath but only authority to heare confessions takes his place of any gentleman that is not an Esquier by birth which is a Knights sonne & heire after his fathers discease, &c.

div.p:
And this he goeth forward vnto the 15. difference of sitting of Cleargy men amÅgst thÄselues, which he cÅcludeth thus 15.
