Next to this do sit priests that are preachers by authority, next them schoolemen, then linguists, after them Canonists next them Ciuilians or legists, and lasty senioritie of priesthood taketh place in order one after another. Good Lord to what vanity are these our brethrÄ growne by contention, that they can leese their tyme in deuising these toyes of Chimerical common welthes? where is the spirit of humility? where is the vertue of modesty
become? is this fit for designed martyrs; or for good confessors or labourers in Gods vineyard? Truly we heare say, that when the Cardinals Protectors heard and read these things in Rome, they could not choose but laugh, but yet they pittied our case also, considering therby the ambitious designmÄts of this new comon welth and commanded the Commissary to enquire of M. Bish. (for that VV.B. wryttÄ vnder the discourse might seeme to import his name) what he knew of the man that wrote this; or the matter?Exam. G. B 25 Ian. 1599. For the matter he said he had not seene the wryting nor subscribed his name, nor knew not the man, but only by hearsay, that he had byn about some 15. yeares in England and had escaped out of prison, and that he thought he had yeilded to the heretikes somwhat to auoyd torture, and get his liberty, and that he had seene a certaine cataloge carryed about of Cath. names, whome rhis man was said to haue detected vnto the persecutors,God graÅ«t he mend novv. but afterward to haue done pennance. And this was all he said of him.

VVel then after all this was considered of, and conferred (as is said) with his Hol.The tvvo Cardinals coming to the Colleg & hearing the matter the 17. of Feb. 1599. the Cardinals came to the Colledge togeather with the Comissary, and to proceed more substantially they hard first the forsaid
dispositions read as also the procurators of the Archpriest what they could say or demaund, who bringing foorth the foresaid letters of the most graue of our natiÅ against this new sedition begÅ; made supplication that some effectual remedy might be put therunto. The messengers also were hard what they could say or answere

And finally after diuers graue speches vsed by the Cardinals against this diuisiÅ in our nation, they departed, promising to relate all vnto his Hol. and to take his resolution for the final sentence, which they sent afterward sealed and signed by their owne hands and seueral seales bearing date the 8. This decree beginneth thus: Quoniam nulla alia in re magis. &c. of April 1599. In which sentÄce, for that diuers things were inserted in the narration which might seeme greuous, and the decree it selfe, which is yet extant to be seene, appeared somwhat seuere, Father Persons, as we vnderstand, procured the said sentence to be deteyned, vntil he had entreated the said Cardinals to mitigate somwhat that sentence, and to giue another more myld of the 21. of the said moneth, not so much by way of iudical sentence, as of a letter vnder their hands and seales, appointing, that the said two messengers should returne,The 2. and final sence of the Cardinals 21. April 1599. the one to Paris, the other to Loraine as they had requested,
but not into England without special licence of his Hol. or of the Protector vnder paine of suspension and other censures, &c. VVhich sentence they accepted and confirmed also by a corporal oath, and promised not only the true and sincere fulfilling therof, but also to procure euery where & alwayes with others in like maner to returne vnto vnity for the tyme to come especially in England, where they assured, that seing his Hol. had confirmed now againe by a new Breue bearing date the 6. of April,The Popes nevv Breue 6. Ap. 1599. the authority of the Archpriest togeather with the Cardinals letters and euery percel therof; there would be no more controuersy or contention for the tyme to come, VVhich how it hath byn performed all Engishmen do know, & wee shal endeuor to set downe breefly the principal points therof in the chapter following.

div.head: OF THE ENDING OF all controuersies vpon the publication of his Hol. Breue. And hovv by the art of the Common enemy matters vvere brought to vvoorse breach soone after then euer before. And of the excesses of our discontented brethren from that tyme vnto the publication of these late libels, togeather with some of their dealings vvith the Councel. CAP. X.
div.p:
AFter his Hol. had wel considered the little weight of reason which these two former messengers had brought in the behalfe of their partners in England, for raysing so great a sedition against the Protectors letters and Archpriests institution, and had giuen some due reprehÄsion to the said messengers by their restraynt aswel in Rome, as by that they were not permitted to returne presently into England, he thought conuenient to confirme the said Protectors letters, and euery part and percel therof with a new Breue dated the 6.The Popes nevv Breue for cÅfirm. of the Archp. 6. Ap. 1599. of April 1599. affirming: Omnia & singula de expresso mandato & ordine, & cum participatione & certa. scientia nostris facta & ordinata fuisse &
esse. That all and euery thing conteyned in the same letters were done and ordayned by his Hol. expresse comandement and order & by his certaine knowledge and participation, and therfore to haue byn, and to be firme, and in force, and of most full validity, &c. And so to be taken, and executed of al men, &c.

This declaracion and confirmacion of his Hol. when it came forth, euery man was of opinion that all questions and controuersyes would be ended therby, seeing that nothing was pretended before by the troublesome, but only to haue certayne knowledge of his Hol. wil and meaning. The 2. messengers also in Rome hauing seene this Breue, did giue great assurance by promises, that neyther they nor any of their side in EnglÄd would euer styrre more in these affayres, whervpon they were presently set at liberty as before hath byn said, all curtesy & kyndnes being shewed thÄ in like maner both in the Colledge & abroad by the English Catholike nation in Rome,F. Persons vsage of the messengers in Rome. but especially and aboue others F. Persons shewed vnto them all kynd of loue & confidence, conuiting them (as we are informed) both to the Colledge & vyneyard, & making large discourses with thÄ of the inconueniences of these diuisions and best
means how to procure and conserue peace for the tyme to come. VVhich councel they promised most faithfully to follow, & M. Bish. in a letter of his to M. Colington of the 29.M. Bish letter from Rome to M Colington 29. Ap. 1599 of April, which was 8. dayes after the Popes Breue was published wryteth thus: Good Sir, synce my last letters I was set at liberty by F. Persons especial intercession and procurement, Hovv then doth he deny this aftervvard. as I am many wayes a certayned, but so that after I haue some 10. or 12. dayes stayd heere to visit the holy places, I shal returne vnto Paris to stay there vntil I heare further from his Hol. or the L. Cardinal Protector, before whome I was this morning and did see in his countenance & words an harty good affection towards the spiritual good of our countrey, exhorting me & wishing vs all to grow into an entyre harty vnity and louing agreement, &c. VVherefore I exhort yow in all frendly sort to set to your helping hand, &c. And albeit at the first yow obtayne not that which we wish yow, By this vve set hovv these men vvere pre
â¢ enders & could not expect their due tyme. and your long fruitful trauels some to deserue, yet vpon your quiet peaceable behauior, we are promised yow shalbe remembred, &c.

By this letter we may see that M. Bish. had another sense and feeling of F. P. dealing towards him when he was in Rome, then now he telleth the world in his printed Epistle, if he did not dissemble greatly at that tyme, which he needed not to haue done, seing he was then at liberty some
dayes before he wrote this letter. And we vnderstand that F. P. not only wrote himselfe in his commendation very effectually to Card. Surdis Archbishop of Burdeaux, F.P. letter to Card. Surdis 7. of may vvhich beginneth. Etsi propter insignÄ, &c. but procured also Card. Caetan the Protector to wryte to the same effect wherby he receaued much curtesy at his hands. The said F. P. also wrote a common letter vnto M. Colington and M. Mush about the same tyme some few dayes before the Breue came forth to wyt vpon good Fryday, requesting them most instantly to cooperate withal possible indeauour to this desyred effect of peace and vnion. He beginneth thus.

p.q:
Reuerend good Fathers and my old acquainted frends the hope I haue of your ChristiÄ vertue maketh me to wryte vnto yow at this tyme,F. Persons letter to M. Col. and M Mush 9. Ap. 1599. especialy in this day of the passion of our Sauiour who died on the crosse to gather together, and to make vs all one, and whosoeuer disperseth yow know is against him. I haue seene diuers letters, and heard by more reports of diuers differences eyther begonne or continued there among brethren, and such as ought to be frÄds; with more vehemency then I could haue wished, especially in such a tyme of persecution, as this is, many are scÄdalized with it, and our cause is defamed
both heere, and in other places. I will not iudge any mÄ, or lay the fault vpÅ any particular: God help all, and I am and shalbe ready to cooperate thervnto, in whatsoeuer I shalbe able.

div.p:
This is the beginning of his letter, & then ensueth a more large persuasion vpon many important reasons which we omit for breuityes sake. He answereth also some obiections of them that make debate, wherof one is this.An obiection ansvvered. To the obiection of some (sayth he) that I am of another body, and therfore no great frend of yours, let my actions answere, to wit, the Seminaryes I haue procured in Spaine and Flanders, and the helpes for Doway, are they for men of my vocation or yours? & if they weare of myne, yet being all to one end and to one publike seruice of our countrey each one in their degree, no good man ought to fauour this emulation, and he that putteth fire to it, or putteth not water where or when he can, hath much to answere for in my opinion. Finaly my good frends, I am stil, and shalbe (God willing) vnto death, the same man that many yeares agoe yow haue knowne me, most desyrous and ready to help and pleasure al wherin I can, and to offend none, desyrous to set forward our common cause wherin soeuer I may, desyrous
of peace and vnion withal, and of breach with none if it may bee, and of that which hath byn to make revnion by all good means possible, & the like I do write to your R. Archp. desyring him and F. G. to do and procure the like, hauing no least auersion (I thanke God) from any mÄ, but can be contÄt, & most glad to loue, esteeme and reuerence him as his place and parts require.

Thus wrote F. P. euen then when yet the Popes Breue was not come forth, as appeareth, for that this was wrytten the 9. of April, and the Breue beareth date of the 21. of the said moneth. And to shew further his earnest desyre in this poynt he addeth to his forsaid letter this postscript. To the end that our R. Archp. and F. Garnet may know my desyre of ending all matters past, I do send this by their hands to be deliuered vnto yow, and I nothing doubt but that they wil concurre also to the same effect.

body.p:
To this letter wrytten as we haue said to M. Colington and M. Mush ioyntly,M. Mush his letter to F.P. 26. May 1599. in ansvvere of his of the 9 of April. was returned an answere by the second of the two soone after which beginneth thus: Reuerend F. I haue receyued yours to M. Colington and my selfe this saturday after the Ascension at my returne to London being departed thence the VVednesday before
without all hope of vnion or agreemÄt betweene the R. Archp. and vs, that forbare to admit the authority before we should see it confirmed by his Hol. &c. Many of good learning and timerous consciences iudged we were not bound to admit the same before some Breue, Bul, or such like from his Hol. could be shewed.

This poynt was stood vpon for d â¢ lay all this yeare, &c. But it is lothsome to renew or styrre in such foule matters all being ended, or I hope presently wilbe vpon the coming and notice of his Hol. Breue which now I haue seene, I was departed London, and vpon the coming of it, I was sent for by post to returne, and so all things are wel ended to the comfort of vs all, and we wil doe our best endeauour to pacifie and vnite all the rest. I trust F. Holtby and I haue made a good conclusion of all things betweene the Society and me at Christmasse last, aswel cancelling all matters of contention or disfrendship for tymes past, as according of a plot for preuenting of any breach herafter, for that is no ioy for me to be at variance with any, much lesse with your selfe,Ex ore tuo re indice, &c. or any of your Society, to whome I cannot forget how much I am bound, yet hath the contrary fallen out by many meanes, God forgiue them that were
in fault. Good Father I accept of your kyndnes; & persuade my selfe of your good wil towards me, and in all I am, I render yow the like. I thinke truly for these. 15. yeares I haue not almost any day omitted to remember yow in the best part of my office, that God might speed and prosper your endeauours to his honour and our contreys good, for which I vetily persuade my selfe yow toyled not a litle and spent yourselfe, when I had the greatest auersiÅ, this I ceased not to doe, and thus I was cÅceited, &c. I am glad to heare so many wayes of the good estate of your colledge, and wil not cease to pray for continuÄce, otherwayes we shal neuer haue true and syncere peace heere, yow haue both wisdome discretion and experience to stop and preuent the occasion of such inconueniences.

Good Father in all kyndnes, and for the quiet of very many heere procure that M. Bishop and M. Charnocke may haue licence to returne home, it wil content many and wynne them if it be effected by your good meanes, that we may haue peace vnion and ioy of all fides:This testimony vve accept novv against thÄ. feare not any disturbance by them for their owne hands wil testifie against them if they should report
or attempt any euil. Thus desyring yow to remember your poore frends wit some almes at S. Peters tombe, I cease this Sonday infra Octau. Ascens.

div.p:
The reply of F.P. the 17. of Iuly to the ansvvere of M. Mush 26. of May 1599 It vvas the 9.To this answere of M. Mush F. Persons replyed the 27. of Iuly in these woords: My louing good frend I receyued the last weeke your letter of the 26. of May in answere of myne to yow and M. ColingtÅ of the 8. (as I remember) of April exhorting and requesting yow both to make that submission to your prelate there, which to my great cÅfort I perceaue by your letter that yow meane to doe and by other letters since that tyme of others that in part yow haue done and procured others to doe, wherin no doubt, but in all respects yow haue gayned much with God and man, and wil do euery day; the more earnestly & effectualy yow proceed therin. His Hol. and both the Card. authorised in our affayres were presently made priuy of your doings heerin, and took the same very wel, and do expect confirmation. The motion also made by yow about the two messengers was proposed, and wilbe heard, I trust in
tyme if this your course goe effectually forward, and especially if their cooperatiÅ be vnderstood to worke with yow by their letters as heere they promissed,Heere vve se the good man vvas deceyued. and I cannot doubt, but they wil performe.

p.q:
For other matters touched in your letter though they be but few, yet were there much to be said, if I thought it not best to let all things past to dye. Yow say it was our fault, that in a whole yeare, we sent yow no authentical Breue about the confirmation of the Archp. and that both learned and tender consciences did thinke it lawful to repugne it. Yow cannot but see how much may be answered heere, and where faults may be layd and multiplyed considering the scandals that haue ensued, and how learned and tender consciences are wont in Dubijs to take the surer part. But as I said in my other letter, I desyre nothing more, then obliuion of those affayres, and that all matters may be lapt vp with due obedience to our appoynted prelate on all hands, and perpetual frendship among our selues, wherin yow shal fynd me euer most ready to serue yow & all yowrs as hitherto I haue byn, and am occupied in nothing els at the presÄt as the vertuous priests that come from me dayly & haue my poore assistance both heere and in other places
can and do testifie, though they in woords should say nothing, and in that course I hope to proceed stil.

I haue byn very much comforted also, and so haue many moe in this place to vnderstand by our R. Archp. letters and M. VValleys of the great good effects that yours and M. Colingtons iourney to VVisbich hath wrought with all there,This vvas an outvvard shovv of reconciliatiÅ made by D Bag. and his follovvers. which charitable proceeding of yours we haue not spared heere to make knowne to your and our Superiours to their consolation, and your great commendation and so shal continue, as aduises of such good offices shall come from thence.

div.p: By this any indifferent man may perceyue how desirous and careful F. Persons was of this peace which appeareth also by diuers other letters that he both wrote at this tyme and afterward to the Archpriest and Superiors of the Iesuits and other his frends to further the same which were ouerlong to insert in this place, but yet some poynts out of the foresaid two mens lettres we may not omit to the end that their concurrance also hierin may appeare.

F Garnets letter to F. P. 20 May 1599.First then we haue seene a letter of F. Garnet of the 26. of May wherin he writeth to F. Persons presently vpon the receyt
of the Popes Breue, saying thus: My last vnto yow were of the 19. of May wherin I answered yours of the 24 of April which brought the Breue since that tyme things are much altered into better and grear hope we haue that all wil go wel & that spedily; or rather I may wel say that all is wel already. I am not with the Archpriest now; but shal heare frÅ him within these few houres. If any new thing come from him, yow shal vnderstand it in the end of this letter, now I send yow heerwith 2. letters of his of the 21. and 24. of this present, for that he meaneth not to wryte himselfe vntil he haue setled all things heere, but out of these his letters & my relation yow may vnderstÄd how matters passed with vs since the receauing of the Breue.

Thus beginneth the letter & then passeth he on to declare the particular meeting of the Archp. with M. Colington and M. Mush vpÅ the 19. of may at 4. a clock at afternoone, where they supped togeather stayd all night, & had long reasoning vpÅ matters past and in the end the said two priests submitted themselues and promised to do what lay in them to bring in other, and namely those of VVisbich.

The Archp. wryteth thus to F. Gar. in his
letter of the 21.The Archpriest letter to F Gar. of the 21. of May 1599. of May.

body.p: Reuerend Sir I haue had as yet no further speech with M. Colington, but I hope to stay all matters in very good maner. This afternoone I mynd to go to him to forward our vnity and to mooue him to subscribe vnto a letter which I haue drawne to all our brethrÄ to suppresse all wrytings of the late schisme, that no aduersary letters do any more appeare among vs. VVhen I wryte ouer, I shal I hope, haue none other thing to relate thÄ of the peace and vniÅ amÅg vs procured vpon the sight of his Hol. Breue with a request of the returne of the messengers into our countrey. This was earnestly desired by M. Mush and M. Colington (at our meting) who promised to liue in all obedience and vnity, and my hope hierof gathereth dayly greater strength, if yow send ouer in the meane tyme my former last letter of the 20. of May and this to the R.F. Persons for his better information of our matters, yow shal do me a pleasure, because before I wryte I would haue all perfected peaceably among vs.

postscript.head: Postscriptum.
postscript.p: M. Colington hath sent for me, he and M. Mush wil talke with me about the pacification of VVisbich whither they mynd to go presently, I hope al wil be wel.An other letter of the Archpriest 24. of May 1599.

Thus he wrote in that letter, & 3. dayes after hauing talked with them againe he wryteth thus, They seeme to be contented and to be ready to procure the contentmÄt of their associates, &c. Three are gone to VVisbich vid. M. Mush M. ColingtÅ and M. Heburne, they desired of me no authority nor commission, they are gone only vpon an earnest desire to draw the Doct. M. Bluet and such other, their fauorites to a submission to this subordination. They feare some difficulty about the Doctor,The Doct. true reconciliation is doubted of by his ovvne frends. they hope to bring in all the rest, &c. I pray yow if you haue conueniency to send this letter or the copy to F. Persons and also my two former, because they conteyne a very true and particular discourse of our proceedings. VVhen all things are wel perfected, I mynd to wryte to our Protectors grace in Latyn of our peace & agreement, &c. 24. May 1599.

And further the same mÄ wryting some few dayes after to F.The Archpriest letter to F.P. 9 of Iune styl. vet. 1599. Persons himselfe begynneth his letter thus: R de. Pater in Christo Nox praecessit, dies appropinquauit, &c. dissention
is put to flight, Pax habitat in tabernaculis nostris. I was enforced vpon their contentious and contemptuous behauior to suspend the vse of faculties in M. Colington, M. Mush, and M. Heborne, but now God be blessed vpon the sight of the Breue Apostical that yow sent, they haue in such maner submitted themselues that I haue giuen them restitution of their losses. Your kynd letter vnto thÄ much mollified their stomacks. I tooke yow as a patetne to follow, and therby such peace is procured among vs that M. Colington and M. Mush haue wryten to F. Garnet of thier good-affection towards him and haue procured the submission of M. Ed. Benet. VVatson, Benson, ChÄpney & the rest to our subordinatiÅ, &c. God reward yow for your paynes in the procuremÄt of this our vniÅ, & he giue vs his grace so to vse your benefits as that neuer we abuse thÄ & that neuer wee fal into any vngrateful behauior,A prophesy of the Archp. to F. â¢ ersons. &c.

These and many other such letters were wrytten at that tyme, both by the R. Archpriest and his assistents, as also by F. Garnet, and others of the Society, and by many particular mÄ of the quieter sort, vnto their dearest frends about this affayre, wherby may be seene their true inward sÄse and meaning conserning the same, to wit,
that they most hartily and sincerly desired and procured it. The other side also made shew of the same desire or at least wayes to accept therof, but whether it were inwardly & sinceer, or outward only for a shew to satisfie the world for a tyme (for that they had protested euery where, that vpon the first sight of his Hol. Breue they would yeild) this God only can truly discerne, and must iudge when tyme shalbe,Doublenesse much doubted in some that made peace. and the most likely is that diuers of them meant plainly & sinceerly indeed, though of some of them, it is doubted that they made the peace only in external shew for the tyme, assuring themselues, that there would not want some probable occasion afterward to breake againe, and to lay the cause of breach vpon the other syde, as in effect we see it did ensue. For that a new deuise being shortly after cast out, that satisfaction must be made to them for some former hard speches vsed or wrytÄ against them in tyme of the contention, and that otherwayes their good names should be taken from them, this was a sufficient match to put fyre againe to all that which had byn raked vp before by the endeauour of the forsaid peace.

Now then all the question standeth in this, which part hath broken the peace or
which was most like to haue desire to maintaine and conserue the same.The controuersy discussed vvho did breake the peace made. For discussing of which controuersy we might vse that argument of Cassius: Cui bono? who are like to receyue most good or hurt, by the peace kept or broken? For the Archp. and the clergy ioyned with him enioyed by the peace all that they could desire, to wit quiet establishment of their subordination, honor, reputation, rest, quietnesse and his Hol. confirmation of all their doinges. The Iesuits also had asmuch as they could desire, and were satisfied in all points as appeareth by their owne letters aboue recited. But on the other side ensued the quite cÅtrari in all respects so as it could not be imagned, but that by this pacification they receaued secundum hominem much greefe and inward indignation. But we shal suppose that the better sort of them did ouercome this passion by vertue of patience, humility, obedience and mortification of mynd,A consideration of moment, hovv f â¢ r our discÅtented Brethren dealth vvith the Counsel or vvere obliged to them. yet is there another consideration of much more consequence then this, which is to consider how matters stood with thÄ, or some of them at least, & with the Archp. at the comming of the Breue, but much more with the councel, and some great men of the aduersary part.

And with the Archpriest the wound
made immediatly before the comming of the Breue was very greene for we haue seene an appellation made the 6. of May 1599. which was very few dayes before the arriual of the forsaid Breue in England, wherin after a narration set downe of griefes and suposed iniuries to be receaued, there followed these words: Nos quorum nomina infrÃ apponuntur contestamur, &c. VVe whose names are vnder wrytten do contest, that we do appeale & to haue appealed by our former wryting (from yow to the Sea Apostolike, as wel for our selues as for all our brethrÄ, who haue adioyned themselues vnto vs in this cause or shal adioyne themselues herafter,

list.item: Ioannes Colingtonus.
Ioannes Musheus.
Anthonius Heburnius.

div.p:
By this appeale not only for themselues but for all others in like maner that should ioyne themselues vnto them (which is against the nature of all iust appeales) is easily perceaued that an egregious faction was meant, as deuised perhaps vnder hÄd, by the persecutors thÄselues, who hauing with them in London at this tyme, if he were not very lately returned, D. Bagshew, called vp as is supposed by his owne procurement,
it is very likely they agreed with him, that in no case what soeuer determination should come from Rome, peace should be made or kept with the Archp. and Iesuites which poynt it may be M. Colington and M. Mush did somwhat gesse at, when they shewed so much doubt to the Archp. (as before yow haue hard) of bringing D. Bagshaw into this recÅciliatiÅ. But how so euer this be we nothing doubt but that these three were egged on by the said doctor to make this appeale and open breach from the Archp. for that the like was practised by him and his of VVisbich before, and from what fountayne he might haue his influence in these affayres doth diuers wayes appeare. And amongst others we haue seene a letter wryten by a reuerend priest in VVisbich (whose name for feare of further daunger we must for the present conceale) not many dayes before this Breue came, to wit the 15. of April 1599. in these words.

body.head: The letter of a reuerend priest N.N. 15. of Apr. 1599.
body.p:
your letter dated the 28. of March I haue receyued, &c. It may be yow are desirous to vnderstand in particular how your frends haue passed ouer these wytner stormes, the same I wil declare vnto yow as breefly as I can. And
first for the matters of VVisbich it is greatly suspected that Doct. Bagsh. was a great cause of the remoual of F. Edm. &c. these suspitions are alleaged: First the day after D.B. was gone the minister of the Towne coming to the Castel, said, that D.B. tould him, that he looked to be remoued, or it were long and therfore it is thought that he was the cause of his owne remoue. Secondly, presently after D. B. departure he sent this message to M. Bluet, that the cause of his sending for was concerning certaine matters which M. Bluet and he had oftymes talked of; and that he had not thought that those matters would haue ben brought to passe so soone as he saw they would; what matters these should be, but the remouing of Father Edmunds, &c. we cannot coniecture. Againe by reason that M. D. B. sent to haue his portion of money as he had before, & that it was denyed by many, and by M. Archer especially who said he could need no money that had 40.This is he that vvas sent vp and dovvne to raise reproches against Iesuits Supra Cap. 6. & 7. crownes to geue vnto Fisher, M. Bluet fel into a great rage, gaue him many oprobrious woords, and by multiplying of speches, he swore before God, he would cal the Constable, which he did, but when he came in, he
had little to say to him, but entertayned him curteously with a pot of ale. Notwithstanding he sent M. Archer this message, that if he did not come to submit himselfe vnto him before the next morning at ten of the clocke, before God he would wryte to the councel, for that he would not be hanged for neuer a knaue of them all. VVhether he did or no it is not certainly knowne; But this is certaine that M. Archer, &c, were remoued to the Towre not long after. Now after the remouing of F. Edm. the very Protestants themselues did say, that if in the castle they had not bin false amongst themselues F. Edm. &c. had neuer byn sent for. Also both before their departure and after; some frends sent word that there was a false brother amongst them who had reueyled all the secrets of the house and byd them looke for troubles.

After the departure of F. Edm it went round that the troublesome fellowes at VVisbich were gone, and that the Iesuits sought to kil the Q. & hÄg D. Bag. who was a good subiect, as also to haue a preheminence ouer the priests, &c. This passing on M. Blu. M. Cauer & M. Thulese gaue warning that they would come, into comons and that the councel had commanded it
should be so, the rest proposed three things to thÄ, which if they would graÅ«t, thÄ they should come with their good wil, other wise they would neuer consent vnto it.The appeale of some in VVisbiche before the Breue. First to submit themselues to the Archp. to this they answered: They had appealed. The second was to liue vnder the same rules that the rest did, to this they answered they would not, for that they would haue no lawes but the lawes of the Church. They being asked who should explicate them, they answered, God would prouide & sayd they doubted not but there would be meanes sufficient to curbe those that would not be quiet,Tis is presumed to be by vvay of the Councel vvith vvhome they dealt. they were demaunded to tel, what that was, but they would not. The third thing was they should not bring the keper with them, they answered, they would not, but not withstanding they said the Councel had commanded that he should come, and he must come whether they would or noe, and in this sort they came to commons.

div.p:
Thus saith that letter, and further declareth a certaine exorbitÄt speech passed a litle before from M. Blu. against M. Barlow a very reuerend and auncient priest, which we for very modesty and shame wil let passe to dishonor our brethren with
the report therof; but all tended to shew what confidence the former of the two had with the Councel, calling the other a trayterous K. for being witnes to a letter receaued from the Archpriest and that if he should be put to death for that quarel he should die a traitor and not for religion. And towards the end of the next moneth after D.B being now returned (if he were not before) another priest wrote a letter in these woords.

body.head: The letter of an other R Priest from VVisbich 28. May. 1599.
body.p:
Our Doctor hath in some sort obtayned his desire, for now he raigneth King in M. Pounds chÄber according to his former plots and designments, yet is he at the last constrayned to yeld his obedience to our Superior with the rest of his confederats, if it be true that M. Mush and some others affirme. For M. Colington and M. Mush came hither vpon thursday night and wÄt away vpon VVhitsonday eue, who belike haue qualified their distemperate humors, for otherwise they seeme to vs, that they are the same men that they were before, &c. Some speeches we heare that we shal haue new orders from the Councel and no stranger shalbe admitted to talke with any of vs,These orders soone after came and vvere 30. in number subscribed by the L of Canturbury & some others. but with the Doctor & M. Bl. only; a goodly submission in the meane while.
Your frend M. B. & my selfe were as deep in the doctors daunger as any of the rest as I am a certayned since M S. his returne, who maruayled exceedingly how we escaped. I hope God hindred that part of his plot, for some better purpose, &c.

div.p: Thus wrote he. And besydes this we haue seene the copye of a certaine relation or memorial wrytten by the keaper of Wisb. to the Lords of the counsel about certaine speaches, which he saith M. Bluet had with him two dayes after the calling to London of D. B. and he putteth the whole speech downe in six Articles, which as we heare some of the counsel made no great secret of, eyther for vsing the same to their commodytie, or mysliking perhaps in way of honour such maner of proceeding one against an other in men of the same religion. And at the last change from VVisb. to Fothringam, an authentical copy was found therof, lost or negligently lefte among papers. And if the sayd Keeper do not greatly abuse M. Bluet in that relatiÅ to the counsel, it is easely seene how far passion and contradiction hath drawen both him and others against charitie and religion. The Copye of the memorial is this that followeth.

div.head: M. Bluets talke vvith the keaper of VVisb. 1599.A memorial of such talke as Tho. Bluet priest had with me W. B. keaper of the priests in VVisbich Castel, two dayes after D. Bag. was sent for by a Pursyfaunt so neere as I could remember. But I am certaine this was the very effect of his speeches.
div.p: First that there were amongst his companie meaning his fellow prisoners two factions,Of this diuision and the true causes, see before ca. 6 and marck the falshood of this information. the one altogether following the humor of the Iesuit Edmonds, who is altogether Spanish; and the other part opposing themselues against him, semes to take part and allow of all such enterprises as the right Ho. the Earle of Essex hath vnder taken in his employments for the warres against the Spaniards so as reprochful speches hath rose betwene them many tymes for this controuersy.

Blu. told me he very muche feared, there mought be letters sent from Rome from the Cardinal Caietan to Edmonds (and as I remember he told me this Cardinal was the Popes nephew) to reproue and chide D Bag. and others, for that they were not obedient to Edmonds the Iesuit & his proceedings.See vvhat thinges & hovv false they suggest to the Councel. Noe mauel though Edmonds vvas sent for presently vpÅ this to the Tovvre. VVhich if it were so, he feared that the Iesuit might be commanded to
sweare all the Priests to be trew to the Infanta of Spayne: but Bluet protested before he would take such an othe, he would be starued to death in the Castle of VVisb. protesting vnto me that he knew D. Bag. to be of the same mynd.

Blu. told me, that the Iesuit and his partakers had wrot to Rome against D. Bag. and his partie, the answere of which letter, Blu. thought your Ho: might intercept, fearing that it was conningly wrot, and sent so as it mought and should be intercepted by your Ho.A very improbable deuise. on purpose to haue your Ho. haue cause against the Doctor to put hym to death which he verely beleueth the Iesuits do muche desyre.

Blu. told me there were 18. priestes (their names he told me not) were banished the English howse in Rome,This is so false as neuer one priest or Scholler vvas trobled for this matter nor the booke euer read hitherto publikely in the Colledge. where Persons is chief, for that they would not consent, that the booke of tytles should be publikely & daily read in the Colledge. VVhich booke he sayed was connyngly dedicated to my L. of Essex by a Iesuit, on purpose if it mought haue bene to disgrace his honour with her Maiestie: and that D. Bag. had mightely inueyed against that booke, for which the Iesuits had muche disgraced him beyond the Seas.

Blu. told me, he thought that if D. Bag.
were examined by my Lord of Essex,This vvas a deuise to be called & examyned. he would confesse the whole circumstance of this matter.

Blu. told me, that if I had occasion to wryte vp to M.Clarcke of Councel. VVade, I should warne him, how he trusted Raphe Ithel for he fauored the Iesuits faction, of which Society he had byn 8. yeares, and doth deale malitiously with those who do oppose thÄselues against the Iesuits bad proceedings, affirming that Ithel hath had of late (as Bluet can very suffi â¢ iently proue) priuat cÅference with one Gerrard a Iesuite,If this vvere true vvhat spirit as this of a priest to bevvray yt to the enemy. who of late brake out of the Tower, and hath continual conference with him.

By this then & diuers otherwayes which we leaue to speake of here, it is easy to see what manet of negotiation these men had in hand when the breue came, and hovv farre they were embarked and entangled, &c. with the councel at this very tyme, who would haue byn loth to haue had the matter ended so easily by his Hol. Breue: and likely it is that the said Councel had greater matters promised thÄ against the Archp.The councels endevour to let our peace. and Iesuites by such as dealt with them, & that this diuision should not only not be cured but be brought in tyme to a greater breach, as by the euent, we haue seene performed. For first vnder the forsaid pretence
of satisfaction to be made vnto them of their fames wounded, delay was made of reconciliation, then new quarels pickt, new complaints fained, new exaggeratiÅs made by words and wrytings both against the Archpriest the Catdinals Protectors, & F. Persons by name especialy concerning the treaty of their two messengers in Rome. Deuises for nevv breaches. the one wherof was, after a tyme inuited to come home and so he did leauing Lorayne where he was confined and for some shew of iustification of his fact (which rather in truth was an aggrauation) he went to a certain Notary & appealed from the sentence of the two Cardinals giuen in Rome with order and participation of his Hol.A very ridiculous appeale of M. Charnock. and accepted by him and his fellow for a whole yeare or there about. And with this going to Paris where the other resided tooke both of them schoole degrees vpon them, this man of Bachler, the other of Doctor of diuinity notwithstanding his Hol.His Hol. Breue against doctoring vvithout approbatiÅ 19. of Sept. 1597. by an expresse Breue had forbiden the same in all Englishmen some yeares before without such licence and approbation as in the said Breue is set downe.

Heere then it was resolued, that mayster Charnocke, notwithstanding his Hol. prohibition, and his owne oath to the contrary, should go into England vnder pretÄce
of lack of meanes to liue abroad, & that only for fashions sake he should aduise Cardinal Burghesius therof which he did by a litle short contemptious letter of the 25. of May. To which the said most honorable and gratious good Card. answered with great patience and modesty the 15. of September in the yeare 1600. beginning his letter thus. Reuerend in Christ as my brother. Your letters wrytten at Paris the 25. of May about your iourney into EnglÄd were deliuered more slowly to my hand, then I could haue wished, both that I might haue answered sooner and haue disswaded that iorney of yours, if they had comme vnto me before yow were departed out of France, for that I thinke the newes of your departure wilbe very vngrateful to his Hol. as it is vnto vs, for so much as it is both against obedience, and against an expresse prohibition, and against your owne promise confirmed with an oath, and is thought wil giue occasion of new contentiÅ & troubles in England, &c.

Thus begÄ the letter, & after he answered to all the obiectiÅs or cauillatiÅs which the other had touched about their hard vsage and iniurious sentence gyuen against them, and how he had appealed from the same. These poynts the good Cardinal answereth
with great modesty perspicuity and breuity, shewing the first two to be false and spoken without ground, and that the third about appellatiÅ could haue no place at all, the sentence comming from such as it did, and therfore warneth him to looke to his conscience about the disobedience and censures incurred, and finally giueth him councel to returne to the place from whence he departed, and there make sute for the reuocation of his Hol. former restraint, which the other little or nothing regarding as it seemeth; perseuereth stil, and doth to this day, in England, exercise as we heare his function of priesthood notwithstanding the censure of Suspension so openly incurred, and vpon the 4. of Nooember returned to his grace an answere much more vndutiful then his former letter, which we heare also they are to print in which answere rouching their oath mentioned by the Cardinal, he sayth thus: quam licet tunc eluderem fraudem, M.Ch his vndutiful reply to the Card. Protector 4. Nouemb. 1600. ad maiorem securitatem vtÃ©rque ab eo absolui curauimus: though I did delude at that tyme the deceyt vsed in making vs sweare (to fulfil the sentence giuen against vs) yet both of vs afterward procured our selues for more securily to be absolued from this oath.

But heere we would aske, who could
absolue from an oath exhibited by the immediate cÅmissary or delegate of his Hol. and especially in a matter which otherwayes vnder payne of deadly synne, they were bound to accept and fulfil? and what security could be in this absolution? we would aske him also with what consciÄce he could eludere, delude an oath offered him by such an officer? and with what credit can he brag of it now? The decree was as cleere and resolute as might be set downe, in these woords:

Quaprepter praefatis Gulielmo & Roberto sacerdotibus sanctitatis suc nostroque nomine ordinamus, The decree of the 2. Cardin â¢ ls 21. April. 1599. ac in vertute sanctitatae obedientiae sub paena suspensionis Ã Diuinis ipso facto incurrendae, alijs{que} censuris paenisque serenissimi D. N. iudicio instigendis strictÃ¨ praecipimus, vt nisi de expressa Sâ¢â¢ Sae. aut Illustrissimi Card. Protectoris licentia, Angliae, Scotiae, vel Hiberniae regna pro tempore adire non praesumant, &c. VVherfore both in his Hol. and our owne names we do ordayne vnto the forsaid VVilliam and Robett priests, & do commaund them strictly in the vertue of holy obedience vnder the payne of suspension from holy orders and exercise of the same to be incurred by the fact it selfe, and vnder other censures and punishments to be inflicted at the iudgemÄt of his Hol. that none of them without expresse licence
of his Hol. or Card Protector do presume to go to any of the kingdomes of EnglÄd Scotland or Ireland for the tyme, &c.

This was the decree: And it is strange that any Cathol. priest would aduenture to breake it so openly and to glory in it by wryting when he hath done. But what? did he attend to obserue the other part of the decree any more then this? which was that they should liue quietly & obediently, and to procure others also to peace and concord: this may be seene partly by the effects that ensued his going in (for within 14. dayes after this his letter to the Cardinal there followed their greatest appeale from the Archpriest) & partly the same may be vnderstood by his owne letters. For wheras the Archpriest was the principal man to whome and towards whome he should performe these good offices it appeareth by the first letter that euer he wrote to him after his entrance into England to wit the 24. of May 1600.A quarreling letter of M.Ch. to the Archp. presently vpÅ his cÅming into Engl. that he sought occasion to quarrel with him. For thus he wryteth: Right Reuerend Sir, being returned into England, &c. This is to request yow in charity to wryte to me, why sending for me to declare the Authority giuen yow by Card. Caetans letters: yow shewed me such instructions as when I came to Rome, I found were not annexed to your commission as yow
at that tyme said were annexed, &c. And then he chargeth him with fowre particular points which the Archpriest denyeth that he euer said, that they were expressely in his instructions from Rome. And he that knoweth both the men, wil easily see, who of the twayne is most to be beleeued.

VVel after this followed stil worse and worse effects, stryfe, contention, contempt of Superiors iniurious letters wryttÄ both to the Archpriest and his frends. Appeales euery where from his authority aswel by them of VVisbich as other where abroad, which were heere ouerlong and tedious, yea lothsome to repeate. Yet may we iudge of mÄs spirits in this behalfe, when 8. priests togeather subscribed a letter to their said Superior with this sentence in it among other:A contumelious letter of D.B. & his fellovves to the Archp. 19. Ap. 1601. Nonimus, & pro animae tuae salute oramus, vt cum timore recorderis, quis mendax sit, & pater eius? VVe know, and do pray that yow also for the saluation of your soule, do remember with feare who is a lyar and the father therof? to wit the diuel.

And this they say to him, hauing in effect giuen him the Lye, diuers tymes in the said letter before, and for that he had said in his letter to them, that the greater part of VVisbich (which were triple to these men) semed to him both the bigger and better part, they accuse
him heere of no lesse then of blasphemious behauiour in that he taketh vpon him the part of God to iudge in such matters, who is the better part. And finally do wryte vnder as before I noted: Vincti Christi peripsema tuum: Christs prisoners, and your castawayes.
VVho beeing the forman of the quest, no man can greatly maruayle of such a Verdict.

And this was the course held by the troublesome especially after M. Char. returne into England, and in all this maner of proceeding yow must vnderstand that F. Persons was inueighed against in all their wrytings speeches, and doings,All faults layed craftely vpon F.P. as the cheefe author and architect (to vse their words) of all their trouble, wheras he (poore man) labored in the meane space by all means possible to stay and compose their breaches as many wayes appeareth, but for that they persuaded themselues that he had principally crossed their designments in their seditious attempts begÅne in Rome, Flanders and other places, and that his presence and credit in the Roman court at this tyme did greately let their designments, all their choler was turned vpon him knowing
also how much they should pleasure and gratify the Counsel by this course. But if this place did permit to bring forth all the letters that he wrote in this meane space into England and other where, as wel to the Archpriest, and Superior of the Iesuits, as also to others on the other side for staying of the sedition, wherof these people that accuse him cannot be ignorÄt, it would make men wonder how passion could so farre draw priests awry, as to accuse him of the contrary. And we shal only touch a few, and those not wrytten to any of his owne, least the testimony might seeme partial: but to others which in this matter cannot be suspected.

After the former letters then wrytten to M. Colington and M. Mush aboue mentioned he perceyuing that notwithstanding the former shew of reconciliation, stryfe went continually forward, he wrote a lÅg and louing letter to M. Colington himself (whome he doubted not to be the head therof in London) beginning thus:F.P. letter to M. Col. 3 Iune for peace. Good Sir, the peace and holy spirit of our blessed Sauiour be with yow & vs all euer. About this tyme twelue moneths or somwhat rather I wrote to yow and to M. Mush at the ending of the affayres of our two frÄds M. Bish. and M. Charnocke, at what tyme
aswel vpon the assurance giuen by them, as also by the answers I had from England, all were in hope to heare no more of those dissentions, &c. But now to our great maruayle we heare of new complaynts, and fresh contentions to begin againe about things past, &c.

p.q: Thus the letter beginneth which is ouerlong to be set downe heere, but after many other reasons and persuasiÅs he sayth thus: I beseech yow good Sir & the rest of your frends there, euen for Christs his sake and for the honour and reputation of our nation, and of our Catholike cause among strangers, &c. Let this be an end of former controuersyes, let peace and vnion be preserued for the tyme to come. Yow see no man pricketh, no man vrgeth, no man offereth greefe to any that wilbe quiet, &c.

div.p:
But some monethes after this againe perceyuing that this did not auayle, he resolued to wryte a very large letter vnto a certayne learned priest, with whome he persuaded himselfe he could do very much, and the said priest with them, or some of the cheefe at least. And in this letter he layeth downe all the reasons & answereth all the obiections which he thought to be the principal about this affaire, he beginneth thus: My louing frend it is now long
since I heard from yow,The letter of F.P. about peace to M. Ioh. Bennet 24. Sept. 1600. though of yow & your doings I haue byn aduertised somtymes by our frends there; to my comfort, namely of your endeauour to make peace and vnion, wherof though I neuer doubted yet am I glad to heare the same confirmed by other mens relatiÅ also, & therfore I cannot but congratulate with yow therin, exhorting yow to perseuer, quia erit operi tuo merces Ã Deo: and such as be filij pacis, wil haue Gods grace to heare both yow and others traueling to so holy and necessary an end. If any be obstinate in maintayning contention and sedition, their iudgement wilbe the heauier, & finally they wil perish therin. And albeit in this argumÄt I know that I shal litle neede to suggest any reasons vnto yow to persuade therin, knowing your iudgemÄt as I doe, and yow also in part myne, and my old desyres about the same yet, &c.

This letter the F. wrote the last yeare ful of many substantial reasons and persuasions to be suggested by him for making peace,The secÅd letter of F. P. to M. Ioh. Ben. 19. May 1601. for peace. desyring the same might be imparted with others, & receauing no answere therunto, nor seeing such effect to growe of peace as he desyred, he wrote another letter vnto him this yeare vpon the sight of another Appellation made by diuers
priests from the iurisdiction of the Archpriest. The letter beginneth thus: Louing Camerado, and fellow of our long iorney,Father P. brought him vvith him out of Spayne to Rome. is it possible that yow should so forget your old frends and acquaintance as in 3. yeares not to answere any of myne? But it may be yow want comodity of sending, &c. About the matters in cÅtrouersy wherof I wrote to yow long ago from Naples, and since againe from hence, persuading yow, and your brother to do some good offices, for making some good end, & accorde: as yow neuer answered me (at least wise I haue not seene any) so to my greife I haue not seene any good successe therein yet, but rather increase of further breach, which how preiudicial it is and wilbe dayly more and more vnto Gods glory and to our publike cause of religion, and to the reputation of all that labour in that vineyard, and to the whole worke, no man can but see. Here hath byn shewed a certaine appellation of late, wherin both your brothers hand and yours, and the subscription of diuers others my old frends and brethren are set downe. I wish greatly that yow and I might haue but one howres talke togeather, to consider of the reasons that might mooue yow and them to so
publike an act, in such a matter, and such a tyme as this is, &c.

By this and many other wayes, but especially by the effectual speches and exhortations he made to all those priests he sent into England, which haue not byn few synce the Archp. was appoynted, and this controuersy raysed; may appeare this Fathers sense and meaning and most earnest desyre of making and cÅseruing peace, but the more he sought, sighed, prayed and laboured to this end, the more obstinate and eager were the vnquiet to follow their breaches, and with all to lay the fault therof vpon him.The obstinacy of the vnquiet & iniurious dealing vvith F.P. And so finally after all their former resistance and appeales aswel of D. Bagsh. and his fellowes in VVisbich as of M. Charn. and others abroad, they ioyned in greater number vpÅ the 17. of Nouember last (if all consented therunto vvhose names are subscribed, wherof we heare the contrary in some) in all which doing of theirs one thing is especially to be noted, that they haue neuer procured any one of all their appeales to be presented hitherto or prosecuted in Rome,A special point to be noted. as farre as we can vnderstand (which yet they ought to haue done within certayne monethes vnder payne, that all is voyd if it be not done)
nay further if the Archp. himselfe had not presented these appellations to his Holines perhaps he had not hard of them till this day, which is a token that iustice and trial is not sought by these men but gayning of tyme and liberty in England for the meane space from all Superiority. And further to shew their resolute determination to liue in continual stryfe, and not to stand to the iudgement and determination of their Superiour, they haue pendentelite, during the tyme of their appeale,Presumptuous and vndutiful proceeding. & before they haue receyued the sentence of their Superior, in preiudice of the said sentence when it shal come; altered the whole case & published libels in printe ful of slaunder, contempt & malediction, aswel against the doings and proceedings of the foresaid Superiors, as against other particular men conioyned with them and following their obediÄce, so as when the said sentence of his Holines shal come forth about the forsaid appeale, which we expect daily if already it be not furth it shal fynd all matters changed to farre worse exulceration then before.
And this is the present state of our affayres. Now shal we passe on in the next chapter to examine breefly what these new libels bring with them.

div.head: ABOVT THE TVVO late bookes or libels set forth by our discontented brethren, how iniurious, slaunderous, and false they are, and how highly the wryters and publishers haue offended God, and all good men therby, with the defence of certaine particular men slaundered therin. CAP. XI.
div.p: NOw are we come (gentle reader) almost to the last, but the most lothsom part of all our answere, which is to handle and examine in particular the two contumelious libels which our discontented brethren haue published of late, the one in latyn the other in English which are such, as verily we haue great auersion and horror of mynd to runne ouer them, & therby to make reflection that Catholike priests of our order, and dedicated to so holy a worke as we professe, should euer be giuen ouer to so base and wicked a spirit as to be authors, spreaders or approuers of such things.

Libelling a great synne.For to let passe first these considerations, which cannot notwithstanding but greatly mooue a tender conscience, to wit, what the
synne of libelling is? c. Hi qui inuenti 5. q. r c. 1. & 2. &c Quidam maligni. ibidem. c. Si quis famosum l. 9. tit. 3 6. caus. 5. q. 1. 2. 3. how greeuous in the sight of God and man? how great censures are layd thereon by the Church and extreme punishments by the Ciuil lawe especially whÄ any religious cÅmunity is defamed, as heere is done? what maner of people they be for diuers respects that heere be dishonored? & of what accompt with our very enemyes themselues, some of them being Superiors,Men iniured in these libels. some of singular merit towards the common cause, others notorious for their knowne vertues. And moreouer what exceeding scandal doth arise herof both to good and bad. To the good, in that they are extremely greeued and afflicted therwith. To the bad, for that they are confirmed therby in their naughty course: for both which (no doubt) these men must answere to almighty God at the last day. All these and other like poynts, we meane to let passe in this place (though highly they greeue vs) and to handle other heads appertayning to fouler faults, if worse may be that is to falshood, deceyt, malice and slaunderous calumniations. For as it had byn a great synne to haue published in these bookes so many opprobrious and ignominious things against their brethren,Deuised contumelies a double fault. though they had byn true, not being forced by any excusable necessity thervnto,
so much greater is the fault, if they be foÅ«d false, light or vayne, inuented or augmented by themselues, and published only of splene and malice to disgrace the partyes with whome they are angry.
This then is our purpose in this short vewe of these bookes, remitting the Reader in euery part for larger proofe of matters, to the chapters before handled.

And to begin with the latyn booke which is dedicated to his Hol. whose title is this: Declaratio motuum, &c. A d â¢ claration of the styrres and troubles, The title of the latyn booke and falshoods therin vsed. that haue rysen in England, betweene the Iesuits on the one syde, togeather with M. George Blackewel Archpriest in all things fauoring them: and the Seminary priests on the other syde, from the death of Cardinal Allen of pious memory, vnto this years, 1601.

In this very title and first page, fiue or six abuses sleights & shifts may be noted to be vsed towards his Hol. which may giue a gesse of the truth in the rest of their bookes especially that in English which they might presume would not be so much examyned. For first wheras the whole world knoweth, that their controuersy is with the Archpriest as appeareth by their appellation to his Hol. Anno 1600. 17. Nouemb. & others before; & that their stomake against the Iesuits is for stÄding with
him & for him as by the whole discourse of both these bookes appeareth. Heere they change the whole cÅtrouersy, and do say that it is with the Iesuits and M. Blackwel that fauoreth them: so as he is put heere but as an Appendix in the cause which is playne falshood.

Secondly they put the priests of the Seminaries residing in England for the opposite part against the said Archpriest and Iesuits, wheras it hath byn proued in the former Chapter that these cÅtentious people are not the twentith part therof, by their owne confessions. Thirdly they say in this title that their contentions against the Iesuits began from the death of Card. AllÄ wheras we haue shewed before in the fourth chapter, by Card. Allens owne letters that some of these seditious, to his great dislike had begone to styrre against the Fathers in England euen in his dayes Fourthly they say: Ad S.D.N. Clementem octauum exhibita ab ipsis sacerdotibus: that this declaration was exhibited by the priests themselues to our most Holy F. Pope Clement the 8. which how true or false it is, his Hol. wil best testifie, who vnto this day as we heare hath neither seene the booke nor hard of it, by any of them or theirs, nor is not like to do, noe more then he
hath done hitherto of their appeales, for that their intention seemeth not to be to enforme his Hol. but to make a noise in England, and to gaine tyme of liberty, and to preoccupate some mens mynds by making a shew that they appeale to the highest, in this their controuersy, but yet in deed would be loth that he should know it, and much lother to answere it before him especially this Pope, whome they knowe by his former acts (what so euer they say) to be an enimy to their clamors and contentions and especially to libelling And if they had meant truly, and sincerly to exhibite this declaration to his Hol. and that by themselues, as heere they say, thÄ should they not haue needed to haue printed it first, or at least wayes not without his licence or liking. But hauing published it both to heretikes and Cathol. & vsed the help and counsel of heretikes especially in the matter and not sent it to Rome at all, it is very manifest what they meane, and a playne mockery to put in their title, that it was exhibited by themselues to his Hol.

Fifthy vnder the title they put this verse of the psalme. Psalm. 106. The great abusing of a text of scripture. Videbunt recti & latabuntur, & omnis iniquitas opilabit os suum. The good shal see this and be glad, and all iniquity shal stop her mouth at it. VVhich how true it
is, and with what spirit it is applyed, to wit, that all good men wilbe glad and reioyse to see this contention amongst our selues (except by good men, they meane only hererikes) and how the mouth of iniquity shalbe stopped by this lamentable sedition in our owne bowels, let other men iudge, for we cannnt see it, but rather the quite contrary, to wit that all good men that haue any sense or feling of piety do mourne & grone at this sight and very hearing hereof and that the mouth of all iniquity (if heresy & atheisme be iniquity) is not shut, but opened by this occasion to laughe at vs and blaspheme our cause, vtinÄ iste non imputetur, we pray God he impute it not to these our brethren at the last day.

Sixtly and lasty it is said in this first page that it was printed: Rhotomagi apud Iacobum molaeum subsignum Phaenicis: At Rhoane in France in the house of Iames Moleus vnder the signe of the Phenix: And whether there be any such signe or man dweling in Roan we cannot yet precisely say, but haue sent to enquyre, yet in the meane space we are most certainly persuaded the thing in it selfe to be false, and that as rhe booke was printed without licence of any Superior (except perhaps the false Bishop of London) and that it was printed in England it
selfe sheeweth not only the playne English charecters therin contayned, but also that themselfes in the end of the booke, for excusing the faults in printing say thus: Propter variaes horum temporum difficultates, &c. VVe haue byn forced through the difficultyes of these tymes to vse the help of any printer, though vnexpart in the latyn toung, and therby to diuulge this present narration ful of many faultes.

Contradiction to thÄselues.This they say in the end of the latyn booke, forgetting what they sayd in the beginning and first page that it was printed at Roan, where no difficulty of the tymes could hinder them nor learned printers want seing there are comonly as good prints and printers in that cytie, as in most cittyes of Europe, soo as heere falshood doth discouer it selfe diuers wayes, vsed euen to his Hol. himselfe, and the truth seemeth to be that these bookes were printed in England by consent of the heretikes, but yet in some secresy for auoyding the knowledg of the Catholikes more then of the enemy: Nay now it is further knowne how the matter of this printing hath past vnder the protection of my Lord of London, to whome his Hol. is much beholden for suffering bookes dedicated to him to passe with so little let or hindrance.

VVel then these six absurdityes, shifts,
& falshoods beeing discouered in the very first page of the booke as preamble to the rest, and vsed euen to his Hol. himselfe, we may imagine what the remnant wilbe. And so at the very first entrance, they tel his Hol what a great scandal it is and wil be to the world to haue these dissensions in England come abroad, and yet they are content to publish them, geuing two reasons, such as they bee for the same.Pag. 5. First that they could not haue copyes inough in wrytten hand. The second to get their good name againe in forraine nations taken away as they say, by the Iesuits. But the first point of hauing many copyes was not needful if they were only for his Hol. information as they pretend. And the second in our opinion wil fal out quite contrary, to wit that wheras they were not infamous before in forraine nations, nor knowne at all, now they must needs be, by these their infamatory wrytings.

All that they tell after this of Cardinal Allen, from pag. 6.About Card. AllÄ. that he fauored them or misliked the Iesuits, or concurred with these factions and their emulations against them, is refuted largely before in the 3. and 4. Chap. of his treatese. And as for that byting florish brought in pag. 8. against F.About F. Heyvvood. Gaspar Heywood, that he did vaunt and
brag in England as Legate of the Sea Apostolike, called a prouincial Synode, abrogated the vigils & fasts of our Lady, prohibited the acts of our martyrs vvrytten by D. Allen, they are partly plaine calumniations, and partly odious and malitious wrestings of his doings: only it is true that some 16. or 17. priests wherof one cheefe man is said to be of their faction at this day met togeather with him,Ionas Meridith. and would haue had all the national customes of England about fasting (for some litle diuersity and difficultyes which they foÅ«d in them) to be reduced to the common order of the Roman Church, which D. Allen, F. Persons, M. Blackwel, and others did not allow, and F. Heywood yeelded vnto these mens opinions; and this is all the difference that euer was betwene F. Heywood and F. Persons which yet these our brethren are not ashamed to obiect against him afterward in this same booke.

Styres in Rome and VVisb.As for the troubles and styrres in the Roman colledge which these men defend pag 9. we haue hÄdled atlarge before cap. 5. as also we haue answered sufficiently cap. 6. all that this booke hath about the styrres in VVisb. from pag. 11. vnto 23. where we haue refuted also the slaunders they bring in against that most vertuous &
blessed confessor of Chr â¢ st F EdmÅ«d VVeston.F. Ed. VVeston. The rest that followeth from pag. 14. vnto 31. concerning M BlackwelM. Black. and his office, and the false and vnworthy accusations of ambitiÅ layd vnto him, as also the many calumniations forged against F. PersonsF. Persons. for procuring him the said office are all answered at large in the 8. chapt. of this booke; where we haue shewed how, and by what motions, and vpon what reason, for what ends, and vpon whose petitions the institution of the Archpriest was appoynted. And for as much as shal cÅcerne the said F. in particular it shalbe further discussed in the next chapter following. Now only we must say a word or two for defence of two Reuerend priests, M. Doctor Haddocke and M. Martyn Array, M. Doctor Haddocke, and. M. Martyn Array. whome these our passionate brethren are not ashamed to goe about to defame in print, for that they were chosen Procurators in Rome by the Archpriest & English Cleargy adioyning vnto him, and did according to their office, resist the two messengers that came without reason to impugne the same, but yet so, as we are most certainely informed that first they indeuored by all maner of frendly persuasion, disputation and argument to induce them to some peaceable agreement, and quiet end from the scandalous
& clamourous course they had takÄ in hand, and afterward when they would not yeild to this they vrged no further, then that by order of law some remedy might be put according to the iust demaunds and letters,Cap. 9. which before we haue cyted, of the principal Catholikes of our Nation.

For this so iust and lawful office performed by them in the common cause,A defence of M. Doct. Haddocke. and for common peace, these men now as angry as waspes run vpon them with the stinges of their tÅgues, telling vs, that M.D. Haddocke had liued no â¢ long in Rome idlely, and that his liberty o â¢ life in England was of no edification, and that he was diuers tymes eyther cast out, or to be cast out of my L. Card. house, for sedition, and that wheras he was of no kinred or affinity to my L. Card. yet he fained himselfe to be his nephew; These are mere calumniations and knowne to be so, by all that know the parties, and consequently cannot but warne the Reader to be wary of such mens spirits, as haue no scruple to publish such matters vpon spleene and choler, to the defamation of their brethren. For as for M. Doctor Haddocks idlenes in Rome, what know they how he spendeth his tyme? and to how many besides may this be obiected that liue in that place, by such especially that are not priuy to their
doings, or may enuy perhaps their state. He liueth there (as we vnderstand) in very worshipful condition, entertayned by his Hol. himselfe, of whole famuly he is, & familiar of the Vic â¢ p â¢ otector Card. Burghesius and serueth his countrey, in such occasions as fal out in that place. And if he did no other thing but help to resist troublesome people, as the two Embassadours were and their companions are, that would ouerthrow all, his tyme were wel spent. And finally if he were idle, yet true is the p â¢ ouerbe, Better idle then euil occupied. VVould to God these men were idle also in England, so they were quiet, and not like busy moles or wants vnderdig our whole vyneyard by busy and pernicious working. And as for his liberty of lyfe (as they cal it) while he was in England, it is false, that it was of any euil edification, and some of vs knew him better then these libellers & his demeanor afterward in Ireland did very much good to the comon cause as we haue hard by them that knew him there, and we could wish the cheefe of these factious did giue no worse edification in their maners. It is false also which they talke of the Card. house, and of his fayning to be the Card. nephew, all men know him to haue byn of kyn to the Card. by affinity, & so the Card.
himselfe acknowledge in all his words and workes towards him while he was aliue & honoured him with the title of his Maestro de Camera. And so much of this poynt.

The defence of M. Martin Array.M. Martyn Array is a very graue priest of the first that were brought vp in the Roman Colledge companion to M. Sherwyn and diuers other holy martyrs, & himselfe a good woorkman in England and of great edification for diuers yeares, both before he was taken, and afterward in prison, and now he is Prouost of the English Church and residÄce of S. George in S. Lucar of Spaine. And wheresoeuer he hath liued synce his comming out of England (as he hath done in diuers countreys) it hath byn with great edification and honour to our nation, & his banishment out of England was by the same meanes, that many other haue byn banished, to wit by intercession of some frends, And therfore for these men now to say against him that he was, SuspiciosÃ¨ dimissus insolita haereticorum beneuolentia, Pag. 31. sheweth a great deale of malice without modesty or discretion.

There ensueth a whole inuectiue after this against diuers particular mÄ, as against M. Iames Standish a reuerend priest, now assistant to the Archpriest; whome they do exagitate most intemperatly, and say that
he was a Iesuite in a preists cote (marke their modesty)Pag. 31. 32. 33. 34. & 35 to serue in Rome for a s â¢ al to procure the subordination of the Archp.Defence of M. StÄdish & others. in the name of the priests without their consents. But we haue shewed before out of the priests owne letters the contrary,Cap. 8. & consequently these ignominious calumniations aswel against this mÄ for falshood as against M. Blackwel for ambition immediately after, and against Card. Caetan for ignorÄce in English affayres, & against F. Persons for abusing and missinforming him. All these fiery and furious darts of malice do fal on the ground or rather do returne vpon themselues by the large demÅstration we haue made before of the truth of this matter about the Archpriests institution.Cap. 8. & 9.

All the rauing also & scandalous raging at the Society of Iesuits with so many odious notes in the margent,Of the Iesuits. that Iesuits seeke their owne, Pag. 45. 46. &c. that Iesuits trouble the peace of England, that Iesuits persecute more then heretikes. These and the like haue byn examyned by vs before and shewed to be inuentions of distempered spirits set on by heretikes and so need no longer answere in this place.Cap. 1.

And thus goeth on this booke rayling & raging, and sparing no man that standeth in their way vnto the receit of his Holines
Breue for confirmation of the Archpriest pag. 61.Pag 61. And then for that they made a certayne fayned acceptance therof as yow haue hard in the former Chapter, they cry out to his Hol. Ecce Beatissime Paeter, quam rebelles in tuam se â¢ em, quam inobedientes fuimus. Behold most holy Father how rebellious we were against your Sea,The dissimulation of the troublesome in making shevv of peace. and how disobediÄt that accepted presently your Ereue; Thus they glory but let vs see the euent, for if this acceptance were true and sincere, it would haue wrought some permanent effect, if this obedience had byn vnfayned, it would haue perseuered. They go about in all the rest of this booke vntil they come vnto their last appellatiÅ to shew that the Archpriests hard proceeding with thÄ was cause of their new contentions and styrres, for so they go noting in their margent first, Archipresbyter bellum infaeliciter renouat, Pag. 62. the Archpriest reneweth the warre (against vs) vnfortunately. And then againe: Origo nouarum contentio â¢ um fuit Archipresbyters epistola violenta. Ibid. The beginning of new contentions was a violÄt epistle of the Archpriest. But suppose that the Archpriest had ouershot himselfe vpon their exasperation and had wryttÄ some angry epistle more sharp or violent (as they call it) then was expedient, should this be a sufficient cause to
priests, that professe modesty, obedience & mortification, and that come to England not only to suffer but also to dy for Christs religion? VVas this a sufficient cause (we say) for these men, if they had the true spirit of their vocation, to breake out for an angry epistle, into such scandalous tumults, exorbitant passions, and furious rages, as in these bookes and other their wrytings, and doyngs are seene? VVhat man of reason or Christian religion wil allow of this, or who wil not say that these men are not out of the right and true path of priestly proceeding.

And thus much haue we to say breefly of this present booke, dedicated to his Hol. but neuer hitherto exhibited as we are informed,Cap. 95. The appeale of the discontented 17. Nouemb. 1600. only the Appellation made the 17. of Nouemb. which followeth in the same booke hauing byn sent to his Holines by the Archpriest, as before we haue noted (& not by these men the authors therof) is to be iudged and censured by his Hol. alone, whose sentence we expect dayly therof, & we doubt not, but it wilbe such as is wont to come from that Sea (assisted by God in such determinations) to wit, graue, pious, fatherly, and prudent, confirming equity and iustice, and authority in the lawful Superior, and misliking vtterly all such clamorous
contentious proceedings in the subiects, and inferiors. This we assure our selues of before hand, when it commeth we shal see the euent, and would to God our hasty brethren would haue expected also the same sentence (as they ought to haue done) without these new scandalous innouations which in the meane space they haue made.

The last thing in this latyn booke is an epistle of M Mush,About M. Mush his le â¢ ter to Monsig. Morra. wrytten to Monsignor Morra, now Bishop, the 27. of May 1598. of which letter the publisher of this libel by way of preface sayth, that it was sent by the two messengers, and that by it, it may appeare that the said messengers had no light or vayne petitions to make at their comming to Rome, Pag. 121. if they might haue had audience. But first all this matter of the messengers petitions or comissions hath byn handled largely before out of their owne examinations, papers,Cap. 9. letters & memorials. Among which as farre as we can perceaue, no mention at all is hard of this epistle of M. Mush though some of the poynts touched in this letter, were mentioned also by others.

Secondly the fi â¢ st newes that euer was hard of this let â¢ er in England, or abroad, was that in May 1599. when the new Breue
was come into England, and the two Messengers where gone from Rome a copy of this letter was brought to the Archp. M. Tyrwyt and some others being togeather; from the B. of Londons house, which how he should come to it, no man can hitherto tel, some do gesse he might fynd it in some search, others do suspect worse that it might be giuen him vnder hand by some of the factious (D. B. hauing byn lately with the councel in London) to shew therby their endeauors against Iesuits, which could not be vngrateful vnto them M. Mush himselfe would seeme to imagine that it had byn shewed in Rome and from thence sent back agayne into EnglÄd by F. Persons,In his le â¢
ter to F. Garnet 1599. and so intercepted by the Bishop of London.17. of Iuly 1599. cited before. ca. 10. But this F. Persons answereth himselfe by a letter to M. Mush at the very same tyme, shewing that he had neuer seene any such letter, vntil it was sent him out of England after the messengers departure and after it was had from the Bishops house, and that the messengers neuer spake of any such letter to him, nor that any such thing was found amongst their papers. And as for the contents of the letter it selfe they consist in 4. petitions or as he more haughtely called them (postulata) demaunds to his Hol wherof the first is
that Bishops of their owne choise be appointed ouer the cleargie of England. The second that the English Colledge in Rome may be taken from the gouernment of the Fathers of the Society, and be deliuered to Engli h secular priests or other religious men ro be gouerned. The third that all bookes should be prohibited, wherby the Queene and temporal magistrates may be exasperated. The 4. that his Hol. would giue them licence to make new rules both for themselues and others that wil ioyne togeather in their former association.

About Bishops and the Sacrament of confirmation.In the first of these foure petitions he goeth so farre vrging the necessity both of Bishops and specially the Sacrament of confirmation, as by the former he must needs condemne greatly his Hol. and the Sea Apostolike for suffering England to be so long without Bishops, and in the second he seemeth to iumpe with his partner in the English booke, who sticketh not to say,Supra. ca. 2. as before hath byn noted, that eyther confirmation is necessary now in England, or else it is an idle ceremony.

About the gouernmÄt of the Iesuits.In the 2. demaund besides that he is cÅtrary to himselfe in his former letters, as hath appeared before by that we haue shewed of his in the third 4. and 5. Chapters, he runneth so farre heerein fayning causes
