against the Fathers gouernment, as he deuiseth things to be spoken by Cardinal Allen & Cardinal Boromeo, which they are knowne neuer to haue said nor thought, but the quite contrary as before haue byn shewed cap 4. and he is not ashamed to obiect to the Fathers their partiality towards some, more then towards other, and all this to drawe yong men to their Society wheras in the former we know by experience, and can testifie, that no other thing euer wrought the Fathers more trouble in the colledge while this mÄ was there, then their ouer much loue and fauour to him aboue his merits, as other mÄ thought, and yet was not this to draw him to their Society, seing they would not admit him, in so many yeares as he pretended to enter, forseeing, as may be thought his perilous nature, which now discouuereth it selfe in these seditions of England, against those especialy to whome vnder his owne hands befote cyted he confesseth to be so greatly bound vnto.Cap. 10.

In his third demaund about prohibiting of bookes that may exasperate the State (naming only F Persons therein)About exasperating bookes. he sheweth only Stomake and malignity and nothing els. For first M. Bishop as before hath byn shewed out of his confessions,Cap. 9.
misliked this demaund, and that such bookes had not done any hurt in his iudgment but rather good: And we do aske further, if any haue exasperated, why is F. Persons named their-in, and none but he? do not we know what styrres there hath byn about the bookes of Doct. Saunders, both his Monarchy and that of Schisme? do not we know what trouble there hath byn about Doctor Bristow his Motyues by name, and that men haue byn posed particularly for thÄ euen to the death of some. And what say yow of my Lord Cardinal Allen (of whome this fellow wil needs seeme a special pupil, but indeed was neuer esteemed by him) his answere to the Engl. iustice, his defence of the 12. martyrs in one yeare; his Epistle for allowance of Sir VVilliam StÄleyes rendring vp of DauÄtry his declaration against her Maiestie and the present State in the yeare 1588. when the Armata was on the Seas, alleaged euery where in printed bookes against vs by Protestans were these exasperating treateses or no? and how then is F. Persons only named by this man, as though his wrytings only were the cause of all exasperatiÅ? Nay was there any man euer knowne to be particularly troubled hitherto for any booke wrytten by F. Persons, by name? VVe are
sure that neyther M. Mush nor any of his can euer proue it, or giue one example, albeit the said Father hath wrytten many bookes to the great profit of our cause, both of matters pertayning to deuotion & controuersies, and yet this man and his fellowes, hauing neuer wrytten any, in any of both kynds, nor euer put pen to paper against the enemy, but only against their brethren, and to set sedition, do wrangle against F. Persons for his wel doyngs.

His fourth demaund for liberty to make rules, About rules of their AssociatiÅ. Cap. 7. &c. is sufficiently considered of before where we haue taken the vew of their platforme of Association, and how quickly they were deuided among them selues in their deuise, and the two messengers were so discontented with this fellow, at there being in Rome for deuising a new plot in the North, different from that which M. Colington and others had inuented before in the South, as they said oftentymes that he had byn the ouerthrow of all. For which cause they neyther presented this his letter if they brought it with thÄ, nor scarse so much as named him in their examinations among the pillers of their new Association; yet now they haue byn content to print this letter of his therby to shame him vtterly with his old frends,
and to bynd him to be turbulent styl vpon desperation; to which end they haue printed also another vnworthy and passionate letter of his in the English booke as wrytten to F. Persons vpon the 13. of Nouember 1600. beginning:An otherâª passionate letter of M. Mush in F. P. 13. Nob. 1600. Pag. 178. VVel vvel F Persons, &c. and subscribid. Yours, as yow are to our church I.M. And the thing it selfe is nothing but a pathetical or passion â¢ te short inuectiue nor worthie to be read of any mÄ of iudgement, and much lesse to be answered and least of all to be wryten, and printed by a priest that is in his fiue wyts, as the world is wont to say, let the Reader be iudge, and whosoeuer may seeme to require answere therin abo â¢ t the two messengers vsage in Rome, let him read in the 9. and 10. chapters of this Apology. And in the meane space let him consider of the wrytters temperature, when he saith that F. Persons hath cancelled all his former good acts done to the English Cathol. cause b â¢ this consenting, or (as this man imagineth) procuring the two messengers to be restrayned in Rome, as though this had byn the synne of all synnes and inexpiable.

About the second booke in English.And thus much be spoken of the first booke that is in latyn, which is more then at the beginning we thought to say in this
place; yet somwhat must we say also of the second in English intituled The Copies of certaine discourses, &c. which booke is said to be prynted at Roan, by the same verity, that the other was before, which is knowen to be printed in London. And to this title there is added also a sentence of Scripture aswel applyed as the former for heere is said out of the Prouerbs Dicit piger, Prouer. 2 â¢ . leo est in via. The slouthful excuse themselues, saying there is a lyon in the way. There meaning seemeth to be that what soeuer standeth in their way, eyther superiority, authority, power, reason, Religion, shame, peril, honour of their contrey, yea the crosse-kayes of S. Peters seate thÄselues or what so euer other lyon, yet must they go forward with their sedition begone; and feare or respect no man or matter. And this was their cheefest principle also in the Roman sedition, vntil the Lyon of the tribe of Iuda, and his true Vicar resolued to dissipate that obstinate resolution, as in the end we doubt not but he wil do this also.

There followeth a preface to the Reader which taking vpon it to set downe the true state of the questiÅ putteth it wholy to the contrary, debaseth the Archp.The Preface to the Reader. and Protector, and in the end layeth open foundation to all disobedience, wherof
yow may see more noted before in the second Chapter of his Apologie.Tvvo impertinent discourses. Then ensue two other discourses, one of him that thirsteth the good of the Reader, the other hath no name to yt, but is subscribed:

Both these do giue reasons, such as they bee, why they did not obey the Card. Protectors letters & were wrytten before the Breue of confirmatiÅ came forth, and so are now superfluous, for that his Holines wil is knowne & yet doth not quiet them.Ouerthrovv of their principle. And wheras all their reasons are founded in one principle, to wit, that they probably doubted of his Hol. cÅmandement & ordination therin,Cap. 2. 10. & 11. we haue shewed before that this was but a vayne pretence, and that they could not morally doubt therof, hauing letters patents of a Card. Protector for the same, and that they were bound vnder greeuous synne, by all rules of true diuinity to haue obayed with farre lesse euidence, especially seing their repugning and disobedience was to bring so great scandal and hurt to the Church of England. VVe haue noted also the scandalous and temerarious propositions therin contayned.Cap. 2.

There followeth after this M. Champneys letter of the same tenor, and no lesse fond and childish then the former discourses,
though somwhat more resolute and peremptorie. He entreth with a florish of a certayne example:M. Champney his letter. If a noble man in England should addresse his letters into IrelÄd, signifying that he had receyued authority frÅ her Maiestie, to ordayne in that countrey what gouernment he thinketh best, and togeather should specifie a gouernment neuer hard of in that countrey, or any other; and if the subiects should stagger or doubt to admit, &c. In this example he glorieth much, which is no more like to our true case then London to Lincolne, nor any way sincerely set downe. For is the Cardinal Protectors letter wrytten in his Hol. name, and by his expresse commandement, no more then of some one of our nobilityes letters into Ireland? if he had said a noble man of the priuy councel to whome all Irish affayres had byn comitted he had said somwhat, though not fully to the purpose. Besydes the Card. sayth not in his letters (as this man reporteth) that he hath authority from his Hol. to appoynt what gouernment he thinketh best, but this namely of the Archp. which he appoynteth. And further with what modesty can he say that this gouernment of the Archpriest was neuer hard of before in any countrey, seing it is knowne to be
(and so the Cardinal himselfe telleth them an ancient title and dignity in the Church of Christ. And albeit the ordinary iurisdiction therof did not comonly extend so farre and ouer so many as this doth, yet may his Holines giue both to him or any other priest Episcopal or Archepiscopal iurisdiction (as these our Brethren do brag euery where of their more then episcopal facultyes) & to deny this were great ignorance and audacity. So as in effect M. ChÄpney (of whose modesty we had a far greater opinion) addeth nothing to the two former discourses, but certayne bold assertions of:M. Champneys bould assertions. I say it was no synne, I say it was no disobedience, I say it was no offence at all, I say the authority did beare euident suspition of manifest surreption, and that it was procured contrary to the Canons of the Church, that it was against the right of natural reason. VVhich (I say) so often repeated against the authority of his Superiors, and this in so yong a man cÅme lately from the schoole and not the best learned among his fellowes (for that the most of his best tyme in his course of diuinity was lost or euil imployed in the seditiÅs of the Colledge, wherin we vnderstÄd he was a principal Agent and counselor) all this we say cannot but import great presumption of spirit, and so discret men wil
iudge of him and esteeme him and his, and their cause accordingly. VVe haue answered such reasons as he brought sufficiently before,Cap. 10. and shewed his ignorance also and euil sense in poynts of diuinity touching obedience, and considered in like maner the information and decree of the Doctors of Paris.

And as for their ostentation of Canons dist. 63. cap. 12. & dist. 61. cap. 13.An ansvvere-to Canons obiected. so often cyted by this man and his fellowes against his Hol. fact of instituting the Archp. without their choice or consent, & quod Episcopus non datur inuitis, that a bishop is not put vpon a flocke against their wil any man of meane learning may discouer how litle this maketh for their purpose. For as we deny not but in diuers former ages, there were diuers formes of appoynting a new bishop, sometymes by al the Bishops of that prouince or patriarchie, which is held to this day in Greece, sometymes by the election of the Cleargie and people togeather, and at other tymes by the Cleargie only, and consent of the people, as in these Canons by them alleaged; so we thinke our brethren wil not deny the preheminÄt authority of the Sea Apostolike in all these elections,Diuers formes of appointing Bishops. and aboue all, and that the Church might, and hath lawfully chaunged the
same forme synce, as we see by experience both in the presentations of Kings & Princes to Bishopricks (wherin neither priest nor people hath commonly any suffrage at this day as also by apointing of diuers immediatly from the Sea Apostolike it selfe without election or approbation of the Cleargie or people, especially when the lesser part reclaymeth without iust cause. For in this case the glosse of the Canon it selfe by them alleaged saith benÃ¨ datur eis Episcopus inuitis. Gloss. dist. li. Can. 13. A bishop is lawfully giuen to them against their wils, whÄ the lesser part only reclayme, as it is in our cause. So as our contradicting brethren being far the lesser part, and reclayming without all iust reason, they are condemned by their owne Canon, though this case of chosing prelats now adayes be wholy altered in the Catholike Church, or for the most part, as euery man seeth. And if this be altered in ordinary bishops, wherof the Canons do speake, and meane, then much more may his Holines apoynte an extraordinary Prelate, as the Archpriest is, with what authority and iurisdiction he thinketh expediÄt, as daylie he doth his legats & Nutioes being oftÄ neyther bishops nor Archb. And therfore so much to vrge this, is great presumption, to cal it no worse.

After this treatese of M. Champneyes,A letter of F. Persons discussed. they haue placed a letter of F. Persons wrytten the 9. of Octob. 1599. to M. Bishop in Paris, for answere of certaine greeuous calumniations which he and his fellow M. Charn. (and others vpon these mens reports) had spread abroad the world of the hard and iniurious dealing vsed to them in Rome, which reports being contrary to all truth, and their owne confessions and promises made at their departure, and not touching so much in deed F. Persons (though in words they would seeme to lay all vpon him) as the two Cardinals & his Holines; with the commissary appoynted to examine them, and the whole iustice of the citty & Sea Apostolike; it seemed necessary to F. Persons to lay forth breefly the plaine truth of the fact, and so he doth. And albeit they haue set forth not only an answere thervnto made by M. Bishop himselfe, but also a much more malitious comentary or censure wrytten by M. I. B. yet is there not one iote of the said letter truly and substantially reproued, as by equal examination wil appeare.

And first for the Censurer I. B. to make himselfe matter to play, as though he were a cunning Cabalist in discussing of numbers, he deuideth the said letter into 24.
paragraphes, and so leapeth from one to the other, forth and backe referring yow now to this and now to that, as yow may easily perceaue, his desyre is to dally & delude the reader, and to seeme to say somwhat, wheras he saith nothing in substÄce, but only vttereth his gaule of spirit against that man to whome (if we be not deceaued) he hath more obligation then to most men liuing. VVe wil shew an example or two, and so leaue the rest to a more particular examination of this treatese which herafter may chaunce to be made, if this do not suffice.

He maketh a great styrre and so doth M. Bishop also, and often repeateth the same, that F. Persons contradicteth himselfe at the very beginning in these words: M. Bishop, it being now diuers monethes since yow departed from hence, and no one letter appearing yet from yow, nor from your frend, M. Charn. it made vs maruayle considering your promise at your departure, &c. And then in the second paragraphe: By a stale letter which I receyued this weeke from yow, I perceyue, &c. Heere they say is a great contradiction, affirming first no letter had appeared, and then confessing, that he receaued one this weeke.Ansvvere to a cauillation. But we answere it breefly. F. Persons sayth that frÅ May to Nouember is more then halfe a
yeare; in which tyme no letter was come from them contrary to their promises, vntil this present weeke. VVhat great contradictiÅ is this, & how desyrous are these mÄ of quarrels, that lay hands of such cauils.

Another matter oftentymes brought in and tossed vp and downe by the censurer, is, that a propositiÅ of heresy was obiected against the Archpriest in Rome,Cap. 9. wherof yow haue heard before what it was, to wit, that no appellation could be made from him, and secondly how substantially it was proued, M. Bishop affirming in his examination that he had it of his fellow Robert, & his fellow saying no one word in all his examination thereof though he were asked about the Archpriest by name, & the Archpriest wholy denying it, and disclayming the same by a particuler letter to M. Charnoke himself at his fyrst commyng into Engl. in May 1600. Yet this censurer is not ashamed to bring it in oftentymes and to wryte thus of it;pag. 8 â¢ . if it should be true which F. Persons sayth that M. Blackwel was touched in the very matter of his faith, An egregious cauil against M. Blackvvel. &c. I doubt their foundation for their going to Rome (to wit the two messengers) wil hardly be shaken. And againe in another place: An heretical proposition is sayd to haue byn deposed against M. Blackewel, which if it be true, of what substance, against a
mans gouernment, in an heretical countrey, such a deposition is, any Cathol. wil easily see, and ought to reflect the more vpon it, if it were in matters directly cancerning his gouernment. And in diuers other places he resinueth this cauil to discredit M. Blackwel withal, being a thing as we see neyther grounded in it selfe, nor prooued, nor affirmed, by any mÄ, but only cast out by hearesay, and tossed vp and downe to make a noyse as yow see. So as these men haue no scruple of conscience to seeke to defame their brethren, yea their Superiors; by what deuise soeuer.

VVe do let passe the 21. reasons which this censurer layeth togeather by distinct numbers to discredit the Protectors letters, which his Holines afterward confirmed, and affirmed to haue byn wrytten by his knowledge order & proper motion.Pag. 48. VVe haue spoken of it before,21. Cauillations insteed of reasons. and are ashamed here to lay open the vanity by more particulars, one only reason of humility, modesty or obedience would haue giuen more credit to the party then these 21. for his disobedience for what cockish scholer can not deuise one & fortie reasons against his Superiors commandemÄt when he listeth not to obay?

There followeth lastly the answere of M. Bishop to the same epistle, contayning
two parts,M. Bish. ansvvere to F. P. letter. the first about iustifying the causes of their not yeilding to the Cardinals letters, wherin for that there is nothing singular from those reasons, which his fellowes haue alleaged before and by vs in diuers parts of this Apologie haue byn examined, and shewed to be eyther false or feeble, we passe them ouer in this place.

The second part treateth of their vsage in Rome, wherin diuers particulars are said by him with such passion as men that knew him before do wonder at him, seing the contrary may be prooued, by most authentical testimonyes and witnesses yet aliue; and part of his passion may be vnderstood, by this interrogation or exclamation. VVhat an irreligious and damnable slaunder (sayth he) was that inuented of purpose to haue vs taken, and shut vp before we were heard? &c.

But to this we aske him againe; is this so haynous or damnable or vnsual a matter to restraine a couple of priests where so many complaints had byn wrytten of their presumption & contempt and of the scandal raysed by their contention as we haue set downe before & doth not euery prince this to greater mÄ then they they are,Supra ca. 9. committing them first, and after hearing their cause: & further we would aske thÄ, were
not they hard afterward so much as they would say or wryte?ExclamatiÅs vvith out cause had they not their papers brought vnto thÄ, to see, read, & interpret? had they not licence after all examinations made, to go and speake with his Hol. if they would? were they abridged of any lawful iustification that they could make for themselues? or was euer any petition of theirs or demaund not heard of or considered of? how then do they exclame and call this restraynt of theirs an irreligious and damnable slander. If all mÄ in the world restrayned or imprisoned by their Superiors for better & more quiet examination of matters, or for their contempt vsed, or other iust cause, should make such exclamations and exaggerations against them for it, yea though they were not (as commonly they are not) so wel handled, prouided for, and there charges borne, as these men were; what a commÅ wealth would this be, and who would liue to be a Superior?

The true causes of their exclamation.But the cause of all this is, for that these our discÅtented Brethren being yong men euil mortified and accustomed to all liberty can abide no Superior at all, nor beare any act of Superiority vsed towards them, as this mÄ himself M. Bishop being demÄded at Rome vnder his oth of the causes
of stryfe in the Castle of VVisbich, he answered, that it was about certaine rules which the greater part would haue brought in, and the lesser part would not, wherof arose scandal, and when the Commissary replyed, he maruayled how any good man, could be scandalized with pious rules of good lyfe, this man answered: Sunt Sacerdotes saeculares, & volunt viuerÃ¨ libere, Ex â¢ m. G. Bish. 11. Ian. 1599. vt decet Sacerdotes, sed nolunt constringi regulis. They are secular priests, and Wil liue freely, as it becometh priests and wil not be bound to rules. And the very same reason is why they wil not be bound to the gouernment of any Superior.

VVherfore wheras this man, and some of his fellowes do often vrge against F.P. in this place and other where of our late good Cardinal Allen his sweet and gentle gouernment and loue which therby he got and retayned: Truth it is,About Card AllÄs manner of proceeding that his condition was such to giue what contentment he could to all men, both by letter and word, and a most honorable disposition no doubt it was, though he could not therby auoyd the euil tounges of all discÅtÄted, as the world knoweth and hath byn shewed before by diuers letters and testimonyes aswel of his owne as others.Cap. 3. & 4. Neyther haue we seene ot hard of any letter of F.
Persons, that hath gon in other style, then that which the Cardinal vsed. Neyther haue we spoken with any that could truly complayne of hard words in dealing with F. Persons. His actions also what they haue byn both in Spaine and Rome both to gratifye, and pacify all are easily seene, but the difference is in the tyme, and our priests being greatly increased in number, and growen also in stomacke, and the Cardinal being dead, whose authority they respected, and no other succeeding him in his place, that could punish by office or authority, yong men haue come; partly by multitude & liberty; partly by inductiÅ of other vnquiet spirits to be impatiÄt of rule, & restraynt. And the selfe same motiue that induced his Hol. to giue thÄ a Superior, to wit lacke of order in so growing a body (which yet was not so needful while the Cardinal liued) inuited them to repyne at the same. And if the good Cardinal had liued to this day to haue consented as he would haue byn enforced to such a Superior in England for their restraynt, that would not be restrayned, he had had (no doubt) his part of contradiction, as the good father hath had, though not perhaps with so open mouth, as against the father, for that they would haue feared
somwhat his dignity, but with no les â¢ e obstinacy, and contempt in couert words, then we see against Cardinal Caetan whÅ euery were they abuse and vse contemptuously for that they hold him to haue byn contrary to their tumultuous designmÄts, and assigned them this Superior.

VVherfore to make an end, seeing these matters are like to be handled afterwards, againe as we heare, more largly to his Hol. & particular matters better examined, we say that the bitternes & inmodesty of these treateses against so worthymÄ of our owne religion do wonderfully cÅdemne the spirit of the wryters, but nothing more then the exceding rancor vsed against this religious man, which so many wayes hath benefited both vs and ours. And to the end that the Reader may see how euidÄtly this proceedeth of the common ennemy, we shal make a particular chapter of the egregious iniuryes done vnto him by manifest slaunders & calumniations which no doubt do proceed in great parte either by compact with the persecutors or els with intention to gratifye them therby.

div.head: OF THE PARTICVLAR calumniations and slaunders laid vpon F. Persons in these tvvo libels vvihout all foundatiÅ of truth or regard of Christian and priestly modesty: and hovv hurtfull this is to the publike Catholike cause, and grateful to the comon enemy, vvith a letter also of a blessed matyr touching one of these chief calumniators and some others about equinocations. CAP. XII.
div.p:
BY no one thing more do we thinke our discoutented and deceyued BrethrÄ to discouer the lamÄtable spitit whervnto they seeme to be giuÄ ouer at this present then by their passionate proceeding towards this ReuerÄd Religious mÄ, whose merites towards thÄ & theirs, and vs all, are not vnknowne. He may wel say with him in the Psalme: Sermonibus odij, circundederunt me, Psal. 108. & expugnauerunt me gratis, pro eo vt me diligerent detrahebant mihi. They haue inuironed me with hateful speeches, and haue gone about to haue ouerthrowne me without cause, & in steed of louing me (for many good turnes) haue detracted from me. Nay
he may say further with the same Saynt that complayned,Psal. 118.24.34. posuerunt odium pro dilectione mea, odio iniqno oderunt me, retribuebant mihi mala pro bonis. And finally with Christ himselfe and to his imitation, multa bona opera ostendi vobis, Ioan. 10. propter quod eorum opus me lapidatis. They haue returned me hatred for my loue towards them, they haue hated me with iniust hatered, they haue payed me euil for good. I haue procured them many benefites, for which now they go about to stone me.

Thus he may say aswel with his master as with many other seruants of the same lord who receyued the same grace & liuery to do wel & receyue euil, and to beare all not only patiently, but also gladly, as we doubt not but he doth and wil. Albeit we know what is wrytten by the holy Ghost: Calumnia conturbat sapientem, & commedit robur cordis etus. Slanders do trouble euÄ a wisemÄ, & do eate owt the very strength of his hart, yet we doubt not of his longanimytie herein, and we nothing pitty his case, but our owne rather and especially that of our transported brethren, who besides the dishonor which they are like to receaue throughout the world, euen with the enemy himselfe, for this their notorious vngrateful dealing, thier sinne
also and daunger with almighty God must needs be great and dreadful and we may wel say vnto them, we feare vs, considering their doings and wrytings as S. Peter sayd to Symon Magus: Act. 8. In felle amaritudinis, & obligatione iniquitatis videmus vos esse: Alas we see yow to be in the gaule of bitternes (by yowr hateful speches) and in the bands or obligation of iniquity by yowr lacke of charity. VVe beseech almighty God we may be deceyued in this our feare. But now to the examination of the matters themselues, wherby the reasons of this we say and feare may better be iudged of.

The groÅ«d of all greef against F. Persons.The grounds of all the greefe and stomacke which our passionate brethren haue taken against F. Persons is, for that they imagine him to haue byn the first procurer of this subordination of the Archpriest amongst them, and the cheefe defender therof since the institution, and particularly for that they persuade themselues that he was the principal cause and procurer of the restraint of their two messengrs sent to Rome.Cap. 8. & 9. In which poynts notwithstanding we haue seene by that which before hath byn treated how farre they were deceyued, and that his Hol. had other grounds & motiues to do that which he did, besids Father Persons, albeit if the said Father had
imployed himselfe in the one and the other for stay of dissention & our publike good, he had not deserued this hatered, but much loue rather and thankes, and so do good men esteeme it, and God (no doubt) wil accordingly reward it. But let vs passe to more particulars.

In the 23. pag. of the latyn booke, where they begin to inueigh against F. Persons in particular they say thus: Quid intereÃ P. Robertus Personius, alias Cubbuccus, A general calumniatiÅ against F. Persons. Iesuita praecipuus, is quidem author, incensor, actor omnium nostrarum perturbationum domi forisque. VVhat did in the meane space F. Robert Persons alias Cubbucke a cheefe Iesuite, that is the author incensor and actor of all our perturbations both at home & abroad, &c. So say these mÄ. And by this exordium we may see their spirit and scrupulous conscience, & what care they haue of speaking truth or falshood ignomynies or contumelious reproches. If any one of F. Persons Ancestors were called also, vpon some particular cause by that other name, what importeth that, or why is it brought in heere but only of malice? For we see it is an ordinary thing in EnglÄd in diuers mÄ to be called by diuers surnames to wit so, alias so, and wheras there are many brothers, nephewes, cosin germans and other kinred
of F. Persons lyuing in EnglÄd, no one of them is called by any other name then Persons so farre as we can enforme our selues. This then is no lesse impartinÄt then the other is false and ful of iniquity, that he is the author, incÄsor or actor of all their troubles, who of all men els hath sought most to quiet them,Sup. cap. 10 as before we haue proued by his owne letters and other mens testimonyes; so as God must iudge in these calumniations offered.

But there insue diuers others in the next page more particular and more shamelesse then these, the first is, that wheras F. Persons before 18. yeares came into England, he so exasperated the mynds both of the Prince and Magistrates by his doings,
Pag. 24. as then first of all by that occasion capital lawes were apoynted against priests and their receyuers.

The first particular cal â¢ mniation.This calumniation hath diuers euident falshoods reproueable by the witnes of all that liued at that tyme in England both Catholikes and heretikes. For first it is more then 21. yeares since F. Persons came into England, to wit betwixt Easter and whitsontide in the yeare 1580. Secondly for his actions in that tyme he remayned in England, they cÅsisted in diligent teaching and preaching, and reducing men to Cath. religion through diuers Prouinces of the
Realme, as the numbers of principal men by him reduced do testifie, and the bookes wryttÄ by him in that tyme, as namely the Censure against Charke, the discouery of Iohn Nicols, the reasons of refusal of going to the Protestans Churches, a treatese of Pilgrimage, Books vvryttÄ by F. Persons in EnglÄd. and some others, vpon which preaching and wryting when many cheefe men refused to go to heretical seruice, there was called a Parlement in the end of the same yeare, & the law of 20. poÅ«d a moneth for recusancie vvas ordayned, but no capital law made against priests or their receyuers, vntil diuers yeares after F.P. was gone forth of EnglÄd againe in F. CÄpions arrainmÄt also, which was after F. Persons departure, there was no one action obiected of F. Persons in particular against the state, though he were knowen to haue byn Superior in that mission, as by the records yet extant may appeare. And consequently yow may consider how many deuised vntruthes there be in this first particular accusation. VVe shal consider in order the rest.

The second imputation is,The 2. calumniatiÅ against F. Persons. Ibid. pag. 24 that F. Persons like a dastardly souldier ran away from EnglÄd, & forsooke the tÄts of God to put himselfe in safty, &c. But this may be as easily reproued, as the former sclaunder, by publike testimonyes, as wel of diuers of our owne order that liued
with him & were priuy to his doings heerin, as also of other lay gentlemen that know the same. For better explication wherof, & of diuers other iniurious slÄders that are to follow, we shal be forced to repeat breefly some poynts about F. Persons intÄtions and doings wherof we haue informed our selues, and might be omytted, if these calumniations did not driue vs to vtter them.

F. Persons being master of art and fellow of Balioal Colledge in Oxford, left the same about the yeare 1573. as we take it, and the next yeare after went ouer the Sea to trauaile and study in Padua, & the next yeare after that againe, which was the yeare of Iubiley, he went to Rome and entred the Society of Iesus, F.P. first coming to Rome and entring the Society & his first actions in Rome. and 4. or 5. yeares after that againe to wit in the yeare 1579. a new Seminary in Rome being begon & instituted, and aboue 30. English youthes dismissed thence vpon a certaine falling out betwene M. Doctor Ouen Lewes then Archdeacon of Cambray and after Bishop of Cassane, and them, the said Father procured their stay by the help of Father Toledo afterward Cardinal, who at that tyme was preacher to Pope Gregory the 13. and greatly in his fauor, and so an vnion was made with Doctor Lewes againe.
And for better cÅfirmatiÅ of the Seminary vocatiÅ he procured that the first forme of oath now vsed, was brought into the RomÄ Seminary, & after that exÄple by himselfe into the Seminaries of Spaine afterwards, wherby all promised to take holy orders & returne to England when they should be appoynted by their Superiors, wherby we may see from the very begining and euer since, what a furtherer he hath byn to priestly vocation and function, wherunto now these our brethren would make men beleeue that he were an enemy.

And these breaches in Rome being wel accomodated by his sollicitation, the next poynt he procured, was to haue M. Doct. Allen called to Rome (as he was) to the end there might be a good correspondence setled betweene the two Seminaries of Rome and Rhemes: and then himselfe in the yeare ensuing to wit 1580. being sent by Gregory the 13. togeather with F. Campian into England, at the sute of Doct. Allen in name of all English Catholikes who desired greatly the assistence of the Iesuits in that mission, F. Persons was appointed by his General to be Superior therof. And this was the first mission that euer the Society had into England.

His actions in England were (as before
hath byn 'declared) for the space of some yeare and halfe, or there about. to wit towards the end of the yeare 1581. at what tyme F. CÄpian being taken and imprisoned, and F. Heywood and F. Holt being come in, to take their places, and the print and printers which F. Persons had procured for diuulging of Cath. bookes being discouered and intercepted, & himselfe being at that tyme in Sussex and hauing a commodity of passage into Fraunce offered him, he had a great consultation with himselfe, and other graue Priests that were with him, whether he should go ouer or no, for better disposing of a certaine vrgent busynes in hand, which he could not wel do without his presence beyond the Sea, but yet with intention to returne as soone as might be. His cheefest busynes as we vnderstÄd were these that do ensue.

First he had diuers Catholike bookes & treateses partly already wrytten, and partly begone in defence of Catholike religion, which could not now be printed in EnglÄd his presse and printers, and M. Stephen Brinkely Prefect therof being taken, and comitted to the tower, nether could a new presse for English matters be wel set vp in Roane in NormÄdy,The causes of F. Persons going out of England. as was designed without the fathers presence at the beginning.

Secondly he had many points of Moment to be cÅferred by mouth with Doct. Allen, as namely to hasten the editiÅ of the english new testament, for the which he had procuted him 300. pound of assistÄce from certaine Catholikes his spiritual children in England, the maner also of contayning and holding vp the English missions, as wel of Secular priests, as of the Society, for which the said Father had obserued diuers things of weigh â¢ in this tyme of his being in England, but not so easy or safe to be imparted by letters, as by word of mouth.

Thirdly diuers Catbolikes in England perceyuing the difficultyes of the tyme to grow on, and that they could not haue Cath. scholemasters in rheir houses at home as they weare wont had treated with the father to prouide them some succour or place of education beyond the Seas for their yonger children that were not yet fit for their yeares and learning to be of the Seminaries of Rhemes or Rome, which he could nor hope to do but by his presence beyond the Seas.

Fourthly her maiestie of Scotland being then in prison in England, as she had procured, first that the said Father had sent a priest into Scotland named M. VVats, &
after F. Holt, one of the Society to conserue the seed of Cath. Religion in that countrey to the good of her sonne the yong king, if it might be, especially now after the putting downe of the Earle Morton an heretical gouernor, & of the aduauncement of the duke of Lenox to that roome being Catholikely inclyned, so had she procured also, that the said father had wrytten to Rome to haue some fathers of the Scotish nation in like maner to be ioyned in this mission, whervpon two beeing appoynted to wit F. Edmund Hayus, and F. VVilliam Cryton, it was thought very necessary, that F. Persons should passe ouer to Roan to conferre with them of their said mission, before they tooke it in hand.

Fiftly F. Persons had vpon his hands at that tyme two yong gentlemen M. George Gilbert and M. Charles Basset, whome he loued dearly, and who for the Cath. cause were forced to fly the land as persecuted and sought for by name, whome the said faiher could not wel leaue vntil he had seene them safely accommodated beyond the Seas which he did by his presence there.

These then and some other reasons we haue vnderstood partly by the father himself, & partly by those with whome he cÅsulted
before he went ouer,Vtilityes that in sued by. F P. returne into Franco. were the principal arguments of that his iorney. All which points had good and profitable effects by his going ouer. For touching the first poynt, he set forth diuers good bookes in Roane, as the Epistle of persecutiÅ, both in latyn and English, the defence of the Censure against Charke, The booke of resolution, & some others concerning deuotion. Touching the 2. poynt he helped much the speedy edition of the English Testament, with the establishment of future missions. Touching the 3. he obtayned a new Seminary for English youths at Ewe in NormÄdy with 100 pound pensiÅ a yeare of the Duke of Guise,Seminary of Evve. besides a house lent gratis by the Fathers of the Society, who also read vnto them, with diuers other helpes of diuers other French Catholikes, all which the said Father procured and established at his being there, and placed a gouernour ouer them of our owne nation, a graue ancient man named M. Chambers, which indured vntil the yeare 1588. when the said good Duke fel himselfe,Seminary of S. Omers and then the said Father soone after procured the erection of another Seminary in S. Omers farre greater; to the same effect.

The fourth and fifth poynts, what successe they had euery man knoweth, for that
out of this first mission to Scotland procured by the said Father hath ensued the good number of Catholikes which synce that tyme Gods holy grace hath brought forth in that realme by his seruÄts labours. And as for the two foresaid gÄtlemen Gylbert and Basset after great example and exercise of vertue much edification giuen, & many good workes performed, they died most holily, the one in Rome, the other in Rhemes, hauing distributed first aboue 10000. crownes in almes, partly to the Seminary of Rhemes, & partly to the Nunnes of Syon and other religious persons, & pious vses.

Now then all this being so, let euery indifferent man iudge, how vnworthy a slaunder it is for these our brethren, or him that wrote this booke to cal Father Persons ignauum militem, Pag. 24. An vnvvorthy in solency. & desertorem castrorum Dei. A dastardly souldier and forsaker of the campes of God, wheras most of these calumniators were yong schollers at that tyme, and some of them no schollers at all, nor euer perhaps had byn, if F. P. iorney out of England had not by Gods ordinance byn appointed for better assistance of the Seminaries, to wit, for erecting that of Ewe, by strengthening that of Rhemes, with 2000. crownes a yeare pension, procured
by his iorney to the King of Spaine, by going also to Rome with Doctor Allen, & procuring his aduauncement, for better strengthening of the whole cause, and finaly by his going into Spayne with great daunger of his lyfe, and procuring not only the yearly continuance of that kings assistance to the Seminaries of Rhemes, and after at Doway againe in those most hard tymes of the warres of France, but the erection also of diuers other new Seminaries and residences for the English nation, as that of Valiadolid, Syuil, Diuers nevv Seminaryes and residences. and S. Lucar in Spayne, and Lisbone in Portugal, & S. Omers in Flaunders do testifie.

All which we are forced heere to remember brefly for answering these shamful or rather shamelesse calumniations of these our vngrateful brethren, who hauing neuer done any one iote in this kynde, but rather fed and byn nourished for the most part of them, vpon this mans labors & trauailes, now obiect that against him, to wit, his going forth of England without which it is like they had not byn now priests nether without nor within England, for that if matters were wel examined, yow should fynd that many of them were sent in by him, and many more susteyned beyÅd Seas by his endeauors.

And as for forsaking the camps of God, we see by experience of temporal warre, how iniurious a slaunder it is against this man: For that he who retyreth only from the station of a particular souldier to defend the whole tents, and to furnish from thence more souldiers, and other necessary prouision for the maintenÄce and strÄgthening of the whole, cannot be said to haue forsaken the camp, but to assist it more then the rest. And thus much for this calumniation. The rest we shal passe ouer more breifly.

The third accusation against F. Persons, is, that after his going out of England, nunquam exinde destitit, Ibid. pa. 24 The 3. accusation against F. P. aut libellis contra Primarios Reipub. magistratus aut litteris factiosis irritare temporalem regni statum. That he neuer ceased to exasperate the cheefe magistrats of the common wealth with wryting libels, and the temporal state of the whole kingdome by factious letters.

This calumniation is refuted cleerly by that we haue said in the precedent chapter in answere to the third demaund of M. Mush about prohibition of exasperating bookes where it is shewed,Cap. 11. that albeit he with the same splene and vntruth (as this man doth heere if he be not the same) doth name only F. Persons, yet he is the man
amongst al other Catholike English wryters, for whose bookes men haue least byn called in trouble, so farre as we knowe. And we thinke our angry brethren cannot giue any one instance to the contrary, wheras for diuers books of Doctor Saunders, Doctor Bristow, and Card. Allen diuers searches, troubles, and examinatiÅs are knowne to haue byn made, & yet are they not so much as mentioned by these men, wherby is euident their passion, and that they seeke only cauillations against Father Persons.

And wheras this fellow heere calleth them libels we haue told in part, what they are, and others may not so wel be named, and yet Catholikes know them, or can gesse at them. And one only booke amÅg them, to wit, that of the Christian directory or Resolution, is knowne to haue gayned more soules to God, then all these men ioyned togeather can euer hope to do, especially with this spirit which now they shew. And wheras these men heere do note in the margent these woords, when they talke of exasperating books, Patris Personij liber de successione. They do shew maruelous rancor, and corrupt affection,About the booke of Succession and no iudgment or desyre of truth at all. First for that it was neuer hard of in England, that any
special persecution was made for this booke. Secondly they do not know but by their owne presumptiÅ, that this book is more to be attributed to F. Persons, then to the late Cardinal Allen, Sir Frauncis Inglefeld, and other principal men of our nation, who are knowne to haue concurred to the laying togeather of that book, as by their owne hands is yet extant, and this to the publike benefit of our Cathol. cause: First that English Catholikes might vnderstand what special and precise obligation they haue to respect religion in admitting any new prince aboue all other respects humayne vnder heauen, and this is handled largely, clearly, & with great variety of learning, reasons, doctrine and examples throughout the first booke. And in the second booke is shewed to the same effect, the great diuersytie of pretenders that are or may be after her Maiestie that now is, to the Crowne, euery man and woman in their rancke and degree, allowing to euery one the vttermost reasons that may be for them offering iniury to none, nor determining of any, but leauing all in suspÄce to this only end, that catholikes seing their obligation; and beholding also their variety of choise in some cases might resolue of that, when tyme cometh which shalbe
most conforme to Gods glory, publike weale, & their owne foresaid obligatiÅ for their soules. And this being the but of both these books, let wise men consider the humour of these people, that make so much ado about it.

The fourth manifest calumniation or rather fiction against F. Persons is heere set downe in these words:The 4. calumniatiÅ against F. Persons. Pag. 24. Multae interceptae eius literae, &c. Many letters of his haue byn intercepted wrytten by him to his frends in England which do promise inuasions of the kingdome by externe souldiers and to dispose the mynds of English men to these expectations. But hÄere we would aske these accusers why they haue not alleaged some one letter of his to this purpose. among so many as they say are intercepted? Nay why haue not those of the Councel or some other heretical wryter, published some one letter of his in all this space of 21. yeares since first he was sent into England & hath dealt euer since in this affayre?Euident resolution. Diuers letters of other men intercepted haue byn published in print to seek their disgrace as all the world knoweth. And if any one of F. Persons had byn taken also, among so many as he hath wrytten into England and to other places in this tyme which might haue byn published to his disgrace, or to the disaduantage of his
order, or English Cath. in this behalfe, is it likely it should haue byn spared? nay if the heretikes would not haue set it forth, these men would haue done it,F. P. letter to M. Bish. 9. Oct. 1599 seing they haue not spared to put forth in print and to exaggerate, peruert and exagitate the same by diuers peeuish comentaryes a priuate letter of his wryten to one of their owne men in frendly sort, for defence of the doings and proceedings of his Hol. and the two Cardinals Protectors in Rome, towards their two messengers. VVherfore it is easily seene with what spirit these men are gouerned, seing they would gladly make F. Persons more odious to the state then already he is, by forging that he hath wrytten letters of inuasion and the like which is a meere malitious inuÄtiÅ of their owne, to bring him and other good Cath. into further disgrace.

The 5. calumniatiÅ against F. P. lb. pa. 24.The fifth calumniation, which might be deuided into diuers, doth contayne a great rabble of fond and false obiections against F. Persons the most of them already answered, as that he slinging and stirring vp the magistrate from abroad, causeth the same to be fearce against them at home, to sceke their bloud and destruction, to condemne them of treason vnder the maske of religion, and that they (poore men) at home do beare the punishments of
F. P. his imprudence and audacity abroad

These are greuous accusations if they were true, and being false are the more iniurious reproches. Touching F. Persons therfore, it hath byn shewed and prooued that he hath done nothing abroad to the preiudice of them at home, but rather much to their good. And as for these men, how much they are vrged or pressed by the temporal magistrate, the effects do shew, seing they are knowne to haue special recourse vnto them; & fauor with them vnder hand, not only for their owne ease (those of them that be in prisoo) and security for them that liue abroad, but for the afflicting also of their Cathol. brethren in durance, that do not allow their seditious course; so as this accusation of their suffefering for F. Persons doings and wrytings is both euidently false in it selfe and very calumnious in the cause therof.

The sixt accusation in this place is,The 6. calumniatiÅ against F. P. Pag. 24. that F. P. misliking the new association attempted by these men in England did go about to defame them with the schollers of the English colledge in Rome, as though they had sought their owne preferment by that association and to be made Bishops & the like. But for answere of this we remit the
Reader to that which we haue aleaged before out of the common letter of the 6. Assistants to the Nuntio in Flaunders about this matter;Sup. cap. 8. as also what hath byn cyted out of their owne wrytings & testimonies before, for making Archb. their two messengers & other of their company bishops, at their returne. All which being considered F. P. wil easily be deliuered from this calumniation, and themselues condemned. And thus much for the accusations in this place and page heaped togeather against F. Persons.

There do follow many more infarced throughout the whole booke (for it seemeth their only or principal study was, and is to discredit this man, therby to get more credit perhaps themselues with the Counsel and Bishop of London, and with some other principal protestants, whose fauour they vse in this cause) and so when they come so farre forth in their Story of the latyn book,Diuers other calumniations against F. P. as to recount the iorney of their two messengers to Rome, they lay load on F. P. casting all the euil successe of their said iorney vpon him, repeating againe and againe these words: That he is the author and Architect of all their hurts. And surely it is strange to consider, whither passiÅ & perturbation
of mynd can precipitate men that suffer themselues to be carryed away therwith. For we hauing informed our selues particularly and authentically of matters how they passed in this action, we fynd so many vntruthes vttered in this narration with such asseueration, as it causeth vs with no smal horror of mynde to consider who do vtter thÄ, how and to whome, and against whome, to wit, Priests, in print, to his Hol. and against a religious Catholike man, whose fame they should cÅserue, but especially not to impugne by falshood or inuentions of their owne: Some particulars we shal heere examine.

They wryte pag. 40. that F. P. being Rector of the Colledge receyued their two messengers first with an angry countenance and troubled voyce,Many vntruths vttered in their narration about their messengers. and denyed them hospitality in the house, though afterwards for a ceremony he receyued thÄ, but thrust them out againe after some dayes, and then caused them to be apprehÄded, &c. But the truth of this is knowne by diuers graue men yet liuing, as wel priests and religious, as others, to wit, that F. Persons receyued them very kyndly in his owne chamber, tould them, that albeit much had byn wrytten thyther against them by diuers of the grauest of our clergy
wherby it appeareth, that the cause of their iorney was such as required not the hospitality of the Colledge which was only for pilgrimes, yet he would willingly receaue them, & deale most frendly with thÄ in all respects, while they weare in the house, vpon one only condition, that they would not do or say any thinge to the schollers that might tend to rayse or renew sedition or diuision now wholy taken away in the Colledge. VVhich conditiÅ they breaking after some dayes F. Persons being aduertised therof by a vertuous priest that serued them, was forced to request them to prouide lodging in the towne, and so they did, yet did he inuite them afterward courteously to the Colledge, & both by himselfe, and by diuers other graue priests sent vnto them, while they were in the Colledge, and afterward, he persuaded them most frendly to come to some attonement, but they would not heare him, growing into certayne strÄge speaches of wilful resolution, as the said priests are yet witnesses, And among other M. Doctor Haddocke, M. Martyn Array and others that talked with them to this effect. And the same wil testifie all the Fathers and priests that remayned then in the Colledge. The two Cardinals also were made priuy of all and dealt
with these men to the same effect and cannot but blesse themselues (namely he of the two that is yet aliue) to see so many contrary vntruthes vttered, by them in this narration.

They say also that F. Bellarmyne (now Cardinal)Falshood and calumniation about Card. Bellarm. letter to F. Persons. his letter wrytten to F. Persons from Ferrara a litle before their arriual dothe proue that the imprisonmÄt of their messengers was procured by F. P. for that the said Cardinal wrote that the two English priests were not yet come but should be imprisoned, whe they came, nor that it should be needful for F. P. to fly or make hast to Ferrara, for that cause, & then they cry out: O tÄporalo mo â¢ e! O miserable tymes, o wicked maners of men that their two messengers should so be handled as to be put in prison, before they weare heard. But God be thanked that worthie good Cardinal is yet aliue, and can testifie all this to be their fictiÅ, and that his Hol. being aduertised in Ferrarae from his Nuntij in France and Flanders of these mens coming, was offended at their new styrring & willed the said Father to wryte to Rome to F. Persons to be enformed of them, and their pretences, before euer F. P. had wrytten or spoken word therof, as the said Cardinal wil beare witnes. And as for the last clause of his letter, wherby he should
wryte that F. Persons needeth not to fly or make haste (as their phrase is) to Ferrara, is added and forged by themselues, and no one such word in the letter.

A heap of calumniations against F. P.They go forward with many inuectiues against F. Persons, first for procuring, as they say, that these priests should be imprisoned rather in the Colledge, then in a publike prison. But to this we would aske them to whose gaine or losse was this, if F. Persons did procure it. Then they accuse him, for that he was himselfe (as they say) the Iaylor. But of this we can fynd no other foundation; except perhaps they should meane for that the keys of the Colledge are wÅt to be brought to the Rectors Chamber at night, for by day tymes they wil not deny (as we are informed) but that the porter of the colledge had the keyes of their chambers to bring them meate, and all other necessaryes, so that he might better be called their Iaylor then Father Persons, if these men lysted, or if any such name were to be giuen to any for keeping the keyes of a couple of chambers by his Holines commissaryes commandement.

There followeth another sharp accusation against F. P. with this modest note in the margent,Pag. 43. insignis impudentia P. Personij. The notorious impudency of F. Persons, in
that he did shew (as they say) certaine handkirchifs, sockes, silke poynts, coyfes. and the like that were found among the stuffe of their messengers at Rome, as though they had byn giuen to to much dilicaty in England. But heere we would aske them, why this should be obiected as a fault of F. Persons,About stuffe foÅ«d in the messengers chÄbers and bags. seing not he but the Popes comissary Signor Acari â¢ ius tooke and looked in their bags, and hauing found in their chamber both swords, daggers, a lute, and other such stuffe, demaunded thÄ therof, as appeareth in their particular examinations, but of their bagges nothing at all only he greatly maruayled of the forsaid things sound in M. Charnockes bag, as we are enformed, where there was diuers sorts both of handkirchifs and night coyfes so wrought with sylke and gould lace, as they might seeme to serue for any secular prince in the world, and the sockes for his feete were of so fine Holland, as the Comissary said, he was wel assured, that his Holines neuer ware such for his shirts. VVhervpon he conferring the same vvith F. P. and M. Charnocke himselfe, when answere was made that priests now adayes for dissimulation are forced to vse such things in England. He replyed that at the least wise it was not needful to bring such
strange delicacyes to Rome, and that albeit in some external apparel dissimulation might be tolerable in English priests at home in respect of the tymes, yet in such things, wherof their vse was only in secret as nightcoyfes and sockes and the like, he saw no such need of excesse or dissimulation. And this was all that pass â¢ d in this matter, nor were they further shewed abroad by F. P. as the Commissary himselfe wil testifie. And where then is this singular impudency obiected not only in the text, but margent also of this libel.

There were no end, if we should follow these men in their maledictions & calumniations against F. P. in these theyr two late libels, for it seemeth they run the course of certayne men, who say in the prophet Isay:Isay. 28. posuimus mondacium spem nostram: we haue put our whole hope to ouerthrow this man in inuenting false reproches and calumniations against him; but we shal draw to an end by examining only another heap of them set downe in one page togeather, which in effect are these,A number of false slÄders against F. P. that F. Pe â¢ sons was expelled out of the vniuersity of Oxford, before he was a Iesuite, with the greatest applause that might be of all men, and with the sound of bels, and this not for religion, but sor sedition and faction, and that since he was
religious he hath incurred the note of infamy for the same spirit of contention, not only among Catholikes: but among those also of his owne orders; that his byrth hath euer byn from his childhood of il fame, that he hath had most bytter and greuous contentions with F. Cryton a scotish man, and with F. Gibbyns F. Heywood, F. Holt Englishmen, F. Alphonsus Agazarius an Italian, and innumerable others of his owne Society, and more then this, with the Bishop of Cassano, Doctor Barret, Doctor Gyfford, M. Midleton secular priests, and with the noble and most Catholike gentlemen, M. Charles Paget, and M. Nicolas Fitzherbert, and infinite others abroad.

Heere now yow see what a conglomeration of accusations, heere are layd togeather, yow shal heare the truth of them, and therby iudge what men these are. And first for that of Oxford if any such thing had happened in this tyme, F. Persons being knowne of what religion he was euer taken to be of there, it seemeth a very vndecent obiection for Catholike priests to make against him now. But we hauing enformed our selues diligently both from himselfe and others, and some of vs lyuing either then or soone after in the said vniuersity, are priuy to the fact it selfe, and do most constantly affirme all this to be a notorious
calumniation,VVhether F. P. vvas expelled the vniuersity or no. as now we shal declare, and that F P. was neuer expelled or put out of any vniuersity or Colledge in his lyfe. And as for the vniuersity of Oxford let the Registers be sought, and the men asked that lyued with him there in his tyme, and by them it wil be found, that he neuer had any con â¢ rouersy at all great or litle with the vniuersity during his aboad there neither had he euer any sute or contentiÅ with any one man in the vniuersity eyther of his owne house, or other, except only M. Adam Squire afterward Sonne in law to the Bishop of London a man of knowne infirmityes (to say no worse) & this for certaine deceyts vsed to some contrey men of his in selling them dycing flies, and other like toyes, which Squire notwithstanding coming afterward by violence of the tyme to be head of Baliall Colledge, wherof F. P. was fellow, he was ready to ioyne with any man in secret maner against the said Father, as he did, but besides this man he had neuer so much as any publike quarrel with any, & much lesse with the whole vniuersity. And this for the first poynt, wherby is seene how truly they wtyte ex Academia Oxoniensi, that he was put out of the vniuersity of Oxford.

Secondly for Balioall Colledge wherof
he was fellow, and wherof these men say nothing (though they must needs meane it) we do affirme that in the forsaid yeare 1573. or 74. his voluntary departure thence and resigning vp the Colledge, is to be found in the publike register, of the said Colledge subscribed with F. P. owne hand, wherin it is affirmed, that he did voluntarily giue vp the said Colledge & fellowship with his right therin, with intention to trauayle, &c. And in deed it is wel knowne that he had this intention to leaue Oxford and go beyond the Seas for some yeares before, and at this tyme especially he had agreed with some frends and namely M. Iohn Lane, M. of art and fellow of Corpus Christi Coll.M. Iohn Lane fellovv of Corpus Christs Colledge in Oxfort. & persuaded him to resigne his fellowship also to trauaile with him as he did and after some tyme entred in like maner into the Society of IESVS and died with great opinion of holynes in the vniuersity of CÅplutum in Spayne in the yeare 1578. And this being so, how then do they auouch in this place, that F. Persons was expelled with the sound of bels and great applause of all men. Surely some mysterious deceit and fallacy lyeth therin, which we shal heere discouer, as breefly as may be; and therby yow shal iudge of the cÅsciences of them that wryte these bookes.

F. Persons being the aunciÄtest fellow of this Colledge excepting one, and liuing in very good credit and reputation in that vniuersity, and especially with noble men and gentlemen abroad, whose sonnes and kinsmen were his schollers and pupils, in greater number commonly then to many others of the vniuersity (for as we heare he had aboue twenty) diuers others of inferior degree in his colledge did enuy him for the same. And among others one Christopher Bagshaw Bacheler of art at that tyme, and a litle before by F. Persons help, made fellow of the said Baliall Colledge; this man then (who is thought also to haue byn the penner of this vntrue story in the libel) desiring to draw some part of F P. schollers from him, and assuring him selfe of the help of M. Squire therin, who was head of the house, and of the other fellowes that were Protestans, he attempred it in this sort.

A notorious bad dealing of M. Bag. vvith F. P. F. Persons being gone to LÅdon at Christmas tyme, M. Bagshaw allured vnto him a very proper youth called M. Iames Hanley of whome F. P. being tutor, had special care both for his good parts, and for his frends who lyued in London, and with whome F. P. remayned at this tyme. The manner of drawing him was (as we vnderstand)
by carrying the said youth forth by night being of very tender age, to certayne commedies which F. Persons had forbidden at his departure, for feare of inconueniences that might ensue in such throng and hauing committed this fault he persuaded the youth that F. P. would not pardon it, and so when he came home M. Bagshaw kept this youth shut vp in his owne chÄber, & would not suffer him to go to F. P. when he sent for him,The story of M. Iam. Hanley. nor yet when he came for him himselfe, vnder pretence of feare that he would punish him ouer rigorously, and the yong gentleman to this day (whome we heare to be hoth very vertuous and learned) can testifie wel this act of M. Bagshaw which act being expulsion by statute to deny any scholler, to the deane, especially his owne (for F. P. as we vnderstand was deane this yeare, of the house) and he hauing no other remedy (for he perceaued M. Squire to concurre secretly in this deuise) he called a publike Chap. of all the fellowes laying open the iniury done vnto him. But M. Squire with the Protestant fellowes being farre the greater part began presently (omitting this matter proposed) to picke quarrels of religion against F. Persons saying that he peruerted a great part of the youthes of the house,
and that it was not meet that a man of his backwardnes in religion, should haue so many schollers and pupils of that quality which his weare, and finally they exhotted him, that seing already he had treated to go beyond sea he would presently resigne his fellowship, and they would allow him such reasonable tyme for his preparatiÅ as he should thinke good in which tyme he should haue all the priuileges of his fellowship and offices which now he enioyed. And further they would sweare vnto him (as there they did) to keep his resignation secret, and if he would not do this, they all protested, that they would violently ioyne togeather to haue him out with all his schollers,A great violence and iniustice offred to F. Persons. what soeuer became of it, and that they would that very night cast out by force and fury, both his and all his schollers stuffe without the Colledge, and that he should seeke his remedy as he might.

This being proposed and stood vpon resolutely, and their turbulent dispositions being wel knowne the Catholike fellowes which thÄ were in the Colledge namely M. VVilson, M. Turner now Doct and some others persuaded F. Persons, that seing he had made his resolution to trauayle, and that they offered him three moneths space
to perpare himselfe, and to sweare secresy in the meane space, and that if they should furiously make this assault vpon him and his schollers, as they were determined, he should hardly get remedy at the vysitors hand, who was then Doct. Cooper B. of Lincolne, for these and like respects (and for that God as we persuade our selues did worke also secretly therin, by these euil mens meanes, to get that man out of EnglÄd) he resolued with himselfe to giue ouer his fellowship, and so resigned the same, as before is said and they taking their oath of secresi, the matter was ended, & all made great frends, as to outward shew appeared.

But in the lent following F. Persons being aduertised that some of this crewe, had not only eaten flesh secretely in some chambers, & drawne some of his schollers therÅ«to, but also had opened the chestes of some other of thÄ, that would not eat with them, and taken thence certaine cheeses or such like victuals, he was tempted to get them punished, and conferring of this matter with M. Doctor Martyn Culpeper, his great frend, lately made VVarden of New Colledge, and now vicecommissary, the said Doctor told him that if it could be proued he would lay them in prison whervpon
F. P. endeauoring to procure proofes,A nevv co â¢ se of breach betvvene F. P. and his aduersaries of the Colledg. and they hearing therof, sent one presently to M. Squire that was in London, and he so informed the Earle of Licester high ChÄcelor of that vniuersity, that he wrote somwhat a sharp letter backe to the vice commissary, saying that he vnderstood of such an attempt or meaning of one euil affected in Religion towards others that were good protestants, for a tryfle of eating a little flesh, and that it was not conuenient to proceed any further in this matter, which letter being come M. Doctor Culpeper durst not passe any further therin, and the other hauing vnderstood of this order from M. Squire, became so insolent, as first of all against their oathes, they published that F. Persons was not fellow of Balial Colledge and further in their fury they ran to the next Church of S. Magdalyn, & rung the bels backward as if fire had byn in towne, and being asked of the people what it meant, they answered, that a great Papist was fyred out of Balial colledge that day. And this is the true story of all the calumniation which here is set downe, that F. P. was expulsed the vniuersity of Oxford with sound of bels, and with the greatest applause of al people. And the partyes herin named; and liuing to this day in good worship, namely
M. Doct. Culpeper, M. Iames Hanley, M. Iohn VVilson eldest fellow at that tyme of the house, M. Doct. Turner, then also fellow & others can and wil testifie, yet went not F. P. from the vniuersity or Colledge for some weekes after contemning this insolency vsed by a few disordered people against him, and after he had byn some moneths in London he returned againe to visit his frends in the vniuersity, which did vtterly condemne so barbarous and boyish a fact as the ringing of the belles. And this was F. P. departure from thence: but how M. Bag. his accuser was driuen from thence after many publike broyles made therin,M. Bag. departure frÅ Oxford. all men do know, as also how F. P. was his chefest frend afterward at his going ouer the sea for his help and direction to Rome vpon his owne request, where he shewed himselfe to be the same man he was before and hath byn since, and for the same cause was dismissed also from thence: And so much of this.

As for the other calumniation which followeth of the euil fame (as these men do speake) of F. Persons birth, is more malitious, but lesse probable then the former and litle needeth to be answered ther vnto, seyng his parens were knowne
while they liued to be very honest, his father reconciled by the martyr M Bryan,Amalitislander. his mother a knowne graue matron lyuing diuers yeares in flight and banishment for religion and dying therin at London about 2. yeares past as many graue priestes also wil beare witnes. Ten brothers and sisters of his the most of them yet liuing, do easily confute the vanity and shew of venome of this imputation.

The rest that doth ensue about F. Persons contentiÅ with those of his owne Society, and that he hath an euil name among them for it, this may be seene in pare by the offices, and charges wherin the Superiors therof do imploy him, as namely in beeing Rector of the English Colledge, prefect of their English Mission & the like which are vnfit offices for a troublesome spirited man, & those that are vnder his charge both in the Colledges and abroad and their peace and quiet, may easily testifie how true this obiection is.

It must needs be also very ridiculous to men of that order,A ridiculous obiection. that these our brethren are not ashamed to affirme that F. P. hath had most greuous and most bitter a contentions with F. Cryton, F. Gybbons, F. Haywood, F. Holt, F. Alphonsus, & alijs innumeris suae Societ. hominibus
& with innumerable other mÄ of his owne Society. And who are these innumerable thinke yow of this Society? or what greuous & bitter cÅtentions hath he had with these men heer named, in accusing yow know honest men ought to be precise and punctual. And surely this seemeth to passe all impudency and must needs cause great laughter and compassion to the Superiors of that Society especially to the General therof, who knoweth best the state of matters & men in that religion, laughter for the extreme folly of such an assertion, compassion for the falshood and malice and that English priests should become, so light & vayne, as to put so notorious vntruthes in print.

The other of strife with the Bish. of Cassano, D. Barret, D. Gyfford, MiddletÅ the priest, Childish & impartinÄt imputatiÅs M. Charles Paget and M. Nicolas Fitzherbert, and the rest, is not worth answering, being ful of childish cÅtrarietyes or impartinÄcies in it selfe, some being euidently false, as that of Doctor Barret, which appeared by his former letters before recyted,Cap. 5. some being trifles, as if one man should differ from another in some poynts of iudgemÄt, & some other points conteyning differences only raysed and continued vpon the pursuite of
the forsaid faction, wherof we haue talked largely in this our Apology. And as wel might our discontented brethren haue set downe their owne names & affirmed F. P. to haue broken with thÄ all, and therby to be contentious, as diuers of these later which they haue named.

So as for conclusion of this defence of F. Persons against so many and malignant calumniations; the reader may see and iudge by that we haue sayd how eager an appetite these angry people haue to seeke and coyne matter against F. Persons and his frends and order, in diuising and penning wherof (especially those of the latyn booke which principally we haue heere examined) for that we are informed that the forsayd M. Bagshaw, hath byn a most principal agent, we are forced heere to set downe a certaine letter of a learned, vertuous priest and of late a martyr about such matter as passed betwene them two concerning this poynt of calumniating Iesuits, and raysing slanders against their whole order. His let-beginneth thus.

The letter of M. Tho. Bensted martyr about Doct. Bag. slaudering of Iesuits 28. Apt. 1600.Right Reuerend being desyred by some of my especial good frends in VVisbich castle to certify your self and the Reuerend M. Blackwel of some extrauagÄt courses of
such as imploy their wit wholy in setting abroach seditiÅ, & in defaming those whose good behauior and asterity of lyfe doth seeme to checke their loose and idle lyfe.

p.q:
And finding no sure meanes in the countrey to discharge my duty herin I thought it necessary to take this iorney to this citty as the fittest place to conuay these vnto your ReuerÄces hÄds, desiring yow that they may be imparted vnto F. B. my Superior. The authors of these seditiÅs are those who not hauing shewed any remorse for hauing inbrued their hands in the bloud, or in seeking the bloud of good men (as the keper of VVisbich castle to cleere himself, hath protested vpÅ this saluation) do now a fresh (their number hauing increased of late) spit out the poyson,Peril vvrought to some by the factiÅs. which so long hath lyen hidden in their brests. The cheefe agent herein, is hee which is the Captayne of that seditious crew, I meane the Doct. who opposing himselfe against me, and seming to rebuke me for hauing at diuers tymes defended some good religious men as haue byn falsely accused of some wicked deuises, did in most vile maner vtter words of defamation aswel against that holy Society in general, as against some particular good religious men therof wherfore
being told of many of my very good frÄds that none might or could for diuers respects speake so wel in this matter as my self, as hauing had cÅference with them, & hauing ben slaundred my selfe by these, I thought my selfe in a maner boÅ«d to satisfie their requests, especially hauing past my promise vnto them to do it. The matter fel out in this sort.

The Doctor hearing by some strangers who seemed to giue some credit to those fayned crymes betwixt F. VValpoole and Squyre,M BÄsteed brought vp in Spayne. that I vpon my owne cÅscience and knowledge (as being partly an ey witnes) had giuen them sufficient reasons to cleere him of that fact as first because he of all others was most vnfit to be accused of any such styrring diuises as being so addicted to his study as he is knowne to be, as also the good lyfe of the mÄ, who is had of many in admiratiÅ therfore, & therfore it weare a sufficient warrÄt to any man of reason & of a good conscience that he had protested to me and to others in my hearing that as he was a religious man and a Catholike, he was so farre from putting any such matters or plot in practise, that he neuer had so much (to his knowledge) as any least cogita â¢ ion therof. Lastly (to omit other reasons
if he would haue dealt in any such matters he is not a mÄ of so smal wisdome as would haue imployed in that so daungerous a bysynes, these men, whose faith, & trustines was of my owne knowledge alwayes iustly suspected of him,Reasons for defence of F. Rich. VValpole. leauing so many as for their faithfulnes & likelyhood were farre more fit to be imployed then they. These reasons though they seemed of such weight vnto diuers, which by the Doctors & others persuasion, had byn btought verely to thinke that some bad matter (as they tearmed it) had passed: as to persuade them that it was but a forged calumniation, notwithstanding by this wise Doct. they weare termed foolish, yet because they had wrought some effect with diuers with whome I had talked, he tooke occasion to enter discourse therof with me, not so much (as I after found) to be resolued of the truth, as to entrap me to get some aduantage by my words, but finding none he fel to most false belying of me, geuing forth that I should say, that there was some priuy dealing and secret conueyance betwixt F. VValpoole & Squire, wheras I neuer vttered any such speeches as after I iustified to his face, when hauing reproued him before witnes he obiected vnto me,
that I had done much hurt to the Catholike cause in calling in questiÅ such matters, which no mÄ doubted of. But my answere & reply droue the Doct, in playne tearmes to exclame against the Society, alleaging that they vsed nothing but dissembling & equiuocations,The obiection of equiuocatiÅ against the Iesuits. wherto I answered, that as for dissembling I neuer could see any amongst them all the tyme I was brought vp vnder them: and as for equiuocations they vse them not, but when necessity requires. And I demanded of the Doct. if he neuer vsed equinocation, wherto he answered that he neuer could abyde them;He that sticketh not at lyes neuer nedeth to vse equiuocations. and I replyed that such questions might be proposed vnto him, as he should eyther be forced to equiuocate or to answere so foolishly as it might hurt himselfe and others, or els to fal into a flatly adding that equiuocations were approued by the example of our sauiour Iesus Christ in the scripture, where he told his disciples, that neyther the sonne of man knew the day of iudgement, wherto he answered that the words The sonne of man, weare an Arrian foyst, alleadging S. Hierome for it. I answered that as for his alleaging S. Hierome, I could not reprooue it, because I haue not read all his workes and that I remembred no such matter, in
that which I haue read, adding that whatsoeuer S. Hierome hath said, now he is to be accompted an heretike which shal obstinately defend it to be Arrianisme, because those woords are approued by the Counsel of Trent to be Canonical scripture, and not an Arrian foyst (as he tearmed them) to which the Doctor replyed nothing in effect. This I thought good truly to set downe as it passed before diuers witnesses.

div.p: ã1 paragraphã .

But now touching the Doctors bold assertion, that S. Hierome should say, that those words of the gospel wrytten by S. Marke, neque filius, &c. Marc. 13. that neyther the sonne of God himself did know of the day of iudgement, but only his Father, should be an Arrian foyst, is most false and insolently spoken, for that S. Hierome in no place of his works hath
any such thing. And in his comentary vpon the 24. Chapter of S. Mathew,S. Hier. CÅmentr. in c. 24. Mathes. where only he handleth this matter, he saith that in some greeke copyes namely of Origen and Pierius, those words neque filius, &c. were not read,D. Bag. immodesty & rashnesse. but yet for that in other copyes both latyn and greeke they were found, he thought it necessary to examine & defend them against Heretikes in that place, as namely against Arrius and Eunomtus, who by colour of these words would proue Christ to be inferior to his Father.

â¢ oth â¢â¢
ãâ¦ã and ãâ¦ã of this Doctor. ãâ¦ã and in calling th â¢
ãâ¦ã word ãâ¦ã scripture ãâ¦ã
