â¢ rria â¢ foyst. About equiuocations and doubtful speches obiected against Iesuits. And ãâ¦ã with the â¢â¢
ãâ¦ã and calumniate ãâ¦ã the Society, as though they vsed equiuocations and doubtful speches, & this for that a Reuerend learned man and martyr of their order M. Robert Southwel vpon occasion & necessity defended the same both truly and learnedly at the barre, when he was arraigned, it is a world to see their wilful error or palpable falshood in this matter, for that none that is learned can deny, but that this poynt of equiuocatiÅ, doubtful speech
or amphibologie (as the doctors do cal it) is handled largely by all deuynes, and not only allowed, but iudged necessary also in diuers cases, for auoyding lying and other inconueniences. VVherof S. Augustine among the Fathers doth treate largely in his booke contra mendacium. And among schoolemen S. Thomas secunda 2ae. q. 110. art.
â¢ . And generally all schoole Doctors do handle the lawfulnes of this amphibologie or hiding the truth by prudent dissimulation in foure general matters: First as their words are in tegendo secreto confessionis, in couering the secresy of confession, which oftentymes can hardly be done without this amphibologie. Secondly in diuers cases of examinations both of witnesses & others accused before iudges. Thirdly in their treateses of oathes, and vttering the truth, whÄ it may concerne the hurt of Gods seruice or daunger of our neighbours. Fourthly about the external confession of our fayth and obligation therin.

All which 4. general matters may require somtymes prudent diuersion or dissimulation of the truth without lying, which schoolemen, casuists, and canonists do calamphibologie or equiuocation of words, which S. Thom. describeth in these words,
when he saytd:D. The. 2. 2. 4. 1. art. 3. ad 4. l â¢â¢ et veritatem occultare prudÄter sub aliqua dissimulatione, vt Augustinus dicit, libro contra mendacium. It is lawful to hide the truth prudÄtly sometymes vnder some dissimulation of woords as S. Augustine saith, in his booke against lying. Thus sayth S. Thomas. And he that wil read one schooleman for all, that gathereth the sayings of all the rest, let him see Greg. de Valent. in 2. secundae disput. 5. q. 15. puncto 2. where he handleth this mater at large, both out of Fathers Doctors and scriptures.

And as for learned Casuists and Canonists, they concurre also fully in this poynt with the schole men, as in name of the rest yow may see in Nauaetrus, cap. 8. de sigillo Confess. num. 17. & cap. 2. num. 8. de non turando & cap. 18. num 4. 5. & 61. de falso testimonio. And finaly he that considereth diuers sayings & speeches in scripture allowed by the holy ghost,Genes. 27. as when Iacob tould his Father he was his first begotten sonne Esau: when both Abraham and Sara said that she was not his wyfe but his syster.Gen. 12. & 20. VVhen S. Paul in iudgemÄt said (to deuide the Saduces & Pharasyes betwene themselues,Act. 23. & to draw one part to fauour him) that he was called into iudgement about the resurrection of the dead (which indeed directly he vvas
not, but for being a Christian,Luk. 24. and many of the Iewes defended also the other) when S. Luke sayth of our Sauiour Christ: Et ipse se fuerit longius ire, &c. he did feigne that he would go further then to the Castle of Emaus, though he meant it not.

And lastly this speech of our Sauiour before alleaged by the martyr, that the sonne of man did not know the day of Iudgement, all these places of scripture and many more layd togeather, do euidently testifie, that good & holy men haue & may vse certayne doubtful speaches or equiuocations without lying, for auoyding other hurts or inconueniences, which for that the holy martyr F. South wel before mentioned, when he stood at the barre to receyue sentence of death for confessiÅ of the Catholike fayth; defended, these good fellowes conspiring with the persecutors haue sought to disgrace him euer synce for the same, and not only him but all his whole order, and namely those that are in England, as though they delighted in equiuocations, which all men that liue with them and conuerse do know to be a playne calumniation, and such as shal read these books and see the infinite number of vntruthes, lyes, slaunders and open falshoods vttered therin,
without scruple of conscience, wil litle thinke needful the vse of equiuocations to these men, seing that equiuocations & prudent diuersions of spech (as before hath byn said) are allowed principally to men of scrupulous conscience for auoyding of lying. And thus much for th â¢ s matter.

div.head: SOME REASONS AND serious considerations, wherby such of our discontented Brethren as are of good conscience, and not too farre gone in wilful passion, may be stayed or recalled from this scandalous and dangerous course begone, of mutual diuision & dissention; and a better way taken to the reunion of all againe. CAP. XIII.
div.p:
PResupposing that diuers of our discontented brethren, whose names vpÅ one occasion or other are set downe or mentioned in some of these late bookes, haue not consented to all things vttered therin but that hauing byn induced eyther by art, euil information, or by some other l â¢ tle passion or ouersight to yeild or concurre in some
one thing, or other are now published to the world for partakers of al the whole disorder, as it is wont to fal out to standers by and lookers on, or to such as go in cÅpany for good fellowship, when some few commit the ryot or robbery, which afterward must be answered by all, for this cause we haue thought good in this place after all our larger declaration before made to lay togeather a breefe vew of such effectual reasons and considerations, as may iustly mooue any Christian conscience in our opinion to looke with more attention into the matter, and much more the mynds of many of our brethren, which we cannot persuade our selues but to be very vertuously intentioned, notwithstanding the great ouersight they haue committed (as we thinke) by adioyning or adhering any way to the prosecution of this scandalous action, by the way now begone of clamors and libels, most odious and offensiue, to the eyes eares, and mynds of our Superiors, & all good Cathol. men lyuing in the world, that are not particularly appassionated in this cause.

VVherfore to come to our purpose, first of all, and aboue all, is to be considered in our opinion, the principal poynt in this
affayre,The first general consideration about the daunger of disobedience. to wit the resistance of power and Gods ordination discending vnto vs from our Superiors, of which ordination and power, though it were but secular and in heathen magistrats and Superiors, yet saint Paul said resolutely therof as all mÄ know, that it was the ordination of God, that they should be obeyed; and thervpon inferred this dreadful conclusion: qui autem resistunt, Rom. 15. damnationemâª sibi acquirunt. Those that do resist, do procure vnto themselues damnation. And in another place the same Apostle:Heb. 10. Nos autem non sumus subtractionis filij in perditionem: we are not the children of subtraction (with drawing our selues from Gods ordinance) to perdition. Yf resistÄce then and subtraction in matter of obediÄce do bring damnatiÅ and perdition, and this euen in secular and heathen power, yea where the comaunders are oftentymes but carnales & dyscoli, Ephes. 6. carnal and troublesome, as the same Apostle testifieth, how much more may it be feared in Christian and spiritual subordination of Ecclesiastical power, wherof Christ saith: qui vos spernit me spernit. Luk. 10. He that contemneth yow contemneth me.

And albeit this matter may be smothed (as all such matters of disobedience are
wont to be) with many faire excuses, interpretations, & glosses made theron, that this is not open disobedience or rebelliÅ for that it hath alwayes byn pretÄded to make recourse to the supreme gouernour, yet he that wil attentiuely and sincerly consider the course that hath byn held, & therwithall the meaning, iudgemÄt & desyres of all Superiors against this course, he shal see that these excuses, are but smothings indeed, ad excusandas excusationes in peccatis. Psal. 140.

For to beginne no higher then from Cardinal Allens owne tyme, who doth not see or may do (by his letter before alleaged to M. Mush)Cap. 4. his playne detestation of hart (being lawful superiour) against the emulation and dissention of some priests then begone against the fathers of the Society in the yeare 1594.Great continuÄce of disobedience. And after his death who doth not know the continuation of this disobedience in these men, and others induced by the same humor of emulation at Rome; not only against the said Fathers there, their lawful and imediate Superiors, but also, and in like maner against both Cardinal Caietan the Protector, and Cardinal Sega their visitour,Vid Sapra Cap. 5. both of them hauing their authority immediatly from his Hol. during the tyme of the Roman styrres.
Nay who knoweth not the affliction of mynd that they gaue to his Hol. himselfe in all that space of 2. or 3. yeares as himselfe protested often,Cap. 5. and once also publikely to some of them at their departure.

And albeit he deferred all this while to punish them for feare of some worse resolution in themâª yet detested he their actions in this meane space. And what impression this might make against them with God, whose place he holdeth, may be considered by other men, and feared by vs, especially waying the consequence of their passing from worse to worse, as daylie we see, they comming into England with a new expresse and most earnest comandement from his Hol. both for them & their fellowes,Supra. ca. 5. and all other priests heere to desist from diuision, and namely from dissention with the Fathers of the Society, they haue done quite the contrary, not only bÄding themselues against them, but for hatred also of them (as it seemeth) haue impugned principally their new Superior, contemned the Protectors letters, condemned the act of subordination made by him, called in question his Hol. authority about the same, doubted of his new Breue, when it came forth, out of what office it was gottÄ,
reiected and exagitated againe the authority of the said immediate superior, & lastly by libels haue sought to defame not only him but all others also that stÄd with him.

This course then being wel pondered, togeather with that which hath byn spoken of before in the 2.An important consideration. Chapter about this affayre of disobedience, to wit how daungerous a point it is, it semeth to vs that euery tender conscience that hath part in this matter, may haue iust cause to doubt how he standeth and whether he goeth. For if we may beleeue spiritual wryters & holy Fathers, no one signe of Gods forsaking and dereliction can be so great as to run headlong against the direct mynds wils and desyres of our Superiors, howsoeuer the matter be cloaked.

It is a soare sentence of the Apostle concerning some that runne of wilfulnes; Tradidit illos Deus in reprobum sensum. God hath deliuered them ouer to a reprobate sense, not to consider what they do. But much more dreadful is that speech of God by Esay: Misereamur impio, Esay. 26, & non discet iustitiam: in terra sanctorum iniqua gessit, & non videbit gloriam Domini: Let vs haue mercy vpon the wicked (saith God by the way of irrision) and he shal not learne the
way to do iustice: he hath done wickedly in the land of Saynts, and therfore shal not see the glory of God. O dreadful mercy (saith S. Bernard)Bern. Serm. Sup. Cant. and more to be feared then all seuerity to haue a mans eyes so shut as he cannot learne iustice.

The cause is as yow see, for that such men haue done iniquity in the land of Saynts: which whether England may now be so called or no, where so much suffering is, so much bloud shed, so many prisons filled with confessors: whether the Seminaryes also may be called the land of Saynts, wherin so many innocent lambes are brought vp in all vertue, feruour and deuotion to be sacrifices vnto Christ, in their due tyme; and whether the seditions and troubles mooued in the one and the other land by these men (both in the Seminaryes we meane and in England) may be called iniquity, we leaue to other men to consider; and therby also to ponder, where and vpon whome the dreadful consequence of this threat of almighty God, may light, if the cause be not remooued. And so much of this first consideration.

The 2 general consideration about the true causes and motiues of this tumult.The 2. consideration may be about the causes and motyues wherby these men in truth and before God are mooued to make
this scandalous opposition and contradiction notwithstanding the smoth pretences giuen before men, which yet are such, as were they true (to wit for liberty of their order, recouering their good names and the like) yet were they not sufficient to iustifie so turbulÄt and scandalous a breach as this is, seing by other better meanes these things might be remedied. But the truth is that euery man of iudgement discouereth other motyues then these, as first manifest emulation against the fathers of the Society,Emulation conuerted by continuance (as may be feared) in cÅpletam malitiÄ, into complete mallice, as yow may see by that we haue handled before in the third chapter of the Apology. And how daungerous a motiue this is, no man can be ignorant, except he wil not see the same.

After this is discouered ambition in the first authors of this seditiÅ and diuisiÅ prefixing vnto them selues honors and dignityes by disordinate meanes,Ambition. as before we haue shewed,Ca. 9. & 1. as wel by their owne letters and others of their consorts, as also by the testimony of the 6. Assistens letter aboue cyted.Sup. cap. 8. 9. & 10. Pryde. Besides these is discouered intolerable pride and arrogancy by their owne words as well in examining and censuring
his Hol. doings and authority,Cap. 2. & 4. as also in their bold speches concerning the Cardinal Protector; The whole Society of Iesuits, & diuers particular men and matters before handled. Cap. 3. And what may be expected where pryde beareth the greatest power euery man wil easily see.

VVe might ad to these causes and motiues choler also,Choler & reuenge. wrath, desyre of reuenge, stomake, singularity, and other such sinister affections discouered almost in euery page of these late libels; but aboue all desyre of libertyLiberty. and freedome from all superiority and yoke of obedience, wherby they seeme to say as those other good fellowes did in the Psalme:Psalm. 2. Dirumpamus vincula eorum, & proijciamus Ã nobis iugum ipsorÅ«. Let vs breake their bands of obedience layd vpon vs, let vs cast from vs their yoke of Superiority: Nolumus hunc regnare super nos, Luc. 1 â¢ . we wil not haue any archpriest to raigne ouer vs, that wilbe free.

But the sentence is terrible that followeth in this psalme, Qui habitat in coelis irridebit eos, & Dominus subsannabit eos. But he that dwelleth in heauÄ shal laugh at them,Psalm. ibid. and our lord shal deryde them, that wil not abide gouernment; And yet more terrible is the next verse:Ibid. Tunc loquetur ad eos in
ira sua, &c. Then shal he speake to them in his wrath, &c. And his maner of speech is vttered in another Psalme to one with whome he was angry, saying: Tu verÃ² odisti disciplinam, & proiecisti sermones meos retrorsum: Psalm. 49. Thou hast hated discipline and cast my cÅmandements behynd thee: All which are good meditations for a syncere conscience in this troblesome tyme of liberty, & contradiction, assuring our selues that the conclusion and resolution cannot be good or sure where the passions before mentioned, of emulation, hatred, pryde, reuÄge, liberty, & other like are counselors and persuaders.

The 3. consideration may be about the euil means taken in hand to execute theyr resolution of repugning & contradicting,The 3. general consideration about the euil means vsed for execution of this contradiction. which were not only these three mentioned out of S. Bernard, first to examine and discusse the Superiors ordinÄce, then to doubt, & lastly to contemne, &c. but they went further, as before hath byn signified, to wit, to scan the Cardinal Protectors letters; to diminish his credit and authority with English Catholikes; cal in question the Popes authority; whether he might do it without their consent or not: and then not contented to doubt themselues, they put doubts & scruples also into other mens heads that doubted
not therof before, they wrote letters; made conuenticles; intreated many men to abstayne from subscribing, vntil they had sent to Rome; promising great hopes by that iourney of their messengers. All which poynts tending to contention & diuision, and not to simple and syncere enforming themselues of his Holines wil (as they pretended) and which might haue bin done by diuers others lawful and quiet meanes euery true meaning man wil easily see what he is here to follow. For seing that as the Philosopher sayth, and diuynes do agree vnto it, that bona ipsa are not bona, nisi benÃ¨ fiant: Arist. in Ethicis. good things themselues are not good, except they be wel and lawfully done. It followeth then that albeit these mens intentions had bin neuer so good, yet being put in executiÅ by such ill meÄs, the fact it selfe becometh pernitious.

But much more, if we consider, the other meanes they haue vsed,Nevv meÄs vsed by the malecontent since the comming forth of the Popes Breue. since the first breach was intended or shut vp againe, by comming forth of the Popes Breeue, to wit, the discrediting of the said Breeue by doubting frÅ what office it was gottÄ the vexing of their Superior the Archpriest; as wel by iniurious byting letters, as also by subtracting themselues from his authority, and
inducing all others, so farre as lay in them, to do the same, the publishing of these late libels, so slanderous and infamous against their said Superior and others, and against a whole order of religious men, cÅspicuous in Gods Church.

But aboue all other meanes the foulest is & ought most to moue a good cÅscience, their ioyning secretly for a tyme, but after more openly, and now most euidently with the common ennemy & persecutor. First (as before yow haue heard) as soone as euer they vnderstood that their two messengers were restrayned in Rome,Cap. 10. & 12. Anno Di â¢â¢ 1599. and not like to preuayle, then D. Bagshaw was sent for from VVisbich to London to treat with the Councel which iourney procured soone after the calling to the Tower of F. Edmunds, M. Pound, Their dealing vvith the counsel. and M. Archer his greatest opposits, & soone after againe was himselfe sent back to VVisbich with great fauour, and euer after continued this correspondence betwixt him and his and the councel; to the affliction and cÅtinual peril of those that were not of that faction.

But fearing of late or rather most certainly assuring themselues, that their disorderly appeal to Rome made not only for themselues, but for all them in likc
maner, that herafter should come to their party (a clause of cleere sedition) should not haue good successe with the Sea Apostolike, they thought to preuent the matter by ioyning more neerly with the councel and Bishop of London. For which cause M. Bluet the second person of the VVisbich seditiÅ, being sent to LÅdon hath had such conference these moneths past with the said Bish. Counsel & Queene her selfe (as his owne letters do import)Effects of M. Bluet negotiatiÅ vvith the Counsel & B. of London. as we see at last the cleere effects therof, to wit first the printing and publishing of these libels, sayd to be printed in Roan, but more truly may be said in LondÅ, then a general search for taking of Catholikes, such as neuer lightly before hath bin heard of, in which search we heare of the discouery of their print and bookes, but all restored againe with celerity and fauour, and general protection for the tyme to come. VVe heare also of particular fauours vsed by the said Bishop towards the sayd Agent, both by carrying him, for fuller conference to his howse at Fullam, making him good cheere, commanding the keper to let him go where he wil, gyuing him good somes of mony, and the like, which we may imagine are to very good purposes.

And finally his last and greatest exployt (wherof he braggeth in his letter of the first of Iuly to M. Mush) for the obtayning of foure of that crew (wherof himselfe is one) to be deliuered out of prison vnder pretence of banishment, & first to ryde vp and downe all England for soome weekes to cast more seed of seditiÅ abroad & then to go forth at what port they wil to set the same abroach also in other countreys.

This exployt (I say) or plot of M. Bluets (as he calleth it in his letter) is of such quality, as may easily declare alone if no other things did concurre, what they meane, and whether they tend, seing that nether Anthony Tyrel nor Thomas Bel nor other that haue precipitated themselues in this tyme of persecution did euer ingage themselues further with the counsel then these men seeme to haue done; yow shal heare som part of his forsaid letter, & so iudge of all your selues.

body.p:
VVhat yow do abroad, or what yow think,The letter of M. Bluet to M. Io. Mush the first of Iuly 1601. I do not know, for I know not how to wryte vnto yow: I spare not my body nor myIt may be he geueth bribes also, but vvhat skilleth this if the B. of London repay him againe. purse in following this matter, &c. These 14. weekes I haue spÄt 12. poÅ«d, & in diuidÄts I haue not receaued vij. shillings, Sed non in hoc iustificatus sum. The case standeth thus: I haue (by opening the cause vnto their honors & to
The Queene after a sorte.
This contenance is shamful amÅg true Catholikes Cesar), obtayned, that foure principal men
shal be banished after a sort to follow the Appeal Doct. Bagshaw, Bluet, Champney and Barnbey, all prisoners, they shal be heare with me on VVednesday next. A moneth they shal haue within the Realme of liberty to ride abroad, for money amongst their fr â¢ nds, and then choose their port to be gone with some countenance. I hope no man wil be offÄded with thisNo for it is a good one. plot of myne, but with their
He had more need of their prayers.
Vpon the Iesuits.
This God vvould not haue so kept. purses assist vs. It hath cost me many a swet & many bitter teares ere I could effect it. I haue in some sort pacified the wrath of our prince conceaued against vs, and of her counsel, and haue layd the fault where it ought to be, and proued that the secular priests are innocent for the most part, &c. Be cheerful and hope wel in spe contraspem, and keep this secret to your selfe. I haue made M. VVatsons peace if he wel himself, when I come downe I wil tel yow more yow are wel thought of, &c. pridie visitationis Bae. virg. Mariae. 1601.

closer.signed: A great commendation for a Cath. Priest.Yours Tho. Bluet.

div.p:
Now let any man iudge by this letter (which came to our hÄds as we were printing this Apology) how this matter goeth. Heere do enter (as yow see) all the peruerse and sinister meanes that can be deuised against good Catholikes, by them that would seeme also to be no euil Catholikes, to wit, bribes, teares, treachery, false accusations,
calÅ«niatiÅs, exasperatiÅs, & subtile conuentions in fauour of heretiks against our owne brethren. M Bluet saith, he had spÄt 12. poÅ«d in 14. weekes, which is almost 20. shilings a weeke, which needed not in a poore prisoner but that perhaps he was forced to giue bribes to haue his matter more set forward though if the B. of LondÅ haue byn so liberal vnto him as men report, he shal little need to complaine as he doth of the want of the poore diuident of VVisbich almes. Secondly he saith that he hath both swet and wept: swet in going vp and downe, wept in beseeching the Counsel to be of their faction, which he needed not in our opinions,M. Bluets teares to the Q. and counsel, they being no lesse desirous to set it forward then he, and beter perhaps had his teares byn spent to God for his owne synnes.

He saith he hath laid the fault of matters in England, & of her Maiesties offence, where it ought to be, that is to say vpon the Iesuits, excusing most of the secular priests. But if her offence be specially for the defence made of Cath. religion and the increase therof procured by them, then is this accusation of M. Bluets more honorable to Iesuits then he would haue it; & all good secular priests wil geue him litle thÄks
for excusing them therin to her maiestie & the councel as not offending in this behalfe But if he meane any other causes of offence, as practising against the state or the like, then is it calumnious to them both, First to all the Iesuits in England, who are no lesse innocent, vpon our consciences in this poynt then other priests, and secondly to the order of secular priests themselues, especially the better sort, adhering to their Superior, who are as innocent also in this behalfe as this mans (most part) which he would haue to be vnderstood perhaps those few of his side, & so leaue al the other no lesse culpable and obnoxious to this slander, as are the Iesuits, wheras it is knowne notwithstÄding that whiles all other both priests and Iesuits haue bin quiet and silent in state matters, these men haue bin busy as farre as their power or credit wil reach or as any prince would harken to them or deale with them. And this apeareth for that they haue sent of thier owne mÄ euen vnto Scotland to deale with that prince in matters of succession,M. VVatson vvas sent and some others. and haue tampered also with the K. of FrÄce by others of thier consorts to like effect, as the Lords themselues of her Maiesties Councel cannot but know and at their going ouer into France
we doubt not (and so we heare it already by some of their Counsel) but they meane to offer themselues wholy to that kings disposition for the next succession of our crowne, therby to gaine his grace and fauour, and yet they vaunt euery were that they and theirs are innocent in these affayres, and only Iesuits and their frends do deale therin. And so M. Bluet told the Q. and Counsel, and layd the fault where it ought to be.

The quality and maner of which proceeding we shal better perhaps vnderstÄd if yow consider rightly that which passed in the story of the blessed Machabies, A consideration of the calumniations against the Machabies and other good people of Israel. and the better and more godly part of the people of Israel ioyned with thÄ in tyme of the most greuous persecutions of Antiochus, Demetrius, Nicanor, Bacchides, & other persecutors, to whome some Iewes at lÄght eyther vpon ambitiÅ, malice, emulation, wearynes of the tyme, or other such causes (as the scripture noteth) went to the enemy to gaine his grace, and accused their brethrÄ, whetof the story sayth thus: Et sedit Demetrius super sedem regni sui, & venerunt ad eum viri iniqui & impij ex Israel, & Alcimus dux eorum, qui volebat fieri sacerdos, & accusauerunt populum apud Regem, dicentes, perdidit Iudas &
fratres eius omnes amicos tuos, & nos disperdidit de terra nostra, &c. King Demetrius sate vpon the seat of his kingdome, and there came vnto him certayne false and wicked men of the people of Israel and one Alcimus was their Captayne, who desited to be highe-priest, and they accused their owne people vnto the king, saying: that Iudas Machaby and his brethren had destroyed all the Kings welwillers in the Iewish nation, and that themselus also were dryuen out by them, &c. And a litle after in the same Chapter, when the said Alcimus returning to Iewry; saw himselfe ouerborne by the same Machabies the scripture sayth: Reuersus est ad Regem, Ibid. & accusauit eos multis criminibus. He returned to the king and accused them of many deuised crymes.

Now let the comparaison be made betwene our tymes & theirs, their persecutiÅs & ours, our spiritual warre & their temporal, Iesuits & Machabytes, Alcimus & this accuser, togeather with the maner and matter of the accusations themselues, and yow shal se no smal proportion: But if yow read the third and fourth Chapter of the second booke of Machabies, where Symon the Prouost of the Temple for enuy and emulation went to Apolonius a heathen persecutor
against Onias the good high priest, & his Superior, & against those that were ioyned with him accusing him and them of many false crimes, to make them more odious to the persecutors yow shal find a more liuely representation of our present state and case. For the scripture saith: 2. Mach. 3. CÃ¹m vincere Oniam (Symon) non possit venit ad ApoloniÅ«, &c. VVhen Sym â¢ n otherwise could not ouercome Onias his Superior he came to Apolonius gouernour ouer Coeli-Syria and Phoenicia and reuealed to him what-so-euer he could against his said Superior and brethÄ, & caused him to reueale all vnto the king who sent one Heliodorus into Iewry to spoyle the countrey and ransacke the temple, and when he had done he layd all the fault vpÅ Onias himselfe. For so saith the story:2. Mach. 4.
Symon autem praedictus pecuniarum & patriae dilator malÃ¨ loquebatur de Onia, tanquam ipse HeliodorÅ« instigasset ad haec, & ipse fuisset incentor malorum. This phrase our men vse also euery vvere againe the Archp. F. P. and others. Symon the forsaid accuser and discouerer both of the money takÄ out of the temple, & of his countrey, spoke euil euery where of Onias the high priest, as though he had styrred vp Heliodorus the Kings officer to make these spoyles, and as though he were the only cause or kindler of all these euils.

The like also doth the same Story report of one Iason as troublesome a fellow as as any of the rest,2. Mach. 3. that wÄt to the Heathen persecutor against his brethren. So as this was an old practice in tyme of persecution euen before Christ. And we might aleadge many examples out of Eusebius and other authors of like practises since, But it were to long.

The attÄpt of seditious Monks in K. Henries tyme.The particular Storyes also of diuers euil monks & friars, in K. Henry the eight his tyme, that went secretly to the L. Cromwel, and ioyned with him for visiting their monasteryes by the kings authoritie and afflicting such good men as were contrary to them in maners and conditiÅs (wherof ensued afterward destruction of all) are very wel knowne, but are ouer large to be handled in this place, yet are they not vnlike to this affayre now; For that enuy, reuenge, and liberty drew them to do that, as the like motiues haue induced these men to this. God send the doers better successe then the others had, or any else to our knowledge, that haue taken this course of ioyning with the aduersary for reuenge vpon their brethren. And so much of this point.

As for the rest that is conteyned in this
letter of M. Bluets about the cÅpact made with the Counsel, for his owne and his fellowes liberty, for their ryding vp and downe England to get money and styrre sedition; their freedome to choose any port where they list to depart thence with some countenance; this wryters desyre of secresy in the matter; his making of M. VVatsons peace with the Counsel (who had scaped out of prison twise or thrise, and some died also for it) with this cÅditiÅ (if he wil) which importeth somthing also that he must do or testifie against his brethrÄ to the Counsels liking.M. VVatsons reconciliation, & M. Mush vvel thought of And finally that M. Mush is now come to be wel thought of by the Counsel: A miserable reward after so many yeres labour in Catholike religion against them. All these poynts we meane not to stand vpon heere for breuityes sake, but leaue them to be considered by the Reader. And so we end this third consideration.

The fourth consideration may be of the effects and fruits which this contradiction of our discontÄted brethren haue brought and is like to bring forth heerafter,The 4. cÅsideration: concerning the effects. which are so euil and so many as may worthily sting the consciences of all those that haue any part in the causes or occasiÅs therof: as namely; the diuision and disfrendship of
Catholikes that were at vnion and good peace before. The fall or backeslyding of such as are weake, and not able to beare or digest such a scandal. The hinderance of others, that otherwayes would haue byn conuerted. The confirming of heretikes & schismatiks in their euil courses, by seeing vs at variance among our selues.

The augmenting of affliction to good affected Catholikes both by interior greefe, feare and doubt, whome they may trust, as also by exterior persecution of heretikes set on, or encouraged by this meane. The hinderance or extinguishing of the spirit of deuotion both in themselues and others, which cÄnot possibly indure, where stryfe. emulation and malice raigneth. The disgracing & discrediting of sundry principal men of the Catholike party, which were venerable before, euen to the enemy himselfe. The infamy of these styrres themselues both at home and abroad as wel for the present, as for the tyme to come, wherby they are like to be made vnapt instruments to do much good herafter. The general note and contempt of our whole nation incurred heerby, as seditious of themselues and giuen to contention. The blasphemy against our cause, auouched for
many yeares by heretikes, but now made more probable to strangers by these proceedings, to wit, that our sufferings in England are not so much for conscience & religion, as of a certayne spirit of contradictiÅ, and of obstinacy therin. The arming of heretiks with matter to wryte against vs and our brethren, furnishing them with arguments of slaunders and defamations, which they knew not, or durst not vse before, but now their books begin to be ful of them, vpon these mens suggestions. And finally the damages are so many and great which daily do ensue vpon these proceedings of our brethren while they go about to satisfie their discontented mynds by euil speeches, as there were no end to run ouer them. Let those afflicted English Catholiks be witnesses, who going vp and downe in banishment, for Gods cause through other countreyes do fynd such alteration of mynds, affections and iudgements towards vs, both in princes and priuate men, vpon this general infamy of our dissentious natures, as they which are in need do rue it. And consequently such as are the causes herof or haue part therin must needs thinke themselues to haue much to answere both to God and man for it.

The 5. consideration about tymes and circunstances.The fifth consideration may be of the tymes and seasons, and other like circumstances when this contradiction and styrre is made, which circumstances may greatly encrease or alter the nature of the offence it selfe. For as in a temporal warre, where two campes are actually in sight one against the other, if any particular men vpon any pretences or occasions whatsoeuer of iniuryes offered them by priuate officers or other souldiers, should begin a quarrel or fray amongst their owne men, indangering therby the whole campe, these men we say should no doubt offend highly, and euery man knoweth what would ensue vnto them both by martial and ciuil lawes. And no other then this in our present case, but yet so much the more weighty and important, as spiritual warre (wherin soules are defended) is more important then temporal which concerneth the body.

The case then being as it is, and our Catholike cause after a long, wearisome, and bloody conflict, hauing gathered some good strength vnto it, and being in actual combat with heresy, and in no smal hope in tyme to preuayle, by the patience, vniÅ, fortitude and longanimity of her souldiers, for these few men now to rayse a particular
sedition within their owne camp vpon pretence of iniuryes or dishonors done them, and further to consult with the aduersary campe, and captaynes therof for the prosecution of these their designments for the oppressing of their opposite brethren; this poynt of what quality it is we leaue to all men to iudge and discerne.

The sixt consideration may be about the end and issue of this matter,The 6. general consideration about the end of matters. which as according to the Philosopher is fi â¢ st euer in purpose and last in execution so haue we reserued the same to this place, though by our discontented brethren it should first of all other points haue byn diligently thought vpon, according to the comon aduise Respice finem, consider wel the end, of all which end may be wayed by vs in this place in diuers mÄners and respects, and all ought to mooue greatly our brethren (if we be not deceyued) to desist frÅ the course,The end or intention of the styrres. wherinto they haue cast themselues. For if we respect the end of this matter, according to the intention and hope of the beginners of these styrres, it can be no other, then some litle wreaking of their anger, or the restraynt or changement of the gouernment appointed (if so much might be acheyued) or alteration of
the person or that an Archpriest may be altered into a Bishop or Archbishop, who might chaunce to be as opposite to these men, and to their designments that seeke liberty, as this Superior is, now already appoynted, or rather more, by how much greater authority the other are like to haue, togeather with more apparant cause and credit to punish these men, if they should continue their tumultuation vnder them, as they haue done vnder this; This we say is all that probably they can expect. And how litle this is to make so much a do for it, all men may see and consider. And for them to hope to obtayne freedome from all gouernment, or to haue such as themselues only like, is a vayne imagination in our opinions.

The end of the aduersary.Secondly then this end and issue may be considered, as it is in the mynd and intention of the aduersary with whome they conferre their in. And of this end no man can doubt, but that it tendeth to our whole ouerthrow and dissipation. And it were in vayne to bring heere the example of all the Cittyes and common welthes of Greece, Quintus Curtus lib. 1 de vita Alexand. which Philip King of Macedony ouerthrew and brought in subiection by setting diuision, and nourishing faction amongst themselues.
The sentence of our Sauiour is sufficient for vs,Matt. 12. Luc. 12. Omne regnum in seipsum deuisum desolabitur: Euery kingdome or power deuided in it selfe or against it selfe (as the text of S. Mathew is) shalbe brought to desolation, which our aduersaryes knowing and cÅsidering further, that the great encrease of the Cath. cause p â¢ ocured these later yeares by institution of Seminaries preaching and laboring of Seminary priests, Iesuits and other instruments of almighty God ioyned togeather in vnion of charity and mutual loue to their contrey and among themselues. And pondering also further the state of tymes present and what it may be herafter both with them and vs; haue thought no one deuise more effectual to ouerthrow all our hopes, at least wayes to hinder and weakÄ whatsoeuer hath byn trauayled for hitherto: then by giuing hand to this attempt of a few discontent & troublesome against the whole body; persuading themselues, that yong men put in passion, wil not cÅsider what preiudice they do worke, eyther to themselues, or to others, which being duly pondered by a good conscience must needs worke great motion therin.

Thirdly we may consider this end in respect of God himselfe,The end of God in permitting troblesome people. who forseeing
all things, hath his ends also ioyned with ours, but oftentymes farre different in the issue, so vseth he warre to chasten sinne, and bringeth forth peace, so vseth he heresy (as testifieth S. Paul) vt qui probati sunt manifesti fiant, 1. Cor. 11. that those who are men of proofe may be made manifest, so vseth he also troublesome men amongst Catholikes,Aug. in Psal. 54. vt boni per eos exerceantur (sayth S. Augustine) that good men may be exercised by them. But what ensueth finally of all this, but only the perdition of them that do so exercise others, if they desist not? which ought also to mooue vs greatly.

The end & issue of the controuersy it selfe.Fourthly & lasty this end & issue may be considered in respect of the matter it selfe, to wit, were it is like to end? what is probable to be the euent or vpshot of all this stryfe and contention? of all this wryting, speaking, defaming and exclaming by the discontented? Truly no other conclusion may be expected in our opinions (and this wil the sequel shew) but as when children haue fondly fought and wearyed themselues, and broken each others head they are forced to be frends with their hurts to them selues: and this is all the gayne which they gather by their falling out.

Heere then is our censure of the issue of
this matter, that broken heads wil follow of all sides, but there may perhaps be some doubt or differÄce of opinions, where most broken heads are likest to light? But he that on the otherside wil cÅsider indifferently who they are and of what number condition and quality, against whome our discontented brethren so few in number and greene in credit do make this voluntary warre he can not greatly doubt of the euent therof.The Archpriest and his Cleargy. For as for the Archp. his assistents and all the rest of the English Cleargy ioyned with them, being men of that vertue, learning and approued grauity, which all the world knoweth, what great hurt can they receiue at these mens handes, but only some little scratches in their names for a tyme (a thing of no moment) and some exercise of their patience, as befote out of S. Augustine hath byn touched. And much more may this be said of the Iesuits who are a body conioyned by charity and rules of vertue,The body of the Iesuits. and dispersed ouer the world, and exercised in diuers places with like contradiction to this, wherby they grow rather in perfection of life and diligent guard ouer their owne actiÅs, then be ouerthrowne or greatly hurted. And with those two bodyes are ioyned
also for defence of peace order, and discipline all higher Superiors of spiritual gouernment, so as our brethren are like to breake few heads here but only their owne (if we be not deceyued) but rather after they haue wearyed themselues must expect the issue before mentioned in the fourth consideratiÅ of hurts and damages to themselues and the common cause.

And albeit some of them perhaps may be encouraged to go forward in this contention by the applause or approbation which they haue found in some good men or women at this beginning,Presumption vpon sinister informatiÅs. seduced or impressioned vpon their owne sinister informations; yet when matters shal come to more mature examination, and the euil effects before mentioned be seene and discouered, it is probable that these being good and godly catholiks and prudent people, wilbe of an other opinion, and by little and little enter into due consideratiÅ, whete authority, where obedience, that is to say, where gods part goeth; on which side order subordination and discipline do consist, where and with whome the body and multitude of our church stÄdeth, where peaceable or passionate mynds do beare rule.Due considerations. They wil looke also with tyme into
the difference of mens lyues and maners, to wit where modesty, humility & mortification are to be seene, what priests are giuen most to prayer, patience, longanimity of mynd, tranquillity of spirit, & who to the contrary. They wil ponder also who are most hated and pursued by the ennemy for their labors and indeauors against them in the Cath. cause, and who are most fauored or tolerated by them? which is no smal marke to know how matters go.

Truth also and falshood in asseuerations lightnes or grauity in accusations (wherby the quality of mÄs cÅsciÄces is much discerned) wilbe wayed and thought on in tyme.Slanders & calumniatiÅs signes of a bad consciÄce. And when Cath. men shal find so many opÄ vntruthes improbable slaunders & manifest calumniations vttered by passion in these their bookes as by no meanes or shew of reason can be defended or excused they wil enter into further cÅsideratiÅ, what maner of priests these bee, how scrupulous or tender of conscience, how they may trust thÄ in matters of their soules, that haue so little care of their owne, what secresy or assurance they may conceaue in matters committed to them, which concerne their liues states and honours (if after they should fal out with them) seing that vpon
a little splene against others their brethren, they vtter what-soeuer they know, or haue hard, or can gesse or deuise, and that to the publike enemy, and to the whole world in print.

These considerations then growing by tyme into the heads of prudent pious Catholikes togeather with that other, that few or none, which euer haue yeilded to the enemy in one or two steppes,Daungers imminent to the troublesome if they go forvvard. could euer lightly go back againe, but haue byn drawne forward, eyther by fayre meanes or force, to yeild in greater matters, and to discouer all they knew against their brethrÄ, if not more. And that the examples of these issues are many at this day in England and that men set on passion and once disunited from their heads and gouernours, by whome Gods grace descendeth, haue no stay or certainty at all in their doings, but do raunge heere and there as their passions lead them. All these considerations we say layd togeathet and many other which their wisdome and experience wil put before their eyes are like to worke so with the better and grauer sort of Catholikes, as they wil haue little confidence in the doings or sayings of these men, if they go forward, but rather to accompt thÄ a troublesome
and wrangling people, daungerous to deale with all in these difficult tymes: and consequently wil fly them as much as they may. And this is the broken head which our brethren are like to gaine by this their wilful wrangling if they cease not.

VVherfore to draw to an end,The 7. general consideration about the necessity & facility of reunion and concord. and not to enlarge our selues further in this matter, we shal for conclusion put two considerations in one, to wit the necessity and facility of this reunion and concord, which we desire should be made among vs.

And for the first which is the necessity therof, besides all that which is said and signified before, so much more may be alleaged, as this poynt only might serue for a whole volume. For what matter did our Sauiour inculcate euet so much vpon earth to his followers as this point of vnion and mutual loue: In hoc sciant omnes, &c. Ioan. 16. By this note shal all men knowe, that yow are my disciples, if yow loue togeather, and haue peace among yow. VVhat did he so much pray for to his father, as for this grace of vnion among his seruants: vt omnes vnum sint, Ioan. 17. sicut tu pater in me, & ego in te. That all may be one, as thou my father art in me, and I in thee. Behold what a vnion he requireth?
And then againe in the same prayer, vt ipsi in nobis vnum sint. That my disciples be one (o Father) in vs. And yet further: vt sint vnum, sicut & nos vnum sumus: that they be one as we are one. And finally: vt sint cosummati in vnum: That they may be perfectly one.

This was his exhortation and this was his prayer. But what were his threats to them that broke this vnion? Truly they were most dreadful in all his speaches, testified as wel by his owne woords in the gospels, as by the wrytings of all his Apostles and disciples. S. Iohns epistle may serue for all,Ioan, epist. 1.2.3.4. who being priuy aboue the rest perhaps to the spirit of his Master, denounced nothing but the necessity of this precept of loue and mutual vnion, and reprobation and damnation to those that breake or liue out of the same. VVherfore of this we shal need to say no more, seing all the old holy Fathers ioyntly do exaggerate this synne of making diuision and dissention, aboue all other synnes whatsoeuer; as a thing peculiar to the spirit of the diuel and most opposite and contradictory, to the spirit of Christ.

As for the second point, touching the facility of making concord and reunion againe, if men wil leaue of acerbity of passions,
& put on the true affectiÅs of a Christian mynd,The facility of making peace if men vvilbe Christian lyke mynded. we see no great impedimÄts of difficulties therin. For we would aske our discontented brethren, that shew themselues so mightely inraged, what is there which they would haue in this matter? who vexeth or vrgeth them? so as they may not liue quietly if they would? As for the Archpriest when the authority was layd vpon him which he in our cÅsciences little thought of;The Archpriest desyrons of cÅcord. & much lesse desired (for what may be desireable in such an office at this tyme) no man can doubte but that if these men would haue bin quiet, & not haue cÅtradicted openly his authority, what soeuer they had done secretly in Rome or otherwise about it, yet would he neuer haue dealt thearin or vsed cÄsure against thÄ for it. And when he was forced to vse censures, yet we see, that he recalled all presently, as soone as they began in any outward shewe to accomodate themselues; & now no doubt if they would do the same after so many and manifest declarations of his Hol. wil for the continuation and confirmation of his authority, if they would giue ouer this impugnation and liue quietly to themselues, there can be no doubt but that he for his part would be very glad
therof, and embrace them all as his brethren and children without any further memory of former amaritude.

The Iesuits ready to peace.The Fathers also of the Society which haue stood with the Archpriest and the rest of the body of the Cleargie of England in defence of his Hol. ordination, if by this they haue giuen greefe vnto our brethren, the recompence is soone made, and therby also the reconciliation. They are men (as we wel knowe) thar desyre greatly to liue quietly & priuately to themselues, as their vocatiÅ requireth, nor meane they to haue any thing at all to do with our brethren or their affayres, but in the way of loue and charity to do them good. They demaund no authority ouer them, nor euer had or sought iurisdiction vpon any one of them or others. They intend not to preiudice them in any preferment for the tyme present or to come. They pray for them, and desyre to embrace them whensoeuer occasion shalbe offered, & are content to put vp all iniuryes receyued by these libels both in their owne persons, and their whole Society, remytting the remedy to God and to their superiors. And this being their disposition (as most syncerely they haue professed vnto vs) what impediment can there
be of reunion, if our brethren wil; and if they wil not, what excuse can they make eyther before God or man of this wilful breach and continuation therof?

VVe and our brethren may liue in England these twenty yeares,All men may liue quietly if they vvil. each man in his residence, quietly and contentedly, if we wil, without that eather Archpriest or Iesuite medle with vs, but only to our comfort: and this wil of ours which is required, is nothing els, but orderly bearing our selues as honest, ciuil, and vertuous priests ought to do. If this may not be had, then must troubles and tumults continue stil with the effects before rehearsed, and God and his ministers must remedy them; from which obstinacy his deuyne Maiestie deliuer vs all. And euery true Catholike, and especially priests in cÅscience are bound to with-draw themselues in tyme, saying with holy Iacob:Genes 49. in consilium corum non veniat anima mea. Let not my soule be partaker of this their counsel and obstinate resolution. And this is the but te whervnto this chapter, yea the whole book, hath byn directed.
